main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: GE offers a great salary, good benefits, and plenty of flexibility to work from home or leave the office early for appointments.

Toxic culture and mostly incompetent management and staff. Too many posers, frauds and powerpoint experts here and few doers. Workload is also too high due to deliberate understaffing.
advice_management: Please learn performance management of employees. Too many freeloaders in this company. Too many selfish middle mgmt also who slave-drive their teams for just short term gains and long-term loss.

summary: "Great company but leadership has no clue of how to steer the company forward"

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years

Not so good Healthcare Insurance
No job security

Poor leadeship & management

advice_management:
It is good only on paper to say, " Flourish in uncertain times". The other way of looking at it is that the leadsrship has no clue what they are doing or want to steer the company towards.
No innovation. 
Learn to appreciate and award hard working employees and not just reward the Leadership Program fresh graduates without experience.
Learn to retain talented individuals in these times when company is not doing well.

summary: "Once great company, trying to recover from post-Welch leadership."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Great location, fantastic people, tackling IIoT problems worth solving.
cons: Too many strategy pivots -- seems like every day we were pursuing a different set of customers and had different product goals. A highly political, large organization organized in large centralized "empires" silos, without a great deal fo urgency or agility. Often slow to complete projects and show forward momentum, preferring over-documentation to delivering business value. Engineering makes all product decisions, while UX is working on cute animations, and Product is busy doing sales.
advice_management: FOCUS. Stop having Engineering run (and ruin) everything -- allow Product, SMEs, and UX to do their job. Stop trying to over-design and over-build everything, instead focus on adding immediate business value to IIoT customers quickly in specific use cases (here is where Product, SMEs, and UX -- NOT Engineering -- will help you figure out what you need to build). Leverage existing frameworks instead of (re)building everything in-house. Reorganize using small, cross-functional agile "Tiger Teams" with specific deliverables and measures of success. Stop chasing "whales" and instead use Product, SME, and UX expertise to discover what market needs then execute to the MVP for smaller and mid-size customers. After the bugs are worked out these solutions can be combined into bundled offerings.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: As a GE employee your on your own.   Salary is average for the most part.
cons:
Don't expect managerial support or help from above.  Management will make unreasonable work load demands on employees and their off-time.   Family means nothing . . . . . ZERO to GE Management and believe it or not, HR is the enemy.

As for Safety, the managerial application and demands for mandatory compliance became the "Problem" and actually resulted in many injuries of workers trying to comply with "Stupid" mandates and requirements created by incompetent and/or task ignorant safety people, using a one size fits all mentality.  

Don't expect to have a job if management needs to boost their stock prices.
advice_management: Listen to those of knowledge with experience, who work the jobs.  Pay for talent.

summary: "Overall a great company to work for"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Permissive Time Off, very personable managers, active career tracking and assistance when transiting to a new role, very progressive and forward thinking leadership
cons: Very big company so it makes you feel  unconnected to some of the things that go on. Many times it is difficult to get a straight answer when important, company-wide news comes out.
advice_management: Progressively changing a huge company takes time, dont expect culture to change overnight.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Paychecks are always deposited on time, and affinity groups are many. That's about all I can think of for pros.
cons: GE in New Orleans claims to have a startup feel despite being a corporate operation, but this couldn't be farther from the truth. Honesty is rare and decisions are motivated by political or individual reasons. Engineers are treated like numbers instead of people. Product work is reassigned often and rarely comes to completion with the same resources it started with, so pride in ones work is virtually impossible to attain. Financial difficulties pushed annual increases off indefinitely. Those selected for layoff and those who are underpaid often have many years of tenure over brand new employees who are kept or compensated better. Loyalty and commitment mean nothing to leadership. Focus on career advancement is non-existent, and there are no roles available for moving up. Medical benefits for family are highly expense yet the annual deductible is ridiculously high.
advice_management: Stop worrying about yourselves and put some thought into decisions that impact those you're responsible for. Also, put some energy into challenging antiquated HR policies that prevent you from compensating and valuing your employees.

summary: "Stay away from GE- Toxic, unethical and stressful!"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: You can learn all about power plants, if that is your interest.
cons:
- I joined GE from Honeywell, at the time of joining I was told that I have unlimited vacation time and I gladly joined as I was getting these benefits already at Honeywell along with free food. After 6 months I am  being told that I have 22 days vacation time! I feel like being cheated, the company that can not stand by its words speaks volumes about its ethics. 
- It's stressful to work at GE with no benefits as such, to a point that I suffered from stress induced acute anxiety at work and have to be on medications. Even for attending my daughter's event for an hour I was pointed out and told to take PTO while many just loiter at work place for hours or WFH while they work at other places on that day. I complained to the HR but all they did was pacification and no action on my request to change my boss/ relocate to another team. 
- It's a dog eat dog world in here, no concept of collaboration what so ever. New hires like me we told specifically not to collaborate even when we the bandwidth.
advice_management: Clean up your company, it's dirtier than you can imagine!

summary: "23 years at GE - 5 businesses in 4 locations in NE US"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Huge field of opportunities to grow; amazingly talented people.  Competitive pay and benefits. Very strong values around integrity (ethics), from the top down.
cons: I worked for GE from 1989 to 2012.  I was - and am - proud to have worked there.  However, I saw two trends emerge around 2005 that bothered me - and it took me 7 years to decide to move on.
advice_management: Two trends that made it a different company than the one I joined in '89.  1)  Selection of leaders became waaayyyyy more subjective and based on pedigree and personal relationships than on credibility with the workforce and good leadership skills.  2) The company's values shifted sharply to the left after Jeff I took over, and never moved back to the center, at least while I was there.  I left in 2012.  I'd still recommend the company to about anyone - just know that you're going to be in a culture that rewards liberal values.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: back in the day when Jack Welch was at the helm, GE was run like a well oiled machine.  The stock split, GE was good.  GE was diversified and the pension was funded.
cons:
Things changed when Jeff Immelt came and took charge and totally screwed up GE, he did not do what was best for the company, nor did the board of directors.  They kept the problem going on for over 16 years.  Replacing Immelt and not giving John Flannery enough time to fix a 16 year mess was wrong.
There is still a good ole boys network and not enough women are promoted.  GE talks diversity but their actions don't always show that.  Obviously the executives don't lead by example, they still spend money and cut everyone else from spending.  It should be across the board.  Expect to always worry about layoffs and to keep getting more and more work assigned to you as more people are cut.
advice_management: After 39 years, this is not the GE I started with.  I was embarassed at the end to say I worked for this company.  Would I suggest someone go work there, no, I would tell them if they want a work balance, look some where else as GE is not the only game in town.  Listen to your employees, they know what needs to be done and they go above and beyond to make things better.  Stop being top heavy in the organization as that is what got the business in trouble.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: people..The most valuable asset a company can have, and previous alstom \GE employees are hard working , competent and diligent.  Given strong management, budgets and  a clean direction. Things will get done
cons: GE management is based and derived on how to save a buck. Anything goes even if the short term decision is going to be long term negative. I have not worked for a company that makes so many poor financial and personnel  decisions.
advice_management: Start making decisions that are in the best interest of the employee's and what will benefit those employee's in the future. Quick hits to make yourself look better only show how detrimental you are too everyone else. There seems to be little to no forecasting and direction setting. There  are no budgets to be checked against. Upper management is only worried about how they stay in upper management. Work as a team not in a silo. Just because it was someone elses idea, doesnt mean it was a bad one.

cons: No raises in 2 years, negligible bonuses. recruiter lies about getting raises and bonuses to lure people in. Insurance benefits offered are the worst 3 options I have ever seen. Disconnected work culture.
advice_management: Provide training to clean up your work culture (employee bullying, inappropriate behaviors, disrespecting other employees, etc)  Clean up the attitudes of the field engineers who work closely with the customers, but have not been held to a professional standard.  Employees who have been with the company for 25 years or more need retraining on work place behaviors. Start cleaning up from the inside and hopefully you can maintain your customer base after their maintenance contract ends.  I’m No one is held to a higher standard inside the company, which is reflected in the 7.00 stock price.

summary: "Hard work and all those hours will not be not rewarded"
main_text: I worked at GE  for more than 10 years
pros:
Great benefits- used to at least
Nice physical work environment
Direct managers generally helpful
cons:
Grossly excessive hours not rewarded by pay, bonuses or appreciation
Promotions do not exist
HR not helpful and cartoonishly evil
advice_management: Company has been very clearly culling older workers to reduce its pension and medical cost. This is the reward for years of working ten, twelve hour days, giving up weekends for no big raises, no bonuses, no stock options, no promotions. The only thing that could be counted on for all that hard work was a good retirement and they even took that away. Think you want to work for GE?

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
New facility opened in 2016.  
Weekly happy hours if that is important to you
onsite gym-free
ping-pong table
Cold brew, popcorn, keg
cons: This office is struggling to create its own culture.  There is close to no senior leadership on site and the lack of leadership is palpable.  They opened a new facility to be in the biotech hub and are so desperate to fill roles they rush to fill them and don't hire the right talent.  This creates an office of unqualified people, bad culture, lack of leadership, extremely high turnover.  Turnover is so high, it results in you are either always doing 2 jobs, or cross-training a new higher... it's exhausting.  It's the blind leading the blind there.  During recruiting, they will try to spin it like this: "great opportunity to be in Life Sciences industry, be part of biotech", but I would not recommend anyone I like to work there.  GE likes to hire cheap, so most people are under 30, inexperienced, with high millennial expectations, thinking the world owes them everything and they don't need to work for anything.  Most people I worked with said that they were sold a job completely different from what the role actually ended up being.  The business is run in a "make the current quarter" mentality where they do anything to make the current quarter revenue numbers.  HR is offsite and extremely useless.  Given GE's overall problems as well, I would steer clear of working for GE in any capacity.
advice_management: The US region is your largest region.  Start acting like it and require the senior leaders for the USA to be located in Marlborough and show visible leadership on a daily basis.  Don't just fly them in for a beat down session when numbers are looking bad.

summary: "It was a good run but time to leave"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Any experience with GE helps build credibility and professional pedigree.  There is much to learn in terms of processes, continuous improvement, and organizational behavior.
cons: In recent years, business decisions are being made for short term gains.  There is undue pressure on suppliers, rather than seeing them as partners in providing the product.  Finding a good manager is critical to success, because the wrong manager can change one's entire experience.
advice_management: A global business should not be quite so "Schenectady-centric," particularly with all the technology that is available to employees. Many good employees are lost because they choose not to live in upstate NY, for a myriad of reasons.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros:
- Good exposure to different operations role at different sites across the US
- Week long training sessions with other GE businesses for development and networking
- Decent benefits overall, pretty good retirement plan
cons:
- Little advanced notice on where your next rotation will be, causing OMLPs to scramble with housing at last minute
- Off-program roles (after graduation) were very limited
- Hard to break the "operations" tag

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: If you like change, want to be challenged, have lots of job opportunities, have flexible work arrangements, then work for GE.  Career opps  have always been vast but with power and oil & gas industry, it has declined.
cons: Change is the biggest challenge thus far as the company sells off businesses previously owned for years, spinning off Healthcare and now  reversing  the deal with BHGE.  Benefits have declined especially around health insurance but all else seems to be ok. Most people are on permissive vacation, meaning take off when you want as long as your work is done - there is no more allocated vacation.  Can be long hours but you also have the flexibility. Diversity is valued and respect is required.
advice_management: Stick to a few key priorities, and stop asking folks to do everything all the time. Everything is not equally important.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: There is a Large Network of peers for knowledge sharing, flexible work hours/locations (for engineering), flexible permissive time, opportunities for travel
cons: Engineers are punished for staying in current roles. Expertise is highly valued and used, however the annual raises for an employee that stays in the same team (which people rely on) is much less than for an engineer that changes jobs.
advice_management: Reward expertise and being a go-to person. Provide a reason to stay on the technical leadership path, we need these people and we're losing them to better paying companies.

main_text: I worked at GE  for more than a year
pros: Flexible Work Schedule, unlimited time off, on-site gym.  brand new office building.
cons: Poisonous Culture.  Management continues to change priorities and plays employees off each other.  Unclear goals, causing long hours and a stressful environment. of spinning your wheels. Also, my title was a misnomer.  There was no Analytical work, only accounts payable work.
advice_management: When I started at Global Ops, I was told I was empowered to make change.  In less than a year, I learned that was nonsense.  No change will occur until Management truly embraces open communication and truly cooperating with other teams to resolve process problems.  Also, Management really needs to understand what their teams actually do on a day to day basis.  Stop preaching the goals if you don't even realize we aren't doing anything to reach those goals.

job_title: Current Employee - Assembly and Test Technician
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Teaming environment makes workers feel empowered when it works. Work is performed inside. Tools are provided. Flexible hours.
cons: Teaming environment is just a trick to avoid paying middle managers and keep workers fighting amongst themselves too much to organize. Pay is not on par with the responsibilities required—you are expected to be more than just a tech but the pay does not reflect this. Production goals are not based on technicians working a 40 hr week. Overtime is not required on paper but is required for teams to meet production goals—at the end of the day the only thing that truly matters is output numbers. Policies constantly change based on the current site consensus. Gatekeeping tactics are being implemented with the tech level requirements, as one group advances they change the requirements behind them making it harder to advance. Support staff are actively involved in decisions affecting technician pay without their own pay even being known. Techs are subject to termination if they don’t comply with certain time requirements yet support staff can blatantly disregard these with no repercussions.
advice_management: Keep support staff out of any discussions that concern technician pay. Tech pay should not be disclosed to support staff just as theirs is not disclosed. This creates a rift that no amount of teaming will fix. If we are truly all at the same level in a “flat” organization, then this unspoken hierarchy of white collar over blue collar has to go away.

summary: "Butt Kissing & "Burn 'em and Churn 'em" Culture, but Nice Benefits"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros:
- Good Health, Dental, Vision
- "Unlimited" PTO
- Company says all the right stuff when it comes to being "employee friendly"
- A variety of flexible working arrangements
- Pay was competitive at best
- Depending on position, you get a bonus
cons:
- Salaried with the expectation that you work over 40 hours a week
- Deliberately understaffed
- Good luck using any of that PTO as it is always at manager's discretion
- Since PTO is "Unlimited", all that time off you can't use is never compensated for with a cash out
- Good luck using a flexible work arrangement
- For advancement, playing office politics is more important than performance or ability
- Someone who works 100 hours a week but produces poor results is viewed more favorable than someone who works 40 hours a week and produces good results
- Butt kissing culture
- Favor contractors to avoid giving benefits wherever possible
- Inflexible and unadaptable management
advice_management:
Learn to listen to subordinates who 
- Have new ways to solve problems
- Know of new technologies that might help get work done
- Have more technical experience/knowledge/training regarding the work being done 
- Disagree with you now and again
- Are not full time employees

Look at quality of results produced by employees, not quantity.

Better identify nepotism by reviewing promotions and promoting practices.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years

cons:
Travel will only be to terrible places.
There is no joy in anything we do here.
Team building is more depressing than a funeral.
The pay is critically low for this area.
advice_management: Start spending money on the people at this location or at least let them know they should be looking for jobs elsewhere.

cons:
- Leadership vision : Jeff Immelt fostered a culture of selling a great vision to customers and employees.  As it turns out, no one in leadership is that great in bringing a vision to reality, which is why GE is where it is.   It is clear that under Immelt GE lost its expertise in running businesses and teams.
- Identity of GE is now lost... GE is now even a smaller footprint and whatever is left doesn't create a sense of GE.  
- Culture is a mess....
advice_management: GE is no longer a conglomerate company... so stop trying to act and organize as one.  Find good leaders who have actual expertise instead of promoting glorified project managers and auditors into leadership positions.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years

Multiple layoffs through the years and transfer of work to those that remain.
Highly stressful environment, low employee morale.
High cost of medical benefits.
Inconsistencies in awards and celebrations across departments.
advice_management:
Treat employees in salaried non-management positions with more respect.
Become more transparent on business direction and strategy.

summary: "Sadly, after a great career I’ve finally lost the ‘silver lining’ attitude."
main_text: I have been working at GE  for more than 10 years
pros: My immediate team is AWESOME! I wouldn’t trade these folks for anybody else. We work hard, support each other, deliver for our customers, and continue to learn and grow despite everything else happening around us.
cons:
HR, Digital (global functions and data), and senior leadership continue to disappoint. No clear direction, great leaders forced out due to ridiculous location strategy, no communication on next steps or what they are doing to fill the leadership gap. In the span of one month I will lose my leader and the next two leaders above that. Our team has been moved around internally four times in the past year and a half with leaders beyond my direct manager taking absolutely no interest in what we do and how we deliver for our customers. 

HR and HR for HR are a joke. Not at all responsive to employees questions and not at all proactive in reaching out to the employees they supposedly support to learn about what we do. HR  is not an employee advocate. They are puppets. HR People Partner...please. Spare me. 

Compensation is far behind peer companies/jobs. Absolutely no faith that we are on the cutting edge of HR any longer. We got cocky, thought we were better than everyone else, and fell too far behind to catch up.
advice_management: Take a hard look at the impact of what you’re doing on employees. Your losing, or will be losing, good people because you’ve lost focus on the fact that it’s the employee that creates our success.

It’s good to prepare for the future but learn to fail fast and pivot quicker. People don’t feel valued or safe in the company any longer.

summary: "I knew it was a shinking ship and bailed...."
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: The colleagues that I worked with that were really interested in delivering value were great people. Unfortunately, they were the only sane people in an asylum run by the inmates and as such, the value that they worked to deliver would never see the light of day because of the risk-adverse culture and the bureaucratic cluster-bleep that has been fostered and rewarded for so long.
cons: Too many to list and I don't think it's any surprise that everyone else hasn't realized. GE is still operating with a management structure that was put in place in the 60's and hasn't really evolved since. Their management is essentially driving the company into the ground and as such, it cannot attract, hire, or retain high performing people to help the company be successful into the 21st century. GE hires and fires people so frequently and often and is so shortsighted and run by making quarter-to-quarter analyst expectations, there's absolutely no way they're going to be able to rebuild for the long-term as long as these short-term goals are driving their business decisions.
advice_management: Retire or leave immediately.  GE should divest itself of all  its subsidiary businesses and then fire all management immediately. The subsidiaries will become independent entities that are free from corporate and should be run like lean startups.

cons: GE hires to many young kids straight out of collage and puts them in leadership positions. And they don’t listen and take advice from the workers who have been there for years and years who knows the ends and out.
advice_management: GE hires to many young kids straight out of collage and puts them in leadership positions. When they haven’t ever worked in a place like GE and when a problem arises they don’t listen to the employees who have been doing the job for 20 plus years who knows the ends and outs of the job. There more interested in trying to get themselves recognized which 90% of the time results in them spending tons of money and time on different ideas of how they think it should be done. And in the end they usually just have to go back and ask the machinists who run the machine how to fix it. This waste of money also cause us employees not to be able to get the tools re need to do our jobs correctly and on time

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Decent pay & benefits
cons: Zero accountability for upper management be it for unprofessional behavior or failed results. Lack of direction from leadership.  Due to the amount of reorganization & lay offs management & employees understand knowledge is power and will not share information or train new employees, creating great opportunities for suppliers & bad results for GE. Culture is broken, leadership talks about change & being open to change, but much stays the same at the top layers.  The only changes that occur are in lower middle to low management staff.  Layoffs occur monthly, constant staff changes makes it impossible to knowledge transfer or create a strategic plan to implement & execute so all work is transactional at best.
advice_management: If GE truly wants change: Define a strategy, communicate  it & holds ALL  folks accountable- measure supplier performance, measure executive performance via external audit companies/process. Hire new staff with external qualifications & knowledge. Get rid of “internal competition” which makes for more politics & kingdom building & the mentality of “this it is the way it has always been & is at GE”.  Improve mediocre systems, policy & processes which hinder most collaborations between  entities & departments (suppliers divide & conquer all day).  Hold managers accoutable for succession & training of staff, so that a token few don’t hold the keys to the kingdom.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
In my experience GE is so large that it really isn't 1 company.   I experience my field service district as if I work for a $15M business,  not a $100MM.

I have a great manager who took over from a very long term great manager.  As a result our district has high morale and excellent production.
cons: We will only be with GE another month or so as our division has been sold to raise cash to deal with corporate's giant mess.   Apparently manufacturing, selling and servicing large electrical equipment is not part of GE's "core business".   They are a software company in case you haven't heard.  (Thomas Edison facepalm)
advice_management: Treat your people well and most will want to work hard.

advice_management: Stay focused on defining a sustainable portfolio of core businesses and don't overreact to the analyst & press reviews.    Need a 10 year view and solid execution, not a 1 year promise that requires unsustainable actions to hit short term targets

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great people, great work life balance(vacation, flexibility, maternity/paternity) and good pay.  I personally had great career growth in my time there. Great leadership programs and training (if you get in/them).
cons:
My cons are specific to GE's current climate; currently it is a tough time and that trickles into everything you as an employee cares about. 

Career growth is difficult at this time, unless you are willing to give everything for the company and smooch smooch smooch, it is difficult because there are so many people being laid off that are trying to stay.
Compensation is being "hit" by the current environment; no raises, low to no bonuses, and even 401k hits.
Job stability.
 
Once GE rights the ship (because I know they will), my cons list goes down to just job stability.
advice_management: Keep being positive, but also honest in particular with those that are/will be affected by the current climate within the company. I am hoping and pulling for you to right the ship. You are a great company and needs to pull through for us who had the pleasure of working there, for the US, and for the customers.

summary: "First class technology company. Enhancement in digital integration of systems needed. Improve diversity."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
People collaborate and are available to help each other. Technical focus on products is impressive. Breadth and depth of knowledge across the company is second to none.  

Benefits are good but declining. Permissive time off policy is appreciated by most.  Compensation is very competitive especially in areas of the country with lower  cost of living.
cons:
Operational excellence hampered by lack of digital integration of data and fragmented process ownership. Much time is spent in manual back room activities manipulating information rather than moving the technology forward. 

Not enough recognition of experienced employees in a company that is very sensitive to diversity.  Discrimination is not overt, but present. 

Some degree of nepotism detracts from claims of being a true meritocracy.
advice_management:
Stress “technology” over “industrial” and fix the digital part of “Digital Industrial”. 

Embed digital experts in functional areas to bridge the gap having them work the right things - developing systems that integrate data allowing the functional professionals to spend more time moving the organization forward, quickly. 

Operational excellence could be improved by developing strong process owners with system performance tied to their compensation. 

Recognize and embrace diversity of all kinds including age and background experience. Huge opportunity to create strong diverse teams combining experience and technical capability, with little effort.

cons: The ownership for almost everything sits with the individual businesses, so if your management is part of the boys’ club, you can bet that they will always be protected and you won’t. Morale has been really bad since the structure of the company has been changing. It’s not a good place to be right now. All the people around you are either getting laid off or job searching. Everyone’s out for themselves. The no tolerance harassment policy is also a complete joke. The company doesn’t care. I truly, honesty feel that my manager could push me into a conference room, take advantage of me, and the company would look the other way.
advice_management: I don’t even know what to say. This has not been a positive experience for me.

summary: "Better stay away from GE at this time."
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great people, large organization, some training opportunities, technical engagements.
cons: GE is going through a mess right now; financially/organizationally/leaders jumping ship. The job security is very volatile with leaders being clueless about software (though GE wants to be a software company). Regular layoffs & scramble to find a job inside GE (only will succeed in finding an internal  if you know the "right" people not if you have the "right skills"). HR is only looking at every employee as a number, irrespective of ones' skills and achievements. The Detroit location is led by poor leadership and is being looked upon as a money saving opportunity (layoff people or move to a better tax discounted area). There is a lot of effort to ask people to move to Rhode Island or Miami. There was a round of layoff in MI in Nov, 2018 (around 300 people), the only reason given was "we are pulling out of Detroit" (Can you believe it - not due to cost pressures, not due to performance but due to location strategy change???). Local HR is unresponsive to say the least.
advice_management: Treat your people well and do not look at them as just numbers or cost saving opportunities. if you want to be a software company - people with skills are your asset. Unfortunately its not the same GE anymore!

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Can try other opportunities.
cons: red tape process,  senior management not always transparent

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Pay is ok, although that is changing for the worse every contract. Market based wages and benefits take always are the norm these days.
cons: Poor management. You will work very hard to do the right thing only to find they only appreciate toadies and people willing to shortcut the process. You will be ignored, belittled, and made to compromise your integrity if you want to get ahead. I retire soon after 39 years and have been ashamed to work here for quite awhile. Very sad, as this is not the company I started with.
advice_management: Do the right thing. Listen to people. Your greatest asset is people who care and you are killing them by ignoring them. Our products carry people’s lives in our hands. Act like that matters!

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: It allows you to  experience multiple businesses without jumping from company to company.
cons: Pay and opportunities disparities - both depends too much on your direct manager and your sponsor(s).
advice_management: Value and respect ALL your employees.

summary: "Why would anyone consider switching to GE at this time???"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Unless you don't have a job and desperately need one or if they are making you an offer at least "6 sigmas" outside the market range, I don't see any pros!
cons:
Where do I even start?? To be clear, this is about GE Digital and not the overall GE. But seriously, this is a great vision screwed up with poor execution. But the main reason I wouldn't advise anyone to join GE Digital is that the folks who screwed up execution are still in the same position, continue making the same poor decisions but get rewarded with promotions or not getting "RIFed".

I have a neutral opinion of John Flannery as such but I fail to understand why he hasn't canned Bill Ruh as yet. My only guess would be that he is too busy trying to save the big mother ship and doesn't have any other option but to stick with Bill Ruh because he can't reveal the true strategy in an interview to any new CEO candidate!
advice_management: Clean up the cancer as soon as possible - Ruh and all his direct reports, as well as HR. Even if someone can say that the RIFs were necessary, the leadership truly failed by not evaluating the actual roles that needed to be eliminated as opposed to protecting favorites

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time

cons:
1) ROI models are too often excel or powerpoint - not customer validated
2) Continued cost-cutting impacts sellers (top line) and engineers (competitive product).. real concerns afetr many consecutive years of layoffs

Managers move around every 2 years, no constancy.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
- Real products, with a vision to power, cure and transport the earth's people. That's pretty cool!
- Diverse work opportunities within GE
- Increased transparency is helping
cons:
- Company vision is polarized between cost-out and innovation, and between centralizing (Corp shared services, horizontal teams) and decentralizing (businesses autonomy) ... these opposing fronts create mixed priorities at every level, lengthy decision-making, excessive resourcing, and weakens both strategies.
- Due to cost-saving-restructuring, many leaders are in dual-roles... this means they are spread way too thin and have conflicting priorities.  All new "big" jobs are being given to existing leaders, who get to keep their current job!
- Significant financial issues with no end in sight - management is making short-term decisions in order to weather the storm. Financial issues have impacted employees: significant cut to bonuses and minimal annual pay increases.  And - stock options, granted annually, haven't had any value for employees for the last 20yrs.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Great work life balance.  If you do great work you get the credit. Solid visibility to senior management.  Line of site to job promotions. There are many inspiring leaders to work for.
cons: Needs to be more clear and transparent vision for where the company wants to be.
advice_management: Promote the managers who can execute and lead teams well.

cons: Big company - above average amount of bureaucracy - making change was often slow and challenging.
advice_management: Trust but verify - less bureaucracy to allow the leaders lead without unnecesary obstacles.

summary: "GE is a floundering due to failed leadership"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time

pros: The people are fantastic, collaborative environment. Big focus on development of talent. Significant opportunity for career progression and growth.
cons: Tough business cycle, lack of transparency in the past has led to the need for tough decisions today. Need better systems and improved processes to avoid too much unnecessary churn.
advice_management: John Flannery has been enforcing a culture of transparency, needs to continue. Tough cycle for the business, but find ways to motivate employees to stay and feel appreciated.

main_text: I have been working at GE  for more than 3 years
pros: Great company with good 'bones'
cons: Incredibly talented people are being  discouraged to work on long term goals for a number of reasons,including the emphasis on where and how they work. Please treat your most important assets like grown-ups. The office is a great distraction, but it is not conducive to deep thought. Google got meditation rooms and message therapist.  You cant compete with that.
advice_management: GE needs more energetic ideas to inspire new workforce and shape the world of the future. The new battery pods are a good start. Please stop pushing the old school agenda of location over talent, it didn't work for IBM or Yahoo. Google is in another galaxy when it comes to incentivizing employees to habitate the office.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time

main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: Flexible Family time, prorated vacation days,  not micro managed,
cons: Promises not kept,  computer training on things that didn't pertain to job site which would take hours and days to complete.   not enough man power to not cause conflict if someone was off or called in sick or to cover work loads. No real pay increases.
advice_management: keep well on promises have them documented, employ more personal at needed sites. stop reducing employees to save money and cause more work for employees not laid off or ones that don't quit.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Great people, solid leadership, strong training/development programs, and good opportunities.   You can usually get involved in projects outside of your main responsibility which gives variety to your role.  Often ad hoc projects could lead to other opportunities within the company.
cons: I really don't have anything to share.  I had a good experience.  I never found GE for as big as it was to be bureaucratic.   Others may see it differently but that was not my experience.
advice_management: Leadership programs (LPs) were sometimes viewed by colleagues (who were not part of the program) as a special club; and the people in those programs would often talk about the fact they were an "LP".   Sometimes employees would feel that individuals that graduated from the programs were given move opportunities even if they were not the most qualified for those opportunities.    This issue is not unique to GE, other companies have similar programs and issues.  At some point in history LP programs were tremendous programs when employees stayed with companies for most of their career.  Maybe it is time to rethink the structure and expected outcomes for those programs for a new generation.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Flex time, casual dress, health clinic on site
cons: Very very poor management, little to low work morale, management always making bad decisons, too many slackers, no funding for projects but still take on work, benefits get worse and worse each year, hard workers just take on more work and slackers just hide
advice_management: Get rid of the people who aren't doing the work that makes decisions

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: travel, exposure, responsibilities, people and learning
cons: pay, pressure, quite American culture with pros and cons

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Relaxed work environment, good pay, flex hours outside of close. Gym on site, work from home when you need to, and permissive time off (unlimited as long as it’s approved by a manager).
cons: Where to start? The work migrated to the Cincinnati location was all journal entries, processes, and repetitive tasks. No real analysis work. The work you do is all random based on what team you’re placed on, and if you aren’t one of managements favorites, forget about being promoted. Career progression is confusing and extremely subjective, no official guidelines on what you have to do to be promoted. GE is obsessed with finding P&L “good guys” no matter how you can get them. The internal audit function CAS is a joke, but it gets you to be an executive. Work has moved to a horizontal approach, so you will be doing only 1 of the following if you’re in accounting at GE: Cash, Treasury, Commercial, Supply Chain, Intercompany, Payroll/T&L, Consolidation, or Tax. GE could decide at anytime to sell off another business and you will lose your job.
advice_management: Stabilize the company so employees feel safe. Fix the communication and structure on career advancement.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
-Greatest opportunity for growth I have seen.
-Very Flexible schedule
-Unlimited time off for senior employees if you get your job done
-Great people to work with
cons:
-Leadership places politics over business needs (this may be changing)
-Mismanagement from leadership the last two years - No bottoms up voice
-Too focused on quarterly earnings and stock price instead of technology
advice_management: GE has the best technology resources in the world. Leadership needs to focus less on the quarter, and stretch to innovate.  The Tesla business model is the way of the future, and the only way to make progress while gaining internal and external excitement. The stock price will increase, and so will profits if GE did this.  It needs to be publicly transparent that this is happening for this to work.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Challenging and interesting projects and smart people to work with; Good life and work balance; internationally renown and well respected company in the industry, good opportunity to learn new things especially for young professionals;
cons: Morale is low, very low; Constant drives to reduce cost, so travel constraints, and layoffs; Leadership is not making important and tough decisions swiftly; Opportunities get lost when no body dares to stand out, make the call and is willing to take the responsibility. From time to time re-org, like big-bang, back and forth.
advice_management: Two many senior professionals holding leadership roles who are mostly serving as messengers in between hands-on folks and key stakeholders; Need to assure employees of future of the company; reinstall faith and confidence in the company.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Typical corporate benefits. Discretionary PTO.
cons: Software development practices stuck in the 1980s: poor source code control discipline, lax code reviews, not using supportive tools (like Review board for code reviews), no automated integration between planning, reviewing, and storing code.
advice_management: Get with the program: learn what proper DevOps practices are.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Exposure to global operations, access to excellent internal training
cons: Lack transparency decision making on many levels, no clear ability to understand the business model and its productivity departmentally. Antiquated business processes that over time no one fully understands but fear changing/improving do to unknown risks.
advice_management: Leadership and decision making is too isolated to few people corporately, expecting flow down without understanding the businesses constraints. De-centralize, and lower the corporate overhead by delegating the lowest business units and hold them accountable.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years

advice_management: Discontinue the useless rotation programs. Focus on advancing people with a record of success and, if someone fails repeatedly, fire them instead of just rotating them to some other department.

summary: "Good company that has lost its direction"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Experienced peers, collaborative environment, and good diversity. Incredible size and scale of projects and platforms.
cons: Constantly reorganizing, recent layoffs, strategy changes monthly. Experience level of middle to upper management has declined in last 5-6 years. Absence of annual performance reviews.
advice_management: Stop chasing other companies success and return to what made others chase GE in the 1990's.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time

cons: Wall Street perception is so important to leadership that it appears all-consuming at times.  The corporate bureaucracy and layer upon layer of reviews is not efficient.
advice_management: Focus on your customers and employees.  When you delight those two groups, the rest will come.  Continue to communicate the role GE plays in the world.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great work life balance, wonderful people. We're powering the world.
cons: collective focus is a mess. Lots of smart people but to many people trying to drive the boat. There is a "reset" at the start of every year meant to affect Q4, and it usually take the first 2 quarters to get everyone aligned; it is short sighted because there is no way to drive momentum or results that short term... but everyone wants to be a change maker. Everyone is busy but nothing is getting done...
advice_management: Start looking at a 2 to 3 year growth plan instead of constantly "pivoting"; just because it is a new year doesn't mean we should drop everything and shift. Keep people in their lanes and focused on smaller more impactful, measurable and achievable goals.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: Good people, diverse industries, great brand name...VERY flexible for work/life balance. Low stress environment. Cool technologies and opportunities to be hands on as an engineer.
cons: Slow, old corporation struggling to adapt even though it wants to. Has all of the resources needed to change, but is bogged down in process/history/approvals.
advice_management: Be risky! Shake things up and encourage your teams to evolve EVERY DAY. Demand more from your employees and encourage cross pollination with other teams.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: They try harder the most companies to place employees elsewhere in the company during layoffs and take interest rehiring laid off employees first.

They sign contracts with recruiters that prevent them from recruiting any GE employee no matter how long the employee has been there. Even if the recruiter has never worked with said employee.  Product managers and technical product managers  have limited leadership skills. In many companies that may not be terrible but at GE they are put in a position where it causes all sorts of problems.
advice_management: Work on leadership skills of TPMS and Product Owners.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: Multi-Industrial, global organization.  Global research and development network.  125+ year old institution that has worked through troubled times before.  Because of its diversity, GE has positions for many different backgrounds and skills in its varied business components.
cons: Cost cutting, reorganization, bad bets and circumspect accounting practices all indicate a downward trend for GE,  The stock is down 45%+ while the market has been up the last two years.  The company needs to pick a direction that works and treat its employees more like the valued talent they need to retain then disposable commodities with a 3-5 year expiration.  Environment may work for the younger generation but there won't be much older talent left within the next few years.
advice_management: Cost cutting is fine but you've cut beyond the bone and need to take a second look at  how the company is restructuring, especially from a talent perspective.  Culture and values are held in great esteem, which they should be, but the only folks benefiting at GE are the senior management.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Flexible work hours (during non-close hours), trainings (non-work related), unlimited vacation (really depends on the manager or the team), relocation bonus
cons:
Management: Rude and clueless senior and executive management who do not care about their teams and will blame you for not have the job done even if things were out of your control. 

Work: Unrealistic work goals, redundant work processes, 15+ hour daily work weeks during close (Accounting/Finance groups), work on federal holidays and weekends, blame throwing on each other is part of the culture. Only certain teams are helpful while the rest feel like sharks in a tank. 

Benefits: Pay is extremely low compared to market average and raises are no more than 2%. Forget about being paid for further education or raises after achieving them. Medical is high deductible only and not affordable to most. Have to pay for monthly parking in the building. 

Career: GE Global ops started off with 1000+ employees in 2016 and now there less than 200 left in the center. You can imagine what the turn over rate is . Changing the teams is a strict process (18+ stay in current position required) with no possibilities for raises or promotions. GE's current reputation in the market has completely deteriorated so recruiters and companies know that you are desperate to get out. More importantly, the company overall is shrinking down at a massive rate and businesses are  being closed down to cut down costs. Layoffs and firings are expected more in the upcoming year.
advice_management: Figure out the direction where the company is successful and then start caring about employees running it.

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Technical Program Manager
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: GE is a great company with a great history.   The company truly believes in its HR policies.  Things like EO, compliance, and ethical behavior are not just once-a-year training.  The company does truly strive to be ethical and fair to employees.
cons:
GE is in the middle of a very painful transition on two fronts.  First, the sales mentality that has pervaded for years has created a culture of 'No one fails.'  This doesn't meant that no one fails - it means that we don't address failures and allow them to continue on by just rebranding them as some kind of alternative success.

Second, GE knows that it must become a digital company to stay relevant in the future and this transition has been very painful.  Instead of bringing in new leaders to make us digital, GE has relied on their legacy managers to just try and to think and behave differently.  Needless to say, the company has not changed enough in the right ways.
advice_management: The shift to becoming a digital company is not like a new product introduction.  This is not some short term thing.  It's a huge cultural shift that needs to be led by people who know software.  It cannot be adapted by a leader that has been living in spreadsheets for the past 20 years.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Very innovative, Allows work life balance with permissible vacation days, great salaries, multiple businesses and opportunities for growth
cons: Expectations very high on new assignments or roles without proper training with immediate results, some nepotism, a lot of layers, older commuter systems, communication can be lost with layers of management. Very different culture to learn fast.
advice_management: Provide direct outcomes and objectives for employees, allow proper time to learn the position and provide better training, more open communication.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: GE generally is a great company to work for. It gets the fundamentals right. Compliance is not just a fancy word. Everyone lives it. Besides, you get to work with really smart people. Culture and people are two top reasons I stick around.
cons:
GE is a big company. It is so big that there are rules and standards to everything. IT tools definitely is something the company struggles on. 

Decisions cannot make quickly as there are too many stakeholders internally. 

Young talented people cannot move up quickly, generally speaking... as there are so many policies and it needs to seem fair to everyone.
advice_management: GE is at challenging times now, but cost cutting target is not the only measurement here. We should still invest in developing people, and we should really support this financially too.

cons: Some GE businesses are failing and GE has to cut cost.  From day to day, you are not sure if your team will be eliminated or laid off.  When you work in a technical discipline at GE you can get stuck in that area.  This is a great place for experts; however, new technologist that may want to branch out to different areas have a more difficult time.  Lots of free internal training is available.
advice_management: During layoffs make a focused effort to retain your strong talent.  Recognize the need to have leaders that will coach and develop the new IT talent.

job_title: Former Employee - IM Project Manager, Operations
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Health Insurance and 401K. 
Work on cutting edge  technologies. 
You do work with very good people.
cons:
For 32 years GE had always said if you were a top performer you had a job. The layoffs in late November 2017 were not based on performance, or seniority, but on where you sat. In my division Digital Coretech 200 of their most highly skilled people were let go because they had been awarded the privilege of working from home in return for being a top performer. The 200 people we laid off because they did not sit in one of 4 locations which include 3 VPs and 5 Directors.  The fear is until GE stock gets back up top $50 a share activist investors are going to influence decision making. 

You need to have an exit strategy if you work for GE, they have become just another corporate employer where employees tend to get looked at as a commodity.
advice_management: Watch your step. The way the downsizing was handled you have created a serious morale problem and from what I am hearing many of the good people are looking for their next job outside of GE.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Ultrasound Only- Leading products most care areas, great innovation brining products to the market that matter. Product development and engineering are shining jewel of company. Segmentation in product development is a key strength sharing innovated ideas across product platforms.
cons: Ultrasound Only- On the commercial side- broken culture driven & managed by fear, extremely transactional, non inclusive, too segemented to a fault in commercial structure, poor leadership at the highest levels. Current distribution model has peaked and needs significant leadership change to correct course.
advice_management: Ultrasound Only- Become strategic in the deployment model or continue to observe stagnation to negative gains in market share growth. Make a change in Commercial Leadership to change the culture. The people in the field make the company, not the leadership that has created a frail self destructive environment. The rest of the GEHC has worked hard to create a great place to work. It is time for a make over in Ultrasound.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: A company that cares about training and leadership development. Very dynamic and fast-paced, with a culture where being nice is rewarded. Great place to learn about business management. Some of the main offices will feel very international as it is one of the most global companies.
cons: GE really struggled in 2017 and is especially struggling to integrate digital technology into the company. Being a data scientist at GE involves working through a lot of unclean and siloed databases and dealing with plenty of managers who fundamentally don't understand what you do.
advice_management: Don't be afraid to get into the technical weeds. The world is moving very fast and people who understand how to use technology are leading it. GE is not.

cons: No career advancement. Pay not competitive at all.  Benefits not great. Layoffs left and right. Unknown future of the company. Nepotism.
advice_management: Let your employees know what's going on instead of us finding out on the news. Promote from within. Develop all employees, not just those in the leadership development program.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Legacy Programs bring continuity to multiple businesses.  It is easy to move within businesses.  Great educational benefits as well.
cons: Currently, there is a major upheaval and the uncertainty is distracting.  It is hard to get employees to concentrate on work while they worry about their future employment.
advice_management: Restructure only once per year so people can focus on their jobs instead of what keeps them up at night.  It's hardly productive.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Director of Service (DOS) and Co-workers were excellent to work with.  Many challenges working multi modalities (CT, PET, AW, and Ultrasound).  Remote support and documentation is excellent and getting better.  Overall, excellent job.
cons: No work life balance.  As most, if not all, large corporations do more with less.  A work week of 60 to 70 hours was the norm not the exception.  I choose retirement due to NO work life balance.
advice_management: Hire more engineers to do service.  This would reduce OT and improve overall work environment.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great pay for legacy workers or management.
cons: The management at GE is generally atrocious. There are a few good apples but not many. They rarely put themselves in their own worker's shoes in order to empathize and improve working conditions. The current problems with the company accurately reflect how poorly our last CEO thought of his employees. Hopefully brighter days are ahead for the corporation.
advice_management: Put yourself in your subordinate's shoes before speaking or making a decision that affects them.

summary: "Not all its cracked up to be"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: It was good pay and benefits. Getting to know some of your coworkers was great and i truly developed from lifetime friends.
cons: Well, where to start. First, the management sucked. No one was on the same page and so many different things were told differently depending on who you were talking to. Second, The perks of being a GE employee got worse and worse every year. Third, one minute the company was thriving and the next minute we were getting laid off. There was never an honest story told to employees by any management staff. We never knew if we were going to be working for a long period or periodically laid off, which happened quite a bit. One day I was making $22 an hour and then told that i got bumped down to entry level, making $16 an hour with no big heads up on the change. And now to learn that the company is up for sell. The communication is awful and the little people don't matter at all.
advice_management: Care more about your employees than you do currently.

summary: "GE will fail due to hiring and promotion tactics"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: The pros are probably the benefits, but that is pretty much it.
cons: The company is selling off and going down hill, but if anyone has been to their Twitter page you can see they aren't interested in the best candidates but are interested in unethical "progressive" hiring practices.  Instead of building up current employees who have passion to work ahead, they hire inexperienced colleges graduates and hire exclusively to meet  "diversity" instead of the best which are usually people already within the company that started from the bottom.
advice_management: Promote only from with in. Management training programs only for internal employees with experience. Terminate all current and former OMLPs. Hire the best regardless of demographics.

advice_management: Support your people, give them the backing they need, and stop thinking change for the sake of change is a good thing!

summary: "Like poor little sheep, they've lost their way.....baaaa, baaa, baaa"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Vast resources. Smart, capable people.
cons:
Organizationally, it's a tangled ball of string - more so than at any time in the past 20 or 25 years. 
The "GE Store" has done little to break down inter-divisional walls.
Poor strategic decisions have resulted in poorly positioned businesses, burdened by huge weights (Alstom).
"Digital-Industrial" was/is the right idea, but inorganic expansion and spending on, and rebranding to this concept seems to have been executed by drunken sailors, blindly driven by group-think. GE may get there, but it won't be efficient - may not be effective, and certainly is not in time to lead the world as GE should have done.
advice_management: SEBs and EBs should act less like lemmings, and Question Authority more often

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Technical Product Manager

cons: GE has a tendency of promoting those that are the loudest/showiest in their work vs the ones that actually do the work.
advice_management: GE's stepped away from its core competency - leadership. I would love to see it return to having leaders with strong integrity and the ability to make the hard, but right decisions.

cons:

2) Strategies are sometimes conflicting such as measuring managers to insource contractors to employees, yet there is a hiring freeze which makes meeting the metrics impossible
3) There are too many corporate mandates that result in complexity for the businesses
advice_management:
1) Empower people to make more decisions and remove the barriers
2) Allow the businesses to do what is right for their customers and employees
3) Stay with one strategy and let the team deliver

main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: If you are willing to relocate often and network with the right people, you can climb ladder.
cons: Poor senior level decision making as evidenced by exiting financial services at the trough, investing in oil and gas when oil prices were sinking, promoting renewable energy but investing heavily in French fossil fuel company. Slow paced, not a lot of urgency as ship was sinking. Teams are often pitted against each other, whether purposefully or b.c the org is so big no one know multiple teams are working on same projects, which is a waste of resources.
advice_management: Understand that the reason your brand is entrenched in the U.S. is because you were in people's homes and part of their lives for decades. By exiting consumer facing industries, your future success will be based on performance, not name recognition. And you have proved an inability to succeed on performance alone.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: GE is involved in so many different areas that it's tough to not find something akin to your dream job somewhere in the company.  If you're proactive, have a good manager, and are willing to work, you will find yourself with a lot of control over your career and the ability to shape your day-to-day work.  The company also has a lot of fantastic professional development benefits - again, if you're proactive and willing to work, you can really develop the skill set that you want.
cons:
The health benefits are outrageously expensive compared to both my and my significant other's previous jobs.  Many perks (pension, home office expenses for those who primarily work out of an office, the retirement payout schedule, and more) have been cut over the last year which continues to impact employees well-being.  Furthermore, with the company having a very down year on the market, there has been a sharp increase in the number of layoffs in several business units which has fed into a developing culture of fear and mistrust.  

Biggest con that I can think of - last year, GE found a way to literally take a paycheck from American employees at Christmas.  The company has a bi-weekly payout schedule for your salary which means twice a year you have a month with three paychecks.  GE, in an effort to get in front of changing OT laws, decided to move the last paycheck of the year to the following week.  In affect, American employees, who tend to look at the 'third paycheck' month as a bonus of sorts, were left feeling like they were robbed.  It still leaves a very sour taste in my mouth.
advice_management: GE is a great company with a lot of opportunity, but at the moment I would leave in a heartbeat if I found a similar job with a competitor.  It's becoming increasingly difficult to to justify working here with the awful health care benefits (20% of my pay goes to health care now), the poor culture, and the feeling of being a cog in the wheel.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: None to speak of, at least relative to the competition.
cons: The much-vaunted 'unlimited vacation' policy is frowned upon if used, and will make you look bad for asking.  Its a great culling tool when layoffs are near.  Despite how it sounds on the surface, veteran salaried employees are routinely denied ANY time off for months at a time and appointments with mgmt to schedule family trips are routinely cancelled.  If you travel for the company, they will make sure you have to travel on bookended weekends that are not rebated.    Good luck if you happen to be married or have kids.  You'll never see whats-her-name again during waking hours.  This is not sarcasm.  I am not being particularly unkind.  It's just 100% true.  It's as bad as it sounds.
advice_management: Keep your 'unlimited vacation' label if you like, but include a minimum guarantee that full-time employees will get at least 1 measly week off per 5 years of service.  A cancelled meeting to talk about vacation should be taken as a 'yes' by the  employee instead of a threat.

It does not allow anyone to feel like there is stable operations, so it feels like there is always a moving target for achieving your goals, not metrics, as you can manipulate metrics to be met, but overall goals of making a difference. It feels like we are dealing with the same issues year in and out, and can't truly resolve issues and grow because there is constant change.

Also benefits have deteriorated over the years with more and more costs passed on to the employee.  No vacation time is earned, with a false story about the company providing "unlimited" vacation time.

summary: "GE stock is dropping for a reason"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
After 22 years with this company, I can say GE had its drawbacks like any company would have, but overall a great place to grow career and meet amazing people.  The last few years, especially after the Alstom purchase, it has been a disaster.  I hope it can turn around.

I am pleased with my compensation, but the benefits have changed drastically over the last 8 years and are negating this pro.
cons:
I do not know a single person who is happy in Schenectady working for GE.  Does HR understand an unhappy workforce leads to low productivity and impacts the stock?  The "you are lucky you have a job attitude" does not = productive workforce.  Health insurance is horrible and the last cost increase was more than my raise.  My first raise in 2.5 years because they were suspended for Senior Bands .    Pensions are at risk of being frozen for older employees and were already eliminated for new employees.  Constant threat of layoffs is draining and demoralizing. 

I was pro GE for my entire career and always loyal to this company.  I actually recruited friends to work for this company.  I am now actively looking for another job and would never recommend anyone to work for GE the way it is today.  I not only feel guilty for having friends come to GE, but now still having a job with GE, I will be competing with fellow employees who were laid off for other local jobs.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: The work is interesting. There are always challenging new problems to solve, technology to develop, and other stuff engineers live for.
cons: GE benefits are bad and getting worse.  Pension is gone.  Vacation is gone. Medical insurance is poor with high deductible and out of pocket costs.  The 60 year old plant in Salem is maintained barely well enough to keep rain off people's desks. No joke.  The company treats the site like we are all factory workers, not engineering and technical.
advice_management: You are lucky anyone agrees to work in Salem, which is in an economically depressed area. In an area with a robust economy, the place would empty out.

main_text: I worked at GE  for more than a year
pros: Amazing benefit package- everything you could want.  Unlimited coffee  and tea and hot chocolate.
cons: Crappy bonus structure, low pay and management that argues with each other and dislike each other leaving employees without the tools they need to succeed.
advice_management: Stop showing up for your paycheck and benefits and actually listen to what your employees are saying they need to do their job well.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: Great teamwork and advancement opportunities.  Work/Life balance was improving greatly.
cons: Below average salary and compensation.  Talk about retaining top talent but no actions behind it.  Very little differentiation between poor to average performers and those that go above and beyond on a regular basis.  It is recognized by your managers and 1 over 1, but all the control over your compensation is dictated by HR who has no involvement in your day to day efforts.
advice_management: Give more control to direct management to run  it like they own it.  Give employees incentive to go above and beyond.  For cost savings projects, offer the project owner a 1% return for their efforts on realized savings.  This will push more projects and you will see them done faster.

pros: Leadership encourages innovation, process improvement, and empowers employees to lead. The open office promotes collaboration and IT collaboration tools further support the ability of remote teams to stay connected. Leadership is focused on long-term solutions and supports employees to be able to do their work and achieve goals.
cons: Analysis and reporting tools are lagging behind strategic vision, but working on improvements. Not all businesses are aligned with the strategic vision and understand the value of Global Operations organization (understandably - this is a big shift in mindset and culture change).
advice_management: Continue encouraging employees to bring ideas and new ways of thinking. Take the time to understand what your team(s) do and ask the important questions about their pain points and suggestions on how to improve. Take action and live the GE Beliefs. Hold frequent touch-points with your team and share important initiatives from senior leadership, so that team members do not feel out of touch.

summary: "FROM EXCELLENT AND SUPERB TO DISGUSTING. OVER 27 YEARS WITH COMPANY."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: In the beginning,  pay was best in the country and so were benefits. 98% of the people looked for ways to help move the company forward and prosper. At least there are a few good managers still left in the company. I believe I have the best one now that I have ever had in my career. He understands that life and work should have a perfect balance. I may cause him trouble from time to time but I'm still trying to help the few guys at the bottom that most senior executives never get the real story about. They cant go up the hall to HR because HR has been trained how to respond to every issue.
cons:
Disgusting, current employee watched company go from SUPERB AND EXCELLENT  TO DISGUSTING.  Benefits and pay were excellent in the beginning but now benefits are 10 times worse tham Obama care. And my pay is less than a third of what I made 10 years ago.
98% of all the people used to try to do what they could to help move the company forward and prosper, now it's everyone for themselves except a few warriors spread out across the company still helping the little person at the bottom to understand how the company has learned to be Hollywood actors and let one think they have input and make a difference. Also, if you have any type of role that is hard to replace, don't bother trying to transfer within the company because they will block your transfer and then lie directly to your face that they didn't. But on a lighter note, once you prove they blocked your transfer with solid evidence, they will finally admit responsibility but make clear that the way they responded the first time you asked that they did not lie to you by the wording they used.
advice_management: Listen, not pretend to listen. Go out face to face and talk to your people. It may cost a little more money to do that but the bottom line will justify the money well spent. You hired great people because that's what's needed in a company to grow. Now utilize those individuals as you intended. I have worked in upper mgmt and at the bottom as a machine operator for the lowest pay, which I might add was more than I make now. I would have had more than 30 years by now and already retired but instead I'm being sold like property. Look at the company's bottom line over 30 years. Jack Welch knew exactly when to bale out because new directives and younger minds started looking for ways to cut expenses without looking at long term repercussions, because they knew that they wouldn't be there when the bottom fell out. In manufacturing, we were a training ground for college graduates. We had six month engineers every 6 months with a project costing millions and then they move on and we're stuck with junk that doesn't work anymore because they are gone and aren't still there fixing the bugs. After a couple of months and a new engineer, we usually just ripped off everything the previous engineer did and scrapped it in the warehouse in boxes. The company's bottom line over the last 30 years speaks for itself. Now the 98% of the people that used to look to try to help move the company forward or the 98% who are trying to figure out how to cut money out of the company.

summary: "High-potential people working hard for their goal; hoping others' goals are aligned.  They often aren't."
main_text: I have been working at GE  for more than 10 years
pros: Great breadth of variability in experience.  Two people with the same title and positions will rarely have the same job. New ideas of thought or process are welcomed especially if it includes the word "simplification".
cons: Long term goals are often pushed aside for short-term needs.  Continual cost cutting efforts drain morale. Messaging from executives often contradicts actions taken at local level.  Most "improvements" or benefits are either a transfer of work or cost savings initiative they hope won't be noticed by the average employee. Anyone who questions the move will be asked to "wear the bigger GE hat".
advice_management: Mean it when you say, "our employees are our best asset".
