main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: career opportunities, compensation and work-life balance
cons: I can't think of any cons
advice_management: excellent management

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: GE is a good place to work with open challenges, and a strong team.
cons: Restructuring of GE will occur every 3 years, and you will be frustrated as it goes on.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: There is a significant culture shift happening within GE in a good way- everything from talent acquisition to performance management is being looked at in new and engaging ways! The focus has shifted from being perfect every time to delivering an intended direction, gaining buy in and iterating. The GE Beliefs are also allowing more empowerment of employees and small teams and there is more opportunity for flexible work schedules.
cons: Carving a clear career path can be challenging, in terms of obtaining information on realistic possibilities as there are so many avenues in a global organization of our size. I know that the teams are working to provide employees more guidance on this area in the future.
advice_management: Keep promoting the culture shift! Outcomes over process...

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Excellent work life balance and great pay. Some of the smartest and nicest people to work with. Access to management was never a problem
cons: i certainly have no negative comments and GE.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: challenging work on CAS in GE
cons: no work life balance in GE
advice_management: improve work life balance in GE

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Empowerment in your position, was not reserved for training period. Management was hands on and motivated greater aspiration than current position. It was a team atmosphere, we fail together and we succeed together.
cons: Because they projected and encouraged great aspirations from the janitorial to the CEO, there was great tune-over in management, because of promotions in stead of pay raises. As soon you are settled into how one manager operates, another is on the way.
advice_management: Encourage depth and not just width. Pay raises instead of moving

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Good exposure but still latent unconscious bias against certain employes.  Great to have GE on the resume for other big name opportunities and if you're devoted and drink the Kool-aid it's likely that you'll ascend the ranks.
cons: Arrogant, apathetic and unimaginative culture in spite of their ad spend to make you believe otherwise with a notable exception to be made for their UX/engineering teams and/or consultants but their internal team a bunch of 'doers' where your higher up leaders force feed you ill advised or researched ideas with zero accountability for SLT, first to go during an economic squeeze are the rank and file not the SLT that makes the bad decisions (Bornstein got promoted after running GE Capital into a ditch -- he's a nice guy and all but still) while a lot of people lost their jobs, most people are miserable waiting to leave in a few years if they find the culture to be a mismatch which it usually is and are just waiting to cash out.  Salary and overall pay relatively low -- need to leave and come back for better compensation, big on talk but small on action.  HR is horrible, 'business resources' nothing human about them -- just looking to fill vacancies even if not a good fit and will lie through their teeth or threaten you in not so subtle ways but they're probably stupid enough to think its subtle.
advice_management: Be a little more humble and hire fewer lifers to get some outside ideas you can respect.  Don't send your HR team to Facebook or Google under the guise of friendship only to then come back to Fairfield HQ to crap on their apps and jargon, i.e., "ideation."  Be more tolerant, live diversity by ensuring it's reflected in your SLT and not a few outliers in the rank and file or restricted to your PR materials.  If your minorities are leaving, assuming they don't think their God's gift to the world for landing a job at a Fortune 50 as many unfortunately do, it's likely because you have a few closet case racists amongst your pack.  Genpact doesn't contribute to your US diversity!  They're foreign Indian contractors who get paid a king's ransom for horrid work!

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Small department, good co-workers, good pay and benefits along with an interesting product made this a good place to be.
cons: Sales of our product never met their expectations. Our department was closed. They have a management program for interns to be our boss for six month intervals. Some of the worst bosses I've ever had have been while working here. Management was more about their bottom line than treating employees with respect.
advice_management: Respect and value your workers. Do all you can to push your products no matter how niche the market is.

main_text: I worked at GE

cons: Does not sponsor H1b visa

summary: "Good place to work for but who knows about the future?"

advice_management: Do not fix what is not broken. There is no reason to so massively restructure a great company.

advice_management: None

main_text: I have been working at GE

cons: GE Recruiting treats their RPO vendors horribly. Good relationships  established were dissolved. This greatly effected overall morale and productivity.

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Mechanical Design Engineer
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: Flexible work arrangement, opportunity to advance
cons: Job security, constant management changes

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Nice people, everyone is friendly and welcoming. Lot's of 'Brainwashing'
cons: Lot of busy work or no work at all. Tons of downtime and very poor organization during the on boarding procedures
advice_management: Have a better plan of what interns and coops will be doing during their time with the company

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: Well respected program that is viewed as being elite in its class both internally and externally.
cons: At times some rotations really lack any substantial value add work which can detract from overall experience.
advice_management: Continue to find ways to improve program through both rotation quality assessments and working with assignment leaders to ensure they truly care about development of FMPs.

summary: "Great start to a career but not for long term growth"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
- Huge community of really smart people - if you put yourself out there, you can learn a lot and make great connections. 
- Challenging and demanding environment forces you to learn and learn quickly
cons:
- Difficult to move quickly within GE. 
- Sales culture tends to be very "old school." 
- Some lack of diversity in terms of peer experience.
advice_management: Try and understand what new hires are looking for from their career and day-to-day and alter culture and increase development opportunities accordingly.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: They do a great job at mentoring and promoting from within and the pay is above industry standard
cons: Very few leadership jobs in Michigan so you can only grow so far and then you plateau.
advice_management: Create management jobs equally at each site, not just the HDQ sites since the teams are usually spread out amongst several actual cities.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: GE has a great culture of collaboration and professionalism. It has its fair share of large corporate bureaucracy, but greater emphasis has been put on driving that out. At this point, the organization is fairly efficient given how large and geographically disparate the workforce is.
cons: I work in GE O&G, which is suffering layoffs and pay freezes due to low oil & gas prices.
advice_management: Limit "transitional" roles to 6 months, max.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: good place to work for employees
cons: nothing much to say on this

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Good technology to work on. It depends on your manager for your experience.

advice_management: Be more agile and willing to change.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Friendly, professional environment to work in.
cons: No issues to report during tenure.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Good Benefits at the time I worked there. My boss was ok to work with.
cons: I worked for GE Money for 4 years. I was accused of something I didn't do and almost got fired. On several occasions we had meaningless meetings and on one occasion I brought issues in the department but it was never addressed the room just got silent. .
advice_management: Be proactive in resolving issues when they occur don't just push them to the side. Listen before you judge a book by its cover.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Benefits are excellent, opportunities, very big company, lots of chances to move around. If you dont want to move around, harder to work for. Excellent for young ppl
cons: Mgmt, upper level constantly changing. Small # in a very large company. Expect lots of moves and job changes, anywhere in the world.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Smart, dynamic, fun co-workers and interesting material, very positive experience.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: Metrics-driven so performance evaluations feel fairer than other places.  There is an ability to move roles every couple of years.  In general, smart people.
cons: It is a huge company so it can feel bureaucratic at times.  Unless you are at the very top, salaries are lower than equivalent jobs in the marketplace.
advice_management: The company will have to continue to evolve - the current positioning of GE as a digital company is a smart one.  Hopefully, you can attract top talent with the new focus.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Good Benefits.  Empowerment for  Employees

advice_management: Take more Risks

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Great place to work at.
cons: pay low and could be better
advice_management: pay more

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: 19 years of unbelievable opportunities in four countries across two continents. A meritocracy. Great leadership role models in multiple organizations. The way diverse people collaborate and build great products and outcomes are second to none.
cons: Not too many. Sometimes certain corporate initiatives get overly political and taken to the extreme to be then overwritten by a different initiative a year or two later.
advice_management: Keep doing what you are doing  -  and solve for promotional opportunities for top talent amidst simplification as promotions to the next leadership band are becoming more scarce.

main_text: I worked at GE  for less than a year
pros: People friendly environment and dedicated to improving corporate business and image
cons: None that I can think of
advice_management: continue to retain people and move away from outsourcing

main_text: I worked at GE  for less than a year
pros: A lot of opportunity to learn.
cons: Very structured work environment. Everything must be done the "GE way"

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Great place to work- love it
cons: Some people may not like the large company atmosphere

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: A big company with lots of opportunities. I have gotten a chance to see many different places and do a variety of jobs.
cons: A lot of bureacracy at times. Not the best leaders thus far in my experience. Can be a stressful work environment. Not a millenial place to work...lots of older people.
advice_management: Reduce bureacracy. Give people more responsibility. Allow for more open dialogue and discussion. Treat employees better.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: I was at GE for over ten years - they are an amazing company.  While many still think of GE as an old company that fires the bottom ten percent, that couldn't be further from the truth.  They are progressive, thoughtful and push for new, innovative ways of thinking.  Light years ahead of other companies.
cons: Due to size, there is constant reorganization going on and shifting of talent.   In some ways this is good, but it also creates a lot of 'sacred cows' that get moved around.  It can limit those with potential from getting an opportunity to grow into bigger roles.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Benefits, Health Care, on site LPN saves trips to the doctor for small stuff, on Site Cafeteria with good food, and easy for Management to dole out free lunches or such for special projects or events.  Education, regularly bringing in experts to teach or mentor on things.  Timely industry relevant Books. Gym, on site free sport equipment to use, bikes, kayaks, camping gear, great perk.
cons: Big company bureaucracy, red tape, politics, buddy systems, egos, too many on line training courses, having to go excessively out of your way to prove your worth during the year and at review time.  At a company like GE, it is not good enough to put in a fair days work for a fair days pay which ultimately affects your personal life and quality of life.  I've come think big companies and "economy of scale" is a bad thing.  It shouldn't be such that if a global company has an issue with a division, it can put a whole town out on the street looking for work.  Better to have more companies, and smaller companies.
advice_management: As stated in the Cons, a fair days pay is worth a fair days work.  Find ways to establish that without over-driving an employee.  Quality of life is important. I've come think big companies and "economy of scale" is a bad thing.  It shouldn't be such that if a global company has an issue with a division, it can put a whole town out on the street looking for work.  Better to have more companies, and smaller companies.

job_title: Former Employee - Learning and Development Manager
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: A great place to learn and grow.  If you want to plug in and get involved there are lots of opportunities to do that.  Great training programs.  Lots of room to grow. Leaders are responsible for growing their people.
cons: It is a really big company and easy to feel like you are a really small fish.  You will need to have initiative to figure things out and jump in.  More work than time to get it done so work life balance is a challenge
advice_management: More Change Management around M&A

summary: "Rental coordinator Frac and production Pressure Control"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Safety oriented, quality, efficiency,team building, Room for advancement, Great Benefits, Training, Great management, possible relocation
cons: They pay was ok and hardly any bonuses .
advice_management: Have equal opportunity for everyone no matter what each, religion, or sex they are.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Pay is good to start
cons: hours but then again it's a good pay

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Opportunities world wide, sky is the limit if you reach for it. Compensation and time off is very good, insurance is not. Also no bonuses for lead professionals.
cons: Insurance is basically catastrophic only
advice_management: Pay attention to everyone's input, not just ladder climbers...some of us have no desire to be executives, but that doesn't mean our contributions aren't valuable. We're the ones who do the real work.  Great ideas are just that...it's the people who execute them that really make the difference.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: great company to work for. they provide great benefits, and do not micro manage employees. company also provides continuous training for employees.
cons: takes some  time for employees to climb the ladder. management also needs to give positive feedback to balance the negative. positive definitely outweighs the negative.
advice_management: give employees positive feedback. constructive criticism goes a long way. Continue to provide the great continuous training you have been providing to on the field employees.

main_text: I have been working at GE

cons: Lack of growth in engineering management

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years

advice_management: do the right things and the right things will happen

summary: "Great Place to Work.  Work life balance challenges"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: I worked in the Retail Finance division of GE for 8 years.  I had the pleasure of working with a group of smart, dedicated and fun people.  GE's main focus is it's employees, which is demonstrated through the many training and Affinity programs offered.
cons: Work life balance is quite a challenge.

main_text: I have been working at GE  for more than 8 years
pros: Good work life balance. Flexible. It all depends on your manager, but they are actively trying to be more flexible through HR practices.
cons: Depends on the manager. Used to work for someone who was not willing to adapt schedule for work life balance.
advice_management: Keep being progressive; keep investing in employees

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros:
Your pay is an important part of your employment with GE.  In addition to your competitive starting salary, the company recognize and rewards individual performance.  

GE benefits are aligned to local market practice and often include pension/retirement plans and healthcare coverage. Some locations offer subsidized services such as sports facilities, medical/dental care and car-parking, and in a number of countries, you may have the chance to participate in a Share save programs.
cons: Since GE is a Matrix company, the working environment in GE is highly taxing, for these reason GE employees have to spread their knowledge and ideas to enable them fit for the role in which they are or will be shown the way out.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Good company to work, they take care of the emoyees.  Benefits are great and cheap medical insurance.
cons: I cannot think of any cons other than the 4 weeks of training, there was a lot of waiting around time.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Lots of ability to move around
cons: Too much middle management, slow to get things done

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Great training on leadership. Encouraged learning culture
cons: Command and control and lots of red tape.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Very good company for leadership development
cons: SOme times decision making is slow

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: The checks clear the bank.  They do interesting work and have interesting products and have access to some of the best customers in the world.  Mostly it's good people trying to get by in a total F up company.
cons: It's corporate madness.   They constantly play games with not just employees but customers alike.   It's hard to believe that Edison's company has turned into such an evil corporation.  They are constantly changing up things, doing this and that and never really focusing on providing a core product or service.  Always gaming the system instead of just doing good work.   You would swear these people in management would trip over a dollar to pick up dime.  It is just that perverse.  They pay well but then you are expected to work 45 to 55 hours per week.  You are considered a slacker with hose ours.  Some are know to work 80 to 120 hours a week.   Some people live at that place.   In most cased you are doing the job of one and 1/2 people at least.
advice_management: Shoot yourself in the head and do the world a favor.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Challenging work, global exposure across IT
cons: growth is little slow as compared with other IT shops
advice_management: Career growth

main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros:
Lot of Ivy Leaguers to learn from
Great resume builder
Rotate jobs every 18 to 24 months
Learn in multiple departments
cons:
Low pay
Six Sigma for every project
Competitive even when not necessary
Political
For some reason could not wait to get out
advice_management: None really.  Had a good time.  Learned a lot. Made double the money when I got out. Great company to work for.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Good employee benefits, good values and a very good brand to have in your CV.
cons: Too many red tapes & too much lips service at times.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: GE flexibility is perfect , awesome work life balance.
cons: Work late hours sometimes globally.

summary: "Highly political if you are in HR- its only about who you know or who likes you, not how well you do your job."
main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: Pay, benefits are unreal- amazing!
cons: HR Management has been there YEARS and need to be out! Mgmt doesn't care how well you do, only how you can impress them personally. If you aren't in the 'good old girls club' you will be swiftly kicked out.
advice_management: Turn over those in payroll and HR who have been there 10+ years- they aren't excellent at what they do...only who they know. Stop being political and preferential. If your 'friend' or Daddy works there- you'll have a job forever, however badly you do your job.

main_text: I worked at GE  for more than a year
pros: Great company.  Great benefits.
cons: I cannot think of any cons.
advice_management: Continue to treat frontline employees with respect and gratitude.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: good place to start a career
cons: raises are not good, promotions are hard to come by

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Good pay, benefits are just right, upper management is helpful and listens to concerns
cons: Problems that do arise take forever to get fixed, there is carelessness in quality of work, there is no discipline handed down to people that do not do their job right

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
Great leadership experience
Lots of responsibility.
Ability to move from role to role and continue to grow.  
Company culture focused on meritocracy
Work with other very talented people.
cons:
Expect that could make more at different company.  
Once you reach certain level, can be hard to take the next step.  
Sometimes too much focus on cost out.
advice_management: I hear over and over again when people leave that the management was blindsided by it.  Senior leaders say that they blame the bosses when a talented person leaves, but it's usually a too little, too late situation.  Management needs to make sure that they reward high performing employees with additional responsibility and opportunity.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Very hands-on work, good team environment, great city to be in
cons: Co-op responsibilities didn't always seem valuable
advice_management: Increase co-op responsibility

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: Great work environment. Great benefits.
cons: 2 tier wage structure. No pension offered for the newer employees on the new pay scale.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Great people, data driven decision making
cons: Company is in a constant state of change.   Also it seems like we have too many executives with unclear value add while the actual teams doing the work are consistently starved for resources.
advice_management: Reduce the number of "professional executive band" workers.   Keep the executives that truly add value by helping their teams be successful and inspire commitment.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: Good pay and overtime available.
cons: good ole boy atmosphere, you can't get ahead unless you are part of clique

main_text: I have been working at GE  for less than a year
pros: Great HR tools and good consistency of process
cons: Brutal when it come to integrating acquired employees. Some get to keep their jobs, some have to reapply to their jb, some get assigned to a new HR role. No rhyme or reason to the decisions.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: People are awesome, great technical teams
cons: Insurance, benefits, min raises, no bonus, medical
advice_management: Reward and retain

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Great company to work for!
cons: Nothing that I can think of
advice_management: none

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Solid company with hard working people.  Six sigma is a big part of their corporate culture.  Everyone needs to be onboard with the methodology.
cons: They sold GE insurance to Swiss re.  They sometimes struggled running an insurance company with their demands for predictable consistent earnings
advice_management: since selling the insurance segment to Swiss re, this segment has thrived and has delivered considerable value to Swiss re.  Other GE businesses continue to grow and develop.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: New permissive time off.  Great culture and collaboration.
cons: Limited openings at certain locations.  Expected to move to advance career.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Great company to work, benefits and working environment. Fairly typical interview process, after passing a phone screening, it's a 3 on 1 panel interview.
cons: This is not the place for people who don't want to give 100% to the job. Internal competitiveness is strong.
advice_management: Keep paying and promoting for performance. That is the way to attract and keep the best people.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: Really great company, good pay and benefits. The management team were all very good at what they do. Great hour.
cons: Company was a little picky on watching your time. Did not always have enough work to fill my day, so did not know how to log time properly.
advice_management: Trust the employees you hire to come in and do the work.

summary: "Great for entry level profesionals and new hires"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Great for new employees. GE likes to invest in new talent, new college grads, new people career development training programs external training opportunities
cons:
- Mid career professionals struggle within the company (very limited investment and training)
- HR offers no value to help employees grow their career
- GE has no place for individual contributors only leaders and project managers thrive
- GE seldom promotes in current job titles it is instead encourage to switch jobs
-  Many of the retirements a forced by emails sent to retiree distibution list 
-  If you're over 40 forget about a leadership opportunities coming your way
advice_management: Jeffrey wake up! You're losing all the talent of the knowledge workers. Project managers alone cannot run a business  Develop the individual contributors so they are learning and developing their skills so they don't become obsolete. Predix is a piece of crap.

main_text: I worked at GE

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Large Corporation.  Stable position.  Room for growth.  Embrace latest manufacturing techniques.  Emphasize training and investing in their employees.  Manufacturing Floor workforce are seasoned and have been there for a minimum of 10 years each.
cons: Large Corporation.  Large amount of politics and management trying to keep their heads above water.  Disconnect with upper management and shop floor staff.  Management is rotated through every 2 years, so they keep their department above water for the time being and dump a new manager in there who typically sinks. No feedback taken seriously by management if you have under a Bachelors degree.
advice_management: Listen to your shop floor employees, even thorugh they may seem uneducated by management standards, they provide more insight though real feedback.  Listen to them.  Management have their head in  a hole and brainwashed by metrics, green belt and black belt six sigma processes; which at times can become counter productive depending on the task.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years

- great emphasis on building leadership skills
- invests in their employees
- fast paced environment
- always trying to be ahead of its competitors
- good reputation
- overall good work environment to work in
- work life balance is great
- always learning
cons:
- very very minimal salary increases each year (if any)
- no bonuses or extra compensation for a certain career band and below
- small salary increase for promotions to the next role
- many people jump outside the company to get the salary bump they are looking for, then eventually come back to the company
advice_management: Be open with employees wanting to switch to other businesses.

summary: "A circus of technical manufacturing. GE-LYNN LMO"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros:
Straight overtime for salary folk on the production floor. 
Never will be bored. 
Plenty of learning opportunities to show how not to organize or manage a production environment.
cons:
Long days (12+ hrs) plus weekends will be spent In the shop.  You will not see the sun in winter.
Management effectiveness is measured in decibels.
No hint of an opportunity to grow or diversify. 
You are measured on several metrics that are directly contradictory,  ensuring you will fail in some way everytime.
Upon failure, you will be publicly ridiculed on your appearance, personality, gender, and maybe (in part) about the actual failure to perform to above metrics. No instruction or coaching or advice in how to improve.
advice_management: People with college educations won't stay in an office  environment from the 1980s. Modernize the middle management methods to reduce your turn over.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: This company had an incredibly robust compliance program. It makes employees very comfortable to work in an ethical environment. Also very big on community service and volunteerism. You don't hear much about these two attributes but really make GE a nice place to work. Sure there is hard work and even some office politics ( although not as much as I have seen in other companies) but working in an ethical place that values employee involvement to help others is really a nice environment.
cons: This is not the place for people who don't want to give 100% to the job. Internal competitiveness is strong. You can't hide or coast.
advice_management: Keep paying and promoting for performance. That is the way to attract and keep the best people.

job_title: Current Employee - Lean Six Sigma Master Black Belt
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Well run company with upward and lateral mobility opportunities.
Strong intrernal training program to develop future leadership
Employees have opportunity to get full wing-to-wing business process exposure, if so inclined
Business leaders are objectively measured against clear KPI's and are held accountable
Internal communication of business strategy is shared consistently throughout the organization, from the top down
Internal projects are approved based on ROI and have a rigorous toll gate process
Those of us hired before 2011, are entitled to a decent pension upon retirement
Company invests heavily in initiatives they see as providing a competitive advantage
cons:
Most often the share holder takes precedent over the paying customer and the employees
When cost out promises are made to share holders, execution of headcount reduction is driven hard and is often nepotonistic 
Compensation lags behind industry averages, especially given the magnitude of the portfolios that leaders are expected to manage
Benefits have been slowly chipped away, as long term cost liabilities have come more into focus
Pensions stopped being offered as part of the benefits package, to new hires, back in 2010- 2011 timeframe
New Aetna healthcare plan saved GE -$2B+ but put much more of the  burden on the employee
Pensioners, which really does not effect new hires, had their GE group healthcare benefit eliminated
advice_management: As headcout reduction pressures become more commonplace, your frontline leaders will tend to protect their friend and not necessarily your top talent. Those who are inclined to do so and are marketable on the outside, will find more secure employment on the outside.

main_text: I worked at GE

advice_management: Pay more attention to the growth of new employees, and benchmark salary with the outside market. Have fewer re-orgs.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: The talent at GE is second to none.  This keep you at the top of your game.  The benefits are good compared to other companies of their size, but their pay does not translate... be ready to negotiate!
cons: The rush to market can be a double edge sword.  Sacrificing quality for reputation is always a bad move.  Also, it pays to hire staff with a diverse set of insights as opposed to hiring from the same talent pool where ideas have already stagnated.
advice_management: Management needs to be directly involved with the fires they are putting out.  Rather than meet the whole day, perhaps interview those directly involved or affected and engage in the battle.

advice_management: We have a lot of very talented individuals coming into the organization, but they are individuals not team builders.   I think we could get where we want to be faster if more of them were team builders rather than team managers.

summary: "Great pay for the area, management OK"
main_text: I worked at GE  for more than 5 years
pros:
Good pay (has since been reduced for new hires), great benefits. Unionized, so there's more employee protection. 
Frequent overtime opportunities for hourly workers.
cons:
Tone of the workplace depends on both the manager of the area, and the coworkers. Some areas have lots of drama, some don't. 
There's a strong Hourly vs. Salary mindset.
Management from different departments have in the past created rules for the workplace that impact morale negatively.
advice_management: Get more employee input about the details of a work area and job before inputting changes, to make sure they're useful and don't make aspects of the work more difficult.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Great people.  Everyone is really bright and trying to do the right thing.  New innovations are always discussed and worked on.  Great work space!
cons: Big company blues:  The right hand doesn't know what the left hand is doing.  Too much bureaucracy and lack of quick decision making.
advice_management: Pick an idea that you want implemented.  Pick the team.  Fund the team.  Trust the team to execute (i.e. don't micromanage them and have them beg for money every 6 months nor make them do exhaustive reporting.)

main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: Great trust  and flexibility in allowing the Area Sales Manager own and manage their market.  The years of developed experience is shared through strong support of one another.  Manager's goals are closely aligned with those of the employees.
cons: Just as in any other sales organization, you are to be moving in multiple directions at once while many times feeling like one hand is tied behind your back.  The cons may lie more within the appliance industry which is facing intense foreign brand competition, ever increasing prices of raw materials and quality across all brands which do not live up to the standards from 20 years ago.  National Accounts in this industry are nothing short of bullies and the kid gloves they are handles with end up being a hit to your bottom line.
advice_management: Continue to support the field and do not roll out blanket initiatives that are known to do well in one market but be a flop in another.

advice_management: Consider not taking advantage of the intern status. Just because you compensate them well doesn't mean you should kill them with the amount of work pressure them with.

summary: "Fast paced and interesting work but old-school, old-boy, clique management style"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Never sedentary/always busy, ample opportunities for top performers, endless variety of work, many competent co-workers, fairly stable, regimented, well-defined processes, interesting possibilities
cons: Old-school management rife with mean-spirited and loud-mouthed alpha-male managers, poor benefits, marginal pay, meager pay increases, poor work/life balance, cut-throat competitive atmosphere, ruthless downsizing and relocation when business units change focus, inability to listen to suggestions/improvements, upper management viewed poorly by all below them, secretive management cliques, promotions decided in back-room deals, "worker bees" get poor explanation of confusing directives, promotion of "spin doctors" with poor results over those with stronger skills/performances, brown nosing encouraged and key to getting ahead, shameless self-promotion required for recognition, hard-working veteran employees forced into retirement after many years of 60+ hours weeks and company dedication
advice_management:
Modernize your management approach: When managers get promoted by being mean, loud and ruthless, the underlings perpetuate that same message - because it seems to get results. 
Acknowledge/appreciate your employees: Just because you get treated poorly by your manager, doesn't mean you have to pass that along to everyone beneath you.  Most people just want a "thanks" or "nice job" for all their hard work but that seems to be a rarity these days. 
Improve work/life balance: I've seen too many solid 30+ year employees forced into retirement because it was financially beneficial to the company. Every manager I know works around 60-80 hours per week and their home life suffers. Treat your loyal employees like humans, not cattle.
Maintain reasonable benefits: Significantly cutting healthcare benefits, meager pay raises, salary freezes, marginal salary compensation are not helping retain or attract employees. GE's benefits used to be what differentiated the company from others and made those excessively-long work weeks tolerable.  Now turnover is fairly high and the Edison graduates sprint for the door once their training is complete, knowing that they will have far greater opportunities, pay and benefits once they leave.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: This company had an incredibly robust compliance program. It makes employees very comfortable to work in an ethical environment. Also very big on community service and volunteerism. You don't hear much about these two attributes but really make GE a nice place to work. Sure there is hard work and even some office politics ( although not as much as I have seen in other companies) but working in an ethical place that values employee involvement to help others is really a nice environment.
cons: This is not the place for people who don't want to give 100% to the job. Internal competitiveness is strong. You can't hide or coast.
advice_management: Keep paying and promoting for performance. That is the way to attract and keep the best people.

main_text: I worked at GE  for more than 5 years
pros: Great place for executive management to learn and grow professionally.  Lots of changes that enable  leaders to stay sharp. Terrific company with deep expertise and technical acumen. And business leaders 4-levels deep think and operate like general managers, which makes GE a great place for leadership development.
cons: Too many changes can distract from long term goals. Lots of internal politics can sometimes lead to a culture of one-upmanship and backstabbing. Sometimes see people getting promoted purely on who they know, however HR is very strong in the company and tries to make things better.
advice_management: Listen to your lower level employees. Give them sufficient freedom to act. Limit the level of politicization at work.

advice_management: Stick to an idea longer than a year. Just as a new idea or business approach was ramping up they would think they needed to change it because they didn't get the results they wanted immediately. They were too impatient. Stop changing territories and product lines so frequently. It confuses not only the rep but the distributors and customers.

summary: "Like Grandpa Trying to "Be Hip" and Roll With The Tech Companies"
main_text: I worked at GE
pros:
- Flexibility to work remotely
- Many events with free food
- Can wear jeans to work
cons:
- Pay is at or marginally below market rate for positions
- At the mercy of "leaders" who want things done yesterday
- Very political organization
- Lack of work-life balance
- Archaic ways of doing things that are justified as being "just how things are done"
advice_management: The direction GE is moving towards of being like a "start-up" company with collaboration and lean only works in a culture that isn't laden with politics and bureaucracy. Just because you minimize the amount of levels between an executive and entry-level positions doesn't mean you're any closer to emulating a digital company in Silicon Valley. Your employees need to feel like they are working towards something meaningful and not like they are working to avoid losing their jobs or from being reamed out by their supervisor. If you're going to attract young talent in your effort to become a digital industrial company, you're going to need to do more. Millennials value work-life balance, crave opportunities to be innovative, and want to be on a "fun" campus. Let some of them take the driver's seat instead of letting the "traditional" GE leaders continue to steer the company.

summary: "Great Company but lack of Vision & a good strategy at top level"

Top management should pre-empt trends and plan for future instead of eternal corrections.
Current CEO lacks the leadership skills to portend future and plan for it. 
All actions in last decade are reactive responses rather than skillful strategies.

summary: "Too big now, individual feels like a number"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Quality of employees, GE reputation
cons: Arrogant, overpriced in a competitive market, takes employees for granted, hard work goes unappreciated and unrecognized
advice_management: Employees aren't numbers and won't stay forever if leadership doesn't change how they treat those that are getting it done. Competitors will get strengthened by those who leave.

main_text: I worked at GE  for more than 10 years
pros: Good benefits,salary,  overall a good place to work as long as you are not in management and don't care about job security.
cons: First level managers were good to excellent.   Next level up were generally useless.  That level of management usually were hired from outside GE or from another division and had little or no market or product knowledge and were strickly spreadsheet jockies.  One more level up and the arrogance was extreme.   I had four very good managers over 10 years that were very long time GE employees.  They all only lasted a few months to a few years in that position before leaving GE entirely.  None would say so but we all knew they left because of the people they reported to.  They were constantly reorganizing, shutting down divisions, moving functions from one locations to another, and moving mfg out of the country.
advice_management: Hire managers that know the products and markets they are managing instead of spreadsheet jockies that don't give a damn about the people they manage.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: Great exposure to high-visibility, strategic deals.  Developed a diverse commercial skill set through writing and negotiating contracts and proposals for deals ranging from $1-$250M.
cons: I spent 2 years completing the GE Commercial Leadership Program, which in retrospect could have been condensed into 1 year.  The rotations were hit or miss so very important to find a mentor in the business when you first arrive.
advice_management: Need to refocus on the qualities that made GE a competitive, engaging place to work.  The stated values of the company do not align with the culture.  I do not feel that working at GE is a true "meritocracy".

summary: "Enjoyed job only marginally better than living under an overpass"
main_text: I worked at GE  for more than a year
pros: Leading a very diverse group of people at site level.  Good location to sustain the downturn in the market.
cons: So many to mention.  Corporate politics, lack of executive leadership, too many corporate folks focusing on future internal career opportunities and not focusing on current job tasks.  Industry culture and customer focus are secondary to assimilating into GE culture.  Terrible business direction.  At times incredibly conservative, then one moment, completely unrealistic business expectations particularly in times with volatile futures prices.
advice_management: Learn how to lead.  I thought that was a pillar of GE lost in the oil and gas pet project.  Communicate business goals and accept feedback thus creating a collaborative atmosphere.

main_text: I have been working at GE  for more than 10 years
pros: Most of the 'pros' no longer apply. New hires don't get any pension which was probably the best benefit this company used to offer.
cons: GE is too focused on Career/Professional Development that has very little to do with the actual job functions of most field technicians. Immediate supervisors have minimal knowledge of job requirements. The HR department at GE is totally non-responsive! Phone messages are ignored.  E-mail is never acknowledged. This was once a great company, but not anymore! Take your skills elsewhere!
advice_management: Listen to your people! Respond to their inquiries. Learn a bit about what they actually do.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: FMP (Corporate) - Great leadership development program. GE has a particularly strong finance department with a top-notch focus on training/development for FMPs. Excellent networking opportunities. Great managers. Top performers are treated well and given preference when considering future job assignments, special projects and perks.
cons: Corporate culture is all about drinking the GE koolaid. Whenever the powers that be come up with a new initiative/buzzword, for instance the finance department pushed "simplification", the results are usually just lip service. The irony in spending countless hours on draft after draft after draft of beautifully formatted powerpoint pitches explaining the benefits of "simplification" seems to be lost on management.
advice_management: Mid-level management is great, GE really does have an eye for talent and promotes internal folks accordingly. My advice would be that GE is not the end all be all, acknowledging as much would help in fostering a more open-minded culture that could foster more "innovation" than just writing the word thousands of time in GE-approved templated powerpoints.

main_text: I have been working at GE  for more than a year

summary: ""I'm really happy sitting in a cubicle all day" said No one ever"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Benefits are ok, pay is great (at least at Corporate HQ where I work)  I get 4 weeks vacation per year, 50% 401k match up to 8% of salary, health insurance is mediocre at best, however I am one of the lucky ones and I was grandfathered into the defined benefit pension plan.  

Pay is typically above market..I will even dare to say that most people I work with are grossly overpaid.  Most jobs here are low stress in the sense that you can royally screw up and suffer absolutely zero consequences whatsoever.  Almost impossible to get fired from this place.  There is a guy here that regularly takes naps, watches movies at his desk, takes 2 hour lunchbreaks and he got promoted and now makes $130k per year.

There really is a lot of opportunity here, but like many other places networking is key!

Sometimes when I tell people I work at GE they automatically think I'm smart.
cons:
Working here feels like Groundhog day (the Bill Murray movie)..not necessarily a bad thing, just not good either.  Each day is the same as the last.  A very mediocre existence.  

Now I'm no doctor, but sitting in a cubicle 10+ hours a day probably isn't good for your physical health or mental well being..but this problem is not exclusive to GE.  Working here results in such a dormant lifestyle--my physical movement on the job is limited to walking to the mens room to drain the snake.  This lack of physical mobility explains why some of my coworkers are the approximate size of a water-buffalo.

What is with people taking themselves so seriously here?  I work at Corporate HQ and everyone seems so pissed off all the time!  This guy sitting next to me thinks he is the cats pajamas.
advice_management:
I have ridden the elevator up with Jeff Immelt several times.  He doesn't look so good lately...I would feel bad for him if he didn't make 400 times my salary.

Who am I to give advice?  But if you insist here it is:

Sleep more, take more walks, eat healthier, laugh more, be grateful, do good things and expect nothing in return

summary: "Cheap and greedy organization towards long term loyal employees"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Good company with good people, and interesting products that challenge myself.
cons: Cheap, and treat their long-term loyal employees like peasants. Management generates zero revenue, only looks at revenue metrics and their own gain, gets paid more and revenue generators (Real workers, somebody's gotta do the work) get pushed like modern day slaves to make ends meat. Don't expect a family with the salaries they pay unless you want to live poor.
advice_management: Spread the wealth to the people who have to do all REAL work for your salaries, and not the ones who do management's work (Again, management's work generates zero dollars).  Defend our existence and actually do some real management of your staff to get them a livable compensation.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great paid time off work. 6 weeks time off for having a child. Solid 401K with 50% company match, and vested after 3 years. Good base pay.
cons: Some positions are extremely stressful. Bad work/life balance. Extremely production driven culture, than is afraid to discipline employees that cheat the system or do not perform their job. Extremely slow decision making and ability to make positive change.
advice_management: Show employees more respect and appreciation. Hire more salaried employees. The increase in headcount salary will be far less than the amount of money saved, and it will decrease turnover rate of burned out employees.

summary: "Hard-edge culture that they are trying to fix"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: It's a big company, so there are many different types of roles you can do at GE. It's in a number of different industrial businesses, so that provides variety. It's also global, so there are opportunities to work with people around the world and learn from them.
cons: The culture is very cut-throat. GE is trying to be more of a "we" culture, but many of the senior leaders got to where they are during a period when "looking-out-for-me" was how you did it, so it's a battle. I had peers (including Senior Executives and VPs) who stole my ideas, slides, etc. and used them as if they were their own. This was called "getting your lunch money stolen," so they even had a term for the phenomena. The culture is also insular: training (including company sponsored MBA programs) is done at GE-only facilities; I did attend one training session where outside businesses were discussed, but mostly the topics were GE-centered, so there was a limited opportunity to learn how others do it; best practice sharing was across GE...very little with others; non-GE-run training was discouraged. Also, the downside of being big is that it can take a lot of time to get things done, although they have worked pretty hard to move decisionmaking down closer to the customer.
advice_management: Keep focusing on making GE a "we" company, not a "me" company. Perhaps after a generation of "we" you'll be where you want to be.

summary: "Excellent Company (but so large it's difficult to manage)"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Excellent company with a literal ton of opportunities to move into different roles in the company.  Lots of opportunities for cross training and networking with different businesses.  Salaries and benefits are competitive to comparable businesses.  One the forefront of the Industrial Internet.
cons: Company is very large and there is a lot of internal knowledge that one must learn before becoming effective at one's job.  The new hire training is abysmal and nearly non-existent.  All training is done by the new hire asking questions and learning by failing.  It makes for a very stressful first year.
advice_management: Hire a team responsible for redesigning the training program.  Diligently push the business into the Information Technology sector.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: GE is a very innovative company that focuses heavily on talent growth within. I have received many job offers outside the company with just having GE listed on my resume. Although I don't plan on leaving anytime soon.
cons:
the atmosphere and culture is very performance based so you have to be laser focused on completing these goals. With that the culture is come and go as long as your manager agrees. This could cause issues with employees who lack initiative.

The compensation isn't the greatest when compared to other tech companies, but it provides my family with a comfortable life.
advice_management: Continue to focus on talent growth within the organization including your own. Continue to take a head-in and hands-off approach and lean on your teams to achieve their commitments.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Job security. Takes risks on younger talent. No real nitpicking about travel and expenses. Freedom to make things happen and execute without much, if any higher approval.
cons: No real motivation to finish projects early or under budget. If you finish early you don't get extra time home, you just get on the next one faster. Going above and beyond or finishing early/under budget does not favor any kind of bonus, as there are no bonuses. Vacation time is extremely hard to use.
advice_management: Clear map of career path. Not everything "has to be done on X timeline", you can always push things a week or two.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year

cons: Can be high pressure at times. If you are not assertive the job can be more challenging. You must be type A to succeed. Not for everyone.
advice_management: Keep up the competitive culture, it weeds out the weaklings and promotes a start-up mentality.

main_text: I have been working at GE

advice_management: Hire from within for senior management. Invest in your people what they invest in GE.

advice_management: nothing to say here. meeting 20 word min. etcetcetcetc etc etc etc etcetc etc

main_text: I have been working at GE  for more than 10 years
pros: Very large and diversified company, it cares about continuous people development.
cons: Businesses operate independently and are not taking advantage of the synergies
advice_management: Try to find ways to approach the Market as an integrated company

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Good pay and benefits. Good people and working environment
cons: Constant layoffs and outsourcing of our workload
advice_management: Better personnel management to prevent such layoffs

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Long term stability, respectful company culture, management is open and patient. A lot of very kind people. Work environment is friendly. Introducing a lot of startup type perks (free juices, ping-pong table, choose your own laptop)
cons: If you are an IT person, it's a bit behind in tech (but is earnestly working on catching up). Many projects still use very old tools. You will learn patience here.
advice_management: Keep T&L budgets high. It's one of GE's best motivators.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Good place to cut your teeth on work experience when you are young but leave before you get too old.
cons: When an employee reaches 60 or older then GE wants to kick you out. No matter what your contribution is to the company.
advice_management: Value older workers as much as trying to hire new college grads.

summary: "Great company to have on your resume"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: High performance expected. This was my first job after graduating from college. The level of professionalism and performance expected from management creates a high level of production from employees.
cons: The bottom 10% rating system is not totally fair in a small group. When its time to downsize, the least effective performer, who could possibly by the last hired, could lose their job,
advice_management: Well trained managers can add significant value to young professionals if they are properly trained on how to lead. Not all management have the social skills to be able to successfully lead a non-technical group.

main_text: I worked at GE  for more than a year
pros: Great benefits and great work atmosphere
cons: In some areas lack of career advancement if you're a really hard worker.move you from station to station if you've earned it its a long waiting game

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: The company had reasonably  generous benefits including vision and dental insurance coverage,  3 week sick days, personal days plus vacation. Management got even more personal days per year.
cons: the rate at which vacation time is earned is a bit stingy when compared to other companies and also unused time could not be "banked" for the following year.
advice_management: make the rate that vacation time is earned more in line with everyone else (more competitive).

job_title: Current Employee - Director Commercial Software & Customer Success
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Strong Leadership and growth Opportunities accompanied by above industry benefits and salary. GE is investing heavily in the  digital business and the incredible talent at GE can create a new age of useful, relevant, and actionable data.
cons: There are really no cons at working at GE with the exception of perhaps a struggle to find work/life balance. That however is mostly self inflicted.
advice_management: The best advice I'd have for management is to be aware of internal power struggles that sometimes occur over growth areas in the company. This can lead to poor cross functional collaboration and can quickly become an issue.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Good Working Environment, full time engineer are really helpful
cons: Not really good place to horn your skills

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Meaningful work; good work life balance; great training opportunities; excellent compensation
cons: General Electric Capital is shrinking

main_text: I worked at GE  for less than a year
pros: Reputation of the company is a big asset
cons: None to mention. Its all good
advice_management: None

main_text: I worked at GE  for more than a year
pros: Good Company in the right direction for growth.
cons: Nothing negative to say. GE is a global company.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: Able to grow and lead, changing roles is easy and the pay isn't bad in comparison to industry/location
cons: No advocacy for career - you have to manage it 100% or be lost in the numbers.  Can feel like a cig in the machine if you let it.
advice_management: More active roles in all levels of organization.  Don't rely solely on voice of your directs - go deep, see the actual vs the simplified version.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: GE provides significant benefits.
cons: I do not have any at this time.

main_text: I worked at GE  for more than 3 years
pros: Overtime was great until it all ended.
cons: the management did not get to know the strengths and weakness of  employees.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: The pay. Higher than industry standard, due in part to union contract, NOT because of GE'S generosity!
cons: Climate of "Screw the customer ". Overall management believes in managing by negative reinforcement. Management declines to accept reality and punishes based on fictitious numbers and unattainable goals. Hostile work environment
advice_management: Listen to your employees!!

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Good benefits, great global support system, good opportunities for career growth and training. Working in cross functional teams helps create exposure to other groups and people.
cons: Can be difficult to access some information; People aren't always willing to help. So many workflows and processes can actually inhibit productivity, albeit necessary for tracking.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Pay was always on time, but as a buy out from a poor performing company, there were high hopes changes would again put the company in a competitive mode in the industry.
cons: As a stock market driven company no effort was put into making effective changes that would supply a competitive product against a privately owned customer orientated company that commands 60%+ market share.
advice_management: Take a look at your competition and how well they win jobs and treat customers vs the MBA training you had.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: At @ GE Corporate, you get to work closely with executives, which is great experience as an intern. There are not many junior or middle-management level employees so you get a lot of experience.
cons: Office environment is a bit dull and there is not a lot of engagement.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Friendly people, business casual, learned a lot.
cons: Paid for 40 hours, expected to work 48 hours.  Contractors are treated as second class citizens.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Learn Tons. Take lots of assignment.  You can constantly be busy. Pays well.
cons: Must always be on.  Limited social life.
advice_management: Realize when you're working your employees to death.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: GE is a huge company with a wide range of meaningful opportunity.  Transportation, Power, Medical, and Software.   There is something for everyone.  GE invests in employees for training and development.
cons: GE is a huge company.  It is very easy to get lost in the number of employees.  The ceiling of responsibility can be reached very quickly. Due to the sheer numbers of employees, management opportunity runs thin.  You can be great at what you do, but never progress if your aspirations are focused on an industry or location.
advice_management: Management needs to find meaningful opportunity for the 20-30 year experienced employees that leverages their domain experiences.  Salary compression from new inexperienced employees in the same class as more experienced employees opens the exit door for experience to walk out the door.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Great company to grow your career provided you can get in
cons: Hard to navigate within the organization due to its size.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Research team I was with was very well staffed and had expertise. My mentor was accessible, made a great learning experience.
cons: Slow process. Some teams get very poor quality of work, even though it is the research division. HR is not very responsive.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Lots of opportunity, great benefits.
cons: Salary is slightly behind the market

main_text: I have been working at GE  for more than 3 years
pros: Strong company with solid leadership
cons: Very large company with cultures varying greatly in between businesses.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: Job security, big business experience, flexible work-life balance
cons: Hard to get ahead, lack of upward mobility is frustrating. Difference in rewards for hard work is not significantly different than people who coast

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Good benefits, many opportunities to grow and change location if you want.
cons: Like any big company, it suffers from a weighty bureaucracy.  You need to keep the right mindset to be happy in that environment.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Working with a great group of people, the amount I have learned while working directly with the older and experienced folks is invaluable.
cons: Typical politics and bureaucracy of a corporate company. I wish it was centered more around innovation but it seems like the commercials on TV are the only things that truly encourage the imagination. Upper management doesn't seem to care much about career development either. Trainings can only take you so far...

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Stable company that invests in R&D. Great benefits and working conditions
cons: Multiple management changes and reorganizations. Still very cumbersome business practices.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Great place to work and got along great with co-workers
cons: Town location isn't the most exciting place to live

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
Friendly family oriented environment
Meaningful Work 
Overview of the industry and business
cons:
The company has been changing to focus more on their industrial businesses
A lot of change and uncertainty

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: For the lighting group, decent group of account managers in the field.  Probably going to lose most of them because upper management does not have sales experience. Decent benefits but not as good as what you would expect from GE.
cons:
Newly hired sales team is < 10% for 2015 - Impossible task.  
No experienced leadership in the sales organization. Account managers are promised a lot and very little is delivered so you are stuck between two unreasonable groups.
Just flat out can't trust the management. 
Very little sales support. Takes a long time to get quotes to customers. Product line is sparse compared to competition.
advice_management:
Tell the truth in interviews.  Not hiring for Strategic Accounts but standard accounts.  Not every organization is a strategic account. 
Your team is about to have a lot of turnover. Don't set the team up for failure and you will have a better turnover rate.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Very nice place to work at.
cons: it is not easy to change and move between positions.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: GE provides good benefits. Employees can grow up by exploring different opportunities within GE
cons: Salaries are low. Some lazy employees take the advantage of GE flexibility and do not finish tasks on time. Managers do not take action toward these employees.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: Fun to work with, challenging, always finding out creative ways to solve problems, teamwork is very valuable, lots of traveling which made it fun for me.
cons: Lots of hours into specific projects, especially when there were startups in operating lines with deadlines. Worked for sixty days on a row on some occasions.

main_text: I have been working at GE  for less than a year
pros: good people to work with
cons: none great place no doubt
advice_management: none

main_text: I have been working at GE

main_text: I have been working at GE  for more than a year

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years

cons: Can be long hours, union can sometimes be a headache, GE is trying to sell of their appliance business so job security os somewhat a concenr

main_text: I have been working at GE

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time

advice_management: Shift focus from making the quarter to long term innovation, require anonymous 360 reviews of all leaders with integration into performance review process.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Great benefits, incredible amount of personal development. If you're in engineering, you're doing cutting edge stuff

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Overall I really enjoyed working at GE it was a solid job in a great company.  The financial backing for projects was un-measurable.  It was  like no where I had ever worked before.
cons: At times I found the focus to be a little lacking,  when a company has so much money to throw at a projects is seems the do so until something sticks.   There was also a very high competitiveness to become a life long 'company man' and work your way up the management chain.  Rather than striving towards innovation, this seemed to be the main concern of a lot of people there.
advice_management: Put more of the focus on innovation and less on trying to climb the ladder to the next rung.

summary: "Great company but needs more long term planning"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Flexibility and respected culture. It is great to have an established brand to rely on during the ups and downs of the economy.
cons: Focus seems to be very quarter and yearly driven, rather than focusing on long term success
advice_management: Manage the business like you would manage your own.  Sacrifice short term wins for long term success. GE has the clout and money to handle long term investments in people and products.

summary: "Great place to work - very fulfilling career"

main_text: I worked at GE

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: GE has many business divisions. The FMP program has a long history. The training and assignment of this program are really challenging and useful.
cons: The company is too big, so it takes a long time to learn every part of different divisions.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: You can make your career as you want it to be at GE.  New graduates are having better chances to become leaders faster than hired professionals.  New grad network at GE is solid and very helpful!
cons: Nothing I can say is bad about working here.  People are focus on being politically correct all the time, try to be nice to anyone, and try to be helpful to anyone, and I see these across the team I work with.  Sure there are tough and stubborn personalities who occasionally will use their positions to get what they want, but that happens every where, right?

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Good Company, Good compensation, great talent
cons: Little resistant to change and fresh ideas

main_text: I have been working at GE  for less than a year
pros: Great people. Culture change in the right direction
cons: Can be slow to adapt. painful cultural transformation to get rid of old bureaucratic behavior
advice_management: Promote the right people.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
- You do the work and company manages your career progression
- can work with multiple business without changing the company
- Provides exposure to various functional skill set early in the career
- Has great leadership programs at all level ( entry, mid level management etc)
- 60-80% people do not leave GE or come back. A great % of employee base has 10 , 20+ years with the company\
- It has a great culture ( integrity, people, extracurricular activities etc). GE almost has its on language. Both internal employees and customers can relate to the culture.
cons:
- Initial year in the company is difficult as its a huge company and finding your feet takes time. Everyone around you helps but just give your time.
- Pay scales may be low up front as GE gives you a brand name - but it catches up as you grow within GE
advice_management:
- Change is inevitable - make it simple for low level employees
- Please continue to keep GE as a powerhouse of mentoring great leaders from tech to finance.

main_text: I worked at GE  for less than a year
pros: Obviously a huge company, so if you don't like your team you can switch to another department
cons: Takes long to get things approved. I feel the intern program is a bit slow and that I wasn't trusted that much. They also completely ignored my team preferences in order to make me more "well rounded", and put me on a team that I had absolutely no interest in.

main_text: I worked at GE  for more than 3 years

cons: scope of the conglomerate is too broad
advice_management: decentralize

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Openness to new ideas from upper management. Lots of smart people who are great to work with. Can get a lot done if you work hard.
cons: Projects derailed because of groups fighting one another. Pushed to work way too many hours. Full-time employees still graded on a curve.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Career opportunities used to be good until GE took over.  Good work life balance.  Senior management was good when 2014, get worse after the acquisition.
cons: salary is not that attractive probably because the plant location is typically around some rural areas.  Not much to do at those rural areas after work.
advice_management: Maintain the original culture and try less bureaucratic move.  Focus on the work instead of too much political move post acquisition.

summary: "GE - A great place to work a myth but not exactly the fact."

summary: "Good company if you have technical degree, but not good for other degrees"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Good pay, plenty of overtime, good people on the floor that you work with.  The management is bad so it's very refreshing to have people that are down to earth and understand the struggles you go through, because they are going through the same thing.
cons: Poor management, too much overtime, a lot of the people in upper postitions are young, never worked the floor, and have no idea about the product lines they're in control of.
advice_management: Look within your organization for your talent before heading to outside prospects.  A lot of us have degrees too, are looking to make careers here, and are not young students looking to add GE to their resume then leave.

main_text: I worked at GE  for less than a year
pros: Was able to work on real projects for customers and work on different aspects of projects to gain experience in all facets of the work I was doing
cons: Seemed to be a different set of expectations from the program leaders based in Corporate and my local managers

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Flexible and autonomous role.   Ability to set your own schedule and priorities.  No shortage of challenges to overcome and problems to solve.  Never boring.
cons: Big, matrixed company with constant organizational change.  Makes communication and accountability difficult.  National/global initiatives rarely tailored to regional markets.
advice_management: Action simplification, particularly around HR events.   Pay regional market rate for skilled labor.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Great culture, manager was focused on me having a good internship experience, exploring interest, building skills, etc.
cons: At the time of accepting offer, no idea (other than engineering) what type of daily work I would be doing. Ended up in a role that didn't really match my interest, but was given the flexibility to explore other areas by shadowing, defining my own goals, etc.
advice_management: More specific job descriptions made available during offer would have been great. Professional development opportunities were good.

main_text: I have been working at GE

main_text: I worked at GE part-time for less than a year
pros:
- Pay (they pay interns very well with overtime extra pay as well)
- Location services (gym, cafeteria, bus from building to parking lot)
cons:
- Sometimes you feel left out there with no real resources
- They say they will work around your part-time schedule but still expect you to put in full-time level of work
advice_management:
Work closely with the lower level employees because they are the backbone to the team and the their value to the team is just as much as anyone else. 
Treat all races equally

main_text: I worked at GE  for more than 10 years
pros: I worked in the factory 16 yrs and for the international dept. 18 yrs. Excellent pay, travel, great working environment.
cons: Upper management cares only for the bottom line. Schenectady went from 36,000 employees in 1980 to around 4,000 now. No longer has a pension plan other than 401Ks. Threw 56,000 salaried retirees into a health exchange this year and hourly retirees next. WAS a good place to work.
advice_management: Any comments would be censored. Jeff Imeltt  has been there too long and the company now runs on greed. Bring GE back.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Collaborative culture, innovative spirit, access to leadership training, access to Lean Training, access to Six Sigma Training, access to many industries under one moniker, etc.
cons: At times, leadership does not practice Gemba.  At times, you may see departments working in silos when a cross functional project is taking place.  You see these challenges in many large organizations such as GE.
advice_management: Practice Gemba with the shop floor, with the buyer floor, with the warehouse floor, with lower leadership, and ask questions.  All with the intent to practice continuous improvement, plus score points with the entire team along the way.
