summary: "Great Pay, Great Company, but Tough & Competitve Atmosphere"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Co-op's are responsible for important projects, and are relied upon by technology team.  Most entry level co-ops are considered as a new full time engineer and are given resposnibilities based on that status.  HR managers are flexible with un-paid time off/vacation.
cons: Managers are very demanding.  Somewhat of a lack of communication between marketing and engineering team.  Also, a loss of feedback from upper level managers is somewhat consistent.  Work load and expectations can be very stressful at times.
advice_management: Management needs to communicate more with technology team about specific projects and why these are valuable to the industry.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Its a nice campus, very nice people, work is work - not much different from other large company but i would say that GE has its own way of doing things so it takes time to get adjusted.
cons: Work life balance is tough, alot of changes within the business and its constantly moving from one thing to another. Management changes out and people move around alot so its difficult to get focus experts on things.
advice_management: Streamline changes so people can adjust quickly to the new structures. Offer more training opportunities and introduce a 6 month "swap" program where two employees could cross train each other so people outside of programs could get an opportunity to try a different focus and branch out to new areas to see if they like it.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: great training programs and good opportunity for advancement.  management team was very involved with overall career management.
cons: not a great location.  winters were horrible.

main_text: I worked at GE  for less than a year
pros: Great exciting environment with plenty of helpful people. Projects were useful and necessary and not busy work at all
cons: not a diverse environment at all. the same type of person works at the facilities. different management styles were in charge of the same project making it difficult to see a clear solution
advice_management: be more innovative in created solutions. use the available technology to you advantage.

main_text: I worked at GE  for less than a year
pros: Great people, great culture, incredibly busy office but fantastic place to work. there is a lot of camaraderie among employees and people tend to work together and not apart.
cons: Some managers tend to pander to upper management a little too much, which gains them favors. Unfortunately, others who are really dedicated to their personal product are discouraged by the favoritism and leave.
advice_management: Look at the value in each of your employees. There is some amazing talent right under your nose, but you will lose it if you don't look past those who would use their higher level positions to take credit for the work being done by others.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years

job_title: Former Employee - Senior IT Project Leader
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Great benefits, health of employees is a priority, education opportunities abound.
cons: Decision making is a 'please everybody' process that takes forever.  Large company - hard to change direction, like a super-tanker.
advice_management: Press the 'best practice' button, not the consensus opinion button.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Good place to start a career and with many opportunities for career branching with the many different businesses under GE.
cons: Not many to point out besides the fact that it is a very large company.  If large companies isn't your thing then you might want to look elsewhere. Other than that there is nothing egregious to point out.
advice_management: Management has been pretty good overall and they have shown that through the ability to manage large teams with good composure and grace. There is no micromanaging either, which is good personally.

main_text: I worked at GE

advice_management: Walk the Talk

main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: This company spends many resources developing their talent.  This creates a rich pool from which to promote and advance careers.
cons:
There are too many instances of roles being filled with Good Old Boys.  Nepotism is too obvious for such a large, progressive corporation.  Recently, roles have been combined instead of being filled with new candidates.

The pending merger with Electrolux has only made these shortfalls that much more obvious.
advice_management: Appliance Park used to have a bad reputation from field sales managers for having a "bubble."  Decisions that affect the sales team in the field were made in a vaccuum by managers at headquarters.  Since the pending sale to Electrolux disrupted the organization, the Louisville Bubble has become more of an "Iron Curtain," and the field sales team feels closer to the end of the whip, waiting for it to crack, now more than ever.

Management and training
advice_management: Be equal, show compassion, do what you say, invest funds where needed not where wanted. Be fair to all employees, don't make accuses for short comings and than place blame else where

summary: "A company that cares about it employees?"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: It is a large global company. You can  move into other open positions at GE
cons: I was laid off after many years. Close to retirement. Told I was being replaced by a contract nurse.    It didn't matter  I only had a few years to retirement nor could my immediate boss offer any input . It was a higher up decision. Loyalty and hard work of the blue collar population doesn't  mean anything to the higher up. I worked so hard there.  Made a lot of improvements in the day to day operation.  I will always have this gut reaction of disgust and distaste whenever I see that GE logo .
advice_management: Is that contract employee really going to contribute as much, be as knowledgeable, or be as loyal as an actual employee? If the ship starts going down due to a leak , that contract employee is not going to bail water.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: You get a lot of relevant experience and exposed to a large corporate company. They have really amazing things going on and the really make you part of the team. Your work is taken seriously and some projects you may have may even be implemented. You also get to meet all the senior leaders. I even had a project that I worked on with one of the executive Vice Presidents.
cons: The offices are quiet. The cubicles are high up so you really can't see anyone else. Some people are outgoing but mainly keep to themselves for the most part. Don't ask to switch to another location because they probably won't give you another offer.
advice_management: you need to be more flexible with location and job preferences. Your employees will hate you if they don't like what they are doing it where they are and don't have a choice in the matter.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years

cons:
- Heavy work loads, sometimes understaffed
- A lot of organizational changes...reorgs every couple of years, usually involving layoffs
advice_management: Create more lateral moves for employees when there are limited promotion opportunities.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years

cons: Management is very hit or miss depending on the group. Processes and systems not very efficient and often prevent work from being done efficiently as well.

main_text: I have been working at GE  for less than a year
pros:
-Great mentorship. Supervisors take an active interest in the intern's experience and keep them in the loop. Just being around, you'll learn a lot. But the real value comes from the work assignments, which are fairly substantive and not just busy work
-Fun perks. The company has tours and workshops all summer that showcase different parts of the business. Even if you have no idea what they're talking about (e.g. a law student learning about complex engineering), it's a good opportunity to learn about new things.
cons:
-Not a great place to work if you're a quiet, shut-in type. People are very friendly and there's a lot of collaboration. 
-Difficult, if not impossible, to actually get the internship. I managed to strike gold and get an offer, but a lot of really qualified people got turned down. Very competitive. 
-No permanent job. As with most companies, they don't hire in-house lawyers directly from law school. Understandable, but frustrating, especially when your law school colleagues get offers from their summer jobs and get to spend the rest of the year coasting.
advice_management: No real advice to management other than to expand the number of interns. Taking on an intern is relatively cheap and in today's legal market, law students are going to be pretty driven.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
You will work with some very smart people. There is not a lot of dead weight to be found.
The company has its processes down pat, so you don't waste a ton of time on non-work / administrative issues.
If you are willing to be mobile, there is lots of opportunity. Training is top notch and easy to get.
cons: You'll work the equivalent of three jobs in most other companies. Your nights, weekends and holidays will get overrun. The tragedy is, everyone gives up their life to the company, so unless you have zero shame you won't feel right taking time for yourself.
advice_management: The science is clear...we humans can only focus on 2-3 big things in a day. It is not unusual to load up an employee with 15 projects and then ask them to "stretch" to add more. Recognize that while there is a line out the door of young, eager college grads ready to work for your company, your seasoned employees are leaving for higher pay and lighter workloads.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Training & development
Hard working, smart people
Competitive group always looks for a way to say yes
cons:
Sometimes bureaucratic
Some weaker employees seem to "slip by"

main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: Career advancement opportunities even crossing business units.
cons: I don't have anything to say.

main_text: I worked at GE  for less than a year
pros: Exciting and motivational place to work.  It has a wonderful team spirit with all of the aerospace engineers.  Workshops to improve skills were offered on a continuing basis. I loved GE (Aircraft Engine Group), Evendale, OH. Further, women are advanced quickly.
cons: The only con for my family were the layoffs which affected my husband and of course the family.
advice_management: Keep treating people as viable entities as you do.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Industry leader and top quality people
cons: You must learn to navigate within business units and cross business  this is not always easy

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: My current supervisor is great. I never see them because their plate is way overloaded. It helps I'm highly motivated. Never a dull moment. LOTS of OT.
cons:
Did I mention LOTS of overtime? Like 70-79 hrs/ week? There is no work life balance, especially working 7 days a week for almost a year now. Absurd. And this is because the management can't plan. Really, they have no plan other than throw the 3 M's (money, men, material) at the cash cow to meet unrealistic deadlines set before they ever understood the process. Morale is way low. Turn over right now is way high, even at the office level.  

They talk about six-sigma and 5 S, but the truth is the mid and upper level management couldn't lead a pack of hungry dogs to a carcass. I have never seen incompetence on such a large scale. Top that off with corporate having no feet on the ground here, and the kids have free reign to drive it right into the ground...... The answer-have the kids work harder.
advice_management:
Corporate needs to intervene. Create a true work life balance. Treat the workers with a little respect. Get rid of the bosses and put in TRUE leadership. Yes, it rolls down hill, but, "the kids" are tired of cleaning up after someone's inability to plan accordingly - which happens with every single project. 

Instead of 5s, push the 6P's to your management here. Hold the inept accountable.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Great pay, 3 shifts, overtime when busy
cons: Lack of job security, union mentality
advice_management: Just back off the employees and do your job. Let the employees come to you if there is a problem.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Excellent pay and benefits, working for a well respected brand and company. Training opportunities are top notch.
cons: Leadership culture focused on short term results. Executives operate in stove-pipe mentality - very little collaborative/cooperative effort. Arguments between executives over who will be assigned credit for perceived cost savings and idea generation. Stuff that drives you crazy. Very little room for promotion unless you are a real go-getter and are contributing to the success of an executive level player.
advice_management: The company is working on a huge shift of culture where performance is defined by outcomes. This is great. Continue this. Get mid level leaders aligned, get some outward focus and context.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
Opportunities to learn as much as you can about businesses, six sigma, as well as networking across businesses.  If you are willing to move, job opportunities grow exponentially.
Extremely ethical and train employees regularly in proper
cons:
Pay is not always highest, but at the lower end of the industry standard pay scale.  
In my particular business, there were a lot of hoops to go through to get management approval for new product ideas.  Seemed like we spent a lot of time justifying our existence.
advice_management: Sometimes it is better to get out of your own way.  Trust that your employees are working towards goals that will help grow the company, brand and/or business.  You are great at hiring smart people, let them be smart.

cons: The company is really large and it is slow to adapt to external changes.  The method of adaptation seems to be through acquisitions and divestments...not true internal change.
advice_management: Be honest with employees and not try to spin every company decision in a positive way.  We appreciate being told the truth.

summary: "Corporate IT Strategic Vision is Inconsistent YoY"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Working with and leading very bright and talented individuals. Many opportunities for change in role provided you build relationships across the vast and different IT spaces and business units. Great training and professional development courses. Excellent experience to build exposure of complex enterprise architectures.
cons: Inconsistent strategy and vision of internal IT solutions. No emphasis placed on strategic decisions made from quantitative data in recent years, with large and grandiose statements being the norm often with no modeling for total cost of ownership. 18 month minimum in job before moving to a new position often leaves 90% completed product, tool or service rolled out with the original project owner or executive champion moving on with no direct link to future project success, failure, or TCO projection alignment.
advice_management: Drive IT strategy with cash flow and cost based approach; eliminating strategic vision statements with no imperial data to validate.  Go back to multi-year valuations to provide data points on project, tool, and architecture success and continue to drive efficiencies of scale.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years

cons: Typical large company. Difficult to understand internal workings. Promotes inexperienced people. Management rotates constantly. Upper management withheld support to meet business goals. Experience and technical knowledge not highly valued. Upward mobility only if willing to relocate. Salaries seem to be below average.
advice_management: Develop management continuity that values critical thinking and creativity.

summary: "Terrible place to work if you want to have a life."
main_text: I worked at GE
pros: The only good thing about this company is the name looks good on a resume. Leaving here is the best thing that can happen to your career. Sorry for the long explanation but I entered "None" for the Pros and received an error because my description was not long enough. Look elsewhere.
cons: Too numerous to list. This was the worst company I have worked for in my life. I had respect for some Sr. managers. With the exception of 1 of my direct managers, the lower management is so concerned about their careers they do nothing to help or build the employees or their direct reports. I gave this place 1 star because it would not allow for 0 stars.
advice_management: Let the employees have some time for their personal lives. All work and no time for family is a terrible way to run a company and you will continue to lose the best people when they realize how lopsided your "Life / work balance" is offset to work.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: GE Aerospace -- now no longer part of GE -- was technologically at the cutting edge of what we did.  Management focus, tracking progress, and support of their employees was very good.
cons: GE Aerospace would cut our budget requests by 5 to 15 percent but still require the same output.  Therefore we routinely requested more funds than might be needed to compensate for the expected shortfall in funding.  It was a stupid game, but we were good -- out of necessity -- at playing it.

From the beginning, they have been slowly infusing their corporate  employees into the company. What is left is a company without any domain knowledge .
advice_management: With an oil and gas company, it is not possible to know a particular  job in 2 years. I would have thought that yoi buy a company because you see value in it. Not to suck a company in and mess it up so badly that it is totally unrecognizeable and to drag its good name through the mud to where it produces nothing.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: You'll get to do and touch lots of stuff, so you can rack up lots of experience in a short time. If you're competent, and a go-getter, you can get promoted fairly quickly as well. Lots of training opportunities (e.g., management, Six Sigma, Lean, etc). If you drink the GE "Kool-Aid" long enough, they'll even send you to Crotonville, which is pretty spiff.
cons: Sometimes, however, you'll get promoted because of the massive #fail happening above and around you. Your boss will often change every 18-24 months, and occasionally, they will back-fill with someone who has an MBA, but no clue or common sense about technology OR business. Lots of politics, especially if you work for one of the major business divisions (as opposed to Corporate). Communication from the top down is almost non-existent. Corporate will mandate stuff, but won't say why we have to do it, and will provide no funding to do it with. Everyone is a special snowflake, and everyone gets a trophy for showing up.
advice_management: Bring back Jack Welch. Let the businesses run themselves. Hire leaders at all levels who have some common sense and some independent thoughts. Stop with the one-size-fits-all approach to the different businesses--they're all different, and have different cultures. Trying to cram them into one big  box isn't working.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Benefits, and vacation are comparable to industry standard. Tuition reimbursement as well.  entry level pay from what I understand is competitive. Great group of people from entry level assemblers, up to leads, and facilitators. Some supervisors aren't bad people, but are mostly figureheads with no real responsibilities.
cons: Very little upward promotions for those who started on the floor. Minor promotions with little pay increases maybe so, but nothing higher than lead type positions. Even if you get a bachelors degree.  Inexperienced supervisors and managers with no production experience, and with integrity issues run the place with incompetence.  No integrity, but back stabbing, and dishonesty by management. Supervisors/managers without integrity, or real production experience are useless, and are a waste of payroll. Hire supervisors and managers out of leads/facilitators that have earned bachelors degrees, as they will make a much more positive impact on the business, but also morale.
advice_management:
Change the OMLP to require 3+ years production/warehouse experience, plus Operations/Supply Chain Management degree, not engineering with the exception of industrial engineering. The OMLP graduates rarely truly understand the production environment even after they're finished, and even after years go by are still more of a liability and waste of payroll.  Same with supervisors/managers, require production experience. Without hands on production experience(doesn't have to be with the product you make, or with GE), including being a lead, they are nothing short of useless. 

Poor performing supervisors/managers with integrity issues who aren't respected by their subordinates shouldn't be promoted or moved to another equal salaried position, they should be terminated without notice, and no severance. Just like hourly employees who aren't up to par with whats expected. If 9/10 of their subordinates think they're useless, they probably are.

Require at least bi-yearly re-certification of Six Sigma, and require hands on experience in the process they are improving. Too often do they contradict Lean/Six Sigma principals. 

No more hiring recent college grads for management unless they have production experience entry level, and as a lead for 3+ years. Engineering degree is not auto-manager material, and it never will be.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Really good money. Preference to promote from within. Pretty good benefits. Some training is done through a really well-done series of on-line courses, so you can do it on your own schedule. Communication from management is good; even when they decided to move our business out of state, they gave us over a year's notice.
cons:
1. Really squeezing employees to cut costs; very few people went home after 8 hours. Management really does not care about your workload, and will force as much down your throat as you will swallow.
2. If you are a small division, management frequently is not at your location, and everybody in the building works for someone who is offsite.
3. Bonuses are calculated based on the performance of business groups, not just your own location. So even if you do great and your company does great and meets all its goals, if your group does poorly, you get nothing.
4. As with any huge corporation, your division can be sold, moved, or otherwise changed, leaving you unemployed. No real loyalty to long-time employees.
5. I would recommend to a friend if their lifestyle could accommodate decent pay/benefits but long hours with little relief.
advice_management: Pay bonuses reflecting the goals of individual companies -- there's little incentive to bust your butt  if there's a dead weight in your business group that's going to weigh everybody down.

summary: "GEnormous company...its large size not a benefit"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Flexibility to move about in different roles.   Decent pay and Benny's but that is slowly eroding away.   Cost cost cost reduction.
cons:
It's too big.    Too many ( inept) Chiefs and no Indians.    Too much turnover in roles.    Most people are in a role for two years and encouraged to move on.    Problem is they don't train the person replacing them so the new guy has to reinvent the wheel.    People are just hitting their stride at two years and are getting efficient in what they are doing.      Zero turn over from former to present employee causes disturbing ripples down the line.   We could be so much more LEAN if we could curb this.

Managers do not know how to do the job of their subordinates.
advice_management:
HR is way overpaid and under-effective.     Look at the salaries of our HR people and they are about 90% over the national average.    HR wields way too much influence in matters they know absolutely nothing about.     That entire organization needs to be torn down and re constructed to be a RESOURCE not managers of a technical engineering company.     They have a 360 degree review process but no one uses it.    Managers, including HR managers, should be required to have a 360 completed by every one below them, anonymously.   

Diversity is nice but putting people in roles because we have fill a certain percentage point.....it makes zero sense.     Put blinders on to where someone is from or what they look like and hire the most qualified people.    You'll be amazed at what you get.

Next,  stop allowing roles to move on at two-ish years.... At least 3 to 5 years in a role should be required.   

Stop the dotted line manager scenario....not effective.     There a lot of ex military in GE.... I don't understand how their military training doesn't spill over as far as  leadership goes.   Most managers have never held the role of the positions they lead.    How can you lead this way?   You can't effectively.     "An effective leader knows how to do the job above them and below them."   Look it up.

Do a better job of training sales people.    A common saying: "customers don't know what they are buying and we don't know what we are selling".   We can't do much about inept customers but we can certainly pair sales teams up with subject matter experts to ensure sales know their product.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: Good pay for the industry. Good benefits. Great opportunity to make more money by working extra Saturdays and selling water filters and service contracts.
cons: Everything from the choice of what area to work to when you get to take vacation is based off seniority.  Not when you come to the company but when you come to the area.  You have to work lots of Saturdays during the summer.
advice_management: Base the rights for when to take vacation off of performance instead of seniority. This will encourage new techs to work hard and motivate the senior techs to maintain a high level of performance.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Numerous opportunities for career growth and great culture.
cons: At times the business is to big to move quickly.

main_text: I worked at GE  for less than a year
pros: People, Hours, Accesibility.  A great place to either start or finish a career
cons: Small fish in a big pond
advice_management: Listen to management, not shareholders

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Very team oriented, good management support
cons: Travel kept increasing, salary too low

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
GE Appliances has some of the greatest engineering talent I've seen; lots of hard-working, young, competent engineers of both genders. The "Edison" program for newly-acquired engineers is a great post-college training program that all large companies should institute.
Great ethics policies, and sticklers for employee health and safety.
cons:
Old facility, lacking in overall maintenance inside and out. The water supply is so terrible they provide a zillion bottled-water dispensers in all of the buildings (thanx, but, update the plumbing).
You have to walk a long distance (in the open) from parking lot to building (terrible when raining or snowing).  
This is a go-go-go environment . . . lots of people work long days, and in the Cooking Products division expect many week-long trips to either Georgia or Mexico.
Heaven help you if you look outside of your division (Cooking, Laundry, Dishwasher, Refrigeration) for a new job position . . . your name will be mud.
advice_management: Modernize, clean-up, beautify the facilities. Add covered walk-ways from the parking lot turn-stiles to the building entrances; enclose their sides in the winter.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: They were very flexible. Job was very stable, you can travel the world (if good manager)
cons: Stressful, long hours, conservative culture, has been, some managers are horrible.
advice_management: Continue to divest and focus on technology. pay more and work smart

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Great atmosphere for motivated individuals looking for a broad company to work for. They are constantly evolving to changing times and give you the opportunity to take on projects that align with your interests.
cons: It can be difficult to get promoted if you are not willing to relocate with the company but if you are willing the possibilities are endless.
advice_management: Continue to allow team members to take on cross functional projects and simplify business operations!

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Challenging projects in unique applications. Interdisciplinary nature of projects lends to lot of opportunities for growth.
cons: Promotions to management roles highly dependent on experience within GE framework on team management, which negates outside management experience somewhat, especially in mid career.

summary: "A good company that can be better"
job_title: Former Employee - Biomedical Equipment Technician II
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: The company has its reputation that serves as leverage between you and the customers. They make great end-products which is something that the workers are proud of. The company is big enough to allow people move from one department to another, or from one location to another. The organizational structure brings workers closer to the chain of command than you expect in bigger companies.
cons: Typical of a big company, it is big and departments don't communicate. This leads to policies that make it harder to perform your daily duties. It's all about numbers, and the average worker means nothing to the company. You'll get minimal to no training opportunities working there. The technicians even have to purchase their own tools used to work. Some people have been there for 5 years without a single meaningful raise. Opportunity for growth is therefore slim.
advice_management: Listen to your employees. Implement a reward system that tracks and recognizes hardworking staff. nothing compares to a meritorious organization that culminates into a high performance work practice organization.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Opportunities to travel, lots of different jobs and locations.  Exciting technology.
cons: Very large and slow.  Extremely limited financial growth potential, even with promotions.
advice_management: When you say your people are important, put your actions behind your words.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Global, Complex and Numbers focused
cons: Very complex to work for given the Global nature.  Hard driven and have to have the will to work long hours and varying management styles.
advice_management: Please demand simplification and transparency from your leaders.

main_text: I worked at GE part-time
pros: great coworkers and supervisors, They help you on whatever you need help in this industry no hard feelings to the fellow coworkers
cons: job is draining, doing the same thing everyday. gets tiring and boring when doing the same thing everyday with no cell phone on working site.
advice_management: Improve the job ability to be more fun and likable when working inside the machine operator room.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Benefits have always been a strong point but have begun to diminish over the past 3 years.  Pay is very good and competitive.  Movement within the organization between businesses is attractive in that you can work in multiple industries within the same company.  In many instances the caliber of talent that you work with is very high, but not in all instances.
cons: Inconsistent performance expectations across team members.  GE often calls itself a "meritocracy" but this is not true.  All too often recognition and advancement are given on poorly defined criteria.  Leadership is incredibly inconsistent in messaging.. the organization feels like it is unstable with a continuing pattern of cost cutting, poorly defined performance recognition.  Over the past 2 years the stability of the business has become questionable and strategy is unclear.
advice_management: Return to valuing the team members that deliver, recognize them, seek them out, leverage and reward performance.  Define the strategy to the employees to demonstrate that there is a future other than continued cost cutting.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Some of the most talented minds on Earth, seriously.
cons: The business I am in is really suffering, seems the only things they care about are:  close the deal, ship the order whether it is ready or not, and collect the cash as fast as possible.  Very short-sided tactical mindset focused only on the current fiscal quarter sales.  Not nearly enough effort to fix really big customer issues.  Zero work/life balance, this GE business like many others will take your life away and you have no choice.
advice_management: Take immediate action to fix all the issues our customers are telling us we must fix, or lose their business.

job_title: Current Employee - Supply Chain ERP Leader
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great Leadership development programs and talent.
cons: Very lean resources due to low margin industry.

main_text: I have been working at GE  for less than a year
pros: Promote/advancement is quick. The company prides themselves on cultivating new ideas and adding new blood with various roles. The work/life balance is good and the extra hours needed are made up for with the salary.
cons: Sometimes the GE politics can get out of control with things constantly changing on a monthly basis. Right when you get use to doing something they seem to change it.

main_text: I worked at GE  for less than a year
pros: Solid pay for the work
cons: Little chance of being hired as a contract worker
advice_management: Look towards the contract workers for the future

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Great company, great support to the customers. A lot of opportunities to move up.
Good benefit package. High tech products with good field engineers
cons: Can be too big at times. they are continuing to change and restructure which causes a lot of turmor. They are looking to elimnate penisons
advice_management: Continue to focus on customers. Until they do away with EMS reviews they will never will satisfly the customer

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: The culture and people, etc.
cons: Bureaucracy which makes it hard to get things done sometimes

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Smart people to work with
cons: No vacation accrual allowed for senior management

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Great exposure to senior leadership with the opportunity to experience four different finance manager positions over a two year span.
cons: Very little work life balance and a lack of ideal locations to be based out of. Internal audit is encouraged following the program.
advice_management: Compensate talent based on market analysis and rethink Corporate Audit Staff as the sole method of developing the pipeline of talent.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: The pay is well above average.  An entry level production employee will start out around $14/ hr and can easily work up to close to $20/ hr
cons: Management is under staffed here at Bucyrus lamp plant in Ohio.  The engineers are used as maintenance supervisors and don't have enough time to do actual engineering work.
advice_management: My advice to management is to spend more time and money to train the hourly employees.  Utilize the experienced employees extensive knowledge of the machines to train the younger ones.  Provide regular training for the skilled trades so they can remain current with technology

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Is a school that lets you learn whatever you want to. It does not limit to your current position, they let you work in other areas.
cons: There are no a lot of positions relative to computers at Puerto Rico.
advice_management: Provide every single month certifications to your employees.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Good software applications
Great opportunity to increase skills
cons:
Expensive Health Insurance
Poor leadership training & management

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Very good mobility.  Great chances to move up or lateral for more experience.  Coaching and continuing education are very accessible
cons: Medium to low salary for the skills applied.  Very long hours (12 to 14 per day).
advice_management: Lighten the load so that people can see their families.  The amount of hours required (and I mean Required by the Executives) is a bit much.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Good Opportunities in various locations
cons: Quarterly Metrics is short term view

main_text: I worked at GE  for less than a year
pros:
learning opportunity.
friendly environment
caring and sharing
cons:
extended work hours
upgradation is required for projects with absolute technogies.
advice_management: good management

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: The pay rate and benefits are top notch.  Legacy businesses can be a bit harder to swallow, but startups are great with GE.
cons: Legacy businesses and union labor.
advice_management: Invest in your equipment and trust your operators.

main_text: I worked at GE  for less than a year
pros: great place to work, people are really helpful of new help.
cons: i dont really have any bad thing to say about the company

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Variety of work. Technical challenge. Vacation has finally caught up to world standards. Some excellent managers.
cons: Salary is too low. Merit increase too low. Salary does not keep up with annual cost of living. Company tries really hard to pay as little as possible. Benefits are continuously downgraded. To much politics. The good old boy club. Broad needs to completely change.
advice_management: See cons and improve all these. Broad needs to be represented by 60% non management employees, 10 GE executives of all levels percent, 30% outside members.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Work with good people and fairly easy work for most.
cons: Bad management. No communication from company or union. Out dated everything.
advice_management: Promote from within the company. Make supervisor more responsible for mistakes they cause. Update things

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: I have been with GE for 18 years, and the best part of working for GE is the training and growth opportunities that they provide...if you are a hard worker, and strive to excel in everything you do, this is the place for you!!!
cons: As I said in the pros section, GE expects a lot from you, and you will work extremely hard to achiever your goals, so if you want just an ordinary job just to get by, this isn't the place for you.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: This place is a great day job if you like days. And having  job.  I enjoyed the diverse staff and the great breaks.
cons: This place is the only place that I have ever heard of being a place of employment were you work and every Friday get paid.
advice_management: Try to be a lit r let better a giving raises that will help a person substantially so that they can afford HE products.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Good management, rewards for high performers,  good work/life balance
cons: Red Tape of the large organization

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Excellent in house training. Great fitness facilities, decent benefits, long term career prospects.  Constant innovation and change.
cons: recent remodel attempt to "googlize" a 130 year old company a complete failure. Staff that previously had some privacy in their cubicles now shunted off to open benches and cheap, Ikea-style open cubicles made out of metal and p article board. shoddy carpet squares in light colors instantly took on a dingy grey cast. Open "collaboration spaces" noisy and not conducive to the kind of work done at headquarters. It wasn't lost on people that the ones who got the worst set up were minorities and that creates a bad image. Not  the impression you want to create at corporate headquarters.
advice_management: Recognize that remodel on the cheap makes sense if HQ is moving, but doesn't mean we like it.

summary: "GE is an ok place to work"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: GE Has been an OK place to work. Great People and great experiences there. Very much a Type A type of environment.
cons: Too much of a type A environment. Sometime the work can be boring/uncreative. SO much cahnge in too little time.
advice_management: GE should try and become a GREAT Place to work. Thats what it takes to maintain and get great talent. Try to let employees be more creative.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Lots of exposure, good culture, team.
cons: Nothing to complain. Great place

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Excellent work life balance. Senior Management if very supportive
cons: GE Capital is downsizing as of 2015, so not much future left in the company.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: They treat their employees well and have good pay.
cons: It can be hard to advance your career, i.e. Not a lot of openings to go after.
advice_management: Be honest about the direction the company is going in.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Massive organization. Lots of resources
cons: Hard to get motivated as you are a small piece of the pie.  Must be on the executive track to really succeed.  Sometimes I feel like we spend 80$ of the time on reporting and management upwards as opposed to value add analysis

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Good benefits, working condition, proud to be one of ge,s
cons:
Too specific job requirements 
, not the most motivating job
advice_management: Opportunities for advancement

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Honestly the best electrical connector I've had the pleasure of working for. Very helpful front office personnel and competitive benefits.
cons: Most of work done on the south side of Chicago. Not a big fan of that.
advice_management: Keep up the good work.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Interesting Business Issues and opportunities
cons: It's not what you do or know, but how you play the politics
advice_management: Focus on best utilizing substance talent vs. who borwn noses best

main_text: I have been working at GE  for more than 5 years
pros: At global research, one can get good exposure to technologies in different business areas that the company operates in.
cons: Work-family balance is not desirable.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Good benefits, decent pay for an internship. Would recommend for anyone looking for experience.
cons: Long and inconvenient hours. Needs better vacation time to keep up with the shift times.
advice_management: Hire those with the knowledge and experience to complete their job. Fire those who are wasting company time and money.

main_text: I have been working at GE  for less than a year
pros: I work at GE and it is a great place to work. I have no complaints as of today.
cons: GE will not hire very experienced people in particular areas for very strange reasons. I don't understand why they do this.
advice_management: Hire domain experts. If you have someone with 15 years experience building and designing rail traffic control systems you should jump at the chance to hire him. But instead, HR will block him because he interviewed previously for another position at GE for a totally different non-domain related position.

main_text: I worked at GE  for less than a year
pros:
- Internship provided real life work and issues not "busy work"
- The staff worked hard to provide diverse experiences
- Evaluative feedback and personalized opportunities
- Friendly and personable staff
cons: The pending Electrolux merger is a concern on everybody's minds

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Six Sigma certification required and sponsored. Since it is such a large company, the culture may be better in other business units that the one I was in.
cons: The business unit that I worked in was definitely not a collaborative environment that fostered customer satisfaction or innovation. Team members were fitted against each other and not one could be trusted.
advice_management: Read "The Speed of Trust" by Stephen Covey. Consider the medium-long term strategic impact on a business unit when resources are allowed to cycle through jobs in 12-18 month before any real progress can be made to influence much needed programs and initiatives to move stagnant business processes forward.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great people to work with, The company has good benefits, The company has abundant resources you may be able to levberage, Because the company has multiple businesses and locations, there are multiple career opportunities
cons: There can be alot of management and leadership turnover and at times it may be difficult to develop and maintain productive business relationships because the managers you proved yourself to have moved on. Large companies can also become internally focused and competitive. The challenges are probably different than in smaller companies.
advice_management: Develop processes and opportunities that leverage employees experience and strengths but also may help build new skills. Get to know your employees and understand how they can best help the organization. Perform regular reviews with employees and ask them what opportunities they see for improvement.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Good benefits and job assistance when laid off
cons: Salary ok. Could use more training

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Excellent training and project exposure
cons: Shallow project teams discourages cross training and mobility within the organization
advice_management: Cross train and do not be afraid to let people take on new opportunities

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Ability to travel both domestically and internationally
cons:
Lots of 12 hour shifts when traveling, some on night shift
Tough deadlines to meet

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: good benefits and wage, laid back pace
cons: strong Corporate environment short training
advice_management: more training!

main_text: I have been working at GE  for more than 5 years
pros:
good benefits and 
flexible schedule
cons: job classified as entry level but is more detailed then that

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Career advancement and great training opportunities
cons: Sale of business is sad. Great place to work
advice_management: Great leadership

job_title: Current Employee - Operations Management Leadership Program (OMLP) Associate
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: GE will allow you to make your career whatever you'd like for it to be. It is a large company, so location and job scope can really be determined by the individual if you are a high performer.
cons: Networking can be somewhat difficult at a smaller site, but the opportunities are endless. Very metrics driven, which can sometimes influence negative behaviors.
advice_management: Continue to lead at developing leaders. Empower them to experience multiple businesses rather than remaining tied to one silo.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: lot`s of promises for career growth in the future
cons: no work life balance only work 24/7

main_text: I have been working at GE  for more than 10 years
pros: Lots of benefits and v job security working for such a large and diverse company,  many opportunities for movement within the organization. Good compensation.
cons: It is such a large and diverse company that the sole drove of the company is to improve the portfolio and increase revenue for the stock holders.
advice_management: Fight for and pay more attention to employee needs such as insurance and raises for performance,  sometimes the worker is overlooked.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: Stable, Opportunities for advancement, Flexible
cons: Bad health care benefits, understaffed
advice_management: We need more people

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Great team/leadership. All were high achievers.  We were all given room to work autonomously. Minimal micromanagement. Adequate opportunities for advancement.
cons: Company was always looking to divest its real estate while I worked there, so platform was always shrinking. Lots of corporate and regulatory red tape to navigate.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Decent Pay and advancement opportunities. Highly diverse culture and plenty of avenues for career development
cons: Capital businesses are for sale. Not much more you can say after being told that you are for sale and will not be moving to the new purchasing company.
advice_management: Advice, advice, advice, advice, advice. No advice to give. Management is not being retained with sale either.. Will revise at a later date.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Flexible Schedule and many sick/ vacation days
cons: Company is in run-off and will cease to exist in the near future
advice_management: Clue in to what team leaders are saying behind your back.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: Plenty of opportunities. Great company.
cons: Have a tendency to continue to pile on work with no extra compensation

main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: The opportunity to learn about the manufacturing industry from all aspects of one of the largest companies in the world
cons: GE culture. Your promotions and opportunity for growth weren't based on your job performance but it was more about who liked you and who you knew
advice_management: Make culture more adaptable to people who want a work/life balance. Also allow more opportunity for growth through cross training.

main_text: I worked at GE  for more than a year
pros: Good Staff and challenging opportunities
cons: No investment in employee training

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: GE is one of the best employers in the world.
cons: Very demanding - but helps you to learn how successful one can be.
advice_management: Keep pushing

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: The employees are the best part of aha working at GE. GE offers ongoing training both technical and leadership. They are always looking for ways to innovate.
cons: Can be slow to move and get things done. Can sometimes have too many leaders/managers and not enough doers.
advice_management: Management should more fully understand what everyone does. Really invest in technology and digital both thx people and dollars.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: If you're good at manipulating people into being afraid to point out that you never contribute anything positive and cause a lot of harm, you can make a lot of money here.
cons: The stars are psychopaths. The peons are enablers or snowed by them or on their way out because they see through it. It's such a nightmare for an honest person to have to sit through so many lies.
advice_management: I refuse to pretend that communicating with psychopaths could lead to any good.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: Challenging roles; freedom to act
cons: Tough work/life balance culture, especially for leadership positions
advice_management: Learn to appreciate and recognize; not simply push to deliver.

main_text: I worked at GE  for more than a year
pros: A large company with decent compensation.
cons: The department I was in did not have a structured internship program. I was the only intern and very bored most of the time.
advice_management: Define a engaging intern program that is universal. Give all interns a chance to interact even if they are not part of the same department.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros:
GE is a top notch employer. From Jeffrey R. Immelt
in down. I've never worked anywhere that safety is of such a high priority.
cons: I have nothing to put in the cons section. You'll not find as fine a organization to work for.
advice_management: Stay the course. Stick with investing in your most valuable asset - those you employ.

summary: "GE is a great place to start out"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Training opportunities, flexible schedules, travel opportunities, reasonable salary for area, exciting projects to work on.  You will work with great people for the most part.
cons: As with most large companies, frustrating bureaucracy slows down / inhibits work.  Lots of office politics... more so recently than in the past.
advice_management: Become better at determining which products are truly important to the market.  Many projects fall short of being what they could be, due to lack of funding, lack of staffing, and lack of proper leadership.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: This is still a great company to work for and progress in spite of changes.  I would love to work there again.
cons: As with other companies, change will force management to make decisions that are not favorable for all employees.  No specific issues with the company.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Lot of advancement opportunities if you are mobile. Many good managers as GE knows how to develop talent. Stable company that has been around for MANY years.
cons: Some beuracracy and politics, but that comes with any company.
advice_management: Keep on this course. This is a great company to work for and I have had a very positive experience so far!

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Great training programs and a great place to gain experience at the beginning of one's career. Surrounding by very smart, accomplished people.
cons: It's a large company and can feel very large company. If you want to build a long career at the company, while also advancing your career forward, can require moving your family time and time again, possibly all over the world.
advice_management: No advice. I think they've done a really great job of bringing more focus and cohesion to their portfolio, especially by selling NBC Universal in 2011 and GE Capital in 2015.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: The brand of GE on your resume can be good for your future endeavor. However, this location is not a good GE location to work.
cons:
The technology and process they use is very old and inefficient.
Lack of work life balance.
The office is very dim and smelly.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: Great pay and benefits.  Plenty of global opportunities. Many very smart people work at GE.  Great place to learn.
cons: Some roles have long hours.  Expectations can be based on unrealistic demands of corporate (not exclusive to GE).

main_text: I have been working at GE  for more than 5 years
pros: Large company, with opportunity to move to other domains
cons:
Salaries and benefits are a little below average at best.
Salary numbers come from average statistics that ignore performance and capabilities
Company tries to commoditize its employees, by ignoring the importance of proven capabilities and domain knowledge.
Cronyism and discrimination are rampant and drive much of the opportunity in the company.
Work/life balance is completely ignored.  Too much overtime for too little pay.
advice_management: Consider overhauling management as the only people you are keeping are those who still have the fixed benefit retirement package.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Excellent Intern Programs, many renowned Colleges & Universities
cons: Benefits have withered.  Seem to be going downward
advice_management: N/A

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Flexible work hours. Friendly work environment
cons: Limited growth in specific area. Too big to be significant

main_text: I worked at GE  for more than a year
pros: Looks good on resume.  Was nice to work from home.
cons: Contract workers are invisible at this company.  My manager basically told me to shut up and not contribute at meetings.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Constant development and feedback, fast-track program, traveling, visibility, exposure to multipl GE businesses, highly motivated and diverse group of people
cons: Work/life balance can be hard at times, but manageable.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Good Local folks in lewistown
cons: Management has no clue  and don't care

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Company culture, resources, good environment
cons: Focus is always on money for the management, leads to difficulty maintaining quality.
advice_management: Either money or quality comes first, not both.

job_title: Current Employee - Medical Device Assembly Or Tech
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: medial device mechanical assembly in clean room environment
cons: machine operator soldering under microscope assembly and inspection and follow procedure
advice_management: possess excellent interpersonal skills and great team player

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: great work environment  and coworkers
cons: focus on very limited work

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: I enjoyed my colleagues.  I enjoyed the work.
cons:
Does not necessarily promote from within. 
The company buys and sells companies all the time.  Therefore, you may get sold.
Reorganizations are frequent, due to acquisitions and dispositions.
advice_management: As the company experienced a "reduction in force"  I was disappointed in managers that hired for open positions from the outside.  In my opinion, folks that were impacted by restructuring should have filled newly created open positions.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: tons of career opportunities
cons: probably not willing to offer above average compensation.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Performance based raises and promotions
cons: annual raise difference between top performers and med level performance is not overly significant

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Good work life balance and career growth
cons: more processes involved which can be reduced

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: great company, huge alot of ups and downs but overtime opportunity so sky is the limit with how much you want to make.
cons: No family time due to the amount of hours that are required by the workload, alot of communication issues between departments.
advice_management: I would like to see a resolution to the communication issues along with more appreciation from our customers who we have contracts with.

main_text: I worked at GE  for more than 3 years
pros: Good culture. Nice environment and I like the culture
cons: Too structured and need approval to do anything. Not enough room to breath.

main_text: I have been working at GE  for more than 5 years
pros: Great visibility to upper management
cons: Lack of detailed Roles and Responsibility between TL and TD

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Great company for personal growth, you can learn a lot
cons: pay is average compared to other similar companies, people join GE to get it the GE name on their resume
advice_management: More competitive pay

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: GE is a great company for people, who want to challenge themselves and grow professionally.  The level of employees there is very high: smart, professional and hard working.  The company is so large that there a lot of career opportunities in several different industries.
cons: GE is known for being very numbers focused and it's true.  Seems like everything is measured and without solid financial support, it's hard to get a project improved...which means that they struggle with taking risks.  They also have the forced employee ranking system, where only 10 top employees can get excellent rating and nice salary increases...which leaves many great employees discouraged.
advice_management: Remove the forced employee ranking system!

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Training, access to world-class resources.
cons: Poor / absentee management. Unwilling to address failures of engineers through termination. No vision or strategy. Promotions generally based on relationships, not merit. Little to no room for advancement. Innovation is absolutely stifled.
advice_management: Quit promoting buffoons.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great benefits, great company leadership when I started
cons: Not encouraging growth in the company, more business than people concerned.
advice_management: Encourage growth from your employees. Allow them to be heard for the safety and benefit of the company.

summary: "Great learning experience but not for long term career"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Overall, a solid company with talented, smart people. Incredible amount of investment put into developing people with leadership training. Lots of learning and networking opportunities. Great benefits.
cons: Inability to capitalize on talent due to constant "hair on fire" mentality. Nonsensical sense of urgency put on EVERYTHING. Output was not valued. Put in insane number of hours for below-market average salary. Upper management is completely oblivious to struggles in execution due to lack of communication from middle management. Leadership is a clique and constantly changing. Impossible to maintain (and therefore execute on) a cohesive vision.
advice_management: Cut down on the number of "cooks in the kitchen"--it's impossible to complete anything when the end goal changes every other week

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Overall a great experience. The Six Sigma process has really become part if the culture.
cons: The company is very large and it takes a lot to stand out of the crowd.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Great people to work with, competitive and improving benefits (such as paternity leave), flexible schedule and working environment, opportunities to volunteer with different charities
cons: Business moves slow and is too bureaucratic.  There is not enough innovation in product or business operations and the business remains stuck in the "old way of doing things".  Need more changes at the top management level.
advice_management: Get out of your offices and be more hands on

main_text: I have been working at GE  for more than 10 years
pros: Starting to get organized as a software organization. Still a large company.
cons: Large company. You can get lost in the shuffle.
advice_management: Need better definition of teams and need to be more cross functional between software teams.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: If you are a early in your career, this is a great place to be. You will be worked hard. You will have the opportunity to contribute very meaningfully, especially in the smaller business units. Having GE on your resume does not hurt either.
cons: It can be bureaucratic. They are trying to fix this, but I have worked in companies of <15 people. Even in a smaller business, things move very slow. They are trying to get better, so I will give them that.
advice_management: Execution is extremely important, we need doers. But if we take a look at our leadership 100% of them are doers. We need more thinkers at that level, we need folks that will think strategically and 10 moves ahead and live with their wins and mistakes.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: great technology and management. Their processes were clearly defined and easy to follow.
cons: Long hours and tons of paperwork.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: New technology to work with, brilliant people, nice training program
cons: Lots of reviews at different stage delaying product to market

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Good pension if you were in in time.  Good Leaders.  Work life balance.
cons: Bureaucracy.  Competing metrics.  Too many initiatives.  Short term vision.  Continue to cut benefits to provide minimum to retain people.
advice_management: Senior Leadership is good but something is lost in the middle.  We say the right things but we don't practice it.  We try to do too much and nothing gets done.  Focus on key items and don't pile on.  Give people running rules and stay out of their way.  Get rid of the matrix structure and have more focused teams.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Pays good wage in a union shop.
cons: Do not like to work with unions. No training programs  or interaction with said union employees with decades of experience and knowledge needed at this gas and oil site in MA.USA
advice_management: Understanding what it means to learn about a business that you do not know about. Buying something and then not learning what people who, work for you, to make your products and just changing this by buying the cheapest is not always the way to go. Customers are your lifeblood in any industry. Making them mad with your name will surely be your undoing.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: GE used to be a great company 25 years ago. It was innovative, risk takers, open to new ideas and brought good things to life.
cons: Company has tremendous debt. It is almost bankrupt. The leadership is immature. Work load on people who are capable is 3 to 4 times what is out there in the industry. Yes women/men are made leaders who are capable of doing nothing. It is very sad.
advice_management: Step down. You are disgrace to the country and to the share holders. You are leaders because you could not do real work. It is amazing how GE works.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: good people, always changing and learning, company becoming more flexible
cons: work 24/7, lots of type A staff,

main_text: I worked at GE  for less than a year
pros: people are nice, very friendly and positive working environment
cons: I did not see much I dun like here in GE

main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: Pay is very good as well as the benefits. Insurance is low cost as well as vision, dental, and life insurance.
cons: Working on the floor is a cutthroat environment. Most people spend way too much time watching what everyone else is doing and are quick to tell supervisors about anything wrong. Management cares very little about hourly workers. If it were not for the pay, there would not be many who worked there.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Employee relationship to upper management is quite good. Upper management is interested in hearing employee opinions and feedback for continuous improvements. Good training opportunities. Good perks for GE field engineers employed in Energy Services.
cons: Outlook doesn't look good for energy services field engineering. Lack of hiring of field engineers in North America. Low base pay. Difficult to move within the company.
advice_management: There needs to be more opportunities available for internal employee cross training and movement.

main_text: I worked at GE

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Market leader, talented people, outstanding resources
cons: Too much process...most difficult place to work...more difficult than is necessary
advice_management: Understand your real driver to success is not just supporting your EB and above population...but the SPB and below who are the backbone of output and achievement within GE.

main_text: I worked at GE  for more than 5 years
pros: Very supportive of community, volunteer organizations and veterans. There is opportunity to move to other positions every couple of years so you can take on new roles within the company.
cons: Many employees don't help each other out or work as a team. Appliance Park is very run down and the roof leaked in the building I was in. The restrooms and common areas were filthy. It can be very difficult to get things done on the line since working with the Union can be very challenging.
advice_management: Add some type of bonus plan to retain employees. The $100 gift cards don't cut it. More effort needs to be placed in upkeep of the buildings. Simple things like making sure the roof isn't leaking, filthy carpet is replaced and the restrooms are cleaned would go a long way.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: GE values their employees and focuses on employee development! They reward good work and provide opportunities to excel and to succeed.  The team I work with is phenomenal and I'm working on leading edge technology.  After years of working for horrible bosses and mediocre companies, I've finally found my sweet spot!
cons: Only con is GE has decided to sell my company GE Capital---but, even still, executive management has been transparent and has shown such commitment in keep employees and assisting others in making the necessary transition! Still the best company I've ever worked for and hope I never have to leave.
advice_management: Continue to value your greatest assets...employees! You're doing an excellent job!

summary: "GE still a great place to spend a career"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great people who pull together. A much, much, better company to work for than when run by Jack Welch, who ran a sadistic frat house. Terrific opportunities now for diverse candidates. Company is making tough choices to remain relevant.  A good place to work.  You live and die by the numbers and accomplishing your commitments.
cons: Benefits, being rolled back at every opportunity.  Previously GE was the gold standard. Pensions are no longer provided, retirement health care, LTC insurance, other insurances, vacations for executive level have all been cut back or eliminated. Culture is such that working on vacations is not unusual...  Like many companies.

cons: Such a diverse workforce drives challenges in communication and coordination.

cons: Not reconized for good work ethics, graded on a whole team effort, your reviews are based as a team and not an individual.
advice_management: They need to listen to the hard working indivudals.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: great leadership and continuous improvement culture
cons: bonus program only benefits upper management

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: All good people only thing bad is the amount of time spent at the office, hours are grueling
cons: No real cons except for hours and expectations, sometimes unrealistic and managers are tough.
advice_management: Keep pushing but remember people are employees too, don't make them work like dogs.

main_text: I worked at GE  for more than 10 years
pros:
In general very high quality people. However, this includes some of the biggest manipulators and thieves known to mankind. Bungee bosses are quite common, but most of the Leaders are quite brilliant, but often lacking in specialized information.
If you go to GE look for mentors, and do what is necessary to build such relationships. Skill, knowledge and experience is not enough to maintain a career. It is a great place to build your skills though.
cons: See the pros They are two sides of the same coin.
advice_management: Do a better job of finding the corrupt and venal. They don't do the business any good, even if they are good at schmoozing their managers and mentors.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Personally the only benefit I experienced was getting a discount at a hotel for being an employee of GE. Other than that, I didn't consider anything a perk in my program.
cons: The program was completely unorganized.
advice_management: Stay consistent with the training of incoming members.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Most of my co-workers are great in my immediate department.  I love the fitness center, extra events the company does like global community day (you volunteer for a day instead of working), family fun day where they bring in bounce house, face painters, things like that.  GE gives out freebies like LED bulbs and t-shirts frequently.  You can still get appliance discounts even though appliances was sold off.  There is no more employee buying discount on top of the friends and family pricing however.  GE also has a great rewards program where you can nominate your hard working co-workers for gifts cards or cash.
cons:
HR made some bad decisions recently. They froze all salaries for senior level employees for a minimum of 3 years (could be longer) to implement a bonus program.  They did not give you an option to opt out.  The biggest issue is the goals to get a bonus are extremely difficult and conflicting.  They've also decide "co-location" is important.  The problem is they didn't co locate people with who they really work closely with everyday.  They also put folks from real offices (walls, doors, windows) into cubicles that are loud and distracting.  It's a global company, so you are working with people all around the world.  You can't hear them on your conference calls with this awful setup.  

There is no such thing as work-life balance.  I've seems multiple people moved to new positions and the old positions now is responsible for two full time jobs.  I was actually given three.

Supply chain and product management get blamed any time something goes wrong even if it's not their fault.  Top management will talk about what great teams we have in meetings of 300+ people when referring to sales, but in the same breath tell them all how bad supply chain is.  Because the executive treat the team like this, all the folks working for them do the same.  It's never ending and disheartening.  The supply team is full of hard workers who make miracles happen everyday, but are rarely recognized for those efforts.
advice_management: Bring back yearly salary increases.  If you want to add a bonus, no problem.  Do it on top of normal compensation.  Focus on retaining your top talent. Right now you are alienating them and they will leave.  Learn to listen. Your team knows what is best and is smart.  Do what they ask when it comes to things like office location.  Stop making decisions to help one goal metric that completely screws up another.  Stop planning only for this quarter, plan for the entire year.

main_text: I worked at GE

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: GE O&G business has products lines from upstream to downstream and is a huge company. There are a lot of opportunities to learn about the various products and excel. The ratings below are for GE O&G and does not reflect GE at large.
cons: As the O&G business is based on acquisitions, there isn't much transparency between the individual business and there are a lot of silos
advice_management: Cross pollinate individuals between the GE O&G business and also other GE businesses to instill culture. These individuals need to come from various levels senior leaders, managers, tech leaders, manufacturing managers to individual contributors. Immerse this individuals in a few months of training to understand the O&G customers and the products that GE supplies.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time

cons: Communication is lacking at times. In the upper echelon of things communication breaks down and gets convoluted. "A lot of chiefs and not enough Indians" mentality.
advice_management: Communicate better between departments. This is said with a small amount of emphasis, most of the time management is very in tune and knowledgeable about what all their people are doing.

pros:
- You'll work with very bright people and have an opportunity to learn everyday. 

- Their is almost always an opportunity to step into a different role.
cons:
- Bureaucracy can still be a hindrance although improvements are being made. 

- It does seem that politics still win over good work when it's time to give promotions.
advice_management: Reward your top talent with compensation and don't always use attrition to reduce headcount. We don't need to go back to the Welch days of cutting the bottom 10% but we shouldn't continue to allow good talent to leave so easily while lower performing employees are just happy to keep collecting a pay check for little effort..

pros: Good pay and benefits. lots of job mobility if you are willing to relocate. Opportunities to learn many things.
cons: Lots of changes happen in a short period of time (can be good and bad) - reorg, acquisition, sell-off. Too many cheerleaders, not enough doers.
advice_management: Keep employees at their roles at least 2 years. They move around too much and there is a lot of wasted and ineffective knowledge transition and buildup of foundation.
