cons: Very competitive culture, long hours, change is constant
advice_management: none

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: GE has great values and cultures
cons: There are definitely days where you work long hours

summary: "Good experience and good place to work"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Very mature infrastructure. Industry leader in many market segments. Reasonable opportunity for growth. Good but not very good salary.
cons: No stock options. Career growth depends on willingness to switch jobs which often means moving to a different organization and geographic location.
advice_management: None

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Great people. Professional environment everyday
cons: Not much room for improving programming skills if you're a comp sci major

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: It is what you make it.  You own your career.
cons: You must seek out everything.

summary: "Fun and challenging, with a great work environment ."
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Great leadership roles that provides a great work environment.  Great place to move your career to the next level.
cons: May take a while to move your career up.
advice_management: hate to say this but, could be a little more strict, very little accountability.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: You can't beat the leadership skills and breadth of experience you can acquire at GE.  In a huge, successful, global company like GE, you can get the experience in 1 job that could take you 4-5 jobs elsewhere.
cons: Change is a constant. While positive change is good, the changes are often wasted energy as a result of constant organizational movements and new leaders marking their territory or making their presence felt.
advice_management: We need to place a higher premium on the leadership traits that make employees want to rally behind our leaders. I see too many people getting promoted who play good politics and align themselves with the right sponsor, but they often aren't the people you want want to work with or for.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: GE is a great place to work and you will be surrounded by many peers who are among the elite A-type personality performers.  There are tons of opportunities within GE and with it being such a worldy company, the opportunities afforded are almost limitless.
cons: The culture can be a very "sink or swim" mentality, so coming in from the outside can be tough as there is not much guidance or instruction given.  They expect you to figure it out.  Also, in order to really move up in one's career path, you really need to be open to moving around in terms of location in order to open up your available opportunities.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Good opportunity for growth within the company and a great culture to be around. the company does a great job selecting the right people for the right position.
cons: Sometimes the decisions that are made are reactionary and tend to have repercussions that end up hurting the business.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
GE level benefits and payment
Proud employee
cons:
Lost know-hows of manufacturing and technology
Losing in competition
advice_management: Admit the capability

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Rewarded for your work
Treated fairly
Training and cross training
Lots of career options
cons:
bureaucracy
antiquated HR systems and policies
'insider' networks keep individual contributors, the 'reserved ones' out
advice_management:
hope Elux adopts our policies
listen to employees about lessons learned, realistic workloads, schedules, details
less rah rah, more how can I help you do your job better

job_title: Current Employee - Director of Software Engineering
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Great company to learn and grow your career. GE is a Fortune 6 company and builds infrastructures of the world. You will be working on really interesting problems in the industrial space. You will meet the best and the brightest. You will be given the support you will need to succeed.
cons: Has over 300,000 employees and it feel like it. There is a large amount of bureaucracy. Almost 50% of your work time is spent working thru GE processes.
advice_management: Work more like a start up. Take chances. Thin out rigor and internal processes which are "thick and heavy".

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great job, excellent pay and benefits, happy work environment.
cons: closed the shop moved it to Brazil
advice_management: Great group of people to work with

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: reasonable place for growth in career
cons: poor work life balance, long and hard working environment
advice_management: management feel far away

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Ok Salary
Opportunity to move around within company
cons:
Cancelled pension as many companies have done.
Moving jobs overseas to Mexico and India and laying off longtime employees
New PLM software for managing engineering drawings and Bill of Materials is a flop. It takes an incredible amount of effort to get anything new in system and through lengthy approval process. Upper management would be seen as failing if they pulled the plug on PLM after investing so much time and money so they keep putting lip stick on a pig.
Many people like "Edison's" start at GE and are promoted through the ranks, they have no real world experience and only know the GE way which often lacks common sense and can be frustrating to forward thinkers.
Managers are afraid of their boss so no one is willing to rock the boat to make the company better.


Guess how many Electrical Engineers are at General Electric ... Not many! And most of them are not US citizens.

Stay away from GE Engineering!
advice_management: Get an outside consulting company to come in and evaluate  what works and what doesn't. Then listen to what they say. If you continue to keep your head in the sand then you will get more of the same and the company will head further down the drain until it is too late to right the ship.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Large company time off, vacation
cons: politics and too slow. lack of technical acumen
advice_management: find quality people and get out of the way

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Pay is decent and hours are great.
cons: Not a job that requires too much imagination!

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Smart people, heavy industries, culture, training
cons: Low salary, location, office, managers
advice_management: Not much

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: great for company values and culture. a unique place for professional development and growth
cons: Long working hours, but tipically flexible

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: If you like to challenge yourself working on fascinating problems that matter, this is the place for you. GE is loaded with some of the best and brightest minds in the world.  Here you can champion an idea and take it all the way to market if you wish, or become a world expert in the area of your choosing.  Be prepared to work hard, this is an aggressive "type A" workplace, and you will reap the benefits if you can hang with the pack.
cons: The culture can be a bit conceded and entitled (We are GE, look how great we are, people love us for our name).  With all the great things, GE is a large company and weighs "risk" very seriously; this can make the company feel slow and bureaucratic, but if you understand the machine you are working in, the behavior makes sense.
advice_management: Keep up the good work, you don't stay one of America's top companies for decades without knowing what you are doing. The corporate education programs are the best I have ever seen... Keep making them available to all employees.  Lastly, remember who you are, make sure the corporate strategies work for the market you are in by listening to the experts in those businesses.

summary: "A company that makes you feel proud."
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
GE is a company that is on the leading edge of technology and innovation.  Every day I worked at GE I felt proud that I was working for a company that developed class-leading technology to address global needs around the world.  You truly feel like you are making a difference in the world around you.

GE is also great advocate for flex-work arrangements.  Although the hours are often long, and travel is sometimes extensive (depending on your role), it was comforting to know that I could adjust my work location to accomodate my family needs.
cons: As a publically traded company, GE is often forced to respond too quickly to the reactions of Wall Street.  In my time at GE I have seen wave after wave of layoffs of some very valuable and experienced people just so that the business could report better numbers for the year.  The result is that those remaining face a dramatic increase in workload with no decrease in expectations.   Then when the market turns, as it always does, there is not enough staff to support the growth.
advice_management: In a perfect world, it would be great if GE could set more realistic expectations with Wall Street.  Since we know that is impossible in today's economy, it would be recieved well by the employees if GE demonstrated a little more loyalty and support to their employees.  Award positive behaviour more rigourously, better communicate if changes are coming, do a better job of giving employees opportunities for advancement.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: The pay when you are in this position is good.
cons: It is very difficult to advance from this position.
advice_management: If your talented people cannot advance and grow within the company you will loose your better people.

summary: "You either like it or can't stand it"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: Good company, there are opportunities if you work hard and look for them.
cons: Too much bureaucracy, not very personal.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: It a great place to work, because you are exposed to vast technologies and a lot of subject matter experts that you can learn from to further you career.  Also, the company has a great set of values.
cons: Since it is a large corporation, there is a lot of bureaucracy when trying to get your job done.  Also, executives are very demanding, and due to this reason their is a poor work/life balance on entry level and mid-level managers.
advice_management: Need to create a better work/life balance for non executives employees.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: very laid back company. as long as you are working and productive you don't have to worry about harsh working conditions or ridiculous hours
cons: the pay is not that great. yes you can stay home on a Friday and not put it in but at the end of the day the pay is very low.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: People are above average performers
cons: Appliance business is terrible.  No way to survive

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Nothing whatsoever!  This company only cares about their bottom line and not the employees that help them achieve it!
cons: Profits over workers, period!  Management is the absolute worst for this company!
advice_management: Learn how to actually treat your employees!

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Only good thing which I can think of is employees are pushed very hard so they learn a whole lot more
cons: Not a great company to work. Tons and tons and tons of bureaucracy. Literally we had meetings for meetings for meeting.
advice_management: I have given the management several inputs earlier and it all went to garbage. So I dont think its necessary

summary: "GE is a good place to gain experience that you will be rewarded for elsewhere."
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Very safety orientented.  Pay was better than many in the industry.  Benefits were good (health, dental, 401k, etc)
cons: Promotion / hiring practices inconsistent with stated corporate policies and values.  Limited advancement opportunity for experienced employees.
advice_management: Weed out the underperformers in the technical and management roles in order to create a safer and more consistent work environment where the hard working and passionate can thrive.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: State of the art technologies. diversity, many talented people
cons: too big. sometime bureaucratic. total compensation seems a little bit of low.

summary: "It has been a great experience, I have been employed here for 25 years."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: The atmosphere is good. The people you work with are like family.
cons: Until recently the company tried to show the employees a caring attitude, but lately that has changed.
advice_management: Remember the people who sacrificed family, personal interests, and energy to make the brand great.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Powerful brand, great benefits
cons: Appliances industry very unstable

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: good pay and benefits, 401k match
cons: sale of divison to electrrolux
advice_management: Treat all employees the same.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: GE has enormous growth potential for anyone who has innovative ideas for growth and simplification.  Flexible work arrangements are available if approved by your manager.
cons: In some cases depending on the project longer hours may be required of course you do have the ability to log on from home if you are a parent of younger children.

summary: "Awesome company with very driven employees and opportunities to excel."
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Good pay.  Good colleagues.  Good training.  Good benefits
cons: The expectations are very high.  You have to work hard every day at everything you do.  You do have to be careful to not loose your work life balance.
advice_management: Work life balance is easy to loose...sadly

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Good benefits, facilities, HR, and professional mobility.  New job every 3 years.
cons: Old boys club, rigid culture, lots of people drinking GE Kool-aid

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: The pro's of working at GE are getting GE on your resume because it has such wide recognition.  The salary is just ok and raises are low but it's comparable to most companies.
cons: GE tries so hard to be more efficient they don't stop to ensure if the projects they are doing make sense. Leadership and employee work ethic varies greatly in that some people are loaded up with work while others are not. Leadership is self serve and middle management is the dumping ground for all things from the bottom up and the top down.  If you are a worker you will have zero life balance and you'll get maybe a .5 or 1% more raise than your co worker who did the bare minimum.
advice_management: GE is a self serve culture and does not foster collaboration among peers.  HR does not engage with staff and there is no talent management.  The employees that stay there are the long term ones that got a pension and are no longer productive contributors.  There is nothing to keep the bright, hardworking and high potential employee there so after 3 years more of that talent leaves.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Very smart people.  Beautiful campus and high tech equipment.  Cutting edge research.
I learned a lot during my time at GRC.
cons: My manager's expectations were not clear.  There is a lot of people protective/defensive about what they do.  They don't want to let things go.  There was limited growth opportunity where I worked.
advice_management: clarity and honesty.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Benefits are great! Career development
cons: People don't change jobs, they change managers.
advice_management: Never forget to constantly give those hard working employees a pat on the back

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Friendly people, good work environment, on-site cafeteria and gym, fosters a sense of community
cons: East Cleveland isn't the greatest location to work, some internal politics, salaries not amazing, over taxation by being in that part of Ohio

main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: Good company with plenty of opportunity for advancement and movement.  Benefits plans have decreased dramatically in recent years, which is a big negative.  If you are already with the company a number of years you feel stuck to see it through to retirement, but if you don't have many years in or were hired in after the big changes to benefits and pension then it's a good company to have on your resume and move on.
cons:
HR is very powerful within GE.  You need to be very careful not to make an enemy of someone in HR because they can make life miserable for you.
No real training opportunities and management is unable to hold people accountable especially in the union environments.
advice_management: HR and Legal need to get a back bone and start holding people accountable, especially in the union environments.

summary: "Great company to work ,  provide unique training opportunities"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: Constant learning opportunities, to upgrade  your skillsets
cons: You have always have to be on your toes

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Overall the company was good to employees. They treated everyone equal which was nice. Perks were pretty good like 401k but health insurance was high.
cons: Cons were that the pay was a little below the average for the area.  Huge company so it was pretty easy to get lost when you come in at an entry level employee
advice_management: Promotions were few and far between.

summary: "A terrible place to work if you want a family and work balance."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Opportunities/. Nothing else good to say about this place.
cons: Politics, Corporate America at its finest. They expect round the clock contact and work from emplloyees
advice_management: Realize these are people that have families

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years

summary: "GE is a great company to work for. GE focuses on large world problems that matters."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: The company invests in continuous education, leadership, collaboration, and lots of operational rhytms. There is a lot of internal hiring opportunities depending in your functional skills. Great place to grow from a functional role in to a leadership role.
cons: The organization structure is matrix and demands constant internal alignment and reporting, taking time that could be invested with customers. There are a lot of opportunities to simplify processes and reporting structure, especially to enable the company become more competitive to incubate and launch new products and services.
advice_management: Need a more entrepreneurial culture that embraces risk and learn from mistakes. Goals and Objectives should be simpler yet ambitious with direct line of sight to customer benefits and then financial returns. Customer comes first!

cons: People who lack performance are kept in their positions with no recourse. Personal growth is held to a minimum or non-exsistant. They promote people with serious integrity issues! and promote doing things wrong as long as it is out the door. Excessively long hours and family becomes a second thought, so if you value family time this is not a company to work for.
advice_management: Hold Managers and the so called "Leaders" accountable for their lack of performance! There is no prescience of a culture although GE claims "Culture Change Works", culture change only works if there is follow through. The only culture change is the lack of culture!

summary: "Good place to work and gain experience"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: GE is a big company with many different divisions, so you can gain exposure to many areas of expertise.  Many of the people are very smart, work hard, and are friendly.  If you need help with something, people are usually willing to stop what they are doing to help you.
cons: While the company has many divisions, it is not very easy to move between those divisions; it's almost as complicated as finding a whole new job.  Promotions are scarce, and the managerial track is more highly valued and compensated than the technical track.
advice_management: Focus more on empowering the individual contributor.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: All the good things that come with working at a big company! Great facility, great infrastructure, well established process for almost everything.
cons: Open office is one of the greatest drawbacks. It doesn't give you enough focus on the tasks at hand unless you like all the distraction that comes with an open office. GE brings with the heirarchy of old school big organizations. It's not a place if you enjoy working in a startup environment. It brings together all the cons of a large organization with the cons of a startup while it should really be the other way around bringing the pros together.

summary: "GE IT - Good to start your career, or if you want a stable job, not a great place if you want to change the world"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros:
- Some facilities are simply superb..I worked at the state-of-the-art AMSTC in Detroit which had all the gizmos, private lake, nice cafe, labs..
- You can grow well if you are good and are around for a few years.
- Managers are very helpful (Director and CIO) since I reported first to Director, then to CIO
- They at least say that you should take risks and try new stuff
cons:
- Really BAD health plan with a VERY HIGH deductible, meaning you pay tens of thousands of dollars deductible before ins starts paying a penny
- To get promoted esp to Director/Leader level, you need be there 5+ years, so don't expect stellar growth like in silicon valley
- Inspite of all the talk about new tech, taking risks, IT is still a support function to business. At the end of the day, what the business head wants, goes. Very different from a software product company, where we techies rule.
advice_management: GE makes a ton of profit, how much will it really cost to provide a good health plan to employees?

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Great pay. Great experience. Friendly coworkers and managers.
cons: A bit more bureaucratic than I would have liked. Needed to wait for 1 and a half week to use a furnace for safety reasons.
advice_management: Keep up the great work!

summary: "GE has dropped from the place to work to the place to leave in just the past few years."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: The GE name is still prestigious on a resume, and from the enthusiastic responses from prospective candidates that keep flooding the job boards, it might appear to be business as usual at the great GE of the past.  But that's not correct.
cons:
In the past few years, the culture at GE Appliances in Louisville has changed from one where employees truly believed that if they worked hard and did right by the company, the company would do right by them, to one where we feel like we are being actively being mislead by management.  

New cost cutting measures are launched  so often it is hard to keep up with them, and each reduction makes the job a harder by adding a burden or removing a benefit from employees and customers.  These changes are always announced with happy talk and pitched as improvements, in the form of easy to read elevator speeches that seem obviously written by a PR company.

Rather than call it what it is - when something is taken from you, it is a reduction in services, quality, benefits, and value.  So why can't they just stop sugar coating everything and acting like we are stupid.  

In the past week, GE and Electrolux jointly announced that GE was in talks with Electrolux to purchase our beloved appliance division, lock stock and barrel with Appliance Park Kentucky.   Even that announcement was written to dance around the truth, the announcement claimed that nothing was certain and the two companies were only involved in casual discussions, when the opposite is true.  

So now all the cost cutting and happy talk of the past few years makes sense:  we've been running on bubble gum and rubber bands to lower expenses so GE Appliances would be worth more.  With that spin removed, any fifth grader can see the truth of this situation:  what will happens next is that our loyal workers, most with more than a decade of service, will get flushed into an uncertain and dismal future just so that stockholders, who own stock in GE but not in the GE Appliance division, can make a few bucks while all this is going down and GE is continuing to apply "MADE IN AMERICA"  logos to all the appliances rolling out of Appliance Park, Kentucky.  

This division of  GE is the company that Thomas Edison formed in 1890, and Jeff Immelt is selling it to a company from Sweden that makes low quality appliances with bad service records.  They want to buy GE Appliances to fix their own problems.  But it never works like that, ask yourself where Maytag is after it was purchased by Whirlpool.  They still make a few Maytag appliances, but it is a shadow of what it used to be.  

My advice to job seekers:  Unless you are coming for a few months for an internship, I think you'd be crazy to come here now.  I probably don't need to tell you what happens when two companies are combined into one - but i'll give you a hint:  layoffs.
advice_management: When you look back on your life, I hope you are able to forgive yourself and find peace for what will happen to the Louisville economy after Electrolux buys GE Appliances.  This is an American tragedy in the making.  And if you are in management and you didn't actively participate in the sale, instead you just stood by, you are equally responsible for failing to lift a finger to prevent harm to good people who trusted you and this company.  But I can no longer stomach this, so you'll have to eat this sin without me.

summary: "Big Company, Big Opportunities, Easy to get lost"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Company is large, but don't let that discourage you from applying. Knowing someone internally will always help move your resume upward on the stack. People within GE rely heavily on connections (internally and externally).
cons: Can't really think of any. The company does a good job of keeping everyone informed and aware of company goals and accomplishments.
advice_management: Keep focus on the end goal of leaving the Capital/Money business and moving more into the infrastructure, technologies industries. At it's core, GE is really a software company backing the many products that it develops (trains, airplane engines, gas turbines, etc.).

summary: "Great opportunities  but it is a very large organization"

cons: Like many large organizations, it was difficult to change direction to adjust to market needs.   Focus of the business is much more on the company than the customer.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: there is a lot of flexibility
cons: they may tell you that there is noglass ceiling... dont believe it

summary: "Not what it's cracked up to be"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Many options for plant sites
cons: They expect 12 hour days every day.  They do everything they can to cut corners (cost over quality all the time).  I have even been told to accept parts that did not meet the specifications many times.  Their strategies are all short term.  (get it done fast, we will fix it later).  They will not promote you unless you have a lot of GE experience (they do not recognize outside GE experience).  It is run much like a cult.  You have to drink the Koolaide.
advice_management: Get your heads out of the GE corporate world and see what the real world is like.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Great company and great people.  Lots of career development opportunities.  Make sure to develop your network.
cons: I can't think of any.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros:
*Located Near Boston
*End Products were interesting
cons:
*Long hours expected without compensation
*Very slow promotion
*Very small salaries
*Pay freezes and small raises
advice_management: I saw two people get fired via email. I was micromanaged by no less than three managers who had to ask me about projects that they should have been asking each other about. There is a huge breakdown of communication with management. Corporate only comes down to speak to the engineers when something is terribly wrong, and even then they usually make them wait in a conference room for no less than 30 minutes before arriving.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Good pay, benefits, challenging, stable
cons: you will get hurt on big appliances if you don't ask for a two man help

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Different industries, lots to do, job can be as exciting as you want it to be
cons: Lots of overhead and BS

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Lots of opportunity for exposure to the cutting edge technology.  Full ownership of program or projects.
cons: Because of the enormity of the organization, it is sometimes difficult to implement major changes and improvements in processes.
advice_management: Opportunities for promotions may be somewhat limited.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: I have been working at GE in San Ramon for over a year and have witnessed unprecedented growth. While most of the product work is in the build phase, one can see the imminent monetization phase materializing pretty soon. It will the place the company in an unimaginable growth trajectory. You would want to be a part of this explosion - work on state of the art technology, solve problems at an amazing scale and get rewarded. Great benefits to go with it
cons: No upside for the employee in growth
advice_management: The company should follow the west coast trend and allow employees who contribute to this growth, benefit from it - introduce RSUs.

summary: "Not a good place to work for"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Salary above industry average. Moving around different functions may be easier given the size of the company.
cons: Nepotism, backstabbing, and discrimination ran rampant in the GE division I worked. Management is blatant about "company over family" philosophy. You have to be a "GE guy" otherwise you are out. The stock price was $50 fifteen years ago and now is $25, which truly reflects the direction of the company, going downward.
advice_management: Find a job outside GE and you may find good life after GE as I did.

summary: "A great place to work if you're old and need to provide for your family"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
- Great benefits
- Not very demanding hours
cons:
- Pay is directly proportional to how many years experience you have (not skill)
- Initiating change is difficult, border-lining impossible
- Product owners do not have technical expertise, which causes problems
- Money is wasted on un-necessary items, which could otherwise be better spent
advice_management: Simplify everything, focus on our own internal software, pay our talented employees more (lest they keep leaving), and stop wasting money.

summary: "Stable and respected company, hard to be in an acquired company and reap the benefits."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: GE is a well established company on the leading edge of innovation.
cons: If you are in a smaller acquired company that isn't a long time, legacy GE company or headquarters you don't see as much opportunity as you would sitting in a different location.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: exposure to leadership, training, good pay
cons: big company so there is a lot of bureaucracy, locations could be better
advice_management: When hiring/interviewing, let prospective candidates know about the work locations that they'll likely work in and where most of the jobs will be off-program. Some assignment leaders are better than others and having a good assignment leader makes all the difference if a rotation ends up being a good one or not. The screening process to make sure assignment leaders are good enough should be more rigorous.

main_text: I have been working at GE

main_text: I have been working at GE

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: They give you a good amount of responsibility which will helps you to grow professionally pretty fast. The people are really nice and they treat you as family.
cons: Overall a good company but not so good with organization and you have to be prepared to deal with a great amount of stress because sometimes things don't go as planned.

summary: "Interesting and challenging projects, but lots of bureaucracy and red tape to get things done"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Big, challenging projects; Opportunities to travel/see the world to install/repair products and educate customers; Work flexibility, depending on role and manager; Plenty of training and opportunity for advancement if you are identified as a high performer
cons: No real organizational structure, nobody tends to know who/what department should be making decisions or taking ownership; internal IT applications/infrastructure are outdated and frequently inhibit working efficiently.
advice_management: Clearly identify your organizational structure and define the roles each department plays.  Make sure that ownership and the strategy behind it is communicated to your employees; the employees need to know who is going to make decisions.

summary: "Good company and department. Benefits are good."
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: You will be recognized for good work and also for not so good work. You do need to perform to do well as General Electric.
cons: Fairly old school management style; focus on short term goals perhaps in spite of long term success. Systems could use some updating.

summary: "High stress/churn but great people and development opportunities"

pros: Employee development, challenging but rewarding environment
cons: Leadership often seems very disconnected with each other

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years

cons: going to SAP, moving away from the businesses that build the company, short term view to make the monthly and quarterly numbers with taking into account how it impacts future results.
advice_management: listen to the voice of the customer

cons:

Like other big corporations political and very structured

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Excellent training, intelligent and friendly co-workers, good managers (for the most part), good co-operation amongst team members, semi-relaxed work environment.
cons: High bureaucracy, average salary, too many processes, lack of opportunities to advance career, average medical benefits, and retaining low performing employees.
advice_management: Less bureaucracy, less complicated and time-wasting processes, less value-added work, and more empowerment to the employees who are actually doing the bulk of the work.

pros: Good training, fast paced, good management
cons: Not enough travelling, not enough bonuses

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Great company for using your imagination to do what is right. New blood and direction has sparked a flurry of motion to bring GE ahead in technology.
cons: The internal systems are out of date and tedious
advice_management: Keep reaching for the future.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: If you have the skills and continue to agree to accept more responsibility, you can move up.
cons: You have to prove yourself for a quite a while before you can move up. You may also have to make opportunities for yourself rather than anyone handing them to you because you've excelled. Company culture of people who actually do the work is caught up in a lot of CYA--lots of employees scared of reprimand, etc...
advice_management: Gain a better understanding of the work your employees are required to do.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Lots of support to get your work done.
cons: Easy to get trapped in specific role
advice_management: Communicate major changes early and better

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Benefits excellent.  Time off policy very good.  Able to research and apply for positions throughout the company in all divisions and subsidiaries.  Leadership training very good.  GE employees are looked at by other companies and recruiters.
cons:
Very high expectations so be ready to put in some long days.  In some areas there is management overkill.
Too much training overlap in some GE business.
advice_management: Stay in tune with your co-workers.  Remember they work for GE, not you.

summary: "Like working with customers and fixing the equipment."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: I feel like my own boss when dealing with customers and scheduling service calls.
cons: The constant 24/7 dealing with all the metrics which you end up doing after hours and on vacation.
advice_management: Make sure what we're getting measured on is what is going to improve the company.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: GE offers growth and learning to launch your career.
cons: GE can get very political.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: GE invests in it's finance employees with programs such as FMP and Corporate Audit Staff. The portofolio of GE businesses across both the Capital and Industrial industries is limitless and a core set of GE finance skills enables long-term employees move among them.
cons: The salary and benefits GE offers do not match the number of hours finance employees typically work. The company is pushing to make work easier by simplifying processes, but in such a large company, nothing is ever simple.
advice_management: Employees are not given the freedom to make decisions and be held accountable to those decisions. You continually have to go through layers and layers of approvals. If something doesn't pan out, the person on the bottom is held accountable even if leaders have approved their decision but have done nothing to help clear roadblocks.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Leverage multi-national staff and resources, good process and policies in place
cons: Leadership assigned to healthcare products and development is a little out of touch with the industry needs.  Sometimes decisions seem arbitrary, and policy decisions change priorities often
advice_management: Work diligently to complete products and ship on time.  Innovation is not always encouraged.

summary: "Invests in their employees and has great talent"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: GE has the resources to move mountains.  The vacation time is great.  Salary is very good.  Internal training and career development course offerings are excellent.
cons: The company's structure is very matrixized.  It often can be cumbersome and complicated to get things done.
advice_management: Continue the efforts on simplification.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Highly Technical Environment and good learning environment
cons: need to take care of promotions
advice_management: need to improve promotions

summary: "Good place to work , then one day the axe just fell..."
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Some truly awesome and amazing people work here who genuinely care about other people and getting everyone to work together as a team to succeed.
cons: During promotional windows it was do or die on almost every program and pet project dreamed up by management.  If you weren't able to sign up key customers, you were then moved to a target list and labelled as an "underachiever" who needed to be put on a performance improvement plan and quickly shown the door.
advice_management: Congrats on driving your stars out the door and into the arms of your competition!

summary: "Pretty good company over all to work for"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: After almost 15 years for this company I have learned many things and have made many friends. The benefits were good and the money wasn't bad.
cons: Favoritism, it was hard getting a promotion because I found out it was not so much of what you knew, it was who you knew.
advice_management: You should promote people who deserve the job, not hire someone off the street that has no idea of the job. Also you should pay temps more and hire the good ones sooner to be able to keep quality people.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Fun work - culture of integrity.
cons: Despite its large size, always seemed stretch for resources.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: The FMP training program is awesome, you get exposure to lots of financial tools and materials. Great competitive culture to succeed. In general most people are helpful. Work hard, play hard the managers are great especially with time-off compensation and happy hour splurge after a rough quarter end/month end close. Truly enjoyed my experience with GE.
cons: Office politics, gossiping and back stabbing from some female managers I witnessed in the Charlottesville VA location. Worst unfriendly location I ever worked at within GE.
advice_management: Some locations just seem very far removed from overall corporate culture goal. promote uniform change.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Office culture is usually good but can be dependent on site/business; market leader; ability to continue growing; training; gaining a good "toolkit"; continuous evaluation and ability to change jobs for those that are good performers; good people to work with and for
cons: Depending on the function, may need to be mobile to work your way up in the company. This is difficult if you want to stay in one location.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Great smart people.  Cares about developing employees
cons: Very competitive, constant work, very corporate

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Big company, lots of area to move up, great culture, reward hard work and willingness to grow and advance your career.
cons: Cheap. They're cheap.  In every way possible.
advice_management: Pay more.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Diversity growth and opportunities for overall development. Emphasis on leadership and quality. Overall a good place to work
cons: huge corporation and visibility is a concern. Some businesses do not have clear path forward.Overall a good place to work
advice_management: Overall a good place to work with some improvements on training and mentor ship. train young talent and provide opportunities to diversify

summary: "GE is one of the best places to work"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Very good company for long term career development and growth. They invest in employee development and have plenty of job opportunities to challenge you over your career.
cons: salary increases are low unless you change jobs frequently (2-3 years), can be very bureaucratic and has pockets of if it's not invented hear, it has no value.
advice_management: need to value long term employees more. They have significant work experience that can avoid future issues

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Great Place, Flexible,friendly,you can learn a lot, fast paced
cons: moderate utilization of resources leading to pressure in a few departments
advice_management: Great Going!Utilize resources to the best.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: Good learning opportunities. Good work life balance, work from home whenever need be, HSA, DFSA etc are good. They have an office almost any where in the world. Good support for new mothers.
cons: If you get stuck with a bad manager, there is nothing to save you. Raises are very less. No bonuses. Need to manage up, down sideways. If you accomplish one thing, you have to tell 20 people for it to get noticed.
advice_management: There are so many managers at GE its hard to give one advice that will apply for all.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Laid back for the most part. Not physically demanding. Easy to work with if you need a day off. Not the same in all areas of the plant though. The test position will set you up for better careers outside the company.
cons: Crappy advancement, pay is not at all adequate for the job responsibilities. Retirement sucks medical is mediocre how ever dental is great haven't used vision yet. Upper management gives the raises and good reviews to their buddies not the hardest working.
advice_management: Stop bringing people down from the Erie plant before giving the Texas employees a chance to advance.

summary: "Getting worse.   Just a cog in a massive wheel"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Fun job sometimes.   Travel is good.   Bennies are good
cons: Management doesn't know what it's doing.   Too many layers.   No promoting up through ranks.   HR has too much control and nepotism runs rampant in certain ethnic groups.
advice_management: You have plenty of ex military running this company.    You didn't have dotted line managers in the service and you didn't lead battalions with leaders who hadn't served in those companies so why do it here?

summary: "Good place for people with no skills and moral but bad one for professionals"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: To build your career forf the cost of others
cons: No promotion for real professional
advice_management: no advice

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Great resources and young culture.
cons: Company name hard to spell.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: pay and good benfit  and culture
cons: work life balance, alot things to do
advice_management: good job

summary: "GE Commercial Distribution Finance - Opportunity with challanges"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Interesting integration work after GE acquired and until 2008 a very vibrant and expanding business.  A strong culture of governance and budget control.  GE provides opportunity to move between divisions.
cons: Extreme use of off-shore IT contractors and contentious relationship between PMO and the rest of the IT organization.  Business fell flat in 2008 creating a stressful environment and  lay-offs.
advice_management: Keep an eye on the culture not just the bottom line.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Fast paced environment working on some of the most interesting projects with talented individuals.  Very open to R&D activities and also to implementing projects based on good ideas that folks have.
cons: Long hours and very little focus on long term incentive plans.  Sometimes your voice will get lost in the crowd without senior leadership support.
advice_management: Focus on retaining top talent and celebrating the successes of your teams - even the small ones.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: People, culture, challenge, benefits, and training
cons: work life balance, uncertainty of hours
advice_management: Greta management!

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
-ability to work from home
-great coworkers
- laid back office environment
cons:
- management constantly changes
- continuous restructuring

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Lots of opportunity and latitude to develop and expand roles and responsibilities
cons: Need sponsorship to be successful

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
People, first and foremost. Every person I have worked with has been willing to help on whatever I ask. The people are smart, courteous, and professional. GE is good at identifying talented individuals and training them for the next level. They have internal professional development courses from the individual contributor level all the way to CEO. Their leadership programs are second to none.

The work I do is challenging and mentally rewarding. I feel that my contributions truly make a difference to my team and my organization. Management is always supportive of me expanding my role.

If you are willing to put in the work, you can move up in this company; it is a true meritocracy. Also, there are 300k+ people working around the world in businesses ranging from lighting to jet engines. Chances are that if you want to do something, it is being done in GE.
cons:
Compensation. If you are truly excellent at what you do, chances are you can get paid more to do it somewhere else. I weigh that against stability and future advancement opportunities. Travel has been cut substantially to contribute to shareholder value. Positions are also being eliminated to simplify the company. 

There is a perception that the company is old, outdated, and slow. People often talk about it like a huge ship: stable, but slow to react to change. This is true, but changing slowly as the company looks to lean processes.
advice_management:
Your employee review system is great. You know who your top contributors are, so pay them accordingly. The attrition rate is particularly high for people out of training programs. They acquire skills and leave the company for more money after a few years.

The company values are right on, and I am glad that compensation is based on values and performance.

summary: "Great opportunity to move between GE businesses"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Excellent structure in place to train employees.  Lots of opportunity to move between different GE businesses.
cons: Can be difficult to navigate the matrix organizational structure.
advice_management: Simplify processes and make sure everyone is engaged.

summary: "I've spent the last five years at GE and the culture of success and the senior leaders to be inspiring."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Working around people who want to succeed.  In sports terms, no one walks.  Especially in a crisis, everyone comes together for solutions to delight the customer.  The culture of compliance and integrity is greater than any business I've even heard about.
cons: The path to executive is opaque and can seem aribtrary.  Joining from the outside (excluding a leadership program) means you will be shelved for years before being allowed on the corporate ladder.  Titles are misleading, but there is an obsession with them from within the functional ranks.
advice_management: Continue to invest in all of the people who want to make the company successful.  Welcome those that have learned about GE later in their career and want to be a part of the solution.

summary: "great place to work overall - lots of great leaders"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: great work environment, smart people, tons of upward mobility
cons: pay below market average, can be easy to get lost.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Great company to develop career skills
cons: Diversified yet  difficult to break into cross functional businesses

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: GE provides a lot of experience in a short amount of time.  They offer the ability to work from remote to some. The pay is competitive.
cons: The major con is that the amount of output expected in the current culture will drown you.  Work a standard eight hour day, then go home log in and work more.  Sadly that isn't even enough time in the majority of cases to get everything done.  There is such a strong focus on reducing US headcount that the employees who still have jobs are being overworked.
advice_management: Provide some open communication. Especially in situations where rumors are flying being open & honest would save a lot of headaches.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: The company is very good at allowing work-life balance, and offers great training courses. The pay is equivalent to the averages.
cons: Very complex company politics that usually hinder performance. The company politics usually cause information to be slowed and sometimes not transferred as it should be. This can be very stressful for everyone with tight deadlines that have metrics tied to your performance. This is a large company so that disconnect can be expected, but it seems to be so large that it may never be corrected.
advice_management: Clean out the systems to have one uniform communication. Allow the employees/managers to set the metrics that best show their performance. Have dedicated facilities for high priority tasks that only the EB has access to. Realize that the cookie cutter roll-outs which the employees, IT, and interfacing parties are going to follow is not always better than what was done before.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: A lot of the people are really good, really helpful, and know their jobs well.
cons: Though GE talks a lot about its HR processes (EMS, training), some managers ignore completely it for years, and HR does nothing.  Until one days 5 years have passed, and you learn your career has been stymied by a dysfunctional manager talking behind your back.

main_text: I worked at GE part-time for less than a year
pros: none, this job was crappy
cons: sales job, make outbound calls,
advice_management: care about employees, give better hourly pay

summary: "Great Company to help grow your career from the beginning."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: They'll invest in you if you invest in them. For early-career, I think this is one of the better Company's to work for. They're intern programs can be really good if you're lucky to get on a good team and their leadership programs are unparalleled if you're accepted.
cons: Things are always changing around here with new re-orgs at least twice a year. Sometimes that makes it hard to plan your 3-5 year career goals.

summary: "A workstation position in which I assisted with Accounts Payable responsibilities as the firm transitioned to SAP."
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Friendly atmosphere, ambitious employees, strong communication among employees working on projects together
cons: Lack of mobility in departments, lack of clear cut responsibilities in several positions (overlapping duties)
advice_management: Push for more defined roles and precise workflow management in the finance departments.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: good name on your resume
cons: long working hours without compensation, bad management, you can only see your manager once a year if there is budget. Extreme pressure to the employee for maximum benefit. If they refuse working long hours, the manager told you " you are not worth the money" then you get fired. I have not seen any place with so many unhappy people.
advice_management: Do something honest so that you can keep the talent.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: There are many positives about the company.  Integrity and a constant interest to 'get it right', to do the right thing, abounds throughout management and the company, for example.  The company is always seeking to do things better, improve, innovate.  Rotations around the company are encouraged and expected, which keeps things exciting for employees, is a key retention tool, and supports constant learning throughout one's career.
cons: Location can be the biggest drawback, especially if you want to work in New York City or do not have an interest in moving every few years for your next rotation.

summary: "Severe issues in Platform team - Nepotism and Unprofessional conduct is common."
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: GE as a company is good. They hired the worst possible Sybase rejects to lead the platform. If GE hires people with people skills this could be a good place to work.
cons:
People in manager positions have no clue what a platform is. 
Serious lack of people skills. 
There is widespread behavior bordering ethical misconduct. 
You will be *told* to work on weekends and not paid for it.  If you don't there will repercussions.
advice_management:
Go beyond fancy numbers in ppt. Management is about people and not about a cherry picked numbers on a ppt slide. 
Address serious lack of integrity.  
Software is about human capital. Focus on employees who get the work done.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: You are surrounded by many intelligent people, managers are usually very experienced, and you learn a great deal vs. other companies.  Development is top notch and second to none.  I would say that I learned more at this company than where I am currently.  I worked hard but learned a great deal.
cons: If you aren't on the fast track in certain key leadership programs or working in an area they need expertise (Tax, Legal, any government facing compliance role) you will be underpaid.  Most employees will be paid less than market, and there is no incentive to stay with the company if you aren't in the select group they pick their leaders from and don't breathe and live the culture.  Work life balance in finance was nonexistent.  Unfortunately, the company for many is a resume builder.
advice_management: Management knows that the company's culture is so strong that they can retain most of their top leaders and develop up and coming leaders who will stay; the other employees who are not on that track will leave once they learn that they are not compensated fairly.  In order to retain your employees, especially the younger generations, you will need to compensate them more.  As the economy improves and younger workers show less and less company loyalty, relying on your culture won't cut it.

summary: "Not what you would think it would be for a company that size"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Work with some nice people, nice office environment
cons: Salaries are much lower than comparable work at other large companies and in the years I have been with the company, the benefits are not that great. Several managers and other employees have all come from the same employer, and the management really has no idea how the business really works. Some management definitely has favorites, as to some things that employees are allowed to do with no repercussions but if others did the same they would be out the door
advice_management: Management needs to really learn the business and understand the jobs well enough that they could do them if they had to, stop playing favorites and come through with rewarding those who put forth the extra efforts.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: There is a tremendous amount of opportunity, IF you know how to work the careers.ge.com system.
cons: No such thing as work life balance.

summary: "Good company, cares about  products produced and how they are maintained."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Excellent learning opportunities, Health and safety are number one priorities.
cons: Big learning curve if new to industry
advice_management: Have more ears regarding what lower employees say, overall good management

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Pay, Good health benefits, Experience
cons: Nothing I would have changed
advice_management: None

summary: "Corporate Cyber Security - Great roles and technology but poorly organized and biased management"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Good to work for such a large a diverse company.  Company updates are interesting.  Cyber security roles are challenging and some of the technology is good.
cons: Very buttoned down work environment.  Corporate culture is ruthless!  Not a fun place to work.  Expectations are set too high.  Very political work environment.  Affirmative Action Plan for women in management is in full swing.  Managers are so worried about clawing their way to the top, they step on employees and contractors whenever they can.
advice_management: Some changes in management have already been made through attrition and reassignments.  Maybe someday they will all get on the same page.  In the meantime, employees will suffer.  The better leaders left for better jobs in other companies already, that says something about the opportunities and people wanting to stay there!!!

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Good opportunity to learn new skills
cons: Too many mgmt layers and no growth

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: the people in the organization and top quality  and the day-to-day atmosphere and the culture is great. great for young, hungry employees
cons: not enough upward mobility and the compensation is on the lower end of the spectrum. decent place to start out though
advice_management: i would advise management to think longer term and try to develop talent on a more detailed basis

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Work / life balance is good. Overall good place to work.
cons: More management -  less technicians, low personal growth (promotions) if you're not in management.
advice_management: give guidelines for advancement

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: It gives you the potential to learn a lot, many opportunities to move to other divisions, and the engineers are all helpful to have you grow.
cons: You have to work long hours to meet deadlines. Sometimes over weekends.
advice_management: Consider the health of the family when employees are working extra hours.  Without a solid foundation, production falls as well as moral.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Lots of smart people; generally a very professional atmosphere; opportunities for advancement, if you're willing to play the game.
cons: Very aggressive and overbearing work schedule, work-life balance suffers.  Their commitment to 'Lean' methodologies is almost a joke; you must get certified to help your career, but projects are done for the sake of doing projects, not really to help; every project I saw enacted actually made things worse.  People are transient - you're expected to move around and change jobs every 2 years or so, or else you're seen as there being something wrong with you.  People will implement some new process to make a name for themselves, and then move on and let someone else clean up the mess.
advice_management: Consider the emphasis placed on Lean projects and how they're evaluated.  Let people develop competency and stay put for a while if desired without being stigmatized.  Especially for middle leadership - take responsibility for actions; if you implement some new program or process, stick around to make sure it works or fix it.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Good company with a lot of standard process
cons: contributors have little say and very little control of what happens in the co.
advice_management: flatten the totem pole

job_title: Current Employee - Lead Quality Supplier Engineer
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great Leadership training grounds for future leaders. You own your destiny at GE.
cons: need to move faster and drive further simplification in our reporting structure. Need to return to "start up approach"
advice_management: Remove the middle man

summary: "Great company for entry-level hires, leadership programs are best in business."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Came in as a college hire into one of the leadership programs. The development you get in the program is top notch. GE is known for its leadership programs and it's a tremendous career accelerator.
cons: Working with a global audience has pros/cons. You might not move as quickly as you would with people from your country, but a great learning experience none the less.
advice_management: Much outsourcing makes it difficult to communicate/move as fast as we need. Need to hire more in-house talent.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Floating holidays and vacation days
cons: Not a meritocracy. Promotion based on race and gender.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: If you enjoy a larger company atmosphere, GE has great programs for employees and enough opportunity to move around and gain great experience.  They were quite progressive in their views on working remotely, but I've heard that may have changed in the last year.
cons: Long working hours, but typically quite flexible.  Many matrix reporting relationships to manage.  A LOT of systems and nuances to work with due to the organizational structure - this can be very frustrating when trying to simplify and lean what is in your area of influence.
advice_management: Standardize across the company, not just within small areas - it has to be proliferated across the organization for the smaller office to feel that things are getting better.

summary: "This experience is what you think of while working for a Fortune 500 Company. Great."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: The possibilities are endless for career advancement
cons: amount of time off is acceptable but, working requirements are full time plus
advice_management: always invest in the people.

summary: "Blue chip credentials. Be prepared to work hard."
main_text: I have been working at GE  for more than 10 years
pros: Amazing coworkers.  Drive to deliver excellence. The high bar is always being raised higher.  You'll never be bored.
cons: Extremely high work ethic.  Long hours required to deliver excellence.  Competitive ( but fair) environment to get ahead.
advice_management: Resource your team a little bit better, so they don't have to work so darn hard to deliver the basics.  The worklife balance is what causes turnover here. Generally speaking, a very well-run company to work for.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: As all he big companies, you belong to a big structure where you don't need to figure out everything yourself. They will train you, feed you, and provide processes for almost everything. And it's a very diverse environment where you can be exposed to all kinds of people.
cons: My business unit was later split from GE to form a JV with another company. It's very common for GE. And sometimes it's good, sometimes not so much. In the middle of this transition, my feeling is: employees really don't have a say. The decision-makers who are deciding your future are mostly out of this. Their interests are untouched.
advice_management: When doing JV, please consider giving more options to employees - options that do make a sense.

summary: "Excellent company, lot of opportunity spanning various industries and ability to move into various roles."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Great training and employee avocation.  Due to the large size of the business, there a full range of activities that can keep you busy through your career.  Lots of opportunity to grow your career and continue to take on new challenges.
cons: Large corporate company feeling - older primarily industrial business. Work life balance can be low depending on your role.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: Great leadership development programs, a lot of opportunities for training, looks great on your resume if you decide to pursue graduate school or a new position elsewhere, decent work-life balance
cons: LImited upward mobility at younger ages, found many instances of people being promoted to manager because it is seen as the next step versus truly being ready to manage, experienced some leaders who were all about working your hours versus working smarter and alloing flexibility
advice_management: Embrace allowing people autonomy and flexibility in their work and work schedules and you will find a much happier workforce, make this a great place to not only launch a career but want to stay

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Strong performance gets higher responsibility 
Team atmosphere - everyone is in it together
Great annual performance evaluation process
Good time-off benefits
cons:
Good performance isn't always recognized 
Highly matrixed - too many "bosses", takes too long to get a decision made
Sometimes you feel very stuck in our your own site, not necessarily part of such an enormous corporation
advice_management: Take the time to truly make things easier, don't just say you're going to simply but actually do it at all levels.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Good paycheck for the job I guess and neat to learn new processes. Very historic area as well, so you can poke around locally or hope over to Boston or NYC.
cons:
Union is pretty hardass about everything and our pay is pitiful in comparison. 
Pretty bureaucratic, surprised me how little salaried folks know each other from other departments. Also surprised me how many problems we see on incoming parts and how fly by the seat of the pants everything is. I thought that wouldn't be the case with GE.
advice_management: Office culture is pretty sterile, how about focusing on making production happen? Enforcing the contract and etc.

summary: "Cooperative, results-oriented atmosphere, almost everybody is willing to help."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: Helpful, small-company culture with big corporation support, pay, and benefits. Almost everyone is downright friendly and knows you just want to get the job done. Almost everything is here in one building so you can always get an answer for anything you need to do.
cons: HUGE corporate push to cut costs, so staffing is short and almost everyone is a little overloaded. Out-of-state corporate HQ approval occasionally needed (though it's not too hard to get). Fewer and fewer people around to remember old reasons why designs are like they are. A little bit of "not my job" starting to creep in due to silo'd management structure headquartered out of state. And company is moving out of state in mid-2015, so future only available if you can move.

summary: "Great company for a self-motivated, ambitious person."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: The opportunities that only a company the size of GE can offer.  On the forefront of innovative technologies, and plenty of training opportunities for the self-paced, energetic learner.
cons: Detachment from various levels of management and disorganization.  It is up to the individual to progress their career, GE will not go looking to advance you, and rather is glad to keep you in your current role.
advice_management: Place emphasis on career development from within the ranks.

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Software Developer Engineer
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Salary, Benefits and Career building
cons: Continuous downsizing of the company

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Training program, salary, challenges
cons: Interview methods, disorganized, long process

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Pretty good for intern and learning many things
cons: Can be disorganized at times but nothing too big.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: There are many good, smart, driven people at GE and - depending on your drive - there is a lot of opportunity to access.
cons: Like any large company, the politics and "climbers" can be a bit much.
advice_management: Stay humble

summary: "Rewarding if your willing to work for it."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Lots of room for growth.  If your willing to put forth the effort leadership typically notices and rewards you with it through promotions.  The people that GE hires are on a caliber unlike any company out there.  They spend the money to get better people and the DJIA is proof of that from a longevity stand point.
cons: Although I can see how it wasn't sustainable for Jack Welch's 10% mentality, GE has grown "soft" in that they will let dead weight hang around for a little to long (industry specific of course).  The management doesn't come around unless its a photo opportunity.  Not a good way to "rally the troops".  In my 16 months with GE I have not heard and or seen our division President visiting any place or attempting to reach out to us.  Our business unit is not very big so its a shame that they don't take the time to visit those driving the actual profit.  Money isn't made in cubicles, its made with the products we sell.
advice_management: Visit your people.  Don't let HR drive the boat....they can help navigate....maybe backup navigate.  Don't drive unattainable margin increases, all you are doing is setting up mediocrity and disappointment.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: GE Has giving me an oprotunity to show my Education skills tha I havce aquired in the Military and formal Traning in a trade school.
cons: They need to implement better rules on divirsity in the work place and make it a no place for hate as they do in High schools.

summary: "Job Stability. There's an opportunity in pretty much every city.. so relocating for personal needs is always easy."
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
-Leadership training
-Career progressions (can change jobs every 18-24 months if desired)
-Great Benefits
cons:
-Lack of visibility in a huge organization
-Very metric focused work environment. More often than not, decisions are made so people can hit numbers instead of focusing on doing the right thing
advice_management:
-Compensation is much better outside the company. Recognize grad degrees and performance when considering compensation
-Focus on talent development and leadership training outside of the leadership programs

main_text: I have been working at GE  for more than 10 years
pros: Global company. Collaborative culture. Excellent growth opportunity
cons: Compensation.size of the company presents in speed of execution.
advice_management: None

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Exposure to incredibly smart, driven people.
cons: Matrixed organization where advancement relies on executive sponsorship despite claims of meritocracy.
advice_management: Invest more in HR and then implement data rigor on all exit interviews.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Extremely well-run, dynamic management, Leadership training
cons: Compensation is not as attractive as tech companies
advice_management: Need to catch up on salaries

summary: "GE is great, this locations leadership is NOT"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Lots of development opportunities, great stuff (on paper), and with the right leadership; you could do well.  Leadership off-site and the vision they espouse is outstanding.  Not sure how there is a disconnect between corporate and the local plant in terms of leadership values and ideals.
cons: This location's leadership is more about backstabbing and micromanagement.  Everyone acted like you were trying to take their job or trying to do their job.  They don't believe in getting both sides of the story, just whom they want to believe and push an agenda that they previously set.  Steal ideas as well.
advice_management: Listen to both sides of the story and follow the facts.  Leadership lacks credibility when facts are ignored.  Additionally, a good idea is just that, should not feel threatened by good ideas.  A place hostile to initiative is doomed to never reach the heights they could.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Being part of conglomerate GE, as an Engineer you will have access to lot of highly knowledgeable people.
cons: managers change frequently and you may not finish what you started working on.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: GE is very fast paced and exciting with great company benefits and quirks if you do your job and show promise. GE gives freedom for growth and self development.
cons: Work life balance is challenging and if you don't "fit in" or play the "office politics" your career can go from one of extreme satisfaction to one of chaos and heartache. Although improvement includes challenging "the norm" at times, if doing so involves the wrong individual in authority, your future within the company is grim.
advice_management: Consider corresponding with the  supply chain employees Middle management does not endorse. Their favorites do as they do, thus the reason they are acknowledged. Communicate with the one or two who do not appear successful as they are the ones challenging the norm with out of the box thinking and those employees are actually key in the new leadership and will be needed to take back our position as the number one company globally.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Stable job. Good pay. Good balance
cons: too many projects on the plates

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Great place to develop skills
cons: A lot of red tape
advice_management: lean out the dead wood!
