main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros:
GE is a great organization! A company with great reputation and integrity!
The meritocracy here is real and all the leaders take it in consideration for promotions and recognition.
We also have a great portfolio of products that add value to our clients and community!
cons:
High level positions are filled with expats. International career outside the region became a challenge.
The local executives have no empowerment and the position is not so porwefull than in the past (lack of empowerment, poor trainings and limited opportunties).
advice_management: The company should be more care more with their executives!

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros:
Smart people, full of overachievers - can be cut-throat.Doing a good job is not enough. Someone else will take credit if you dont. Culture is always changing. Trying to streamline.
Lots of growth opportunities, you are expected to move up every two years. Great opps for women and minorities. Lots of public services also. People are very responsive and expect you to be as well. Pay is low for country but high for the depressed area. People are very friendly, almost family like, once you are in and they know you're name.
cons: Work with union can be frustrating. Expect long hours and little to no appreciation. Lots of bureaucracy. IT is very behind and networks are slow and it takes forever to do simple tasks. Too many meaningless Reorgs with too many levels of high paid managers and no one to do the actual work. Busy work can be redundant and a bit ridiculous at times.
advice_management: Top Down Leadership is Needed. Vic Abate is doing this and was very needed. (Keep up the good work). Union needs to go if GE wants to stay competitive in long term. Lower level managers are given way too much power and take advantage of it without being properly training in people and leadership skills. HR needs more transparency and more support for employees. Also - invest in IT and find ways to recognize your people at all levels - positive feedback and regular recognition would go a long way.  Better more relevant training is very needed, especially for the plethora of it programs that dont interact and one must use.

summary: "Great til it was taken away from me"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Was a great place to work
cons: Upper management  was tough
advice_management: More training

summary: "Job was Ok, Company sucks, people were good,  pay was great."
job_title: Former Employee - High Speed Finishing Operator
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great pay and good hours
cons: The rich and powerful moved production overseas and shut us down. I started with 600 people working and ended up with 133.
advice_management: Grow a pair and keep jobs in the United States!

summary: "System Engineer/Program manager for Smart Grid initiatives"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Fast pace, access to lots of technologies
cons: large company, highly political, no established process for Software or technology career paths
advice_management: Establish a network with actual worker bees

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros:
-Competitive pay
-Excellent benefits
-Overtime
-Annual pay raise considerations
cons:
-A lot of travel
-Emergent tasking
advice_management: None

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: GE has a strong brand and overall a solid reputation. It's a good experience to work for GE.
cons: They don't have a strong training program. They have a complicated compensation plan for the sales team and they are likely to change the compensation plan at any given time. Its such a large company (over 300,000 employees) and each division/business unit has the authority to run their own business which makes it difficult to work with other businesses that have their own goals and agenda.
advice_management: Spend more time with the customers and the employees who work with the customers on a daily business in order to have a better understanding of customer needs and to learn about how GE can provide more value to its customer base. Also, changing your sales team's compensation plan in the middle of the year is a terrible thing to do and its a bad way to retain your employees.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Multiple options for career advancement. I literally felt as though I could be anything I wanted to be in the company. They have a great training program and with the abundance of opportunities within the company, you are sure to find positions that fit your wants or tailor a path to your needs.
cons: There are very many smart people that work here and you have to be willing to deal with the egos that come with this.
advice_management: Keep up the good work.

summary: "High Pressure job, Too many piers, High paid Medical Insurance"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Better retirement benefits, Reduced GE products
cons: High Pressure job, Too many piers, High paid Medical Insurance

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Strong company with a great focus.  A lot of innovation and they treat their employees with a lot of integrity
cons: Can be long hours but if you are good at planning your day, you will be more than fine.  Overall I can't say too much here
advice_management: Stay the course, you are doing a great job.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: This company is well respected, with a wonderful history. The GEHC (Healthcare) will continue to decline due to governmental regulations and declining healthcare reimbursements.
cons: The organization has become very complex since Jack's departure as CEO. There are many unnecessary managers, operations managers do not need to exist as the GM should be doing those functions.
advice_management: Get rid of all of the layers, stop promoting sales force to managerial/operational roles.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Offers competitive compensation, open-door policy, transparency from top-down
cons: processes can be cumbersome; reluctant to change from key stakeholders, lack of training for new experienced hires

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Great people to work with.  Benefits were top-notch.  Fitness Center on premises.
cons: Worked for a manager who was having an affair with her manager.   Made it very uncomfortable for all of us.  Upper management looked the other way.  Lost respect for the company.
advice_management: Continue to invest in employees through Crotonville and/or classes locally.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Compensation was very fair and substantial monthly bonuses were basically guaranteed. The benefits were top notch. There was a lot of "down time" that could be used for personal calls, emails, surfing, etc. I was offered as many hours as I wanted to work therefor I could make as much as I wanted to make.
cons: It was a high risk job and the possibility of serious injury or death was real on a daily basis. The hours required along with being on call 24/7 for 27 out of 31 days of the month make this position hard for anyone with any kind of family. Ultimately I had to choose my son over the job.
advice_management: In my relatively short time with the company I saw the top dog within our location replaced. There is rediculous money to be made in this industry and along with it occasionally comes corruption I suppose.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Great company laid back work environment definitely a career job on all levels
cons: It is hard to advance your self to a higher level. Management roles are protected by HR. Everyone is email crazy. We gave lots of meetings. EHS standards are extreme.
advice_management: It would be nice to now more about our company new locally and business wide.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: - A lot of training for new engineers
cons: - Hard to move up because you work for a big company
advice_management: - Good work-life balance

summary: "Rife with politics, but great learning experiences"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros:
-Great learning
-Amazing training
-Challenging work
Overall, a good place to kick start your career.
cons:
-Office politics
-Wok life balance
-Low salary
Seek to hire a more diverse set of people, everyone seems to be type A go getters from the suburbs.
advice_management: -Increase salaries

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Money is ok, work environment got much better over the years in some departments, others not at all. There are some very talented technical people here, but spend too much of there time on GE imposed bureaucracy.
cons: Never know when the winds off layoff will blow your way. GE as a corporation is fickle and will remove large chunks of a business oversees at enormous cost. I guess the tax savings are worth it. GE is declining in the healthcare industry and will probably be out of any US based manufacturing in less than 10 years.
advice_management: N/A

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Immense learning opportunities and experience you gain by being sorrounded by leaders is invaluable
cons: Not considered as a pay master. When compared to other larger Organizations, GE could do better in terms of pay
advice_management: Keep up the good work

summary: "it was a good job but it was only temporary."
main_text: I worked at GE part-time for less than a year
pros: it was nice to meet new people.  I worked by my self, they rented me a new car, I did my job and e-mailed them after every job and told them how everything went.
cons: trying to find some of the houses.
advice_management: good job.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: everybody is nice and food is good
cons: no longer offer pension to new hires
advice_management: old school

summary: "Great if part of GEHC proper, challenging as a recent acquisition."
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Talented people, great tools, competitive salary and solid development and training opportunities.
cons: Heavy and sometimes burdensome processes, different benefits and bonus plans for acquired P&Ls (be weary and ask)
advice_management: Ensure newly acquired P&Ls are staffed adequately to both fulfill requirements of GEHC processes and to do quality work in the process.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: I worked at a remanufacturing facility in the Midwest.  Good pay, great benefits.
cons: Lack of clarity on career progressions to move up, changing priorities based on leadership directives.
advice_management: Set people up for success and leave them alone.

summary: "Excellent environment, if you like what you're doing."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros:
The sense of being a part of something special was pervasive throughout the company, which you don't really see at many other places. 
Most managers treat their employees like adults, and are flexible.
Benefits are outstanding.
cons: Once you're in a technical role, getting in to leadership is almost impossible. GE likes to scoop up college grads and run them through a 2-year rotation that spits out management. Alternatively, it's possible (though difficult) to get hired in as a manager.

summary: "Grat experience working for such an innovative company"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: People, Benefits, Culture, flexible hours, company values
cons: Constant changes in policy and structure

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Nothing, the company is so big and bureaucratic that you're just a number.  They talk about simplifying work but all they do is pass it along to others
cons: Too many to list.  My suggestion is not apply to this company.  They don't care about you they just care about the bottom line after the senior executive team writes a check with their mouth to the board that their ass can't cash
advice_management: Quit lying about stuff.  All of you talk about simplifying and work life balance but the first time that someone speaks out your mid range managers take retaliation on them.  You all should be ashamed of yourself

summary: "I have never worked for GE. Worked 17 years at Honeywell as electronic tech"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Cutting edge tech. Working with latest tech
cons: Really can not think of anything that GE does wrong. Good people, good work area.

summary: "You are not a person, you are a number."
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Once GE took over, I cannot recall any pros.
cons: If your company was acquired by GE, first of all, you will lose the familial atmosphere that may have been present. You become a number, not a name.  They do not care about their customer base or their employees, only "spirit of the letter" and metrics. If you  have an issue to report, they claim anonymity and safe from retaliation, then you find yourself on report.  If you have health issues and have directions from your family doctor, a faceless panel of doctors will decide if the directions will be allowed.  If you have an appointment, unless your manager lets you make the time up, you will be docked half a day.
advice_management: Do not let GE acquire your company!

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: The starting salary was fairly good as well as the hour flexibility and cultural diversity.  A lot of positions also offer great travel opportunites.
cons: The corporate structure tends to lead to management with very poor qualities.  Most are just yes men who only care about their careers and have blinders on when it comes to confronting difficult employees.  Health care benefits are run by a horrible HMO.
advice_management: Say yes less and why more.  Open your eyes and don't just get a pulse of your team, get all the vitals.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
They have great dedicated people that only God Knows why they stay
There are many opportunities within the OKC site since people have been leaving
If you have a sponsor there are opportunities within other GE divisions
If you like to get involved there are many groups and activities to be involved in like the Employee Activities Committee, United Way Campaign, Women's Network, Veteran’s Network, and Volunteer's Group
Since the acquisition most people are getting Green Belt trained (but not certified)
Great physical location in Oklahoma City
They have just installed Tornado shelters
Company provides coffee
cons:
Most managers are not in tune with their subordinates needs
Within Oklahoma City there is not much career growth
It is hard to get certified for your Green Belt because the data is not readily accessible
There is a lengthy workflow for everything
Most departments are busting at the seams with people
Thus, parking is a hassle
Some, not all, managers micromanage
Some, not all, managers do not promote career growth with their people
In some departments there are too many layers of managers
Each department is even more silo'ed in their group than before due to the workflow burden
Though the company provides coffee, it is a different grade of coffee between builds. (Engineering is known to have the best coffee, tea selection, and hot chocolate stash, WHY?)
There is constant blame games even within departments rather than let's fix it and be a team
Terms & Conditions are ridiculous on contracts for orders as well as to approved suppliers
GE Corporate has unrealistic profit objectives and holds the divisions responsible even if the company within are hitting their targets
advice_management: Learn the etiquette of managing people, be authentic NOT fake

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Training is #1. Best training program going today.
cons: Annual evaluation process is not good.
advice_management: Change the evaluation process. Need to be more one on one talking...

summary: "Great place to be challenge and rewarded"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
- diverse team with great skills 
- fast paced working environment 
- fun team outings
-  picnic day
-  they pay for college courses
cons:
-  company still learning the Houston way of business..... They will get there!
-  often always seemed like we were working on the same problems
advice_management: Balance the staff with both experienced industry folks and new talent

summary: "Unfortunate Waste of 6 of my Best Career Years"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: The money was good for the area.
cons: No matter how hard you work, if you're not one of the "chosen ones" you probably will not get the training needed to advance. To me, it seemed corrupt, far too competitive, and strategically controlled to benefit very few carefully chosen individuals. Not for me. Many others were unhappy but wouldn't dare say so for fear of retaliation, despite the "most ethical company" reputation they have somehow "earned."
advice_management: A little fairness goes a long way.

summary: "Good career opportunities but serious old school culture"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
Good access to training and conferences
Offer industry-competitive salary
Good access to tools and resources including video conferencing and software
cons:
Projects and processes bogged down by old school bureaucracy
Difficult process changes
Lack of focus on design-oriented culture
People in roles they are not qualified for in training or experience

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: There is seemingly a system or workflow for everything.  GE really does work hard to structure the teams to reduce conflict of interest and relieve the potential for politics.
cons: There is seemingly a system or workflow for everything.  It can be very bureaucratic, and many managers will want to see six sigma methods applied even when it isn't appropriate, like treating software defects the same as manufacturing defects.
advice_management: Develop or hire some technical managers, there are far too many layers of useless management even after the de-layering.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Free lunch on Fri. Can't find any other compelling pros that gives GE an edge over other companies.
cons: Salary is not with par to other companies in Bay Area. Too much favoritism from Sr. management in the Platform team. You work overtime almost every other day and you are not allowed to report that time. If you bring this up with the mgr, the response is that you are expected to share other's work load.
advice_management: Be fair to everyone and hire more people when you know there is a lot of work. Compensate people for working overtime. And when people with designated responsibilities are willing to take up more responsibilities, make sure they do their original responsibilities along with the newly accepted work. Don't expect some one else to pick up their slack on the original responsibilities.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Great Company love working at it...
cons: None cant say anything bad

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: fit for all level people
cons: less leaves no issues found never
advice_management: all fine

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
The people are really nice.
Vast amount of opportunities across a large scope of industries
cons: Things move slow in a big company like this
advice_management: Keep up the culture and values you've created.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Was able to telecommute.  Learned a lot about the business process.  Had the opportunity to work with a diverse group of people from around the world.
cons: Had a hard time understanding goals and expectations.  Lots of corporate speak, but not a lot of down to earth lets get it done information.
advice_management: Consider in-sourcing your support.  You only get what you pay for when hiring outside consultants to run your systems and there is no company loyalty.  If you want your support people to go the extra mile for you, you should have them as full-time employees.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Good people, lots of work to keep you busy, and lots of on-the-fly learning opportunity.
cons: Old equipment, small budget, poor advancement opportunity, poor training opportunity. Mfg-Eng-Mgr has gorilla grip on job and will throw company and employees under the bus to protect his position.  Yearly Goals and Objectives review program can be manipulated by management at will.
advice_management: Rotate engineering managers every 7 years, or so.  Invest in newer tools and equipment. Invest in training employees. Fix the review program to prevent manipulation by managers.  Stop raping company's, transferring lines offshore, and then selling the company's off for profit: your killing america!  At least pay some effective taxes.

summary: "Good or bad depending on the manager"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Good name
Access to other GE companies
cons:
Some managers may not favor minorities
Too many managers
Managers focused on keeping their jobs and not benefit the company
advice_management: Eliminate some layers of managers

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Great compensation for a co-op. Possibility to work on interesting projects.
cons: You are a drop in the bucket. Depressing work environment (badge in, trudge down an infinite hallway, sit in an office with no windows, leave). You are quite likely to be a copy boy/girl the first rotation, possibly all of them.

main_text: I worked at GE part-time for more than 5 years
pros: great pay and benefits, facility comply with all OSHA safety standards.
cons: worked a rotating shift for continuous operation of laboratories and facilities which meant nights and weekends.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Upward mobility, mentoring, management, positive attitudes and work - life balance were nothing like you'd imagine.  Products priced right with new technology products.
cons: They could improve upon making their excellent benefit package more understandable as it can be quite complex.  Other than that the organization has so few faults.
advice_management: In general - this large organization may benefit from an entrepreneurial perspective at all levels.  This may increase the intensity yet offer a more go-getter attitude.

summary: "Great technology company, can do better on HR side"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Top technologies,, great processes and tools. As a technologist or engineer, this THE company to work for.
cons: HR management could be better. Too much internal politics.
advice_management: Treat your employees with more fairness, I.e., based on real competency rather than on how political waviness...

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: fast pace, great salary, good benefits, many opportunities, great projects available to work on
cons: competitive environment, not for everyone

summary: "GE is a great company to work for especially starting out as an intern or co-op. I'm glad I have the opportunity"
job_title: Current Employee - I T Systems Engineer Co-op
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Team based environment, opportunity for advancement, opportunity to grow and develop professionally, Celebration of Diversity and culture, great pay for interns and co-ops
cons: Atmosphere can be too laid back and boring, over hear about people getting laid off often
advice_management: There should be at least one day out the week dedicated to all work no meetings, and another  and certain hour dedicated to team members focusing on a new innovation

summary: "Need more focus on employees and long term vision"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: Everyone knows GE as a company, and it typically carries a strong reputation. I've gained some good experiences, and I've worked with some good people. Flexible working has been nice. There usually is not any scrutiny around working from home vs. in the office.
cons: Everyone is expected to be "on" all the time. So, make sure to bring your phone and laptop even if you are on an international vacation. Decisions are made with "making the quarter" in mind with no long term strategy, which results in quick processes that break later. Employee advocacy is low. Employees are not considered when tough business decisions are made, and front line leaders and HR are left to help employees through these decisions afterwards.
advice_management: Not everything is about the financials and numbers. There are people that drive our business who deserve to be heard and their opinions considered. It's okay to take a hit on the short term to create a lasting long-term strategy.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great company to work for when things are going fine!
cons: Hourly workers are loaded with multiple tasks that require more than 40 hours a week to complete. Heard this happens in other locations and observed it first hand in FXO. This worker sometimes worked more than 50 hours in a week, and was not paid OT!
advice_management: Know more than $$$$

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: Good Pay for the area
cons: GE's processes make it difficult to complete even the most simplistic tasks.  They have built too many non value steps and approvals in all their IT Project processes

summary: "Great people, great products not customer focused"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Some leading edge products.
A lot of sharp coworkers to share and learn from.
cons:
Ever increasing work load.
No follow through on new products.
advice_management:
It takes people to make it easier for customers to do business with GE.
NPI's aren't finished until the customer accepts and uses them.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: GE expects you to give your all to the company. They provide excellent training.
cons: If you get a "bad" manager it is extremely hard to get off the team.
advice_management: Don't create such a line between team members

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: You are placed into opportunities to show your worth. The GE family is great to be a part of though you may be stressed beyond what you believe you can do.
cons: Training is a major problem. You must be a self-learner and highly motivated to succeed
advice_management: Enact better training programs as well as better acknowledgement of accomplishments.

job_title: Current Employee - Lead Advanced Manufacturing Engineer
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros:
3 wks vaca
Good salary in a city with low costs of living
cons:
few women
stalwart managers
poor management and organization

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Opportunity to advance career, lots of mobility within company, good pay and good work life balance. Colleagues are helpful and there is a culture of cooperation (most times). Good training provided.
cons: Salaries are good but not great, medical benefits have been cut back and more burdensome on employee. Things move slowly on the work front, which can be frustrating at times.

summary: "While providing excellent experience in a large corporation, the culture was overall very stressful and highly demanding"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: GE was great company with regards to training, gaining experience, and flexible work arrangements when needed.
cons: The bureaucratic red tape blocked new and innovative ideas from being worked quickly,  internal politics were often very frustrating to work around, and communication between management was severely lacking to the point where collaboration was very difficult.
advice_management: Listen to the people who get the work done on what their needs are.  The employees work very hard and do want the best for the company.  But they want to work smarter, not harder.

summary: "A good place to start your career, other than that, GE is just an O.K. company to work for"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: A slow but relax environment company
cons: A typical big company that pays very low
advice_management: Need to raise employees' pay more often

summary: "Practically unlimited career opportunities, fantastic professional development"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Practically unlimited career opportunities - can do just about any type of job, just about anywhere in the world... if you want to.
Great professional development - both from training as well as learning from colleagues.
cons: Working for the wrong person can be devastating to your career. Generally not a problem, but if you are in the wrong department at the wrong time, job cuts or shut downs could end a long, successful career before you know it.
advice_management: none

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: The atmosphere and co-workers are great. Everyone is very helpful and will help with any issue. The company has many perks such as incentives, moving to other locations, and moving to different positions within the company. The company also has excellent moral values. There is vacation time and rewards are given to the best team. This is a great company to work for. Also the health benefits are excellent.
cons: The time schedule may be difficult to work because you bid for your time to work. There are flexible hours but people with seniority get the first choice.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Vast array of opportunities for advancement.
cons: If you get the wrong (incompetent) manager, you'll go nowhere fast until they leave the company (most of them do eventually leave)
advice_management: Trust your individual contributors more than the managers on your staff

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: this company has a deep talent pool; very high level thinkers; open to new ideas; encourage employees to be creative
cons: lately there has been a focus on simplification and going lean which, while certainly understandable, has required some reshuffling and cuts
advice_management: continue to reward performance

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Awesome job couldn't wait to go to work!
cons: Nothing, couldn't find anything moving to be the next jack welch!

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: You get to work on best of healthcare driving experience.
cons: Highly Government regulated. Under the compliance of FDI. Meaningful use drives the priorities. This may have impact on building future techincal programs
advice_management: Stay ahead and lead

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: They have wonderful tools for learning
cons: You usually move onto a new role every 18-24 months; however, moving into a role that best fits you may take a few rotations

summary: "GE is not what it used to be!"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: GE still has a good name, but read on !
cons:
GE's name has been synonymous with allowing imagination, creativity and fundamental work flourish to generate new directions in research resulting in new concepts, products, etc: this is not true anymore! 
The health insurance, vacations and other benefits are not really on-par with the reputation of the company.
advice_management: What I say might seem unrealistic but I suggest that you revive the old GE with its culture of creativity: while I understand corporates (like GE) are there to make money, please do not forget long term investment in research and fundamental work in favor of generating quick revenues that looks good only in short term.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Project Management discipline
Culture of excellence
Company values
Growth opportunities
cons:
Compensation
Benefits declined while I was there
advice_management: Reinstitute benefits or compenstation

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Lot's of resources and internal options for location and experience.
cons: Red tape, office politics.  Work load often get's larger and larger without recognition or compensation.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Great work experience.  I learned a lot.
cons: There is a great turn around for contractors.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Training continuously, good place for a couple years to get started.
cons: Profit driven,  advertise integrity but have very little in middle management.  Middle management constant turnover 5 bosses in 4 years!  HR not much better.  Annual reviews are a joke, you write what they want, plug in your numbers (metrics), then your manager fills in his.  Manager stated "I can put anything I want on your review no matter if it's true or not and you can't do anything about it"
advice_management: Integrity, you better learn it, It is every thing we do.  it's not just reputation it's the person we are, the ability to actually listen and if it's wrong stand up for that person or problem.  I know you have such large turnover in middle management, this to act as a buffer to upper management. so your integrity is as good as the lowest you have and that is local managers.  Last I checked, heaven doesn't have corporations. You are responsible for every decision you make or ALLOW to happen. It is not a balance sheet, I did 3 good things that will make up for that.  It is every decision! every act! Every statement.  Integrity reevaluate yourselves.

summary: "Place to solve the world's biggest problems."
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
World-class leadership development.
Genuine support of diversity.
Variety of industries. Lots of opportunity to move around.
cons: Not really a con exactly, but while many support resources exist, one is required to manage his/her own career.
advice_management: Keep driving customer focus at all levels.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great company with lots of products to sell. Integrity in every transaction and interaction is paramount.
cons: Big company. Takes years of learning to navigate and master.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Raises, understands family issues, great medical benefits. Pretty much a cool working environment, any issues would probably be with staff, not the job itself. Easy to apply to other positions, company promotes internal hiring.
cons: No room for growth in customer service, but potential to move to other areas.

summary: "Great environment for job development and growth."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Everyday at GE provides you with learning and growth opportunities. You are exposed to so many different aspects of how a large business runs and how all the various teams interact with each other to make the Company successful.
cons: It can be easy to get lost in the complexity of such a large organization. It takes effort to network and to make sure your contributions are recognized and appreciated.
advice_management: Continue to seek out and nurture internal talent.

summary: "Still doing great things. Very strong culture for those looking for 20 yr company careers"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: GE still has the capacity to build, buy and create capital intensive products that have fare reaching effects on society.  For those who want to build a career at a single company, there will be tons of opportunities.  Good leadership in pockets.
cons: Very strong, old, insider culture.  Most people come in after undergraduate school and stay for 15 or 20 years.  Good for understanding how things work but can limit change inside and present challenges for those coming from outside.  Below average pay, except at the top of the pyramid. Good leadership in select pockets.

job_title: Former Employee - Financial Management Program and Financial Analyst
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Their entry-level training programs are a great way to start off a career if your primary objectives are gaining a strong foundation (albeit a GE-focused one).  The industries they work in are on the forefront of the global economy (Energy, Healthcare, Finance, etc.).
cons: The "merit-based" culture sounds fantastic in theory, but not as much in practice at the General.  It creates a culture of finger-pointing and blame-avoidance rather than teamwork and working towards common goals.  Also, the health insurance went from great to significantly below average over the course of about a year.  The costs were shifted to employees (although it's tough to blame them, seeing as how their costs were ballooning).  If you want to succeed there, you have to make work your life.  I have not seen any higher-level folks (nor seen anyone advance) unless they spend countless hours working at the office and out of the office.
advice_management: Focus more on long-term goals rather than quarterly results.  Create a culture of successful employees by helping them to find the right fit.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Excellent benefits; interesting and meaningful work; many professional and helpful coworkers who were dedicated to providing quality work
cons: Huge workloads with constant pressure to perform and improve with measurements being taken constantly; inadequate training for my position; team leader was too young and immature for her position, tried to undercut people to management and made it feel like high school; growlers on the job with management ok (some will like this but no one should be drinking on the job)

summary: "My experience with the company is great seeing as people are treated fairly and there are plenty of opportunities."

advice_management: Pay more money to your rising talent; you have invested a lot of money in them.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: GE has the resources and capacity to do world-changing things.
cons: The ideals Jack once preached have been twisted into a cultural nightmare. Teams are pitched against teams, primary focus has shifted from achievement and accomplishment to dodging blame and avoiding being the punching bag. Frequent layoffs and reorgs lead to a fear-driven operational mindset.
advice_management: Refocus on core values, make sure every employee feels like a stakeholder working towards a goal instead of a cog in the machine trading their soul for a paycheck.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: It was an excellent opportunity for me to work with strong product development teams to develop a new product line.

advice_management: Purge the senior people that are stuck in the mentality of doing things the way they were done 2 decades ago.  If they won't change for the better, do not allow them to slow down progress.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years

-100% tuition/books reimbursement while employed
-no retaliation guarantee for raising concerns
cons:
-large campus, lack of personal privacy
-insurance is horrible (office visits are not $25 copay - you pay all until deductible met)

Please consider revisiting your commitment to employees and training managers in the art of retaining talent.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Lot's to learn. Big player in industry.  If you are self motivated there is an endless amount of information to pull from.  GE brand certainly helps sell products that might no be purchased if it didn't have the meatball on it.
cons: The restructuring of the sales force caused and continues to cause complete chaos.  Despite the "one GE" attempt, the company is simply not there.  Too political and the customer in the end suffers from very slow responses. From a product perspective, in healthcare, GE is behind the times.  In a majority of categories there is a superior product on the market.  At the same time when there are major quality issues, things are not escalated to address or fix due to channels need to put up numbers
advice_management: GE is not the military, make it easier for the folks taking care of customers to get to the right person without fear of hand slapping or worse.

advice_management: Stay current, listen to the younger generation, use social media more, leverage technology, try to benchmark google or the like. Old ideas die, it's the new ones that will make or break you as a company.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time

summary: "Tremendous diversity of experience in finance rotational programs."

summary: "GE is a large company that places value on innovation, self direction, and integrity."
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Job security, challenging, plethora of career opportunities
cons: Extremely demanding while rewards don't necessarily compare to businesses in the same field.

summary: "exciting company, strong culture but too focused on the short term"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros:
Despite being one of the largest companies in the world (300,000 employees), GE still feels like one company, driven by one very iconic (and highly respected) leader.  The leadership are strongly committed to developing employees and the opportunities are limitless if you are willing to relocate frequently.  You could easily spend 20-30 years at this company, moving into a new role every 2-4 years in a new industry and even a new country - it's not uncommon for people to have lived in 2, 3, 5 or more countries during their careers at GE.  The compensation is good.
Also, GE is all about delivering - the processes are incredible here.  If the company wants to roll something out, stay out of the way!  The downside, though, is that there is a lot of process and a tremendous amount of bureaucracy, despite the strong push from the highest levels for simplification.  Overall, though, if you are looking for one company to stay at for 20+ years and build your career, GE is a great option and you will never be bored.
cons:
GE is so focused on the short term (meeting quarterly targets) that long term planning just doesn't happen in most of the business units.  It's surprising.  There are many extremely smart people here but strategy seems to be done only at the highest levels - everyone else is very focused on process and short term goals.  There isn't a lot of entrepreneurial thinking here - people generally wait to be told what to do - and then they'll do it exceptionally well - but they don't come up with the ideas.
Also, the perks are great but the benefits are terrible - they are massively shifting costs to the employees to reduce the overall costs to GE.

To get anything minor accomplished, you have to go through many reviews and redesigns to the point that the finished product is out of date before it's finished. I didn't feel a sense of culture there at all. It was very much a "punch in, punch out" type of environment.

cons: Big company bureaucracy can sometime make projects take forever and seem inflexible.  Definitely doesn't have the feel of a small company

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great Company, diversity programs, various opportunities to learn, network and visibility to leadership.  They have a portal for on line learning including some Harvard classes.
cons: Too many changes in two years.  The company is not recognizable from 5 years ago.  Not sure if the company sees value in the work that you are doing.
advice_management: More communication is needed to low level employees to reduce anxiety and worry.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: Work environment is very good. Very Competitive work environment
cons: No growth. Sometimes it's frustrating to see that the effort you put in doesn't pay off to anything.
advice_management: Incentives

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Great people with fascinating projects
cons: Remote location, poor commuter benefits

summary: "Great entry level training, high pressure environment"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Good growth opportunity, high importance given to employee development, good brand name recognition
cons: Hours are very long, little focus/understanding of work/life balance, must navigate high levels of bureaucracy, poor retention after rotational training programs

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Independent work, creative freedom, flexible schedule, minimal micro-managing, exciting projects and novel work, good starting base salary, clearly defined career path within the technician band...
cons: ... However no real path from technician to professional band, ceilings for positions are clearly visible - particularly referring to salary and mobility within the org, HR-heavy and very bureaucratic processes slow projects and teams
advice_management: Don't be afraid to stick your head out of the box and challenge HR.  Step up to bat for your employees and provide a clear interest in the advancement of their careers.

summary: "Smart people, constant change, lots of access to resources"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Diversified company that continues to invest
cons: Large scale of organizations get big quick

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Opportunities - global diverse work force
cons: Too "clicky" - have to be in the club
advice_management: Best people are not always your best friends

summary: "Confusing re-organizations don't save money ... they just shuffle people around"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Great leadership training, if you can get it
Large, currently stable company
cons:
Short term thinking (everything is about this quarter) will hurt, long term
Hard to rise to the top with so many competitors (many of whom are willing to break the growth values to rise)
advice_management: Walk what you talk - the growth values are right.  Enforce them.  Ruthlessly.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: multi cultural and values and good company
cons: none...do not remeber any right now
advice_management: na............will let u know later

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: GE has some good development opportunities. The corporate programs and its Crotonville training center provide valuable experience to someone starting out his career.
cons: Corporate programs breed a group-think mentality. Additionally they seem to develop managers rather than leaders. I witnessed people think more highly of themselves because of job titles rather than their own personal and intellectual merits.
advice_management: Don't blindly promote corporate program participants. It creates a culture of entitlement and group think.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Large company, well known, amazing people (coworkers and management), lots of growth potential, excellent leadership development, a procedure exists for everything, CEO values permeate the entire company
cons: Work-life balance can be difficult, benefits do not take additional education into consideration and lag behind industry after new-hire, sometimes the procedures are too restricting or not well defined, "support the customer" seems to mean do whatever they ask instead of aiding them in understanding the rippling effects
advice_management: Overall good job so keep it up. It's good that you are highly visible, but most of the time we see/hear you it's because of a problem you want fixed, sometimes the working level needs you to provide additional push on customer. Employee annual review seems like a bloated process but it works pretty well.

summary: "Led implementation of vision, strategy, planning, and execution of budgets & metrics of cross-functional teams"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Work life balance, salary and career growth, top level leadership saying/doing right things but not filtering down through mid management to working level
cons: Politics, kingdom building, functional silos, quarterly budgeting, transactional work environment, too many systems, hard to get things done, too much focus on "internal customer", too much focus on competition.
advice_management: More collaboration, focus on external customer, break down the silo walls.  Get out in front and "lead", don't hide behind glass doors.

job_title: Former Employee - Director of Program Management
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Large company with stability and opportunities to work in a diverse business
cons: very impersonal, treated like a number

summary: "GE is full of amazing opportunities, in any field you can imagine."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: GE cares about it's employees, has great benefits and help, is full of growth opportunity, and wants to see you succeed.
cons: Because of the nature of the business, some of the job functions can be more difficult than they need to be. Communication isn't always the best, but it depends on what each individual makes it.
advice_management: Do more for the people at lower levels who do the brunt of the work.

summary: "Large stable company with lots of complexities and operating rhythms."

summary: "Highly capable people, overall wonderful company to work for."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Highly capable associates to work with
cons: Too much bureaucracy interferes with the ability for talented individuals to show their capabilities.
advice_management: You hire very talented people - trust them; give them authority and responsibility and you will be pleasantly surprised.

summary: "A Okay company for new graduate. Not much growth room for expericenced and talented people."
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Big company, stable finance. Some intelligent employees.
cons: The parelle structure of the company leads to low efficiency. The compensation is poor, especially the medical insurance plan.
advice_management: Inspire the people under you and give them the opportunity for the carrier growth.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Good focus on training and development in early portion of career as a young engineer. Technical development programs are very challenging but worth the time and effort.
cons: Very long product development cycle. For a yong engineer it takes a long time to see multiple design cycles full-circle.
advice_management: Upper management has been good about extending more progressive vacation benefits to younger employees. (3 weeks after 1 year and 4 weeks after 5 years). In order to keep younger millenials, it will be important to enable transition within the different business and locations.

summary: "Great Place To Learn, Not so much for a Career"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
-If you are labeled as a top performer (I was), you are given many opportunities to attend various trainings and are given exposure to upper management
-Generally a very hard working and good workforce, good people to work with.
-Meritocracy (used to be more than now) where hard workers are rewarded for their efforts
-Job security, as long as you do your job you will have one because GE isn't going to go out of business anytime soon
cons:
-Bureaucracy.  Not too long after Jack Welch left the company, the bureaucracy has grown like cancer.  This is what you would expect from a culture that believes in Meritocracy, but the company is extremely slow to experience real "organic" growth, so this leaves limited positions for advancement.  The bureaucracy hinders "outside of the box thinking" and leads the organization to seek after short term gains.  
-Leadership full of little "Napoloens" who rule their own domains with little concern for their employees or other domains
-Benefits are becoming less and less attractive.  What used to be a generous stock, health care, and salary package has been whittled away to be average or below industry, even for top performers.
advice_management: Get rid of middle management.  Look beyond the metrics.  Grow the company (IP, products, industries), not just the bottom line.  Reward the employees more fairly for the best years of their lives

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
International experience
At the forefront of technology
cons:
Heavy processes
Balance work / personal time is bad

summary: "Good place to work. It's a big, dumb company, but it could be a lot dumber."
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Good benefits. Offers excellent training. Lots of opportunities to advance if you're willing to move around a lot. Overall good corporate culture.
cons: You pretty much need to be willing to relocate if you want to advance very far. Lots of things move very slowly. The corporate culture does vary somewhat from division to division.
advice_management: Try not to be a big, lumbering company.

summary: "Large diversified company with lots of opportunity"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Lots of opportunity for different job functions, product lines, etc. Pretty flexible work hours
cons: Pay is not quite competitive. Very high expectations. Bureaucracy.
advice_management: Trust and recognize your employees. Most work hard and do what's best for the company. People are driven away when they aren't given kudos.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Security, independence, benefits, good middle managers, good VP
cons: Low pay, peers are incompetent and unprofessional
advice_management: NA

summary: "Very busy - do more with less environment."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Great training programs and classes.  Lots of opportunities for travel (if job allows).  Great way to build a network.
cons: Very self driven - if you don't know how to do something, you better find someone to help you, because management will not.  They also want everyone to be leaders - which just isn't always feasible.  Performance measures are tough - Failing, Passing, Exceeding
advice_management: Performance metrics should have more flexibility - you can't always cram peoples accomplishments into 3 boxes.  There also needs to be a better process for people mid-career joining GE - They aren't new to the business world, but they are new to GE's complex environment.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: The pay and the hours were great.
cons: No mater how you try there are some people you just don`t get along with so you just try to do your best.
advice_management: When you have people comming  to do work they don`t know everything about the site rules so don`t expect them to know everything.

summary: "Huge company with great training and resources, but not very personal."
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: GE has some of the best business training in the world.  Some is available for all.  For the best classes you must be nominated.  Your fellow employees are some of the most talented people available.  Some employees can successfully move from one industry to another.
cons: Regardless of how well you perform, decisions about your employment are made far above you, often by someone you will never meet.  It's all about the numbers.  There are unbelievable politics and layers to navigate here.  The commitment to integrity is put to the side when it comes to reducing staff to make numbers.
advice_management: Don't make decisions about eliminating top talent without careful consideration.  These choices appear to be made in a vacuum, looking only at the numbers.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: GE is a large, multi-national company with strong futures in many industries.  Hourly wages are some of the best in the area.
cons: Local plant is closing due to international competition.  Work environment is not clean, and an attitude of apathy has crept into the production line.  Two-tiered pay system contributed to an attitude of complacency and suppressed employee desire to do any more than the absolute bare minimum.
advice_management: Locally, there were no incentive devices regularly in play.  Workers had no reason to continue to produce the high-quality, high-volume work that historically had come from the plant.  As a result, waste increased and productivity decreased.  Re-institution of regular employee reviews with recognizable, visible consequences (both negative and positive) should be put in place for similar situations.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: the pay and the connections this corporation brings
cons: none really, this company is great
advice_management: great

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years

management is too cut throat...they are always looking at ways to cut jobs....
not reallly a great environment for creativity

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year

summary: "Plant HR Mgr.; contract negotiations, union shop; legal compliance; grant writer; benefits admin.; safety management res"
job_title: Current Employee - Human Resources Manager/Vice Presid
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: growing company; long history; recognized product worldwide, opportunity for growth, aggressively seeking international markets, seeking grant opportunity from State agencies, looking for new approaches to governance.
cons: Still need new approaches to management (big issues), need to provide better training to mid-level workforce, reluctant to change, poor relationship between two separate, but important departments- fight each other; two opposing sr. managers; internal conflict
advice_management: Work cooperatively, reorganize reporting relationships. establish clear head manager, working with a common direction and scope. Poor systems/processes_ I was Change Management Leader, implementing Oracle and Change management processes successfully.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: benefits,  flex schedule, work life balance
cons: seek talent internal before going outside
advice_management: eliminate old boys club attitude

job_title: Former Employee - Material Handles- Assistant to Foreman
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Stable, fair, advancement opportunities, safe work place, very well run departments.
cons: Union, not always equal opportunities, not always fair management of work force, No flex time work schedules, feel like your just a 5 digit number.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros:
- Option to work at home, but even though this is a supposed employee benefit, it does more for GE since they do not have to pay for office space, etc.

- GE brand name on your resume

- The company has an interesting portfolio of products and services

- Being able to talk to some of the few remaining old timers who worked for GE when it was truly an innovative American company
cons:
- The company is so large that every process is extremely fragmented and bureaucratic.  Simple requests or orders must go through multiple levels to be approved.

- Hypocrisy abounds, e.g. you will be questioned as to why you spent an extra $50 on a job but your managers are driving around in brand new company-issued Chevy Volts

- Health and other benefits are extremely poor for such a large, profitable company that does not pay taxes

- Constant divisional name changes leave employees confused

- Employee titles are inflated so that everyone is a "leader" or "specialist" which gives the wrong people an elevated sense of importance

- The common worker and mid-level manager salaries are stifled to support a massive bureaucracy of upper-level management and redundant HR / admin personnel

- Like most large American corporations, there is NO long-term thinking or planning.  Every decision is made relative to how it financially benefits the current quarter.  If you propose a $1000 expense that will negatively affect the current reporting period but will reap ten times the amount of revenue down the line, they won't do it.  If they think you spent an extra penny unnecessarily, they'll crack open your kid's piggy bank to take it back.
advice_management: Your GE logo will only get you so far these days.  Smart consumers can have their services performed by equally qualified companies for half the price. Your employees are defecting to more forward-thinking companies with better benefits and hours.

summary: "GE O&G is a quilt of acquisitions... experience will depend a lot on legacy company.""
main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Lots of opportunity for movement within company
cons: Pay tends to be slightly under market. Some P&L's have more "red tape" issues than others.
advice_management: Simplify workflows. Metrics are important, but tracking every tiny detail is affecting performance.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Very diversified global company with people from different backgrounds and cultures; Flexible working from home policy
cons: Glass ceiling, limited career advancement for experienced professionals came outside of the company
advice_management: Stay focus - align people and process while making changes

summary: "Good people to work with and the environment is fun."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Good people to work with
cons: Low pay and and promotions might not be forthcoming

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Investing heavily in big data, technology, and trying to be ahead of the curve in advanced manufacturing.  Job-wise, they will invest in your learning and development, and you have many opportunities in different functions, countries, areas, etc. due to its global scale.
cons: At times is too focused on stock price... some projects that span 1+ years get unfair budget cuts after a year since finances are reviewed and squeezed every year, making it tough to truly succeed (exception for larger major long-term projects like jet engines)...
advice_management: Don't be afraid to let the weak/underperformers go immediately, invest in strong talent with long term goals in mind.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Pay is good and the physical amount of work is good. It's not a sweat shop like some of the other places I've worked.
cons: Very large company and it is not a very personable work environment.  You are just a number.  Company is closing.

summary: "Of the companies where I have worked, GE is at the top in terms of ethics, meeting both the letter and intent of the law"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Amazing benefits, even as the rest of the world is offering dwindling benefits. A regimented employee review process: you never have to wonder where you stand. Excellent talent: once you are in, you know you are among the best. Superior technology: cutting edge, forefront of all that the world has to offer.
cons: Forced rank system: employee review is a double edged sword…  you have to perform to stay in the pool.  This is not a con, if you perform well.
advice_management: Labor may be cheaper in developing countries, but what is the ultimate cost to productivity? Invest more in agile development, continuous integration, and employee development, regardless of where the employee resides.  Attainable goals vs. arbitrary dealines.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Great place to start a career
cons: Not a great place to continue a career

main_text: I worked at GE

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years

summary: "Good salary, benefits, but no job security."

advice_management: To the Top management, please remember the "Corporate America"  includes some thought to being loyal to your home country.  If decisions are based only on the bottom dollar, there won't be any "America" to worry about.

advice_management: Foster an environment where employees feel comfortable to share

summary: "Good program but not a good choice for computer science majors."

summary: "Leadership needs to focus on more than just the bottom line. Needs to treat customers and employees with more value."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Strong corporate brand. Good work/life balance
cons: Annual pay increases don't keep up with cost of living. Management pay only $2000 more than subordinates, manager hiring decisions based on lowest cost, not most qualified. Pay not competitive with peers in industry. Leadership uses fear as primary motivation tool. Leadership unwilling to entertain salary negotiations. Benefits/perks eroded over last 5 years. Leadership chooses "favorites" over smart business decisions. Unwilling to negotiate with customers, continue to lose customers to competition.
advice_management: Strive to become a top 100 employer. Treat employees like a valued asset.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years

advice_management: To save cost quit taking away from people who are doing the work and elimate middle managers

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years

summary: "Good place to work, if you've got the time."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: There are lots of opportunities to be promoted and you learn a lot of valuable skills while working on the manufacturing floor.
cons: Most positions in manufacturing require a lot more hours than the 40 hours that your salary compensates you for and only Operations Leaders receive overtime pay, because there OT is mandatory. Great place to start at, if all you want to do is work a bunch and save money before family life begins.
advice_management: Stop cutting costs by overworking your salaried employees and begin addressing the very real, and costly issue, of getting an average of only 4 hours of actual labor from the hourly workers on the floor during an 8 hour shift.

summary: "There are good and bad elements to working for GE.  It really depends on the leadership of the specific GE company"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Innovation, and the sr. corporate leadership group is second to none.  Learned a bunch from the Marketing and Research Group - again, from the Corporate group in Fairfield, not my specific GE company.
cons: Benefits went downhill a few years ago.  Too many long-time GE leaders, insider politics rule, so if you're on the outside, salaries are not competitive.  Advancement of women and minorities is a joke in some GE companies, others not so bad.
advice_management: Be aware of the insider mentality - it's getting worse.  Base rewards and advancement on results and not popularity.  Middle managers are aware of the pay inequities, and you are losing great people because of it. Would recommend GE Corporate, Healthcare, Energy and Aviation, but not the others.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Great team, culture and work atmosphere.
cons: Slow to changes at times.
advice_management: Act quick to keep good talents from getting lost.

summary: "In like a lion, out like a lamb (a lamb who went 12 rounds with the lion in a cage match)"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Many of GE companies are great to work for. GE Capital, Commercial Finance, former VFS (Vendor Financial Services), etc. Others, not so much. I was fortunate that Jack Welch was CEO for approx.  67% of my career with GE. Throughout this era employees BELIEVED in GE Values, embraced fantastic training tools such as Six Sigma, CAP (Change Acceleration Process), Leadership Training. Customer Satisfaction (referring to internal customers..GE Employees who engaged IT Client Services for support) was top priority. Employees/Teams worked in the office..together..engaged everyday with various teams. I loved getting up in the morning and going to work. Goals and Objectives were established during the first quarter of every year based on solid data. Projects/Tasks made sense. If an employee was a top performer there was no doubt she/he was on a solid, very timely career path.  to be continued below.
cons:
Then Mr. Welch left. All GE Capital IT employees were transferred to a centralized IT department under GE Corporate for phase one of the OneGE initiative. A centralized IT group serving all GE Verticals. Only a select one or two small GE divisions (small in regards to number of employees, but extremely integral to GE as a whole), Sigal Zarmi, one of the few female CIO's in Corporate America had the vision and foresight and COURAGE to push back. While the rest of GE IT..now Corporate IT..disintegrated quite rapidly with multiple cost cutting initiatives, outsourcing, so many re-orgs and name changes, team changes..impossible to keep count.  Morale of the majority of IT personal desperately treaded water but couldn't hold out. It began sinking and continues to sink to this very day. GE Values mean nothing, Spirit letter means nothing. 

Don't take my word for it..survey Corporate IT employees. Give them the following list of GE Core Values that drive Leadership and employees to excel.

*Strong Work Ethic: Valued employees who work hard and work smart
*Dependable/Reliable: Take Accountability for the teams they lead or projects they manage
*Positive Attitude and Embracing Change
*Adaptable and Flexible: Projects don't always go as planned. Adapt, think outside of the box, and motivate your team.
Ask them to rate them in order of importance. Also give them an option to rate ALL of them as EQUALLY IMPORTANT.

Now lets make a charitable David vs Goliath bet.  Me v.s. Glassdoor.  $5000 donated to the charity of choice. I will wager that over 94% will select the option that All of them are equally important.  It does not matter how many employees actually rate them. My wager? Less than 6% will reply back that the values listed are important but are NOT the GE CORE Values that are critical to the growth and success of General Electric

The real GE Values which truly ARE critical when INDIVIDUAL Goals and Objectives are identified in a one one one meeting with a manger. They are the following:
External focus
Show imagination and courage
Drive inclusiveness, 
Have expertise 
Clear thinkers

Most teams are virtual, in silos, have no idea what related teams are doing. The teams that were outsourced work in sweat shop environments. They are treated as lepers, beaten with a stick, not embraced as teammates. In my last months at GE, after engaging HR and the Ombudsperson because my boss was a bully, a former Army vet who treated employees as if they were in the Army at boot camp, not part of a team. Sticking up for the team who STRONGLY advised me NOT to go to HR as it is the kiss of death and told me flat out they would plead the fifth if approached. They all advised me to shut up, collect the paycheck, pay the bills, and be grateful I have a job.  I couldn't do that. I dreaded going to work each day. I was depressed..desperately searched for another job at GE and FOUND a perfect fit.
But it was AFTER I went to HR. I was not allowed to move. I was put on a performance plan.
When I was informed by my boss that I was being put on a performance plan (even though I achieved ALL my Goals and Objectives along with additional stretch goals) I explained that I needed a change after working for 4 years on a team that was constantly in flux, no stability, four managers in four years...my manager informed me that I COULD interview for the position, saw no reason why I couldn't move but he wanted to discuss it with HR first. End result, I was NOT allowed to interview..was put on a plan. 

The rest is history. I could literally write a book about Corporate IT. It would be incredibly entertaining. Solidly backup my claims with data. The scandal stories alone would make it a best seller.  I decided not too because I am grateful for the fantastic managers I had in my early years. Grateful for the wide skill set I developed in those early years. And my last 4 or 5 years? I was schooled with 500+ examples of how NOT to lead, manage projects, treat people.
advice_management: For GE Corporate I have none. Every year we were surveyed, every year survey data spelled out (make some serious changes) and nothing ever changed. The advice I would give would endorse (x, y, z) and that goes against Glassdoor Rules.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Fantastic place to learn and think like an entrepreneur regardless of the job function. Everyone is expected to have well thought out their ideas and encouraged to speak-up. Leadership training is offered to those who have the "sponsorship" from one of the company officers. Therefore <10% people end-up in executive ranks. Functionally, those in Sales or Finance are valued the most. The rest end up being worker bees for their lives.
cons: Very intrinsically focused for a company that has better than average products. GE is good at acquiring businesses that have good products. However, GE is weak in Product Management. As a result, there is little improvement on products over next 5-10years even though a huge amount is spent on product development. Once competitors catch-up, GE starts lowering its price and hence takes a margin hit. This goes on until the product is unattractive and then GE divests the company.
advice_management: Cut down the multiple layers. Adding a layer to bring two or three businesses under one umbrella doesn't help. The synergies are not there and hence 1+1+1 is not greater than 3.

summary: "Exciting corporate headquarters of diverse multinational corporation."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Smart coworkers, leadership development programs, access to executive leadership.
cons: Removed from main P&Ls, corporate is not really where the action is.
advice_management: With the return of the GE Capital dividend, invest in R&D and M&A.

summary: "Too much administrative requirements that have nothing to do with your job"

cons: Company spends too much time focusing on shareholders and not enough time focusing on customers and employees.  Benefits have gone downhill tremendously over last ten years.
advice_management: We are only here as long as our customers continue to purchase from us.  Make it easier on them.

summary: "Great pay, lack of benefits, unsure future of job site."

cons: The worst thing is the decline in work orders and the government sequestration thats causing an unsure future.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: If you are not a manager, you can get work experience but don't stay.
cons: A manager of 10 hourly employees earns more than an engineer with MS degree. Bonuses for the management are based on them achieving goals sent down from on high. The corporate philosophy places almost all their emphasis on meeting the quarterly financial projections ("numbers"). Goals are often unrealistic so when they are not met, then those doing the actual work in the group must be rated low ("C"). As a result, many engineers do not get pay increases but of course the managers still do and get their bonuses. The Six Sigma quality program was used to take cost out of the business instead of increase work quality. When the economy is bad the management uses it as an excuse to freeze pay and make layoffs instead of figuring out ways to sell more. Etc...

summary: "If you like a more structured research and product development team, this is for you""

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Size of company, talent of teams, some truly great employees. Good communication from executive leadership

summary: "Low growth conglomerate, struggling under the weight of its own hubris"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: some vestiges of its former glory remain in its instant name recognition, which is helpful on a resume
cons: it is simply too big to be innovative anymore and it is disheartening to watch desperate people who have clawed their way to the top, sometimes clamboring over their bosses' heads to get face time with their bosses boss, stab each other in the back to hold their positions in the midst of all the layoffs over the last five years.
advice_management: Thin the ranks of overpaid top level execs and be more nimble; don't think you've modernized just because you transitioned six sigma to lean, because GE is anything but lean.

summary: "GE invests heavily in the training and growth of their employees"

pros: The most competent, motivated, and skilled workforce I have ever worked with.  The most valuable resource at GE is by far the people, I know of many employees that have left to work elsewhere and they either become leaders in their new companies or come back to GE because the love the culture here so much.
cons: Highly technical and competitive, you must be willing to work hard and learn everyday.  The culture here is focused on continued everyday improvement of yourself and your co-workers.  Be prepared for honest developmental feedback and be prepared to actually execute on your personal development plans, including furthering your strengths, but also working on your weaknesses.

summary: "Compared to Countrywide, it was like a breath of fresh air"

cons: Extremely difficult to affect positive change in GE's corporate structure. Middle and upper managers know things are being done wrong, but are powerless to change them. Senior leadership is far more concerned with quarter-to-quarter numbers than long term viability of the businesses and customer loyalty. GE gives lots of leadership training and lip service about opportunities for advancement, but posted leadership positions always require prior experience.

GE gives lots of leadership training and lip service about opportunities for advancement, but posted leadership positions always require prior experience.

Hard environment to work in.
Long Hours

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 8 years
