summary: "Huge company that is a little too diversified"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Incredible effort and resources spent to develop leadership, in those that are nominated through the “Session C” process (yearly employee performance reviews).   Good opportunities if you work hard and get results.
cons: Way too internally focused on the short term numbers.  Spend more time telling people above you what you did last period, and what you are planning to do next period than actually doing anything.  Managers are not given the power to make decisions over what is their responsibility.  Decisions only made after all other managers are in agreement, which requires multiple meetings over months and months.
advice_management: Stop talking about "Simplification" and actually make things simpler.  Get rid of most of the “work flows” and allow your people to manage their responsibilities.   Change the metrics so that we create long term value instead of making our quarterly numbers.  We will never become a great company unless we look further than the end of the quarter.

summary: "Difficult archaic culture with low employee respect at GE Transportation"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: GE produces incredible products, from jet engines to locomotives to MRI machines. It is a product company.
cons: GE is made up of numerous divided and disconnected operations. The cultures vary depending on where the employee is.  from an employee standpoint GE's business producing jet engines is A+ while GE's business producing locomotives is an F. So, if you are considering a job with GE, make sure you look at the operations as separate companies. GE medical and GE aerospace are recommended.  Stay away from GE transportation, where the culture is hard and miserable and new comers are treated as second class citizens.
advice_management: Advice is targeted specifically to the management team in GE Transportation: Make faster decisions.  Appreciate new ideas and new comers to your business.  Get ahead of the technology curve by leveraging solutions from the automotive industry. Slow down on the continuous meetings with the same people, since nothing new gets invented within a committee.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: A lot of leadership and professional development, team members are very smart.
cons: Very competitive environment and it can be easy to get lost in a very large organization.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Multiple units within the corporation that afforded possibilities for job changes.
cons: Outsourcing too much, building own systems, all of which bogged down the underwriting process and made customer service a challenge, as the underwriter!
advice_management: Check with the 'workerbees' before implementing major system overhauls.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years

cons: Still have to work a weekend day even as salaried employee.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years

cons: Dirty place to work. Never believe anything the company tells you they lie about everything they tell the city, the state and their workers.
advice_management: Take some classes on Integrity!

summary: "A solid company that doesn't pay so well"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years

cons: They do not pay very well

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years

cons: Management, Salary is low, no good benefit
advice_management: Need new mid level management

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Pay and benefits are fair
cons: Constant rumors and feelings of instability.  Dealing with a Union.

summary: "Good for the right person, in the right segment, under the right people"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Good, honest lower level employees.  Good advancement opportunity if you like to move and kiss the right rear ends...  Great advancement oppurtunities if you are a minority and female.  Strong focus on training and personal development.
cons: I can only comment on one specific segment of this company, but can honestly say middle management did not walk the talk of upper management. I actually witnessed our business leader cheat twice at company functions and preach about integrity and accountability the next day!!  No joke...  it made me sick to my stomach. Others managed with very unfair, underhanded tactics... Of course, they got promoted!  Management often made decisions that were costly and doomed from day 1, which the people on the ground recognized immediately but could say nothing.  Some employees were assigned major projects and spent months completing the assigned tasks only to have all their work scrapped for another last minute decision.  Very poor forecasting and direction. Crazy pay variances- up to $20k differences for the same job.  One supervisor made less than the people they hired. Of course, discussing salaries with peers was grounds for dismissal. Review process was unfair and did not motivate.  Ratings were handed out on percentage guidelines.  Only x% could be rated excellent, x% good, etc.  Friends and favorites got the high ratings while others often  found random, subjective, unverifiable complaints never mentioned before the review that lowered ratings and raises.  When questioned about one review during an outstanding year, my supervisor simply said "Well, I had to write something negative!"  It was a joke!  Good benefits have dwindled to very poor ones.  Frequent buy-outs caused instability...  I interviewed for my current position three times!  There were also frequent layoffs to cut costs...  all while we still made money in stressed financial times.  Current employees in my old position report being overworked, underappreciated and afraid to say a word for fear of winding up on the next chopping block.
advice_management: Practice what you preach...  Talk to the ground level employees before making decisions you know nothing about...  Don't set an arbitrary deadline for a decision or project and rush to a poor result... Reward employees fairly based on facts...  Keep reducing benefits and you will not retain your stars employees.

summary: "Your experience will entirely depend on who you have as a manager."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Terrific company for early career individuals
Great skills training programs
cons:
Lots of corporate politics
Poor middle management
advice_management: Rewarding short term thinking, (quarter by quarter) is really hurting the organizations.  Real innovation occurs with rewarding a longer term focus.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Part of the GE Corporation (although you can barely tell from the culture of this place).
cons: Disorganized company.  It's been cobbled together through numerous acquisitions that were never well integrated.  Business processes are a mess.  Technology is a patchwork.  Management and HR are horrible.
advice_management: Start recognizing the talent you have in your staff and stop taking advantage of them.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Very stabile company with great people, good benefits and good pay
cons: Hours, hours, hours, Be careful if you value your work life balance as there is none....especially in the finance group. Also, the company is thick with GE culture that adds to the hours expected. Some love it, some don't.
advice_management: Hire more people for amount of work that expected.

demanding.
not compensated based upon your performance

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Some organizations invest heavily in people and work hard to ensure that have the tools and resources they need to be the as effective as possible.
cons: It can feel near impossible to change the mentality at GE or to make a notable difference.  I suspect this is true at most very large companies, but was particularly difficult for me at GE.  GE also relies on data to the extent the metrics overshadow people and common sense.
advice_management: GE would do well to hire good people, good managers and then rely on experience and personal trust to get work done.  Metrics are over-used and work is done to match the metric rather than to resolve the underlining issues.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for less than a year
pros:
Easy to purchase required tools as long as they weren't too expensive.
Very large support system
Many knowledgeable technicians employed
cons:
Pandering to customer throughout unreasonable requests
Too large to accomplish anything effective
Unavailability of required operating documents
advice_management: The customer DOES have a limited culpability sometimes.  Very difficult to achieve contract specifications if the customer maintains their equipment out of specification.  A relationship with a client is supposed to be a symbiotic one.

summary: "Great people and projects, but expect to run into frustrations from time to time"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Generally speaking, great work environment (socially and intellectually). There are many challenging projects to be worked across a wide range of interests. The opportunity exists to expand you knowledge and influence to areas of business outside your field of study.
cons: Culturally, at a turning point. The business must decide how it wants to proceed and take the appropriate actions to make it happen. This has shown signs of improvement, but it seems the adage holds true: "it takes a long time to turn the Titanic." Still many instances of bureaucracy and process driven red tape that holds little to no ultimate value.
advice_management: Take a hard look at what is actually adding value to the company, and take action. Yes the direction of the company is moving, but it must move faster. All sides must be on the same page.

summary: "process driven culture at it's best and worst"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: If you thrive in a process driven culture this is your kind of company!
cons: Process can sometimes get in the way of innovation

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great people, good processes, lots of opportunities
cons: Upper management disconnected, many executives move up the ranks too quickly and lack knowledge depth
advice_management: The fast track 2 years per role, then move to the next role, executive leadership development model does not work well.  Rather than create generalist leaders with no depth, I think they should focus on developing more specialized leaders that have deeper understanding of their areas of expertise.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Strong industrial businesses providing really big solutions to customers. Spend a lot of time developing leadership skills.
cons: Not the best US locations. Though getting better with big hubs in Houston, Chicago, CT.

cons: Bureaucracy slows down the work.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Experienced leadership. GE is a big global player in the energy space (its technology powers ~25% of global energy needs). Company invest in growing its ppl, ex. training, leadership programs.
cons: Schenectady NY is an awful location for young and single people. Sometimes too much of traditional conservative and bureaucratic company. Little diversity results homogeneous narrow minded culture.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year

job_title: Current Employee - Software Distribution and Asset Management Engineer
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Management listens to employees and seem to honestly want feedback. There are a lot of opportunities for growth and advancement. The company is very willing to send you to training classes that target the career goals you have in mind. You will most likely get Six Sigma and Leadership training within the first 1 to 2 years of being on the job. Also may opportunities for technical training if you speak with your manager.
cons: Sometimes it may seem as if you have more than one job.
advice_management: Provide a better benefits package.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
1) Flex Time
2) Competitive Salary (other benefits not competitive...) 
3) Opportunity to travel
4) Work with Global Team
5) Makes high quality products.

This company is very good for technology for interns.  Lot's of opportunities to learn from smart people, and new technologies.  Work / life balance can be very good if you are in the right function.
cons:
The company is driven by politics and ego.  The majority of people spend more time defending why they don't have to do something, instead of just doing it.  A very hostile, competitive environment to work, with lots of wolves in sheeps clothing.   Very little actually gets done, except for power-point presentations with lots of fluff.  Functions are constantly posturing, trying to prove which one is more important (who has most power).

Most in management positions lack integrity, and there are very few people feeling happy and secure there.  Due to insecurity and/or arrogance, most people are constantly trying to "out-do" one another, so there is very little real teamwork.

Due to their inability to compete with Cree and Acuity in the LED realm, and with legislation banning traditional incandescent lighting,  this company is going to go through massive restructuring over the next few years as it's sales continue to nose-dive, as it relies heavily on the brand, which carries little value in the consumer lighting market.

It is going to be like the sinking Titanic, with people trying to run to the back of the boat to survive....everyone trying to save their own skin and stepping on anyone that gets in the way.
advice_management:
Do the right things for the right reasons, instead of for the political reasons.  Many in upper management are incompetent and make bad decisions repeatedly, but remain in important positions because of the politics.  

Instead of firing your 10% when you miss YOUR revenue OP plan, go to the root cause for your lack of sales !!   

Actually listen to your people on the frontline.  They know more than you may think, even if they are not part of the "gentlemen's club".

pros:
Development programs to get new employees up to speed.

Very competitive environment.  Employees fight for promotions and divisions compete for funding.
Certain segments of the company are favored over others.  Make sure you are in a growth business.

Continue to shed underperforming or auxiliary businesses.  GE is too diversified and needs to focus on only a few core competencies.
Reduce reliance on GE Capital.

summary: "Just another call center job - no room for advancement"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Local management tries very hard to create a fun working environment, and to value employee concerns. Job seems to be fairly secure (several DSS representatives have been with the company 25 years) although GE's lighting business itself is declining.  Working hours are strictly defined and working from home is not allowed.
cons: Very few to no opportunities for career advancement.  If you're ambitious, work somewhere else.
advice_management: Create either a "customer service/call center" or "inside sales" position for the current DSS representatives. Don't try to be both with the current role.

cons: Benefits seem competitive, and in many areas pay is too, but not everywhere. It's a complex matrix that can be slow to respond and frustrating to manage through. Employees don't feel a close connection to each other at the major locations, but it's the opposite at smaller ones.
advice_management: Worry as much about the strong performers as you do about the poor ones and that will help. Make sure you find one on one time for the people one below one.

summary: "Small fish in a mammoth but great ocean"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
GE is a huge company that is made up of multiple strong businesses. Irrespective of what role you are in, every day you learn and grow exponentially. The leaders are selected through a tough selection process so any GE leader is a role model. This is the place you need to be to learn leadership skills and grow your business acumen and domain knowledge. Also GE really knows how to sail through tough business cycles with the help of both innovative and effective decision making.

Due to all this I was able to grow from a systems analyst to a seasoned management professional when I quit. I owe a lot of my skills and knowledge to GE.
cons: GE is not a place to be if you would like to grow your technical skills in IT since IT is not a core competency there. Also at times you could feel like very small fish in a mammoth ocean, a cog in the wheel and hence your achievements start looking small in comparison
advice_management: Some India leaders of IT teams try to control their teams as if they are in IT Services, which is far from reality...and they fail!

summary: "OK if you come in straight out of college"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: Great Vacation and Sick day benefits. Good systems and tools. Supports diverse employees as long as you dress and act like everyone else.
cons: GE is risk averse and conservative in spending. Great place to be if you come in through one of the many college hire programs. Those are the people that get promoted. If you join later, career growth can be a real challenge or nonexistent. People with 10 to 15 years of experience are considered interchangable. Employees are not important unless they are senior level or higher. To move up you have to change jobs and cities every 2 years.
advice_management: No advice since no one will care unless you are really high up in the company. Until GE stops believing that they have all the answers and that those answers are the BEST, they will continue their downward slide.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: GE has been smart enough to stay around for a long time because management is pragmatic and tries to stay grounded in real numbers and safe bets.
cons: Risk taking is not always rewarded, even when successful. GE tends to take safe bet and looks for innovative ideas that they can buy through aquisitions rather than branching out and trying new things themselves.
advice_management: Find a way to communicate your vision for the future of the business than by telling us the revenue you want to achieve. Having an end goal is great, but you need to tell us how you want us to get there.

summary: "The employees are among the best people."

advice_management: Buzz words do not equal leading.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time

Lots of great opportunities

cons: Can be too big at times a lot of red tape
advice_management: Simplify all of your administrative policies

summary: "Great legacy, but not near the technical or managerial titan of the past"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Job Security, Incredible dedication and talent at the working level, many employees work from home and even in the office no one punches a clock, Quick promotions if you fit the right "profile". GE will go to the ends of the earth to keep from laying off or terminating employees, regardless of their job performance.
cons: Lack of accountability. Processes, programs, complicated software "solutions" that are rolled out business wide are routinely problem plagued, bug filled, and developed and implemented by teams that do not understand the business or customers. Operational teams are forced to immediately develop work arounds that sometimes exist for years until the process problems are at least partially corrected. No one is ever held accountable for these failures, on the contrary the individuals are often promoted. Many middle level managers have no idea exactly what or how their direct reports do their jobs since understanding how a particular business functions is seldom a job requirement to be a manager in that business. No or tiny promotions if you don't fit the right "profile". HR structure and policies make it extremely difficult, time consuming and labor intensive to terminate non performing employees.

summary: "6 years in GE Energy Air Filtration Sourcing Organization"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Good compensation relative to other companies, constant training, high expectations.  Very much enjoyed co-workers and my cross-functional team.
cons:
Our small business has had 4 different General Managers in my 6 years - I've had 3 different direct managers in the same time.  Thus the vision and path to achieve it has changed pretty radicaly multiple times.

Only as our office is closing is there any real interest to deeplu understand what I do and how I do it.
advice_management: I don't have any advice.

summary: "GENERAL ELECTRIC MEDICAL SYSTEMS, INCORPORATED is not a company I would ever agree to work for in the future."
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: They started me out at a good salary - had good benefits package.
cons: Uses SixSigma Program as blackmail tool to squeeze ideas out of employees. No SixSigma report, No raise possibility.
advice_management: Stop doing what is described above. As a result of my experiences with your company, i would NEVER work for a SixSigma company - any SixSigma company - EVER!!!! This company requires all employees to submit SixSigma reports on a minimum of one per year in order to be even be eligible for a cost of living increase in salary. in addition, they allowed no time during the normal work day to prepare these reports. The employees were EXPECTED to come in on weekends and stay late in order to complete them. If an idea was accepted, you were rewarded with theater tickets or something similar - even if the idea saved the company millions. Upped management really loved this SixSigma program - probably got them huge bonuses. Personally, I think it stunk to high heaven!!!! And so do they!!!!

summary: "It was a very rewarding, enriching and valuable opportunity"

summary: "Little Vision, Big Company, Out of Date, Grim Future"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: One of the world's largest companies, but losing ground.  The Power side of the business is dying and no one wants to believe it, but they will continue to sink money into NPI on secondary technology.  Very top heavy so as a manager you will make one or two decisions a year making your job pointless and very easy.  Training programs are amazing.
cons: Executive management has lost touch with reality.  Strategy or vision is one provided by a training class.  The job Czar is worried about doing the right thing and chopping necessary dead weight in COEs, research centers, and Greenville.  India technology and engineering centers are a joke, and domestic resources are significantly more productive but the global imagine looks better for the company.
advice_management: Very few born leaders and the GE created Executives sound good push the company lines but can't think or lead on their own.  Please own up to the mistakes and take the one time shot and clean your organization up... You will go red on your matrix but save your company and make it a better place for the future.

cons: Health care costs higher than many other employers, politics/bureaucracy, large offshore presence with IT.
advice_management: Work harder at retaining top employees rather than replacing with offshore resources.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Good Salary, Good Benefits, Great Projects, Great Colleagues, Generally Good Management,

advice_management: Watch the E Band old boy/girl networks. Power goes to their heads.

summary: "Good experiences could be made Great experiences"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Highly skilled, hard-working employees who strive to be the best at what they do.  Family-type atmosphere at my site.  Opportunities for advancement though may require relocation.  Great communication to employees.
cons: Work/Life balance is not as good as it once was.  Increasing headcount in Operations, Engineering and Quality organizations means increased workload for support functions but they get no relief.  Fifty to sixty hour weeks are common.  Simplification needs to be applied to all processes.  Takes numerous workflows and approvals to get anything done.
advice_management: SImplify all processes.

summary: "Enjoyed my experience working for the company."

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years

cons: At times, focus on quarterly earnings over shadows customer needs.

summary: "Lots of talent, a good company to work for and to have on your resume"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
- a truly global company
- lots of great talent and very smart team - way above average and almost no low performers
- lots of opportunities to learn and acquire new skills
- pretty good pay
- lots of work responsibilitties and you're able to work on huge projects
cons:
- poor medical benefits
- lots of red tape
- a very hierarchical structure
- senior leadership only expects to hear good news, few are brave to say how things really are
- unclear strategies from the very top
advice_management:
- encourage open communication and "force" people to talk about problems: managers are needed to fix problems and build upon success
- cultivate a culture that appreciates people's work and acknowledges their successes

summary: "GE is a great company that treats interns like employees."
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Great benefits, interesting work, global company
cons: Can sometimes get lost in the shuffle

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
-Big company that provides infrastructure globally (water, power, healthcare, transportation, finance)
-Meritocracy: Best people rise
-Constant feedback: Provides regular feedback (often tough)
cons:
-Slow to change: lots of process
-Bureaucratic with senior roles going to central staffers rather than those driving business results 
-Risk averse
advice_management: Drive an entrepreneurial spirit, Reward people who follow-through on implementing their ideas rather than those who move every 2 years after making change

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Large organization with opportunities to move.  Good place to hide for a career as long as you have decent performance appraisals.
cons: Politically correct environment which is heavy on bureaucracy and work flows.  Constant talk of "simplification" but have not seen anything other than lip service.  Abundant job hopping, especially in management ...which is encouraged for growth (best route within the company) but horrible for business continuity.  Matrix Organization intended to cause creative stress, but should be renamed to Siloed Fiefdom Organization to reflect reality.  Also, bonus structure tied to unrealistic goals (20% increase in revenue for 2013? Really? Pure fantasy. For the record, we are down to plan by about 10%.... well outside of the bonus range unless you are in the Executive Band [EB]).
advice_management: Follow through... make the process more simple, but restructure matrix so one manager has some control and is able to set direction instead of hoping the collective does not have key individuals worried more about their career advancement as opposed to the organizational needs,

summary: "The two happiest days of my (professional) life, the day GE hired me and the day I resigned."
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros:
- Compensation & benefits were decent
- About 1/3 of the people you work with are truly pleasant to work with
- The company name caries prestige
cons:
God, where to begin...
- The majority of leadership I encountered were incredibly demanding of their subordinates, but rarely held themselves accountable for anything
- Be prepared to spend a sizable amount of time per day on CYA activities; seriously this will become your new part time job
- Get used to senior leadership having 'favorites' and God help you if you're not one of them
- Do you like a 40 hour work week? Double it.
- Don't care for profanity in meetings? No one cares, get used to it.
- Need support from a leader to resolve an item at work?  You'd better hope you've done something for them lately or it's not going to happen.
advice_management: Haha, as if they'd ever stoop to take feedback from their employees, seriously I laughed a bit to myself at the prospect of giving advice to those people.

summary: "Over 20 years of experience in the Test Engineering field"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: One of the top companies in this country
cons: you can get loss in the paper shuffle
advice_management: Hire quality people

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Competitive salary and benefits for employees with longer service history.
cons: New employees salary and benefits package differ from employees with long service history.
advice_management: Options for exempt employees to work from home offices is slowly deteriorating productivity and accountability.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: With plenty of opportunities for growth the company is one where you can move ahead no matter what gender or race you belong to. Equal opportunities and its leadership courses are world class.
cons: Salary is a bit on low side and benefits could be better but still a great place to work in.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Great training experience for a fresh graduate
cons: Relocating  very often, if you don't like that

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: the people are great. Comfortable environment.
cons: almost nothing. Normal company politics.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great Pay, and many situations and jobs to become a very big asset to the overall value of the company.
cons: Difficult people. Sometimes an atmosphere was created to compete for management's affection.
advice_management: Be more unbiased

summary: "Great products,  good people, and typical mgmt nonsence"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
GE makes some truly great products - especially in their Healthcare and Power & Water divisions
At the entry and mid-career level they pay well and have competitive benefits
cons:
Management has the same political BS that is evident in most large corporation.
GE is a highly distributed corporation and it is quite common to have a team spread out across the US or globally and even your own manager in another part of the world.   It is tough to have a team concept or unity in this setting.
advice_management:
Optimize teams locally instead of proliferating the world-wide model
Treat all team members the same regardless of geographic location - items like bonuses should be equally distributed regardless if one is the in the home office or a remote office

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Opportunity, balance, benefits, safe compliant atmosphere, lots of support. I loved working for GE. Change is always going on.
cons: Degree required to be hired for most positions, Change is always going on.
advice_management: Having a degree does not always make the perfect knowledgable employee.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Smart people, making and selling neat products. Brand maintenance is key at this company.
cons: Hard work seems to be less important than the appearance of hard work and bootlicking to leadership program coordinators.
advice_management: Let's stop serving so much Kool-aid to the younger crowd.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Great people, great projects. Was a great place to work.
cons: None that I can think of

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great learning experience for me, lots of smart people and challenging tasks.
cons: A very Competitive  environment but kept me looking forward
advice_management: Great training system for young professionals!

summary: "GE is a great place to work"
main_text: I have been working at GE part-time for more than 10 years
pros: You can have a multi-dimensional career within one company and can carve your own path
cons:
constant reorganization
Spend a lot of time making sure you will have a good role for the next reorg, so you become too internally focused
advice_management: Invest for the long-term, not just the next 2-3 years.  Technology is changing our environment quickly and we need to build the framework vs reacting to it.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: ability to have 4 jobs in 2 years, gain domain expertise, grow your network, work on projects that are very significant to the business (sometimes with $MM in impact). Six Sigma Green Belt Certification, 100% paid tuition to either Georgia Tech, NC State, or UCONN technical engineering masters degree.
cons: You must be committed and have a strong passion for engineering. Buisiness taught Graduate School courses are challenging and have large time commitments. Many deliverables are required outside the typical 40 hr work week.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
lots to learn
many opportunities
great people
cons:
takes too long to find your way
not the best benefit-wise

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: very good posiiton to hold
cons: very busy with all projects

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: great place to learn, contribute, make the career you want
cons:
bureaucracy
layers
pace of change is slow
advice_management: be bold, actions talk

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Great Company to work for, a lot of room to grow within company.
cons: Must manage your own career.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: great place to work lots of growth
cons: none to think of right now

summary: "Highly Competent People, Gap between Leaders and Employees"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Strong ethics background.  People are very capable and competent.  Follow leadership direction.  Huge strength in organization and backing.  Excellent training and development.  Working on organization simplification, again.  Don't track vacation, personal time, or sick time.
cons: Quarterly driven, rather than focus on long term sustaining strategy.  Lost discipline with Lean and Six Sigma, and Quality programs.  Arrogance displayed with customers and suppliers.  Employees are disposable.  Complicated Matrix Organization.  Functionally driven.  No root-cause analysis for fact based decisions. Problems are unacceptable if not presented with immediate solution.  Tough to leave if you are well compensated compared to external market.  Benefits package has deteriorated, including medical and retirement.  Metrics driven and must work lots of hours, with high stress.
advice_management: Be willing to surface problems and learn from mistakes.   Look at the gap with the GE Employee Opinion Survey and resolve the difference between Executives and Senior Professional employees.  Stop spinning the numbers.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: It is still considered to be a resume builder to work at The General Electric Co but that value is diminishing daily.
cons: It is too massive. The benefits are reserved for the very top. And even my boss felt like a number. Worst of all, my stock is worth half of what I paid for it.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Good stable work environment. A lot of opportunities for new positions and advancements
cons: Company culture is very strict. Executives walk on water.

summary: "Happy with challenges, team & industry impact, often frustrated with bureaucracy and size."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: GE is a leader in every industry we pursue.  I have found tremendous opportunities to make an impact within the GE company, thereby influencing an entire industry segment.  I have been given tremendous flexibility on my job scope, work-life balance and have been compensated very well.
cons: It can be easy to get lost in such a large organization, and the pathway to promotion is not always clear.  Compensation is generally lower than smaller companies with equivalent job titles for most employees.  Health benefits were recently dramatically reduced.
advice_management: Further simplification of the business is key to employee morale.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
-Global focus
-Strong leaders
-Moves fast
-Cross business and functional moves
cons: Corporate is too CT focued

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: many experts in different fields. global opportunities, can transfer to  many places, if you prefer. good green card policy. relatively efficient
cons: non-competitive pay, esp. seniors. poor retention rate. management seems not care. poor health insurance, very high deductible.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Good Benefits but slowly declining,
cons: advancement oppurtunities limited, Pay raises not very common, senority means nothing.
advice_management: More accentives to advance

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Excellent Resources and talent to learn from. Engaged management allows you to express your ideas.
cons: Huge company and some times you are treated as a number.
advice_management: Keep listening and acting on employees advice from bottom up.  Simplify complicated systems and processes. Improve negotiation of purchased  parts price and long term agreements.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great culture, great experience and the smartest people you will ever work with.
cons: Work life balance can be challenging

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: New and exciting technologies for Trains.  Great co-workers and a 100+ year history of Engineering and Manufacturing in Erie, PA.
cons: Old plant, old offices and crowded work environments.  The movement of the headquarters to Chicago and the recent layoff announcement in Erie, after opening a new manufacturing facility in Fort Worth.  The current atmosphere in Engineering is negative.
advice_management: There needs to be more communications between the management and the employees.  Many recent events (Management move to Chicago, New manufacturing in Fort Worth, and pending layoffs) have us confused over the future of engineering and manufacturing in Erie, PA.

main_text: I have been working at GE  for more than 5 years
pros: Culture, Brand, Values, I am not sure
cons: One has to market themselves if not you stay where you were.
advice_management: Think long term; not short term margin improvements.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: Lots of opportunity and a tremendous opportunity for Talent development
cons: Too big of a company

main_text: I worked at GE
pros:
Rotational programs are some of the best in class
True "meritocracy"
cons: Compensation may not be worth the hours
advice_management: The GE way can be "old" to young professionals

main_text: I have been working at GE

cons: repeated works, don't see much future as a statistician....

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years

cons: Benefits: high deductible makes the healthcare coverage like a catastrophic medical insurance
advice_management: Motivate and energize your employees

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years

cons: Not as agile given the size, non risk taking, healthcare costs shifted more to employees, processes are not always simple.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year

cons: Big company- kinda get that big fish in small pond feeling.
advice_management: Be on time to meetings.

summary: "Solid company that offers great security and opportunity."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Stability, training, benefits, opportunities, flexible
cons: The company is excellent but seems to be a hostage at times of political pressures.
advice_management: Management is excellent and company is headed in right direction

summary: "For your own good do not work for this company"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: It looks good for your resume
cons: Working for GE is an worst experience in my career. I have been working 70 hours a week. And the manager expect you put a lot of over times to your work. There is no bonus or over time pay. I have been a healthy people of my whole life. Recently I got seriously sick due to the high stress, toxic environment and over work. The company advertises they value leadership but those are just false advertising. The culture is hypocritical.
advice_management:
Tell the truth to people. Stop lying. 
ITIL program does not work. The young kids who just graduate from regular college and have no experience at all should not be the manager. Even they are cheap but those incompetent people will negatively affect many people's life

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years

cons: Rely too much on overseas resources because they are cheaper, so US-based jobs were cut significantly while overseas jobs keep growing
advice_management: Take care of your US employee

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 8 years

cons: Understaffed, Benefits, way too many clients, need to focus more on employee development, very clicky, managing up is more important than doing a great job.
advice_management: Stop making so many changes that seem to be knee jerk reactions to stockholder feedback.  Listen to your employees.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years

cons: Growth is flat. No growth

cons: There are a lot of office politics and you do have to cover your backside often.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year

summary: "Great business to get your foot in the door with GE"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Employees are passionate about what they do.  Strong sales teams across the US.  Great atmosphere to work in, very relaxed.  Work/Life balance is very good and management respects this.
cons: Leadership has made many poor product and investment decisions over the past 5-10 years.  Sales is responsible for EVERYTHING.  You cannot grow a business with this structure.
advice_management: Let the regions run the regions.  Better say-do ratio.  Lots of smooth talkers in leadership positions that do not get the job done.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Global company with a strong and challenging culture.
cons: So big that is bureaucratic as any government.
advice_management: Road blocks on every step...  Very difficult to really be a changing agent.

summary: "OK if you want to either move bilaterally or stay in the same position"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for less than a year
pros:
Good pay
Great time off
Reasonable accommodations for work environment 
Recognition
cons:
Redundant
Boring
Horrible customers
Bad employees make great money because they're ruthless
advice_management: Overall, great place to begin working out of college if you're in need of a place to make some money, however my managers were not college educated and I am...I felt like my background was not appreciated. I enjoyed customer service but felt like it didn't matter how well I treated my customers if the person beside me got a bonus too and was rude but made her numbers. Needs to be a way to treat people fairly but recognize good service.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Stability, flexibility, ability to move up
cons: Long hours, stressful conditions at times

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great opportunities for advancement within the Company
cons: The health benefit was the main reason I joined GE and it's definitely not what it used to be.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Was exposed to a new type of business environment.  Learned allot.
cons: GE gave you many tools to do your job. Little training was given and tools were correct about 60% of the time.
advice_management: Give your people more training and tools that work.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Benefits, growth, scope. Being one of the largest companies in the world has some weight.
cons: Rigid review, many business units are fragmented. Exploring new technology not at the top of the list due to scope.
advice_management: Accept technology

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: So big with so many groups working in silos, you can basically collect a paycheck forever flying under the radar.
cons: Management nowhere near what it used to be. Constant restructuring, no career path, managers change ever six months.
advice_management: Bring Jack Back! Switch focus back to customer satisfaction instead of cheapest outsourced solution.

summary: "great place to learn and develop your career"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: GE does and excellent job investing in training for their employees. The work content is great and you're given a lot of responsibilities early on. This is a great place to start, and if you want to, finish, your career.
cons: Pay is too low to keep the best talent. There are not bonus so its a low risk, low reward career choice. There are definitely ways to accelerate your career, especially in finance by joining the corporate audit staff, but ultimately the company overvalues this. Also, in the finance function you feel very disconnected to the customer.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Good place to work, good income and good friends
cons: many opportunities and hard to specialize

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: Incredible opportunities... Big Company...Great leadership
cons: Big Company, Metrics may compete against one another
advice_management: Focus on excellence in all areas.  Motivate your people to do the same.  Continue to invest in the next generation of leaders that demonstrate potential.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Obviously GE has perfected numerous best practices and is usually operating at the forefront of efficiency. In addition, the opportunities for ownership and differentiation are abundant. Corporate training is top notch as you are learning right next to some of the smartest people in the world.
cons: Culture can definitely be abrasive. Many individuals who had been with the company for 20+ years but weren't in an executive band position seemed to be hollow inside. This is one of the main reasons I left.
advice_management: HR has a long way to go. They never once helped me with anything. That is, they often got involved, they just made life more difficult rather than help me in any way shape or form. Probably because they are so focused on moving up the ladder and don't care about the people they are responsible for during the 18 months they're in a role.

summary: "A good place to work .... for a few years, may be"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: GE Energy has friendly co-workers, healthy work atmosphere and flexible hours. There is excellent technology being produced and engineers in particular, get to work on competitive products. A lot of knowledge exists in design reports and there is a lot one can learn from.
cons: GE Energy's higher management lacks strategy especially concerning its workforce. There is little recognition for the work that employees produce working in high pressure environments, most typically about 50 hours a week. Pay raises are meager to non-existent. Growth is super slow. Work can get monotonous very quickly and the senior management does not seem to care about its employees saturating. Conservative and rotten HR policies make for a nightmare, and it is easy to lose motivation.
advice_management: Value your employees. Address their pressing concerns quickly and rapidly. GE is where it is more because of the employees at the lowest rung than because of executives who make big bucks.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: You could probably work your whole life with a decent salary, good benefits, and comfortable work environment here.
cons: It is boring and slow.
advice_management: You're doing a good job, it's just the nature of the industry.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Great Job to begin career
cons: Nothing Really bad to say
advice_management: Keep it up

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Great benefits and tuition reimbursement.
cons: It is a battle of the passive-aggressives clawing their way to be recognized.  The managers are the weakest lot I have ever seen.  GE embraces the matrix reporting structure whereby nobody is accountable and face-to-face interaction is out-moded by Web-ex and conference calling.
advice_management: Hire actual managers to manage and lead groups.  Let the engineers solve technical problems and leave them out of the leadership roles.  Lose the matrix reporting structure; your employee effectiveness is greatly reduced by layers non-action protected by 'managers' who seem oblivious.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Good company to work at.
cons: Enjoyed working there. Don't have anything negative to say.
advice_management: Keep up the good work

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: GE is an established company with well-established product development plans.  There was clear and concise information from management about the program goals at the front end of the project, but they were willing to adjust those goals depending on feedback from other groups.  GE has a number of process and systems in place to promote and challenge their employees.  The company is so large and diverse, there is never a lack of opportunity within the company.
cons: GE continually challenges its employees, which can lead to stressful work situations.  The benefits were not great when I was there.  New employees (regardless of previous work experience) were given 2 weeks of vacation.  There was pressure on the employees to not take much vacation during the year but to save it for around the end of the year (most employees take off the last two weeks of the year).  In addition, the healthcare contribution was significant for families and were high deductible plans.
advice_management: The company has a good vision and good overall technical and project management, but better benefits and work/life balance would be helpful for employee retention.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Plenty of work to go around, whether on customer projects or new product development. Good working environment where everyone has an office of their own. The salary is competitive for the area. I generally enjoy the people that I work with. Minimal drama.
cons: Legacy product with little room for incorporating new technologies in any substantial way. Not many opportunities for advancement outside of management.
advice_management: We need less upper management.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
- Great people
- Good Benefits
- Okay environment
cons: - Not much challenge, same thing everyday. If this is what you want to do the rest of your life, then this is the place for you.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
The schedule is very flexible.  - Flexibility
The leaders are in place to make sure that the company succeeds - Leadership
cons:
It is a business based off of culture.  
Does not allow for outsiders to grow and prosper.

summary: "Great place to work, learn with a job satisfaction"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Working environment, friendly colleagues and good learning options
cons: not much to list here as I didnt see any
advice_management: as of now..nothing

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: - Easy commute for ppl who live in San Ramon. For others there are better companies on the other side
cons:
- Some very questionable ppl have been given Senior positions in this office who have no clue what they are doing 
- Questionable hiring practices 
- Current Management lack proper training, communication skills and don't know how to talk to their employees 
- If you want to get hired, you need to know someone or be related to someone. Very shady.
advice_management: Senior GE management should look into hiring and HR issues within this location before they blow up.

job_title: Current Employee - Engineering Design Lead - Composites
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
The salaries are fair.
The flex time makes the job easier.
Being such a large company, the job options are limitless.
Working for GE always looks good to other potential employers.
cons: The hours worked and multiple personalities that you will encounter can become cumbersome at times.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: Stable company, learning curve really high
cons: Employees are commodity. The management has no idea about the skill set of employees.
advice_management: Learn to interact with the employees and take suggestions

summary: "Good stepping stone to start your career"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Good internal mobility to move to different groups
cons: Low pay vs a lot of industry competitors

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros:
- Opportunities are everywhere, but they are what you make of them.
- Majority of people are great to work with and are generally very bright and willing to lend a hand.
- Advancement of technology and information sharing is paramount to driving innovation and future growth.
cons:
- Large corporation with complex organizational structure and lots of bureaucracy.
- Government oversight due to the nature of the business reduces speed of developing new technologies and slows new product introduction to the market.

summary: "GE used to be a GREAT company. It is not a mediocre company."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: There are many super-talented, experienced, creative and impressive people working in GE. Unfortunately, those people rarely advance to become senior leaders within the company, but they are wonderful people to work with. The GE culture is tough, demanding and aggressive. I say those things all in a positive light, as my own personal style closely matches the "GE persona."
cons:
For the past several years, most senior managers are not leaders, visionaries, and can easily pitch out buzzwords and speak about "driving growth" "innovation" and "collaboration."

In reality, most senior managers care exclusively about managing their own resumes to land their next gig either in GE or elsewhere. If you want to be inspired and learn from senior leaders, get a good book or watch an inspiring TED Talk. You won't find it here.
advice_management: Stop promoting people who are nothing but "taking heads" who simply repeat empty, meaningless buzzwords that they don't understand themselves. There is a tremendous pool of talented employees within the ranks with more active braincells than most of the folks sitting in corner offices. What a shame.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: GE is committed to developing leadership.  In order to take on big projects, a team needs to take risks to differentiate from the competition, and GE encourages this type of leadership challenge for all its technologists.
cons: It is a big company so filling out the online forms to get a job done can be tedious.  Overall, it is a good system and we try to improve efficiency of the system all the time.  Which is good overall but leads to constant change (that leads to employee complaints).
advice_management: Keep up the good work trying to steer the big ship by always re-evaluating our systems for constant improvement.

summary: "Had a good experience on leadership program, learned a lot, but ultimately was not able to pursue desired career path."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: The pay and benefits were good, ample training was provided, company values were in line with my beliefs
cons: Competing metrics between departments often led to inefficiencies, stressful environment at times, understaffed and took a long time to backfill vacated positions
advice_management: Allow young, high potential employees to move laterally and gain different expertise and explore interests.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: benefits, environment, opportunity, development, people
cons: Can't think of any cons at this point

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Ge allows movement throughout the company easily.  Moving to different locations is not hard to do.  Lots of options throughtout the world.
cons: They make short term decisions that bite them in the @ss.  Very quick to reduce headcount to meet a yearly number.  Also global locations seem to be underperforming compared to US counterparts
advice_management: When making headcount decisions, use caution.  These are people not numbers

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Challenging work with great colleagues
cons: A little chaotic, vision is sometimes blurred by timeline

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
- Opportunities to grow and travel.
- Leadership programs available 
- Good place to build strong foundation of business skills
cons:
