- Can get lost in the large organization
- Pay is average

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Meaningful, interesting work, strong leadership
cons: Long work hours expected, alot of work

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
- Sheer size & scale of operations 
- Great internal leadership programs such as FMP, CAS etc.
- Generally intelligent & driven employees
cons:
- Fed oversight bearing heavily on productivity, creativity & profitability at GE Capital
- Industrial side of business not growing earnings quickly enough
- Tax as one of top 5 P&L's by net income: probably sustainable, not equitable
- Too inward-looking at all but highest levels
advice_management: Fix Healthcare business, open Crotonville up to lower-level employees

summary: "Great people that make up the company, but bureacratic processes."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
- great businesses built for the future
- strong quality of co-workers
- constant acquisitions which provide personal growth opportunities
- good compensation for strong performers
- fantastic personal development opportunities both skill set and learning/training
cons:
- I work 10-12 hours a day with frequent weekend "catch-up"
- email is incessant... there are very few admins so you have to balance strategy with tactical
- the better you perform the more you get until you leave while poorer performers in the same job/band fly under the radar without much repercussion
advice_management: GE has become overly matrixed and bureaucratic - too many approvals, tie-offs across multiple lines of business and regions while not enough holding people accountable for delivering for our customers and shareholders.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time
pros: great work environment, competitive salary, great people, ideas encouraged, large network, endless opportunities, and knowing I was a part of something great
cons: none at all. This was a great place to work and I would highly recommend it to anyone.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Strong leadership, excellent training, extremely strong senior leadership.  Highly technical company that manufactures goods in the United States.
cons: Bureaucracy.  Your value in the company is dependent on your ability to network across a web of stakeholders.  May not be a good fit for some.
advice_management: Simplify the business structure

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Structured, visible path for moving through the company
cons: There tends to be a lot of bureaucracy

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Get to work on great game-changing products and technologies
cons: Senior mgmt consistently disregards estimates of level of effort to get jobs done, putting the team in no-win situations.  Working hard is one thing, undue and unnecessary stress is another.
advice_management: Listen to your people who are your greatest asset.  You don't want to kill the geese who are laying golden eggs for you.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: innovative, changing the world, always reinventing itself and challenging its employees. everyone is working towards the same objective.
cons: no real cons come to mind immediately
advice_management: the increased communication in the past few years been great, keep it going

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Diverse, challenging work
Opportunity to switch functions / industries
Smart, competitive co-workers
cons:
Bureacratic and political
Undercompensated for performance
advice_management: Focus on developing talent instead of group harmony

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Broad range of experience in 4 different rotational roles
cons: A significant number of unhappy employees
advice_management: continue with the same

summary: "My experience was average as at most big firms"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Great brand, good locations, good starter company, lots of locations, easy to swicth jobs, lots of sub divisions, lots of opportunities to move around
cons: average pay, lots of hours, people are usually jack asses, minimal respect for work, squeeze work out of you with teh carrot being not fired and stick being the pink slip
advice_management: Start paying people well.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great culture , management and product breath.
cons: Short term goals and expectations , too many changes which affect customers loyalty
advice_management: More customer inclusiveness and business continuity

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Good Salary, Good Benefits, Oppurtunity to move between businesses, Diverse Experience
cons: Everyone is just a number, Either compromise your ethics or you will not move up in the company, lots of managers that are inept and got there because of years in and politics
advice_management: Actually enforce the Spirit and Letter Policy, Break down politicing and cronyism, take a look at what is really going on at the lowest levels of the company, I guarantee you would be embaressed.

summary: "Great place to settle into a career . . ."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Easily one of the best places to work if you're interested in learning how to manage people.  GE basically wrote the book on people management (and for good reason).  It's been around on the NYSE since it's inception and makes a huge effort in developing future leaders.  Great company if you're a more seasoned professional in Finance, Legal, or one of the hard Engineering Sciences (Mechanical, Electrical, Material).
cons: Software Engineer and Computer Science employees are quite often referred to as simply "IT".  This can be very troubling if you want to develop great software products or simply be on the cutting edge of technology.  Very bureaucratic, often to the point of reduced productivity.  Definitely a management culture and not an engineering culture.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: GE Consumer and Industrial promotes innovation. It appreciates its employees.
cons: Some of the corporate requirements detract from overall employee satisfaction. For instance, there is too much focus on variouse "compliance initiatives".
advice_management: Try to lessen corporate beurocracy.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Interesting work, lots of smart minds around, high level of technical work, flexible hours.
cons: Bad work environment, no windows, very corporate feel

summary: "Fair relationship with the company but I wouldn't return"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Good benefits and volunteer opportunities
cons:
Too many layers
Lack of work style diversity
advice_management: Embrace innovation

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Cutting edge management techniques. Learn from the best. Always the best equipment. More of a meritocracy than most companies I've worked for e.g. Lockheed Martin, DuPont, Xerox. No place for drones to hide. Either perform or out.
cons: No longer offer pension to new hires. Draconian health care plan that sucks money from your pocket. Great sick and personal day allowances..... but if you use them, it's frowned upon and mentioned during your annual review.
advice_management: The performance of employees is what drives the bottom line. Since Immelt took over, he is reducing benefits of employees and taking money from their checks. Sooner or later this will lead to an exodus of top-notch people and the general quality of employee will decline... as will profits and the stock price. Pay more attention to the long term consequesces of your "bottom line" employee-squeezing decisions today.

summary: "Solid company but difficult for new employees to learn the politics and how to navigate the system"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Great brand recognition, many of the factory employees have been around a long time and have a ton of knowledge
cons: Sales management a local regional levels lacks sufficient leadership skills to be effective.  Local account managers are held accountable for everything but have no authority to make changes bases on current market conditions.  GE Industrial policy of signing any distributor up only pits GE distributor against GE distributor which erodes market pricing.  Too much of of the good old boy network means local sales management never gets challenged or held accountable.
advice_management: Move DSMs out of that role after 5-7 years, they get to the point where all they worry about is doing and saying anything to keep their jobs.  When you have account managers turnover at the rate of 4-5 every 2-3 years then management is not doing their job.

summary: "How badly do you want to succeed?"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
- Learn a lot
- Have a ton of responsibility
- Move up quickly as long as you have the right connections
cons:
- No work/life balance
- Higher expectations of people without children
- Constant finger pointing
- It's all about who you know, not necessarily what you do
advice_management: Feedback on how to improve is always valuable, but a pat-on-the-back (or maybe a thank you) can be motivating every now and again.

summary: "One of the best companies to begin your career."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Excellent mentoring program. The staff is real helpful
cons: Too big to get lost!
advice_management: Keep up the good work

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Opportunity to grow, consistent training and development, great people to work with and for, good salary
cons: Benefits aren't as good as they used to be. But at what company are they.
advice_management: Continue staying in touch with employees doing day to day operations

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Big company; the new hire programs are good, most companies copied GE.
cons: Too big, too much red tape, difficult to get anything done, you'll be relegated to a cubicle and most of the people there typically just suck

summary: "Lots to learn in a postive environment."
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: There is a lot to learn.  The people there for the most part are easy to get along with, easy to work with.  The people are helpful and friendly.
cons: There is more bureaucracy and red tape than I have ever seen in my career.   It is sometimes hard to get things done because of all the permission one needs to obtain.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Many different projects, wide spectrum of people (with diverse scientific backgrounds), connection between research center and GE businesses
cons: Sometimes technical depth is missing, projects are on annual cycles, poor continuity of projects, politics like in every large company
advice_management: focus more on technical advancement and innovation than on EHS

summary: "So far, GE Software has given me unbelievable support, recognition and opportunities for growth."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros:
- Market-competitive compensation
- Smart, team-oriented and supportive colleagues
- Commitment to excellence and to GE Values
cons:
- Commute to San Ramon is unpleasant, for most tech professionals
- Open work space approach works well for developers and engineers, but is disastrous for Marketing, HR, Finance. Difficult to impossible to hold effective meetings (even by phone) or to do any sort of critical or abstract thinking
advice_management:
- Consider the best of Silicon Valley approaches to improve location challenge
1) Satellite offices
2) Work from home flexibility
3) Company shuttles

- Ditto with open work space challenge -- build offices for your top talent.

summary: "Good place to work if you can handle the bureaucracy."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: The culture is very relaxed, the business is very profitable, and the people are generally all around good and smart people. Work/Life balance usually has a pretty high priority.
cons: The salaries are just average, annual raises are typically small (average less than 3%), lots of bureaucracy within the GE matrix organization. Upper management sometimes also has a habit of selling products that don't exist, which creates a strain on the engineering teams.
advice_management: It would be better if the upper management rewarded employees for hard work. Especially when a particular business (such as Bently Nevada) is very profitable.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Very committed to personal and career development. Immense resources. Good benefits
cons: Lots of bureaucracy. Even tiny decisions need to get approval many levels up.
advice_management: Keep benefits packages strong or employee retention will suffer

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros:
Great co-workers
Great Benefits
Opportunity to work in various industries
cons: Not a lot of downsides
advice_management: Better followup on the annual Goals and Objectives

summary: "GE Houston  Horrible took a 10K pay cut just to get away"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: competitive pay is about the only positive thing i can say about this company but with the benefits getting as bad as they were i'm not even sure if the pay makes up for it.
cons: Horrible management,  GE bought our offshore service company and brought in their own management. They had no idea about our industry and no idea about our product. They didn't follow our policies or their own, if you had an issue and it actually fell under a policy they would just change the policy or ignore it all together. They skimped on everything from tools, supplies, software, you name it, it wasn't uncommon to bring something from home just to be able to complete a job. There was also a horrible attitude when it came to the customers so long as the customer didn't know it was wrong then it was okay. This attitude was directly from our upper management and just had a trickle down effect. It was definitely a blame  game with very little accountability.
advice_management: Reevaluate, put a little more value in actual experience, we had guys with 10+ years of experience leaving left and right because of our management or lack of.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros:
-Good Learning Opportunity
-Lots of job opportunities
-ok to move to different fields of interest
cons:
-pay tends to be below market
-high work loads with long hours
-poor health care
advice_management: movements to lessen employee benifits without compensation has reduced the number of people that feel the need to lock in with the company for a long career.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Good emphasis on getting correct processes in place.  Large company that seems to put emphasis on mobility.  Strong HR processes.
cons: Very corporate atmosphere even by corporate standards.   Due to size, some areas have more beaurocracy than one may be sue to, but its necessary to protect the company.

job_title: Current Employee - Junior Officer Leadership Program
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros:
Leadership
Strong Market Position
Great location in Houston (Galleria Area in Houston)
cons: The nearby oil and gas companies in Houston may have better work life balance (every other Friday off with the 9/80 schedules).

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: If you are in finance or can are an effective commercial sales person, this is the company for you.
cons: Not so great, if you are in different functions or struggling business (i.e. healthcare). Layoffs are very common.
advice_management: N/A

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Lots of opportunity to grow
cons: Lower pay by 30% and took away the pension
advice_management: If they expect to keep the new employees happy and with the company i suggest they offer them something that the legacy employees do not get to make they drop in wages and pension fare

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Job security. Still a good name to have in your resume
cons:
•	Little or no training except for a very few selected ones
•	Cheap, cheap. Poor performance has put pressure on everything including travel, and training
•	Jack Welch’s GE is gone. Layers and layers of bureaucracy have been created with mediocre and unprepared Managers.
•	The employee evaluation system is outdated 
•	Metrics and useless processes are a waste of time and money and become extremely frustrating for an employee that really wants to get his job done
•	High turnover, especially young employees
•	Bad healthcare benefits
•	Terrible computer/IT resources
•	Politics and backstabbing culture
advice_management: If you really want to fix this, start with upper management and not with useless reorgs. The Managers of this company do not have accountability and go through one reorg after the other trying to kick the can down the road.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Given alot of independence in getting the work done.
cons: No opportunity for professional growth.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Great products
Great pipeline of products based on great technology
Really smart people
Unlimited opportunities
cons: Diversity to an all new level

summary: "No matter what widget GE is selling, it is really selling it's people."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: Good professional development, variety of things to work on. This location provides significant collaboration and learning opportunities.
cons: Don't work here if you are lazy or think that your good personality will carry you. It is a large company, so there are lots of processes you go through, sometimes to do something simple.
advice_management: More often than not you have good, dedicated people that work for you - empower them!

summary: "GE is a great place to work!  The freedom and opportunity to drive your own career!"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Tremendous freedom to develop career path, Great Technical Expertise, Challenging problems, Great industry, Opportunities, Competitive Salary, Strong Senior Leadership, Awesome Training,
cons: A bit heavy on the beauracracy.  Things can take a while to develop.  There can be some frustration with the slow pace.  A big company can often get in the way of its own progress.
advice_management: Identify great talent and challenge them with huge problems if you want to change the game!!

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Many smart people work here and are generally pleasant colleagues.  If you are right out of school and can get into one of the management programs, it is a good place to start.  If you are an experienced professional and need a job, then maybe this is a place to wait until the economy improves.
cons: GE is an extraordinarily bureaucratic company, despite the internal company line.    It continually  reorganizes (every year I've been here) so there really is never a steady-state.  The company is investing in systems, but currently the info systems are absolutely dismal.  It also off-shores a lot of employment to contractors in India, and many of these people have poor English language skills, and you will have to work with them.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Stable company with a desire to innovate.
cons: Too big and too many people and processes to be able to get out of its own way to innovate and stay ahead of competition.
advice_management: Cut down on processes and red tape, and run the company like a 100 person company.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great leadership learning and work with some of the brightest people
cons: low salary and heavy politics
advice_management: Be strong and willing to bend

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great place to learn. Lots of opportunites to stretch your skills.
cons: Too much overhead. Simple changes require too many approvals.  Lots of administration required for every job. Completing all the non-job tasks takes time away from doing what  you were employed to do.
advice_management: Ask the engineers. They care about the product and actually know what it needs.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: It is a big company which has great diversity and a lot of opportunities to learn/grow.
cons: Because it is big, sometime you feel you are only a tiny fish in a big pond. If you are not agressive and seek opportunities, chances will never come to you for promotion.

summary: "Good challenges, but has a tendency to jade you."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: GE will constantly provide you with great challenges which will push you to your limit every day. The management tends to be friendly, and most people there care about you as a person and employee.
cons: The bureaucracy of most large companies are bad, and GE is one of the largest. If you can't play the political game you are either shoehorned into a particular role or forgotten about. Old-world style managers will make their way upwards while very talented individuals will be used for their abilities, but will ultimately suffer in their personal lives as a result. You can make it big at GE--for a price.
advice_management: Keep listening to your employees. Get out of your bubbles, but don't go so far as to micromanage. The world isn't GE, you can't expect our customers to think as we do internally so be a little more realistic about what GE is and what we can provide as employees.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Good training program within Company
Flexible Work Schedule
cons: Sometime compensation may  not be competitive but work life balance can outweigh this con

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: family values, good 401K, current with technology
cons: old fashioned, dominated by men who earn more,
advice_management: need to invest in more education to the sales field

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great motivated and driven co-workers
cons: Do not join as a direct hire - all upper management, and I really do mean all, enter via the various Leadership training programs straight out of College.
advice_management: Do try to actually manage your direct reports, stop managing up so often

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
* co-workers are generally great people with a good work ethic
* with persistence making change can happen
cons:
* way to process heavy
* decisions take too long to make
* highly risk averse
* organizational structure is getting deeper

summary: "GE is downsize and outsourcing their operation"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: good Pay and benefits for the employees
cons: pressure to perform to high and this make the employees make up data to create their good peformance
advice_management: Value people the tell the truth even when this show that something is not working well

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Friendly supervisors, weekends off ,decent starting salary,many raises,huge opportunitites to advance yourself within the company,and a work schedule that fits everyones needs.
cons: Not the best benefits package available,some jobs are very dirty and noisy,The on the job training could be more clear. You are shown what to do but a lot of the times why you have to do it a certain way.
advice_management: I think when being trained we should be shown why we do what we do along with how we should do it.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great place to work. Freedom to innovate.
cons: Too much work pressure all time
advice_management: contribute towards employee development

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: GE is a larger company that has a lot of resources and is not ever really hurting for money.  Because of that it is very easy to get help and to try new things.
cons: In my area there is a very strict advancement schedule which was a big factor in my resignation.  It is a big company and you are often feel lost.  There were times that I felt like employees were not valued much.
advice_management: Have a little more focus on your own human capital.  They are very important to your success.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: I still have a job
cons:
My pay went down, while health care cost went WAY up when GE aquired the company. 
Yoy must be "GE born" w/an enginerring degree to advance in the company.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Fast Paced, exciting, demanding, satisfying
cons: Long hours, Long hours, can be very tough environment
advice_management: Care for your employees as much as your targets.

summary: "it is a good company for startup"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: good management, nice training program, learn a lot for the industrial environment
cons: some times the management is nonefficient

summary: "Overall it's a good experience of working at GE"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Can try a lot of different things. Culture is good, colleagues are good. You can have a huge resource pool to leverage.
cons: Sometimes it is difficult for those who work very hard but are not good at showing off. Sometimes some superficial tasks take too much time.
advice_management: No

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
-There are Career Opportunities everywhere
-It is all over the World
-Takes care of Customer
-Huge focus on EHS
cons: Difficulty to move to another Country
advice_management:
Increase Communication
Don't do Micromanagement

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Great name, not too much pressure.  Lots of good people.  Very little politics at the engineer level.  At times some amazing resources can be brought to bear on a problem.
cons: Bureaucracy can be nearly impervious at times.  Sometimes it may take months to get simple agreements signed.
advice_management: Contrary to popular belief, management should have some familiarity with the technology their team is working on.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros:
Decent benefits
Upward mobility if you are willing to stay with the company
Challenging work
cons: Little to no direction at times

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Job and learning opportunities abound for those with initiative
cons: Bureaucracy; time and effort needed to make decisions
advice_management: Advocate ownership thinking among employees and empower

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Good name in the industry, great training programs, opportunity to grow.
cons: Weak management in certain businesses. No growth if you are in such a business.
advice_management: Get some general management training.

summary: "GE is a great company to learn the latest technologies"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Great place to learn Corporate culture
cons: Alternative Energy should be brought in mainstream
advice_management: Alternative Energy to be given more consideration

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Have cleaned up the Schenectady plant quite well with new paint. Do your time and projects and can move up quickly.
cons: Never get to know the ins and outs of the products. To conserend about shipping product on time to care about quality.
advice_management:
Get back to quality. Make it a more enjoyable place to work and stop worrying about pennies. 
Remember  what made GE , quality.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Diverse areas of research, academic-like environment, flexibility, freedom for new ideas, lots of learning opportunities, good job security, nice area for living
cons: The hierarchy may be too flat, such that there are less opportunities for promotions.
advice_management: Create more opportunities for new/young people. Not everybody follow the same career path or at the same pace. Give those who wish to advance chances to shine. You may be surprised (in a good way). Be more open to new ideas, even the far-fetched ones.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Very congenial work environment. Smart, and respectful employees who took notice of interns.
cons: Lack of transparency in hiring decisions. Didn't seem to be a lot of opportunities for future advancement.
advice_management: Create more structured junior level development program.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros:
Culture
Job Security
Diversity of Business Platforms
cons: Slow Path to Upside for Most, but definite potential
advice_management: Keep up the good work

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Extremely well run global company with a clear vision of how events around the world will impact the business.  A solid team environment where one can be expected to be stretched in order to reach the company goals.  Strong history of innovation;  long string of firsts with respect to new technology inventions and/or technology commercialisation. Without exception everyone in management respects their team members and works to find a work-life balance in a demanding environment.  Given an opportunity I would gladly return to work for GE.
cons: Often times the business will not fund a new development effort until a competitor is perceived to have reached a break-through technology. Very difficult to move from one business unit to another without putting yourself in harm's way.
advice_management: I believe employee satisfaction and productivity would increase if it were more acceptable to move laterally within the company.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Great products and challenging products. Great leadership and technical training opportunities
cons: Lot of competition for vertical promotions.  Great work life balance.

summary: "Great place to start a career, promotions and salary stagnate"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Steady job.  Great training and educational opportunities.
cons: I've had a generally good experience.  However, despite managements best efforts to keep their valued employees happy, they are not willing to back it up with salary.  Promotions are few and far between.
advice_management: Pay to keep your top talent.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Good rotations across businesses.  Solid manufacturing and business training.  Not as good at sourcing.  Excellent opportunity to attain a Masters in Supply Chain from Penn State however there is a 4 year retention agreement requirement.  Decent benefits.
cons: The program manager for Energy does play favorites when it comes to deciding OMLP's position and location preferences.  The Program Manager is very impersonal.  His scope is very large with over 50 direct reports yields minimal if any one on one time or feedback on performance.  Cost cutting is a constant struggle that can negatively impact the experience.  Salary is non-competitive when compared with Oil & Gas companies, decently paid compared with other energy industries.  There is a lot of "who you know" when it comes to getting the next position or getting things signed off on.  Highly political environment.  Frustrating getting through unnecessary red tape.  Some positions lack oversight and accountability.  Despite the reputation of Six Sigma at GE, there is a lack of worthwhile and meaningful projects yielding realistic results.

summary: "stressful always placing more on people than they could reasonably achieve"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Great benefits, good pay, company vehicles
cons: downsized so much that everyone wears all hats, very stressful, always wanting more from emplyees. would promise changes at meetings and never follow throughbe
advice_management: be  honest

summary: "Top pay for talent and company makes a profit regardless"
main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: As long as you get your job done, no one bothers you.   Loved my co-workers.   I was able to work from home as necessary.     Many benefits such as 20 sick days a year.
cons: Manager frequently said India engineers would work at half our salary.   Had 3 (remote) mangers in a year so no decent review.  RIF'd then then offered another position similar responsibilites at 50% previous wages.  Lost 401k contribution because I wasn't vested at no fault of my own.
advice_management: Invest in your talent and retain them.     Everyone I talk to has done a stint at GE and gladly left.

summary: "It’s a great company, but you have to be a GE type of  guy !!"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros:
-Company has technically competitive advantage over competitors
-GE in your resume is very good
-Except for cost, Customers are generally satisfied with the services received
-Unlimited access to training Technical or Commercial
-Lot of Opportunities for growing (although up to some level)
-Benefits package is very competitive
-Sr level Managers are ok.
cons:
-As any other metric oriented company, there are a lot of work to do to have it met and correctly measure
-Salaries are bit short from when they should

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time
pros: Lots of career opportunities and ability to move within GE.  Extensive personal development resources if you have the time to utilize them.
cons: Lots of hours at work are expected. Compensation could be higher.
advice_management: There are lots of opportunities to improve productivity in the plant.  Just take the time to look and have the courage to make needed changes.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: are there any? well ... it was very easy to get an offer ... that is all ...
cons:
1-Managers DO NOT care about their employees.  They can take months of vacation time. Go play golf with their other manager friends.  Play "angry birds" at their desk during work time. BUT if you want to take 1-2 days off they question you.  OR they tell you that "now is not the best time to take 1 day off"  ... unbelievable!!!! 

2- Again, managers DO NOT care about their employees. Whether something has been done properly or not does not matter to them. Whether their employees are happy or not does not matter to them.  They take credit off of your every accomplishment as if they have anything to do with it, but when something goes wrong, they will burn you at the stake. They just want to get promoted and have big fat raises to their salaries.  

3- When upper management make mistakes, workers, and engineers pay the price! As an engineer, my job is to build the engine as good as I can. As a manager your job is to find a customer for this engine.  IF as a manager you can not find a customer, THEN it is your fault. Please resign your position to someone more competent.  But nooooo ... those who are at the bottom of the packing order pay the price of the poor management. 

4-It is a good company if you want to get a job straight out of college with bachelors degree. If you have a masters or phd, DO NOT even bother, your education or experience will not be valued at all ... you will take orders from someone who does not even know the science behind how things work inside the engine just because that person has been in the company more than you do. 

5- There is too much bureaucracy!  in order to get one simple task done, you have to fight with numerous people.  

6- If you are planning to come here to work, you'd better be good at kissing a lot of a$$, agreeing with everything that your seniors tell you, or you will not get any raise/promotion any time soon.

7- The company is located in a VERY conservative area, and most of the employees are also very conservative and biased towards those come to the company outside the south (especially north east or the west). 

8 - Check the stock values, since 2008 stock values of GE's competitors went back to their original value. Yet, GE is still half price.  Obviously something is not going right.  Instead of replacing those who put the company at it's current position, they are laying people off ... sure!!! lay people off ... then waste money and hire clueless new graduates ... train them ... waste money ... then lay them off to cover your mistakes ...  :)  

9- benefits?  what is that mean?  you will get the cheapest health insurance out there ... you will have to work on national holidays ... you will get the worst retirement benefits too ... GE cuts from its employees, so it can offer a sweet retirement to upper management ... i.e. check John Krenicki's retirement deal ... what did he do to deserve such a sweet deal?  Did he invent the gas turbine? 

10- The corporation made $14 billion dollar profit last year, but did not pay taxes ... what is the deal? why? I pay my taxes ... 

11-I finally had enough and applied for positions in GE's competitors. Currently I work for a competitor in Jupiter Florida, and get paid $15K more  :)  I have better health and retirement benefits.  I am not sure how many employees have to leave GE for upper management to realize that they have to treat their employees with a little more respect. 

In the end we work for you! you do not own us!
advice_management: your employees are not disposable, please treat them with respect!  how many employees you have to lose to your competitors to realize that?

summary: "A great place to grow and build a career."
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Good working environment, family oriented people, good wages & benefits.
cons: Every employer has cons, but the pros far outnumber them.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: really good leadership program, fairly good management, decent pay
cons: lack of organization at times, lots of red tape to get things done
advice_management: for erp, dont just set a strategy, set a strategy AND an execution plan

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Easy to get a different experience without changing companies.   Full pay for Graduate school.   Older employees have hard-to-beat benefits:   matching 401K, pension.
cons:
You have to work the system to get better than average salary.
Younger workers get the worst health plan available and poor pension.
advice_management: It's apparent that the strategy is to off-shore the Engineering staff.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: close to home, good pay, career opps, weekly pay
cons: high insurance, high deductibles, no air conditioning
advice_management: no advice

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: None It is an awful company to work for. Discrimination constantly.
cons: Low salary Awful Managers and terrible HR
advice_management: Liquidate the company

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Good Benefits and work hours
cons: They don't promote within and they hire a lot of temp work
advice_management: Promote from within

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Campus, colleagues, work environment, cafeteria, career opportunities
cons: Compensation, health benefits, office space
advice_management: Improve health benefits

summary: "Excellent company to work for ... GE takes care of its people"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Development
Challenging work tasks
Great location
Promotion based on merit more so than tenure
cons:
Long hours at times
Alot of politics to navigate
advice_management: Work hard to remove impediments to ensure that employees are encouraged to pursue project of interest and create an environment where failure with learning is acceptable.  Empower employees to take calculated risks.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Good pay, some tuition reimbursement
cons: Management is all about money, not people

summary: "Cost out targets driving the wrong people away"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
- Good people, smart... driven
 - Great opportunitites if you are willing to relocate every two years
 - Great place to be from
cons:
- Great people leaving ...many, many great people leaving
 - There is an internal battle between regional teams and P&Ls in the Energy business, a complete distraction to the entire company
 - GE promised to stick with senior managers that have industry and domain experience, but most of the CEO placements recently are a move to place the GE favorites with respect to industry knowledge
advice_management: - Get in touch with your employees and listen before they are all gone and you need to start over

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
- Leadership development and training
- Exposure to senior leaders
- Will gain experience that you would not be thrown into if at a small company
cons:
- Alot of Bureaucracy 
- Metric driven culture ... pressure to perform
- Long hours during planning sessions / qtr close
- No consistence between P&L's with regard to ERP's
advice_management: Be thought leaders. Encourage innovation. Embrace the ideas of the next generation of leaders

main_text: I worked at GE part-time for more than 5 years
pros: very open management, good working condition
cons: long hours;,good food and more...
advice_management: be polite

summary: "Great place to learn, tough place to innovate"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Lot's of different opportunities, easy to move around to take on different challenges.  Lot's of opportunities for training.
cons: To much momentum, hard to make changes or process improve.  To many people are satisfied or comfortable in their position - don't rock the boat attitude exists from the top down in many places.  To much overhead / wasted effort
advice_management: To many people working in a box, engineers are taking on assembly line tasks - people are forgetting why they do something.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Great benefits
Work/life balance
Career opportunities 
Traveling and training opportunities
cons:
Office politics and intrigues
Favoritizm!!!!!
Management uncompetence
advice_management: To executive management - Pay more attention whom  you are hiring for management positions. Lower and middle managers’ unprofessionalism reach high level. Some managers look just ridiculous.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Benefits on par with any big company 401K, Medical, Dental, Vision, EAP
cons:
No respect or opportunities for experienced workers. 
Medical not as good as at other big companies I've worked at. No bonuses or profit sharing
I've found my managers to be incompetent, aimless and verbally abusive.  I've had 3 managers and the last has been the worst. No way to deal with him. Had to simply remove myself
advice_management: You need to do a sanity check on your culture. It's costing you in terms of performance and productivity. Lots of lip service to culture. Execution sucks.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Strong brand with market recognition on products, service
cons: Technology out of date, and GE acq. makes it exetremely difficult to work in front of customers and markets
advice_management: Respect market and focus more on market (instead of internal structure) - GE or HE or JE, you all have to do this!

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Great developmental training
Lots of functional responsibility
Emphasis on leadership & ethics
Complex, global industries that will shape the 21st century (energy, oil & gas, aviation, transportation)
cons:
Large company; lack of autonomy and accountability for middle management
Complex bureaucracy with global functions that supervise local business leaders
advice_management: Great portfolio focus, now decentralize the businesses and encourage middle management through smaller P&Ls

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Great place to start a career.  The sky is the limit if you're willing to play the corporate game.
cons: Again, if you're willing to play the corporate game.  Revenue targets are handed out without any regard to the reality of the market...

summary: "Great company with superior opportunities, but hard to stand out"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Lots of talented employees, many different opportunities for a wide variety of positions. Innovation is strongly encouraged and rewarded.
cons: Very large company, hard to stand out among hundreds of thousands of talented individuals. There are also many long standing traditions in some of the areas of the company, and are hard to break.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great people and a great company. Lots of opportunity to learn new things. Freedom to make decisions without being micromanaged.
cons: A lot of higher level people. Look down on the "less educated". Not much room for advancement.
advice_management: Make a plan and stick to it. Don't be all talk and no action.

summary: "ok, but other better companies out there"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: good work/family balance is good, that's about it. Good company if you're trying to be a corporate person, but if you just want to be just so, then look else where. I guess everything else is ok
cons: promotion is based on who likes you rather than your performance. They are not good when you want to refer friends/family to a position.I havent really had a good experience working with them in the 5-6 years I've been affilitated with the company
advice_management: fire them all, get new ones

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: GE management is top notch.  Good decision makers in the right place.  You should be an over achiever in order to work or succeed here.
cons: GE has a great name, because of that a lot of people want to work for them.  Therefore, the pay might not be as competitive as needed.
advice_management: Filter out some of the irrelevant paperwork to the lower lever employees.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: great company, many industries, many countries, many roles and responsibilities
cons: well established systems and processes, need to learn and adapt
advice_management: continue to live the growth traits

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Great  growth and development opportunities
Great place to learn
cons:
Lot of bureaucracy
Too many leaders not enough expertise
advice_management: Pay more

summary: "Decent entry-level sales support position, but low pay and high health insurance costs"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: GE Lighting seems to be a stable place to work. Many of my coworkers have been here 15 years or more. Managers are very open minded and do not micromanage. Each DSS employee is given a few dozen accounts to manage in a particular region of the country- all lighting distributors, business-to-business sales support - so job is very professional.
cons: Opportunities for advancement at GE Lighting are few and far between - only 5 managers and one field sales rep in the Richmond region. Pay tops out in the $30-$35 K range for this position and is flat salary, no commission.  Only high-deductible health plans are offered (premiums are free, but a $3200 yearly deductible for me and my spouse).
advice_management: Offer some more incentives for merit-based pay. I can't support a family on my salary.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: GE hires good talent, is a challenging environment, and tends to have more interesting assignments than other companies at the same career level.
cons: Very competitive environment, people tend to chase after a specific career band to the detriment of staying in jobs long enough to see things through.
advice_management: n/a

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Great talent and innovative products.  The work environment is fast paced and the only constant is change.
cons: Pay is on the low end relative to competition

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: Has a lot of different businesses which provide for a diverse set of job opportunities.
cons: Quick to cut positions when not meeting financial targes even if they are still growing.

summary: "Great... if you are on the fast track"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
invests in employee development and training
Takes big swings on early career employees ... opportunities and responsibilities
cons:
Working at GE is opportunity cost... you will always make more when you leave.
Organization is too complex and networks matter more than competence sometimes, but not in the long run.
advice_management: too complex and not in a good way... walk the talk about caring for employees

summary: "Don't work for a company that doesn't know how to be honest"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: You can have a good work balance
cons: This company will only promote people that will do the dirty work not the one's that take care of the customer. They promote the people the like regardless if they can do the work.
advice_management: If you talk it then walk it. Treat people how you want to be treated.

summary: "GE The worst high school I ever went to"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for less than a year
pros: Paid well , weekends off, some overtime
cons: Coworkers bickering / management had no idea what was going on/ only 2,  10 minute breaks
advice_management: Get a clue

summary: "Great Place to Grow Your Career, Not Salary"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Excellent exposure to various learning opportunities and businesses ranging from: aircraft engine manufacturing, locomotive manufacturing, financial services, healthcare manufacturing, software development, energy services (wind/water/power manufacturing), and more.
cons: Not the meritocracy we were promised from a salary perspective. GE is terrible with incentive's for retaining their top talent, and as a result most leave once they discover their earning potential elsewhere.
advice_management: Work on strategies for retaining top talent, as once they get wise to the fiscal opportunities outside the company, they will most certainly leave, as evident by the already large - and growing - turnover rate of top talent personnel.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Pay- better than average
Autonomy- allowed to be creative with job
Time- will allow you the time you need to take care of family issues
Training/schools - will pay for a variety of education
cons:
What have you done for me lately mentality
Must move jobs every 2-3 years they don't like for you to be sedintary
Tough glass ceiling - thousands of people for very few upper management positions
Watch your back- very political,  keep your friends close and ....
advice_management: everybody wants your job

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Competitive salary/benefits, entrepreneurial environment, flexible hours, good corporate reputation with most customers, talented coworkers
cons: Overemphasis on quarterly financial goals, little compassion when goals missed, too much compliance crap
advice_management: Cut your own salaries. Spend time in the workplace with factory workers and office people - talk with them.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: A lot of opportunities, everyone is very intelligent, lots of programs
cons: You must move to get ahead, you feel like a number

main_text: I worked at GE  for more than 8 years
pros: - High awareness level about career paths, constructive feedback process & many available roles with real significance & input to strategic goals.
cons: - A lot of experienced & proven talent ready for the next opportunity and so this creates cut-throat competition.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than a year
pros: GE is a great place to come for a short period early in your career to get great early experience, training, and learn from mentors.
cons: Advancement is slow and does not pay nearly what you can get from other companies

summary: "Large company  with a different career opportunities"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Highly valued company with a wide range of businesses and a broad range of career opportunities.
cons: Excessive sense of self-admiration combined with a bureaucratic outlook on product development leads to a lack of ear toward employee satisfaction and career progression. Promotions can be hard to come by.
advice_management: None at the moment.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: They have the capital to research ideas, and develop new products.  There is always interesting programs to work on.  They have many talented people.
cons: Way too many layers of management,  lots of institutional inertia, too many managers of engineers with little to no experience in the area that they are managing.   Programs get cut with little rhyme or reason.
advice_management: Try to reduce the number of layers between the decision makers and the individual contributors, the message (top-down and bottoms-up) seem to get lost.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Big company
Lots of opportunies to advance
Good business
Nice offices
cons:
Big company
High pressure
Pressure on performance
Pear pressure

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great products. Great engineers and technical experts.
cons: Work and stress and more stress.
advice_management: People make the company great.

main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Large company with lots of diverse opportunities.
cons: Management too focused on short term deliverables.  Poor strategic management, planning, and implementation of Mission One programs.
advice_management: Reward people that contribute and stop keeping dead weight.

summary: "I was surprised by what I found.."
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
Easy going staff
Bsness Casual attire
Can work from home if needed
Flexible if need time off and/or to leave early, come in late etc...
No micro-management
Nice cafeteria on ground
Large parking area directly across the street
Nurse's office on ground
cons:
Not a lot really :
If you are a contractor chances of becoming Perm is VERY VERY rare - bigger chance of you contracting long term and being extended numerously.
Cafeteria is in building but somewhat pricey

summary: "GE Works: for some but not all"
main_text: I have been working at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Working level people are usually really good people. Lots of community involvement. When there aren't any budget constraints the company can be vibrant and an exciting place to work offering many opportunities for people looking to stretch their talents
cons: Too bureaucratic and too many golden calves. Over emphasis on diversity at the expense of missing out on really talented people. Not a meritocracy but more of a who you know network. Old industrial style type management theories. Managing numbers quarter to quarter sacrificing long term growth opportunities
advice_management: Change compensation structure of executives to reward them for long term performance and keep executives in jobs long enough to reap what they sow. Expand IC to people who really drive the company Senior Professionals. Ditch Session C and revamp operations cycles.

main_text: I worked at GE full-time for more than 10 years
pros: gOOD COMPANY WITH GOOD LEARNING POSSIBILITIES AND FAIR BENEFITS
cons: Company does not know how to run electronics....they are a great engine company but they should really re look at the electronics side of the house
advice_management: Mergers and Acquisitions is not a great competency

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
- leadership
- training
- feedback and development plans
cons:
- compensation
- healthcare plans
- politics

main_text: I worked at GE
pros:
Great opportunities - to travel, work and grow 
Overall very good people
Very good learning in short period of time
cons:
Sometimes long hours (depends on business and country)
Can be very political

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: A large company that offers a diverse career path in just about every technical field whilst keeping you challenged and engaged.
cons: GE is company desired by most people and thus allows a long list of people will to come to work for such a good company, salaries not always competitive.
advice_management: Management is great to engage the key team members but need to ensure visibility and exposure are maintained and appropriate recognition and credit provided.

summary: "Great place to work and grow, Great for learning and leadership Training"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: For gaining experience and leadership skills there is no company better. They invest a lot in the employees and they give plenty of opportunities to grow. They care about there employees and in situations where it maybe unsafe they will take every precaution to make sure it is safe.
cons: Its wont be the best paying job and its just as important to pick the right manager as it is to pick the right job. Once you have figured out the best way to do that you will go far. In GE during the first 5 years you will determine whether you love it or hate it.
advice_management: Be more competitive with your compensation. Finding, training, and growing great talent is a huge advantage that GE has over all other companies... Keeping them is the difficult part. If you are competitive with your compensation, salaries, you will keep the vast majority of your talent and it will pay off more then what was spent on salary in project execution.

summary: "Tough, interesting work, with lots of opportunity for advancement and poor pay/benefits."
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: GE recognizes talent/motivation, and does a great job of providing those individual's with opportunities to advance their careers and improve their skills.
cons: HR gave a presentation about how they aim to pay 5-20% below market value, but they make up for it with great benefits.  Six months later, they tanked the benefits plans, which was basically a 5k pay cut for every non-executive in the company.  Most of the people I know left for their spouses plan... If that was an option.
advice_management: There is a reason your top talent is leaving en masse.  You need to decide if employees are a necessary evil, or a mutually beneficial resource.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: You will have smart colleagues to interact with.
cons: You get labeled and cannot change your label.
advice_management: Be logical.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: A very large and proud company with many grow opportunities so long as you are one of the "insiders" and/or the "choosen" to be a active, valued contributor for the business.
cons: My experience is that opinions outside the mainstream or "NIH' are not recieved well, especially when they point to a flaw or fault in a business plan.  This happens a lot with an acquistion because it's not the GE way, which by definition is wrong.
advice_management: As part of a small acquistion, I feel management needs to be more honest with the employeees on why the acquisition is really happening...is it just to fill a spot on the "line card,' or do you intend to invest to grow the business, committing to the future.  Managment most often doesn't care to share the long-term plans for the business.

summary: "It is easy to get lost in the management matrix"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Good co-workers that are experienced
cons: The company can be too big for some. Too much of an emphasis on quarter point results.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Great company very very positive experience. he Money, the money...oh, and the also the money money money moeny money
cons: Bullying, pettiness and insane focus on the totally unimportant is not only tolerated it's rewarded in the name of the principles.

summary: "30 minute lunch breaks, very regimented,tied to a phone all day. Very low pay"
main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Lots of training and feedback.
cons: If you make 9.00 per hour - that's considered VERY good at the company.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Respectful, professional, organized, and great.
cons: I have no cons to add to this line
advice_management: Hire more

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Challenging work, great technology, great people and opportunities to define your role.  Multiple development opportunities in leadership, finance and IT
cons: Bureaucracy and red tape, political and unspoken rules dictate how things are done but overall a decent place to work.
advice_management: Increase base pay, start offering bonuses to all employees based on company performance and offer rotational assignments outside of FInance

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: It was a good place to get experience and it will beneficial to have it on my resume in the future.
cons: There was a lot of busy work.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Large support network, good training opportunities
cons: Mired in bureaucracy and overly rigid processes.
advice_management: Rethink the processes which slow down the P&Ls

summary: "Continuous learning environment.  If you can deliver consistently, sky is the limit."
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
Working with some of the best and smartest people in the world.
The companies size allows them to take risks on people and put them in "bigger" jobs than they'd find elsewhere.
Daily challenges and learning opportunities.
Great employee feedback process
cons:
Hours at times can be extreme
Sink or swim environment
Large company, comes with some bureaucracy
Some leaders seem to have survived regardless of performance (Minimal and often the exception to the rule)
Salary can be lower than individuals market value early in career.
advice_management: Continue to invest in new products and people.  Technology is our key to winning.

summary: "Intelligent personnel, but a somewhat backstabbing environment. No real loyalty among employees and chain of command."
main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Smart, driven and competent employees.
cons: Senior management doesn't have great leadership ability. Managers are out for themselves, without any real training or motivation to develop subordinates. GE advertises flexible work/life arrangements and programs, but when you approach HR about these programs, they basically try to steer you away from utilizing the same programs that they brag about so much.
advice_management: Consistent, specific feedback and regular performance counseling (whether that performance has been good, or bad!).  Take care of your people and go to bat for them when interacting with more senior personnel.  Do what you can to find out their own goals and help them to achieve them.  I felt that most of the reviews I received at GE were considered a waste of time and more of an afterthought or annoying requirement by my chain of command, and I never got an real useful information in these reviews.  Also, feedback should be formal and regular, not once a year.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Competent and able workforce, strong work ethic, infinite resources available if management allows it, training programs are great learning opportunities
cons: Feels like a government with the amount of bureaucracy...to many layers of managers and not enough "do-ers", no bonuses or "rewards" available to non executives, management has "ivory tower" mentality on a lot of issues
advice_management: Stop promoting and realigning management and empower the people at the "bottom" who are making a real impact on the business

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
Global recognition
Career development potential
cons:
Large multinational
Easy to get lost in process
advice_management: Think small

summary: "Big company with a lot of oppurtunities. You just need to be in the right business."
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: it is a land of oppurtunity.  There are offices everywhere so your career growth isn't restricted.  If your willing to travel or are globally mobile, then you can do anything you want.  Some of the people there are absolutely brilliant and very motivated
cons: Structured annual increases.  Your hard work may get you an annual increase of 5% but really whats that when the guy next to you gets 2% and leaves at 4:58pm everyday regardless of things not being done.  Also, after turning down a few job offers I am irritated at the percent raises on internal transfers.  I would rather see what they're willing to pay for the job rather than basing my salary on my previous job.
advice_management: It would be great to see more direct communication from senior leaders. It's comical when you get thank you emails from senior leaders that were "sent on their behalf".  Come on, really...

summary: "Work is very interesting, people are great"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
Work is interesting
People are very motivated
Professional atmosphere
cons:
Since the organization is so large,  work tends to get very specialized.
Somewhat political environment
advice_management: Keep focusing on making better products to make the world better for all inhabitents.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Work satisfaction. Good content. Smart people. Good Culture
cons: Work life balance is not great.

summary: "Work Experience is limited to older techs that are already existing in the company"
main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Nice communication with senior management, good work-life balance
cons: I have seen a lot of people getting fired.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Lots of opportunity for job advancement; GE has offices in almost every major city; some of the best leaders come from here
cons: Some sites don't take care of their buildings; some managers are awesome but others don't seem to care about employee engagement
advice_management: Walk the talk - make employee engagement a priority in years other than when the GE Opinion Survey is distributed

summary: "Relaxed atmosphere, lot of waste, poor leadership"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Pension, decent benefits, relaxed atmosphere, not stressful, good training, moderate salary compared to industry.  Lots of opportunities to learn and training programs
cons: Excessive focus on metrics.  matrixed organization, beauracratic.  Networking is key to success which leads to favoritism.  Leadership training is severely lacking in diverse thinking.
advice_management: Less focus on new "fad" initiatives.  More focus on core strengths.  Diversity in leadership in terms of experience and non-GE grown talent.

summary: "good but very demanding place to work"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Good Pay for the area, tuition reimbursment, good Reputation in the industry
cons: very stressfull, long hours, too many hard to progress as an engineer (though this is changing).
advice_management: Faster decision-making cycle is needed, less red tape for making changes.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Compensation was fair, benefits were average, always worried about job security. Management not straight forward about future plans. Never trust HR
cons: Easy to become just a number in such a large company. Management cared more about their own advancement then in your development.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Great Enviornment, advancement opportunities, great networking
cons: Hard to find opportunities without moving.

summary: "Not nearly as good as it looks from the outside."
main_text: I worked at GE
pros:
It's a big company and it looks good on your resume. 
Lots of cool projects to work on.
cons:
Lots of politics. Lots of hierarchy. They do a terrible job retaining top talent. They layed off a bunch of really bright employees and kept the yes folks. It's no wonder the business has to grow overseas. The engineering is okay. The science is really subpar.  The creative folks are not encouraged to be creative. GE's greatest strengths are its name and its marketing, because people still view it as the great American company. It's become a me-too company. Lots of acquisitions. Organic growth is non-existent. The So-called global research centers are a technological farce at best these days. 

Lots of projects, but they get canned all the time. The R&D is terrible because it's at the mercy of the businesses.
advice_management: Retain better talent. You're letting go of some of your top employees either through attrition, poor reward systems or layoffs and keeping the yes folks. The stock price is slowly going back up but that's due to international growth.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: - great leaders and managers to guide you
cons: -stressful enviroment sometimes because of the union
advice_management: i think its great!!

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: People are nice.  Managers are friendly.
cons:
Management seemed distance and do not understand the technical work and challenges that engineers face.  
Too much segregation.
advice_management: Need to have strong technical leaders in each project.

summary: "If you are a person who has no family or personal life or who doesn't care about it, this is the company for you."
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Compensation is comparable, BUT you work endlessly. Good place to learn, then get out of there after 2 to 4 years. It's kinda of like making a deal with the GhostRider mentality, damned if you do and damned if don't.
cons: Learn to play the HIGH Performance game early ON in your career here or else you'll find yourself under the bus everyday.
advice_management: Learn to LISTEN to logic and not what you think you know. Understand the value of thinking outside of the box instead of saying it to your employees and owning the implementation of the concept. Since you admire your CEO so much, review his management style and then look at your own. See how that aligns & works for you and your department.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Endless opportunities to learn and grow.  Very rewarding experience.  Breadth of technologies, products and services you can get deeper into.
cons: Very high expectations.  Average performance is not enough to be rewarded.
advice_management: Engage employees more into strategic decisions.  Reward performances more and reduce pressure for annual rating and ranking.  Provide better benefits.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Starting salary is good,  the pension for older employees (which is no longer offered to new hires), starting vacation time and vacation growth, freedom to come and go as you please as long as your work gets done, freedom to take time off whenever you feel like.
cons: Salary grows at a snails pace, management does not know you exist, promotions don't appear to be given out on a performance basis but instead by nepotism,  long hours, little reward,  subjective performance evaluation system, senior management consistently makes decision that aren't transparent to anyone below them, constantly having to do useless hr activities, constantly have to take useless online training, constantly forces to do activities that reduce your productivity, engineer is done by a large committee (everyone feels they should be involved regardless of how small GE project is)
advice_management: Be more transparent, know when people are going above and beyond for you and compensate them accordingly, promote based on performance.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Work Environment, Reputation, Security, Location
cons: Very Competitive, Only the higher level executives develop into higher level careers

summary: "Positive learning experience but unclear upward mobility"

cons: Less favorable work life balance in finance. Pressure to be flexible among locations and to change in job function.

main_text: I have been working at GE

main_text: I have been working at GE

main_text: I worked at GE

cons: Pay is less than average.  Raises aren't as much as they could be.
advice_management: Would be nice to see pay equal to industry standards.

summary: "Good place to work. Nice work environment"
main_text: I have been working at GE

cons: Salary may be the standard/average.

good cultrue ,good training,Most Admired Companies in Research Science, Black Engineer & Information Technology, 2010
 
Global 100 Most Sustainable Corporations List (#1), Corporate Knights, 2010

summary: "Great company with excellent talent at all levels"

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Great leadership, open culture, freedom to execute your ideas.
cons: Healthcare benefits, stock price is languishing

summary: "GE is the big business depicted in the classic movies"
main_text: I worked at GE
pros:
The company is the only company that openly admits to employee online monitoring! 

I think that says a lot for their integrity! (A++)

They maintain a amazing company educational cours4e library of several thousand personal. technical. and up to date business courses free for employees. And still offer tuition reimbursement incentives for educational facilities you may enroll in locally.. (Colleges, tech schools, etc)

There is an annual program for the performance review process that is basically making you keep your resume up to date, and the emphasis is to use the  new "buzz words" corporate feels is right for the times - after you take an in house class about them..

Their retirement plan is incredible,  and remains the best I have ever seen for a big business, especially as so many other places phased them out. the heart of it is 100% company funded!

I was in a target department during a RIF that was unfortunate to be involved in, but I also feel it was a wise bjusin3ess decision! I stayed my remaining 2 weeks making sure my project transitioned seamlessly for our customers. I am sure most people, including myself, would have simply left the same day at other companies!
cons:
The biggest downside is management always in a state of concern that they could be sacrificed to provide "the scape goat" needed  to satisfy stockholder concerns over company profits and or projections.  

Watch a couple of the movies from the 50's where there are a dozen "yes men" always following the CEO around; or even realize most f the comments made by  Jay Leno about GE (partners with NBC) are not fictional one liners - they are real! 

Even 30 Rock is a reflection of GE conglomerate day to day issues - but with a bit too much embellishment!

Of course, they are well compensated for their stress and most stay loyal for their entire career, so is this really a con?  I would return in a heartbeat!
advice_management:
To management I can only recommend weeding out the active "yes men"! Don't fire them, just get back to basics on their own merits! Many of their predecessors have been guilty of this for over half a century, but I feel GE would be much stronger as a business in these troubled times, with the workforce becoming more loyal and projective as a result! 

But overall, GE's management  does a fantastic job!

Note: The CEO at GE receives a salary and compensation that appears excessive to the media and the public often misled by uninformed reporters. But he really is a great deal for GE in the big picture, and worth the price!

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: You get to work with great people who have a strong work ethic. There is the opportunity for gaining experience in many different types of engineering jobs--from the design side to the product maintenance, innovation, etc.
cons: The work is demanding--if you don't enjoy what you do, it could be rough. Enjoy engineering, and it isn't as bad!
advice_management: Keep hiring people who love their jobs. The people make the job. Being in a community of knowledgeable and interesting people is one of the big reasons I enjoy my job.

summary: "I worked at GE for 13 years and always found them to be a very fair employer"
main_text: I have been working at GE

1. Smart colleagues
2. Access to training

4. Resume' builder
cons:
1. Large company (sometimes impersonal) in the midst of difficult times
2. Benefits are under pressure (especially heath)
3. Have to be willing to move for advancement
advice_management: GE Capital needs to be pared back. We need to be a technology company again.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Opportunity to work with a large company, exposure, looks good on a resume, employees very dedicated to their jobs
cons: Extremely top down, no respect or communication to various "levels" within the company, Executives look down on engineers as the "little people" and make decisions based on their own well-being. Lots of secrets.
advice_management: Respect all employees, take pride in the work of engineers, don't be afraid to talk to employees lower on the totem pole

main_text: I worked at GE
