summary: "Intelligent community with tons of networking and advancement opportunities"
main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Globally respected conglomerate with opportunities to advance both professionally and personally.  You have a wealth of learning tools and very smart collegues who are more than willing to show you the ropes.  If you play your cards right, you can have a long lasting career with this company.
cons: Salary by far is the downside to working for GE.  Get in, get the knowledge, meet the people.  But, similar to other business models, if you advance from within the company there is only a minor salary increase, versus if you come from outside, the offer is definitely sweeter.  Great company overall.

main_text: I have been working at GE

cons: Balance between work/life is not the best
advice_management: Not applicable at this time

summary: "Good worklife balance, limited job growth opportunity"

advice_management: Give people stretch role when they deserve it

summary: "GE is a really great place to have your career."
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: GE is a really great place to have your career.  You will get a comprehensive view of what you would like to achieve as a business professional as you start working in GE and people around you will be extremely supportive on that.
cons: High reward sometimes come with high effort so it's up to yourself how you would like to balance your work and life, but the company fully support people to have a life if that's their priorities.
advice_management: Maybe it's important to have a vision of where GE will be in the next 10 years and drive the  company to that direction progressively.  Sometimes you need to get rid of the debt faster so that you could get up to speed quicker.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Good people, good products, traning opportunities
cons: Long hours and HR drives a lot of the business decisions.
advice_management: Empower your teams

summary: "Large, complicated organization with much chaos and need for streamlined processes"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Training provided throughout year, opportunities for growth, flexible manager on time in/out, employee recognition, convenient campus facilities like medical center, cafeteria, gym, etc.
cons: Often the organization seems to have grown so large that there is lack of accountability on projects, miscommunication, departments don't know what each other are working on (even within departments). Way too many emails and over-communication on useless things. Terrible onboarding process.
advice_management: Fix the onboarding process; it is a chaotic mess. Hold people accountable for when huge mistakes are made. Cut down on emails by providing usable intranet sites.

summary: "Average place but management is very poor"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
good compensation package, No need to work after hours hours/weekends very often. 
good opportunities for training. You can meet very professional people here.
cons: Very bad middle management, they are only interested in politics. Half of the day usually lost in unnecessary phone calls, too much powerpoint. very subjective apprisal process. You never feel safe at your job.
advice_management: Let the people to be focused on their jobs, stop distracting them with unecessary things. Promote managers based on results not politics.

summary: "Ge has gone from GE is ME to cost reductions and profits to please stock holders"
main_text: I worked at GE
pros: If you have the self discipline for self learning, there are many opportunities there.  Pay and benefits are okay.  401k matching is fairly good.
cons: GE doesn't seem to really care about it's people any more.  It is very risk adverse.  I was told that in order to be successful at GE I needed to be an aggressive a-hole (which is not my character).  Even if you are within budget, funding for your project may be cut with only a day or 2 of notice.  Typical 50+ hour work week.  You can talk about GLBT (gays, lesbians, bisexuals, and transgenders), but to mention Christ is forboden.
advice_management: Vision on what is going on and where GE is headed is not transferred downstream very well.  Change is slow and not much recognition.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: GE was an enjoyable place to work - many young engineers that we excited about their work. Also, the large number of interns made for a more enjoyable atmosphere as an intern. Engineering team was very helpful in teaching us, but I learned the most from the line technicians and machinists. They were very willing to teach me about the process and the machines involved. Recognizes the value of go-getters.
cons:
There was occasionally personality clashes between members of the engineering team and members of the technician team. In these clashes, both sides were 100% certain they were right.

When I started there wasn't  any structure to the intern program, I was led to my office then told to 'talk to the other interns to figure out what you need to do'. As I was leaving they were working on implementing a structured intern program.
advice_management: Provide more structure from the beginning. Work on getting the technical and 'non-technical' teams to work together with out fighting.

summary: "Small part of large company was crazier than start-up companies!"
main_text: I worked at GE
pros:
+ Working with some high-quality, knowledgeable and supportive coworkers.
+ Work with teams from around the world
+ Work on some top-quality products in the industry
cons:
- Lack of available training and development to be effective in position
- Lack of appreciation and understanding of hard work provided and challenges that employees face
- Lack of advancement opportunities
- Discourage honesty about what it'll truely take to be sucessful in projects -- lack of listening and understanding
advice_management:
+ Provide and encourage employees to hone their skills through training and development
+ Appreciate and respect the hard work employees perform for the company and challenges they face

summary: "Great place to start, not good to finish"

Excessively arrogant management, this attitude is now being crushed by hard working and quality oriented management from foreign competitors (very similar story to GM).

summary: "GE is such an amaing place to be"

main_text: I worked at GE

summary: "I learned a lot about work and why things occur in the workplace"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: GE is a great company to have on your resume and other companies love it.  It is a huge fortune 500 company that offers a lot of opportunity.  You learn important information about software that can be brought to other jobs
cons: The work there was a times very dull. I also felt that it was sometimes unprofessional in nature with dress and behavior code.  I hope that in the future in another job I do not have that same experience.
advice_management: Make sure that interns are treated fairly.  Often times I was very concerned with my position there and often felt that my boss would not let me do things that other interns were allowed to do.

main_text: I have been working at GE

cons: There are no cons that I can think of, except for the lack of diversity in some of the businesses.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: The best reasons to work at GE are that they have lots of benefits. From paying for college to helping with rent they are the best.
cons: The downside to working at ge is that they are a big company. There are so many people that you may be lost in the shuffle.
advice_management: The leadership at Ge is great. However I would change a few things. I would have more people in charge.

main_text: I have been working at GE

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Able to work independently and learn new skills.   Part of larger GE family with GE benefits packages.   Was getting better when I left, although still had a long way to go.
cons: Local management was horrible at communicating and leadership.  There are clear 'favorites' and inconsistency associated with many parts of the job, how assignments are given and when giving instruction/feedback.
