main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
•  Broad range of products and services to spark long term career interest
•  Process oriented company
•  Great training programs offered for both new and experienced engineers
•  Great employee / company support for community activities
•  Excellent job posting system spanning entire company
•  Ability to transfer to different businesses within company (subject to management approval)
•  Purchase GE products at reduced cost
•  Flexible working arrangements
cons:
•  Bureaucratic - rigid processes often inhibits individual initiative, creativity, and customer service
•  US based company with more non-US employees promotes transfer of technical skills outside of US
•  Management frequently asks for opinions and feedback but often hears what they want to hear
•  Pay raises not commensurate with contributions
•  Defined pension plan replaced by contributing 401K for recent hires
•  Company sponsor medical plan (dental, eye, medical, medicine) revamped at great employee out of pocket cost.  Yearly expenses can range from 4% gross base pay with little / no illness to 10% or more with typical family medical expenses
advice_management: Corporate officers are out of touch with their people.  Don’t forget the people who made GE great long before you became a manager and probably long after you leave on your next promotion.

summary: "Large company, with varying degrees of competance"
main_text: I worked at GE
pros:
-Very competant engineers
-Lots of money within the company to fund new ideas
- Management makes an effort to support the interns
cons:
-Large company, very easy to get swallowed up
-Sometimes difficult to obtain work as an intern
- Since the company is so large, management styles vary greatly
advice_management: Please remember that interns are a valuable resource, and many of us are only a few quarters away from being eligible to become full time employees.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: In general management is very good. There are a lot of training opportunities within the company for individual contributors. Pay seems ok.
cons: Offshore IT folks are a disaster, GE gets the cheapest offshore folks they can, projects often take 10 times the time they should.  Healthcare benifits are really poor for a large company having a baby is very expensive.
advice_management: Fix the IT software development processes. In my experience this is more a matter of getting the right peopel then new initiaves. Reduce the buerarcracy

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: lots of opportunities, great coworkers
cons: can be over worked, not always being lead properly

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Options are a lot. Diverse culture
cons: Beuracacy, slow to respond to market, benefits are poor
advice_management: Too many layers

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: As much as some employers claim to offer internships with "meaningful work", GE is one of the few where a college student can actually leave with an understanding of the impact they made, makes it feel much more worthwhile.
cons: Internship quality can vary somewhat depending on assignments, but then again so can any other job. Slightly lower pay for a CS student than a straight up programming gig, but worth it if you don't want to be stuck at the same desk all day.
advice_management: Program might be improved through increased communication between assignment leaders and the program heads.

summary: "Performance-driven culture with great career opportunities and really smart people."
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Integrity matters...performance-driven culture...opportunities for advancement...exposure to senior leaders...strong benefits package...listening and learning culture...solid performance review processes...basically if you perform at this company you can go far...socially responsible employees and supportive Company...strong internal and external support of Green and Health initiatives
cons: Can be too bureaucratic...not always a "make the market" company, but a fast follower...fairly conservative, which actually has served them well in the recession...
advice_management: Keep innovating on the industrial side - the future is in global infrastructure

summary: "Excellent experience, earlier on in one's career, working with extraordinaey people."
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: A flexible approach to career advancement and leadership development. Ability to move between many businesses and multiple experiences. Opportunity to "fail smart" and take risks.
cons: Although things are changing, you will work very hard, sometimes very long, and in a good deal of ambiguity.those who are not decisive, inclusive, and lacking a good mix of thoughtful and provocative thinking will struggle to succeed.
advice_management: Engage the sr. leadership more often, and utilize social media more effectively to connect employees. Take the gloves off when it comes to attacking opportunities to lead the charge among competitors.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: good benefits, salary which are the industry standard or above and beyond
cons: things and work can get very busy
advice_management: listen to your employees

summary: "Great place to gain experience and network in a corporate environment"
main_text: I worked at GE
pros:
-Assignments are what you express interest in
-Salary employees are very friendly and happy to work with the interns
-employees and management are supportive
-The IMLP intern program does a good job of holding roundtables with upper management (we met with the CIO), planning volunteer activities within the community, and trying to make the program fun
-
cons:
-Ladder climbers
-bureaucratic
-encourage staying after work hours i.e. work/life balance shaky
-Expectations are not well expressed

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
Interesting work, people, dynamic roles.  Enough rope to hang yourself, as they say.  Cutting edge technology, products.  Access to anyone in the world.  Everyone takes your meeting.
There's little that GE doesn't do, and one can move professionally through the diversity of industries and functions if you're interested and focused.  Great place for those who are looking for a work-life balance.
cons: Bureaucracy.  Tough to get things done if people you never knew in divisions you never heard of could shoot down your program from out of nowhere.  Politics commeasurate with size of organization.
advice_management: Take more risks.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Technical Depth I gained was very helpful
cons: Lack of personnel understanding from Leadership.
advice_management: Excellent Keep doing what they are doing now, improve flow down communication.

summary: "Great company to work for and lost of learning opportunity."
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: great place to get experience. there are great leadership examples. Good treatment to minority employees. good chance to work overseas.
cons: Due to being large it can be old fashined. certain leaders can be quite authotratic. benefits are not the best in class.
advice_management: should give more emphasis on the core IT structure. Certain leaders haev no hands on experience in their field resulting in trial and error type of decision making.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
You work with very smart people
Louisville is a great place to live/work/raise a family
You have the opportunity to change jobs within the larger GE family
GE is very respected in business community
cons:
Employee engagement is not taken seriously
Financial measurements rule exclusively 
If you make your numbers but don't take care of your team there are no penalties
Leaders are stretched so thin they aren't being setup to be successful
advice_management:
Upgrade the facilities - especially those used by many like Monogram Hall and GCC - they are an embarassment.  It will increase morale.
Measure how many employee touch points leaders have every quarter - not just electronic ones - hold them accountable for building relationships with their employees.  If they do it right, it will drive the bottom line.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: get to work on a lot of varied and interesting topics
cons: poorly managed, too many managers with overlapping responsibilities, managers do not understand the jobs of the people they manage, treat employees like serfs
advice_management: respect employees and and respect competence not political savvy

summary: "I love the company and the culture although progress is slow sometimes."
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
Some of the best reasons to work at GE are:
1. Leadership development
2. Size,scope & scale
3. Ability to solve big problems
4. Meritocracy - for the most part
cons:
Program graduates have a huge advantage over non-program folks
Pay is middle of the pack
Tendency to promote smart-people vs. Leaders
advice_management: Implement a 360 feedback process on all people leaders by their direct reports

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Career possibilities are very good but need iniative and 24 hr commitement at times.
cons: Business can't seem to get out of a "GE" mold of leadership.  The new world needs change.    Too many layers now reinstated over past few years.
advice_management: Stop being afraid of sticking your neck out when it comes to senior leaders.

summary: "Performance = Job security, Communicating upwards = Pay raises, Networking = Job promotions"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
GE has a good library of learning resources
Support a culture of hard work and Open communication
Potential opportunities to grow are seemingly endless
cons:
Has a 'Silo' based org structure difficult to navigate.
Moving across businesses is challenging.
advice_management:
Try to be a more horizontal organization. 
Divest businesses that are found to be laggards in the current and future economy.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
Exposure to new technology
Learning how to work in a corporate environment
Opportunity to work on projects that affect many people
cons:
Very little communication and cooperation between GE groups
Leadership programs favored young under graduates
Contractors treated poorly
Unnecessary office politics
advice_management:
Encourage and reward cooperation between business groups
Develop programs for IT graduate students
Encourage more in-house IT knowledge 
Look for ways IT can create value for the businesses

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: The company does an unlimited things, and there is an infinite amount of work and things to learn.
cons:
GE doesn't believe that employees can do the next level of their task, even if they have been doing it for years.  They believe that people hired from outside are better than internal employees.  They spend zero time training their employees in preparation for the next level promotion.
Senior leadership seems to be asleep at the wheel.
advice_management:
Look for and recognize the employees that are motivated and moving the company forward.  Use common leadership techniques to show your employees you are connected to them and invested in them.  More promotions from within the company would be a good indication.
Follow the spirit and letter of the policy.  Don't just post jobs because you legally have to, use this to identify what employees are looking to do more work.  And when you find 100% of your internal candidates don't have the skills for the next level job, start training them for the next level, don't just hire a friend of a friend into the position and ignore the problem.
Having 100% of your employees unprofitable (because they aren't) is an indication of poor management and a lack of leadership.

summary: "Excellent program to begin your career at GE or elsewhere"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
The financial management program is GE's leadership program in finance. The classes you take are in accounting, both managerial and financial, controls and business strategy. The classes are very useful in your role and great for general knowledge on how businesses are ran. 

The four roles you get on the program can make or break your experience. Personally, the roles I've received were beneficial in my career growth, with manager's that give decent feedback on your performance and help work with you on your career development.
cons:
There are several downsides to the program. Top of my list is the sheer amount of hours you devote towards GE. You have your normal role as expected, and you work 40+ hours a week. Like most other entry level career programs, you can expect to work 50+ or 60+ hours a week. In addition to that., you have to take the courses, which have recently become extremely time consuming. About 10+, 20+ hours a week. In the end, you spend every waking hour, breathing and living GE. Essentially the courses you study for as free training. 

Your managers also vary every 6 months, and I will have to say that most I've found were mediocre at best. In my four rotations at GE, I have had one manager I truly thought was exceptional. The others were not, in my opinion and in GE's opinion (given the amount of time they've spent in their current positions) "promotion-worthy." The courses for the first year is also unnecessarily demanding.
advice_management: Continue to find not just 'good' managers for the different rotations, but 'great' managers. The courses for the first year are unnecessarily hard.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Very professional and concerned about employees.
cons: Occasionally bureaucratic but not a significant problem.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Great company with a lot of great people. The network is still one of the best. It connects GE employees from all over the globe. Promotions and advancement is still available for those who are smart and hard working.
cons: Health benefits have been getting worse and worse over the years. Cutback are everywhere. And once they are cut, it never comes back. Work enviroment is also getting more policatical.
advice_management: Provide clear and honest communication to all your employees. We might not like the truth but we will understand. Don't try to sugar coat everything.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Brand Name looks good on resume.
cons:
High bureaucracy. People are promoted based on speaking skills rather than merit. 
Raises are negligible. Employees are overworked and there is no clear vision from upper management.  High attrition rate, most of the good employees have left.  Management is clueless about project planning. Legacy Technologies are still prominently used across the board.
advice_management: Let go off the middle managers and slacking employees. Hire bright individuals who have managed and implemented production ready software development.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: paid for extra hours worked, big name company
cons: direct reports making more a lot of the times and they are unskilled
advice_management: fix the pay scales

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Still looking for a cutting edge technology
cons: Large company, need to lean out some of their procedures

main_text: I worked at GE
pros:
GE looks impressive on your resume to some people.
Nice building.
They teach you how to give a good pitch!!!
cons:
The whole experience of being a GE employee is a downside.  GE is constantly hiring and firing people.  They staff up for projects and then when the project is complete lay people off.  GE has layoffs down to a science which is something they pride themselves on.  Your coworkers are constantly joking nervously about the layoffs.  Coworkers are not friends, they are your competitors and they will screw you if they can because it is the difference between staying employed and getting let go.  GE expects that you put in a ton of hours all the time, so much for work life balance.  Between worrying about getting let go and putting in a ton of hours most GE employees hate the world.

Stay away from this place at all costs.  Quite frankly your better off unemployed than working here.
advice_management: Resign.  Try treating your employees like human beings.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
* Great people to work with
* VERY challenging projects
cons: * Too much focus on the current quarter, not enough strategic planning

summary: "Unless  you are an IMLP yo uare out of luck"
main_text: I worked at GE
pros:
It's a big, pretty stable company
If you like it there and they like you, you may be able to move from one busines to another
cons:
They have an IMLP (Information Mgmt Leadership Program)  program offered to college grads. It lasts  2 years and once these kids complete the program they are on the fast track to stardom at GE...to the detriment of everyone else. The result? Young people rising too fast and finding themselves in over their head with respect to their roles and responsibiities. 

This serves to demoralize the rest  of the workforce...
advice_management: Look beyond the IMLP program as a way to promote talent from within the organization. This is the only way to get the legitimate, mature leadership you desparately need.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
World Class training
Leadership is  big on "Say Do"
Challenging and makes employees more Innovative.
Great Awareness programs for Health
cons:
Below Average cost of medical insurance
Pay raise are minimal
advice_management: Identify top performers and promote them

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Average pay, lots of opportunities to learn and develop skills and job security.
cons: Very competitive work place and lots of very smart people, sometimes it's hard for great employees to get noticed.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: You will always have an opportunity to try something new in the IT environment.  During my time at GE I was put into roles where I had limited experience and given the training that would help me become successful in the role.  I was also provided with coaching and mentoring that helped me ask questions and get the job done.
cons:
You will work like  a dog to be successful.  It is a 24/7 environment and its difficult to break the cycle once you get to performing in the organization.
There is a TON of bureaucracy in the company.  You have to get approvals from a variety of people that know nothing about your project and its time consuming bringing everyone up to speed.  Sometimes you feel like you are a salesman peddling your project to different people just to get them to approve it.
advice_management: If we continuously change we will never reach the performing stage of group development.  Once you feel like you get to that level then we shake it up and then shake it up again.  This is good for the business but it gets discouraging for people doing the projects.

summary: "Great place to learn and grow professionally, but big business politics can be frustrating."
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Challanging work and high expectations drive you to be a great Engineer.  Global business builds communication skills and provides an opportunity to travel abroad.  Coworkers are easy to work with and the vast range of expertise allows for great collaboration and problem solving.
cons: Big business bureaucracy restricts creativity.  Some managers are not directly involved in work done by those underneath them which makes it difficult to get an adequate and meaningful performance review.
advice_management: Choices in managers closely working with Design Engineers should have a sound technical background and personality skills that make it easy to communicate with this person in technical and magagerial conversations.

summary: "GE has always brought good things to my life"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Professional development, compensation and challenge
cons: Can overshadow time for family
advice_management: None

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Having GE on the resume provides for automatic credibility.  The culture is very "up or out", which is good in terms of opportunities for promotion.
cons: As with any large organization, it is easy to become a cog in a wheel.  It takes a lot of effort to get the bigger picture.

summary: "Great People, Mobility and Learning ... Comes with Beaucracy"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
World class people
GE allows you to jump functions, businesses and locations ... very rare
Teaches you how to be truly global
Very Challenging Work
cons:
Big company so lots of Beaucracy
Short term focus due to intense financial focus
Lots of change

summary: "OK to get a foot on the door in private equity"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Good place to get an understanding of the private equity industry, get your feet wet on co-investing and, over time, do get the chance to participate as lead in growth company financings
cons: GE is a public company where the return to the shareholder comes from predictable quarterly EPS growth, which is not aligned with the private equity industry.  GE Equity deals with non-private equity issues of corporate approvals and income generation challenges, an environment that is correct for GE but does not lead to efficient management nor to maximize returns.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Talented staff works on globally impacting projects
cons: Health Insurance costs are too high
advice_management: More interaction

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
Support of work-life balanace.
Numerous career opportunities
cons: Salary may not stay competitive once you get in the company

summary: "Good for starting your career, better opportunities exist outside of company once you have GE on your resume"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
-Leadership Programs are designed to create future leaders/managers
-Great training and development opportunities
-Great work/life balance, ability to work from home
-Lots of visibility and exposure to leadership early in career
-Employees are very helpful and interested in growing new hires
-Managers are competent
-Size of company makes lots of opportunities available, employees can easily move between different GE business
-Good processes and best practice sharing
-Global exposure, even for interns and new hires
-Very intelligent employees
-Sense of pride in working for a company with so much history
-Clear vision and direction set by leaders
-Leaders are honest and open
cons:
-GE expects you to move every 2 years to move up
-Lots of bureaucracy and politics
-Extremely matrixed and confusing organizations, simple tasks require approvals and sign-offs from hundreds of people
-GE is sometimes like a cult
-Employees dont actually understand our products, competitors, etc (and mgmt likes it that way)
-Suck-ups that do B.S. work for leadership move up
-Few opportunities in major cities (NYC, LA, Chicago)
-Salary is below market, no overtime pay
-Lots of work done by offshore contractors, often results in low quality work due to short contracts focused only on quick development
-Too "number" focused, everything must have a financial benefit (increased satisfaction is never a reason to pursue an initiative)
-People are expendable
advice_management: Focus on people. Recent decisions (i.e. new benefits package) have made many employees frustrated.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Chance to work on cutting edge technology with the best and brightest people across all levels of the organization. Possibilities are endless.
cons: Health benefits require high out of pocket annually if you suffer from any kind of chronic condition. Available office and conference room space is scarce and cubicles are small and noisy
advice_management: Embrace use of remote office technologies to ease site congestion. Award productive gains made by work from home colleagues. Trust your employee to meet goals.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: world leader, best technology, continuous re-invesment, global opportunities, committed to customers
cons:
its all about the customer, unless they get in the way of the quarter

complicated organization structure
advice_management: admit it, its all about the quarter ... we are an inward facing company.   keep communication open, flowing and honest

summary: "Well rounded technical environment to sharpen your political skills"
main_text: I worked at GE
pros:
You will get the opportunity to work on a combination of old and new tech.
Variety of projects depending on what you can handle
Large scale projects after you spend some years in the environment
cons:
Very politically charged
Silos and protectionism within managers
Middle management layer is challenged
You work 9-5 but you are 300% allocated and would rarely have the satisfaction of a productive day
All projects have lots of hairy issues so be prepared to be a model of patience
advice_management:
Resources are tremendously over worked and under appreciated
I have seen very competent employees literally cry due to the pressure

summary: "General Electric Aviation is a dynamic place to work"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: GE is only a handful of big corporations that still has a traditional pension plan with good benefits. It is the only company left from the original 10 NYSE start-up companies. General Electric is one of the more respected and recognize company in the USA and the world.
cons: Like most large companies, cost of health insurance and compensations have brought forth a reduction in work force either by layoffs or early retirement.  Newly hire workers do not have the traditional pension plan anymore but allow increase in 401K and matching contributions.
advice_management: WIth the increase in older workers looking for retirement, it would be beneficial to the company if new workers are brought in earlier for training to capture the years of experience and to improve this transition.  One more advice to GE Corporation, it would save the company BIG money if the "Union" workforce is to work a full 40 hours before overtime is paid out.  This will eliminate absenteeism and increase productivity.

summary: "All about the manager not the people"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Company good name. Need work life balance
cons: HR sucks they are not part of the company. Plant employees are treated different than other Areas employees. Family is not part of the Ge culture.
advice_management: Work life balance. The more important part of the job is loss.

summary: "Bureaucratic Nightmares Abound, Business is Obsessed with Cost and Risk Reduction"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Generally, GE is impressive on a resume and people who know it from earlier decades have a surprising reverence for the few remaining US employees.
cons: Bureaucratic nightmares entangle in every possible task.  At the present, upper management seems obsessed with cost and risk reduction as the only way to improve the company.  All meaningful benefits have been stripped from employees (health, retirement, anything left is so limited as to be functionally useless).
advice_management: Give back the benefits from five years ago, or give us pay increases to offset most of the tens of thousands you saved (and we now shoulder) by taking them away.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: GE is one of the best places to get manager training. They have well developed processes even if they don't necessarily get used. Their Six Sigma and IMLP training pays off in the real world
cons:
Hyper aggressive cost based culture. As much as it can build people up, it will also tear people down and a lot of fast risers will often get "boiled" if they stay too long. 

Also the company is so large that one side may not know what the other side is doing.
Also GE tends to hire a lot of seasoned workers from other companies such as AT&T. This will have an influence on management which can create a hostile work environment.
advice_management: Keep on auditing your processes. Also, your ombudsman program is a sham.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
Challenge work that allows you to stretch your current abilities.
Fun industry to be in.
cons:
Extensive means you spend a lot of non-productive time just trying to figure out who does what.
Understaffed means everyone has to put in extra hours to get things accomplished... regularly working late nights, early mornings and weekends.
advice_management: Please hire more people, quickly.

summary: "proud, satisfying but disappointed with the politics and lack of structure"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Large company environment with flexible opportunities to move with in. Some really great people.
cons: The great people do not work well in teams and often are not aligned.
advice_management: Quickly put together systems around how the functions work with each other. Try to identify talent suited for systems environment by looking beyond the layers of smoke screen.

summary: "A great place to work and advance in your career"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: GE's knowledge base is very vast you can get support from all segments of the business when ever there is a need. GE is investing lot of money into R&D, specially in energy sector. If you want to be in Energy filed then GE is one of the prefferred companies.
cons:
New acqusitions and differences in culture.
Because of the new acquistions, employees talk bad about GE because of the culture differences.
Lot of buarocracy as you move up the ladder..

summary: "A great business to work for, however it's a very cut throat environment"
main_text: I worked at GE
pros: I think GE is a great company to work for, everyone on the team was very competent, friendly and willing to share their knowledge with you.
cons: It's very difficult to get a full story about something. Information sharing is a definite challenge.  Also you are held accountable for the mistakes of others if your project suffers even if they aren't on your team.
advice_management: I would say that the managers need to tighten things up in terms of information sharing and cross team collaboration.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Strong company, nice work environment.
cons: Difficult to advance quickly in career unless willing to relocate.
advice_management: Keep up the good work!

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Working on solving some of the toughest problems in the world and developing products in those area... people I work with
cons: Requires a considerable amount of personal time beyond a typical 40hr wk to stay ahead at GE
advice_management: Need to re-evalaute the new healthcare system... very beuracratic and takes work time to resolve a lot of issues

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Experience, Leadership, Reputation, Opportunity, Growth, Rewarding and Inspirational
cons: Performance Appraisals can sometimes mean that a employee may not receive a favorable performance review eventhough he/she is an exceptional employee.  Unfortunately, or fortunately depand on where you stand most everyone is expceptional, the best of the best or they probably would'nt be working for GE so it makes it tough to reward everyone on a system that bases performance reviews on a Top 3rd, Middle and teh Bottom 10%.  Regardless of the Bottom 10% actual performance.
advice_management: Be fair in a difficult system.  Coach all employees.  Mentor new employees

summary: "good place to start then need to move on"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: good place to start career
cons: poor reward, does not value on research

summary: "Overall striving to be a good company, yet too large for consistently fair treatment and motivation of employees."
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
Technical depth (engineering) or other technical fields. 
Large company size - lots of internal move opportunities (if only theoretically)
Resource availability
cons:
Too big to be efficient
Theoretical opportunities seldom play out 
HR and Finance play too big of a role in management (running the company instead of leaders and managers)
Very slow to make any significant change
Compensation/benefits are not competitive to market
advice_management:
Hire only best people for middle-managers to make sure you can trust your team to foster and maintain the type of environment that will attract and retain talant. 
Focus on long term, as opposed to short term live/die by the quarter - travel freezes and other policy rigidity only hurts the company and employees in the long run

summary: "Satisfying I enjoyed going to work everyday"
main_text: I worked at GE
pros: I found everybody to be very professional, friendly and easy to work with. Everybody is very knowledgeable and helpful in there field of expertise. Great bunch of people.
cons:
The benefit packages offered were, I believe, sub par for such a large company.
The work/life balance was quite a bit skewed toward work.

summary: "Like a bad dream about the circus"
main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Big name company looks good on resume
cons: 100 layers of mgmt and as you move up the layers each layer gets more incompetent, crappy pay, ridiculous emphasis on six sigma which the proof is right there that it is useless
advice_management: Fire yourselves

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Great pay, and good benifits. GE company over all is a great company. I would not recomend working for the Wind side, in Texas or Oklahoma.
cons: No work life balance. If you get over time they send you home at the end of the week. Its not what you know but who you know. Your  voice is never heard and your thoughts dont matter. If they dont like you they will try to find things to write you up about. Lots of Micro manage. Dosent matter how you do your job they want you to do it there way even when they dont know anything about a turbine, or suck at what they do and made it as a lead, because of who they know. There way may be  the crappy way, but you do it your way fix the problem then they write you up for not following directions.
advice_management: You need to listen to your employees, they are the back bone of your company. You can set up contracts all day long but, if you dont have anyone to do them what good is you company to make money. Stop favoring people this is a bussiness so treat it like one and be fair to your employees.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: There are very few pros to working in TSG (a group that supports Aviation and Energy).  The only potential pro is getting your foot in the door to quickly go elsewhere within GE
cons:
There are too many cons to completely list.  The management has no idea what they are doing.  They are so out of touch with the employees, it is borderline neglect.  when anything goes wrong, TSG goes on a witch hunt.  They want a name to go along with anything that happens.  In a technical environment, things happen.  Regardless of best intentions, that person will be attacked.  

If you have ambition to get promoted within TSG, it will only be if you tear someone else down.  HR is not there as an advocate for the employee, but more to cover themselves in the event of a lawsuit.
advice_management: All Management needs to be removed and this organization disolved.

summary: "Sink or swim, but came out with valuable experience."
main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Company Recognition, fast paced environment, learned everything with on the job training
cons: Incompetent management, people too involved in other employee's personal lives, office gossip, little to no job growth

main_text: I worked at GE
pros:
Unbeatable reputation - The name and the corp structure helps keep that reputation
Diversity - Many different divisions to move around to and from
Structure - Management approach
cons:
Salary low - not very competitive to keep good talent
Does not weed out the real talent well-Managers are not trained to nurture good employees
Promotions are few-have to be "connected" to move anywhere
advice_management: Try harder to keep the good talent you have, but also think about past talent that you could use right now.  Some people went through reorganization, but would love a welcome back if asked.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
Pay is good
benefits is good
options are good
people are great
cons:
private company so you will not get a 401K matching
smaller company so you have to wear many hats in your role
advice_management: senior management is going a great job by meeting on a weekly basis and reviewing the current standing of budget vs actual results.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Well paid and retirement benefits are good.
cons: Need to coerce people to help you work. If it isn't in PPT it didn't happen.
advice_management: do more one over one over ones.

summary: "Not much room for growth potential...also find mgt NOT TRUTHFUL,LACK INTEGRITY"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: the only thing I can honestly say is the salary and benefits
cons: not much room to grow in any field unless you kiss _ss
advice_management: You put out these Integrity Guidelines...why doesn't MGT and HR abide by them

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
IQ
Vast Resources & Disclipines Available
Platform
Industry Leader
cons:
Salary
Limited Promotions
Lack of Stock Options
advice_management: Competitive Analysis on base salary, bonus and commission

main_text: I worked at GE
pros:
The support staff that surround you is the best in the business
Resources to get things done, but get it done
cons:
Who you know, not what you do, will move you up
Very much an in crowd and those on the outside
advice_management: The incrowd where those raised in the GE culture, and they do not like to hear how it was done elsewhere

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Good pay for an IT position in Louisville. There is a company pension (5 yr. vesting period) and good contribution to 401k.
cons: Stone age IT department and management attitude to go with it. Weak benefits (health, vacation). No mobility unless you are in the right management path.
advice_management: IT management needs to stop doing what they've always done because that is the way they always done it. Also - IT should support the business not be run as a separate business. Don't just listen - learn and change.

summary: "Interesting work but pay and benefits lag behind the competion"
main_text: I worked at GE
pros:
Challenging work.  Interesting technical problems.
Great leadership training programs if you are one of the chosen few.
Good career opportunities.
cons:
The pay is well below industry averages.
In recent years they have slashed what was once a good benefits package.
advice_management:
I think you are well aware of it, but a lot of people have left in recent years.  GE Aviation has a large experience gap between the 15+ yrs of exp and the 0-5 yrs.  Its the 5+ years of exp folks who are leaving, and a lot of the ones who remain are discontent.  Right now its not a good situation to be in.  A lot of my colleauges have left.  Its very simple, and no retention committee will spell it out for you clearer.  Pay people what they deserve and they will stay.

Your salary surveys lie to you.  Now that I've seen a couple other companies from the inside, I can tell you that every company uses the same salary surveys to reach the same conclusion:  "we are paying our employees at slightly above the average for similar companies".  Its just not true.  Someone must be manipulating the data, because I have worked at similar positions at three companies in the same industry doing similar work.  GE pay is far and away the worst of the three, yet HR says they pay at a rate slightly above the industry averages.  Coincidentally, each of the other three companies reached the same conclusion but at a higher pay rate.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Good resources, some good people
cons: Needs better people specially at the bottom to work properly

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Corporate Culture provides strong fondation for overall business skills.
cons: Large company sometimes turns very slowly.
advice_management: NA

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Great network, a lot of support.  Worked as a team, supported career advancement.
cons: Extremely large and global, so you don't get a lot of face-to-face time with colleagues.  More of a challenge to build relationships on the global level.
advice_management: Communicate, communicate, communicate!

summary: "Senior management wanted me to be a punching bag for their union."
main_text: I worked at GE
pros: The only good reason to work at GE is that their company name is not completely tarnished and the experience looks good.
cons: The company culture at GE is not to do a good job, but to get a promotion. So many people are worried about their next job and not their current job.
advice_management: Take responsibility for your actions and stop playing the blame game. Focus on making quality products and not on reducing costs.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Strong deal flow and experience processing deals.
cons: Heavy internal politics, beaurocracies inhibiting speed.

summary: "Great experience overall - a place where you can build a career on your own merit"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Strong common culture & values generally shared across the globe and the various GE businesses; Overall very good people; Flexibility in career opportunities.  Incredible investment in training of employees.
cons: Sometimes too big and bureaucratic; communication is decent but messages can be a bit slow to trickle down to all levels

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Ability to change jobs/career and stay within the organization.
cons: Inconsistent recognition, and little/no public recognition.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros:
I liked the work and the people were smart.  it was a good place to work.
there were good benefits and pay was stable
cons: Too much work at times.  not much growth options but this was known from the start of my employment.  not much bad to comment on .

summary: "Very good people, personal and professional growth"
main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Good people, corporate processes, onboarding, coaching and mentoring.  Great place to build career.
cons: Matrix organization, can be confusing to people who have not worked in this type of organizational environment.  "Decisions by commitee."  Younger, leadership...too much "inside the box" thinking...not enough external experiences by leadership team.  Most manager have spent 8-12 years from college, and then run an organization..the "GE way"
advice_management: Simplification and eliminating "red-tape" grew GE when Jack was running the organization.  Too many layers.  Length of decisions cost money and resources...get back to basics!

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Interesting technology and work.  The direct people you work with are great.
cons: Impossible to meet deadlines, lacking resources, and constant "help" to meet deadlines.  You have to understand GE treats employees as a commodity and once you understand that everything makes more sence
advice_management: either say this is the way it is deal with it and stop asking for our opinions, and what we are unhappy with when you have no intension of doing anything with the data

summary: "Rewarding, challenging and a very unique experience"
main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Training, communication skills, hire the best, leadership skill development, many opportunities to advance if so willing
cons: Retire too many too early, cutthroat culture,
advice_management: Keep leaders in place for more than 18 months, stop moving the generalists around from one business to another.

summary: "Good place to work, but expect manage your own career vs seeing a plan created for you"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: management training opportunities, ability to change fields but not company, reasonable compensation, certain benefits are good (401k) but some are avg or below (healthcare)
cons: 24/7/365 job, accept it or look elsewhere, work/life balance is your issue to manager, not your boss's, incompetent managers tend to linger and may be promoted vs removed
advice_management: This about how to recognize and reward the pillars of the company: people who stay in their job for multiple years and perform at a high level, but are not really interested in advancing, relocating, or becoming 'Big Leaders'. Current plan is just turning them off and causing them to look outside the company. Risk to GE from this exodus is high.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Money and benefits were good. There is a lot of room for promotion if you're willing to play the politics.
cons: Watch your back. People working for General Electric are way too competitive. If you want to get promoted you have to be on your game at all times.
advice_management: Relax the business etiquette so that employees feel more comfortable. Offering a BBQ every once in a while doesn't make up for the fact that the people working for you are miserable.

summary: "My experience at GE has been very challegning and work life balance is an issue."
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: GE is so large and well respected that even if you decide it's not for you and you leave after a few years, others will be impressed with your experience there based on the reputation of the company. There are many, many jobs available within the company so you could potentially make it your place to grow throughout your career.
cons: Though the company claims to promote work life balance, it's understood that you're expected not to be a "9-5'er". Any significant advancement requires working a lot of unpaid overtime. Only those who devote almost all of their waking hours to the company have real chances of "success".
advice_management: I think managers could do a much better job of managing resources, meaning trianing employees properly instead of the sink or swin methodology and not having one person do the job of 3.

summary: "Good work experience, plenty of challenges, pay ok."
main_text: I worked at GE
pros: - Many challenging opportuntities to work on
cons: - Demands make self-control of work/life balance absolutely necessary
advice_management: - listen / respect employee opinions.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Good to work in future
cons: Has some bureaucracy that might stop growth for individual
advice_management: Its better to avoid bureacracy

summary: "not good they closed the vplant ship jobs over seas"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: good benfits lots of tranning.
cons: may ship your job over seas, if nthey see a bettet profit margin
advice_management: not bad they train thir mang well. lots of classes tqm,black belt,etc.

summary: "A great place to woth and grow!"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: A very good enviroment for work ...
cons:
- Too noisy! 
- Not so good heath insurance plan.
advice_management: Talk more with your employees.

summary: "THE BEST JOB AND COMPANY IN THE WORLD!!!"
main_text: I have been working at GE
cons: - Too many rules and procedures that slow us down;
advice_management: Keep believing in your employees and the world is ours!

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: The leadership programs are beneficial and recognized.  You can receive Six sigma certifications that can advance your career.
cons: The culture is depressing and cut throat. Raise increases are few and far in between unless you are working 12 hour days...  Even after you leave the company, managers are not Supposed to give ex-employees recommendations or references.
advice_management: Management should focus on the people more.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: People oriented, very challenging company.
cons: Some cases burocratic, changes took longer.
advice_management: None at this time

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Good job stability & overall benefits
cons: Clear that they are not a top payer, benefits being reduced every year
advice_management: Middle management is creeping back into GE.

summary: "In the beginning it was good, but about the last 10 years has been an unpleasant  experience."
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Work schedule flexibility. Lower level mtg  seems to be more understand employee's needs better than upper level mtg.
cons: Pay, benefits and executive level mtg just doesn't get it.
advice_management: The upper level mtg team only seem to care about profit and tighter schedules. And the employee always suffer when these things are put 1st.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: The money offered is awesome.
cons: Long hours in a given work day.
advice_management: Allow me to progress on my own.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Employee Mobilization, code of conduct, People Friendly, Ideal to retire
cons: A bit Beauracratic at times
advice_management: Keep up the good work

summary: "They have adequate talent, but not the leadership to motivate and drive them."
main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Good benefits.  Computing hardware is pretty good.  Very flexible and helpful IT department.  Nice work environment.  Books are easy to order, and training is easy to get set-up.
cons: Poor project management.  Lots of dead weight.  Hard to stand out.  Departments are very closed-off.  Very much a "sit down and shut up" environment.
advice_management: Actually listen to employees.  Encourage an environment of openness and collaboration.  Remove barriers to communication and actively create cross-discipline teams.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Great Opportunity to work , great people
cons: Layoffs and job cuts which are prevalent in htis time
advice_management: More communication

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Good reputation, advancement, like the training programs and not cheap on conferences, and classes. company car, health and dental, good.
cons: they will keep you in the same place if you dont make your moves up the ladder, be sure to take advantage of opportunity
advice_management: listen to your employees to make sure they are fulfilling what you are trying to accomplish or it is all for nothing

summary: "Cut-throat as most emplyoees are treated like cogs in the system"
main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Pension and vacation/personal business time allowed; prestigious company to have worked for on resume
cons: Medical coverage is pathetic compared to recent years.  Demand of work hours do not match salaries well.  Review process is very cookie-cutter and fails to develop employees.  If you are not a program graduate forget about progressing quickly.  Very young and inexperienced employees made managers too early in career which in turn causes them to fail their teams.
advice_management: Metrics can't be the only focus if you truly care about employees.  Develop young leaders and worry less about your bonus, but rather the future of the company.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: You can do anything you want if you have a good work ethic.  GE will put you where you want to go.
cons: Salaries are below competitive range.
advice_management: Pay people what they are worth, and you will get more out of them.

summary: "Lots of dead weight and very political"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: You don't see a lot of mass firings in the engineering department.  They are happy to put you in a position to do a job that you may not be considered for in another company because of lack of experience or qualifications.  Free parking,  coffee and occasional lunches.
cons: Like others have said.  They have trouble getting rid of dead weight and difficulty motivating the top talent to stay.  Very much a sit down and shut up environment.  Feedback is not encouraged.  Everything is political.  Requires a policy and procedure for everything.  It is common to see people thrown under the bus.  Getting basic tools to do your job is impossible.  Lots of lip service to software development methodologies in use etc.,  but no execution to back it up.  Turnover is high.
advice_management: If you want to attract the best and the brightest you need to create an environment that encourages it.  When I was recruited into the company the HR person told me about how GE looked for people who can connect the dots etc..  The culture actively discourages this kind of thinking and many of your hires have trouble doing this.  Ditch the ceremony and get to the essence and give your people the tools that they need to do their job...if people are not able to perform after you have given them the tools and environment you need to remove them from the team.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: GE has good pay and benefits. There are lots of opportunities to take on new projects and create new projects. Additionally GE has exciting and various product lines.
cons: Employees at GE seemed to be over worked. It seems to be a very political environment. Employees are not always treated with respect by management.
advice_management: Make sure to promote people who are qualified. Treat employees with respect.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Experience working for a dynamic Fortune 100 company.  Pay and benefits are competitive.  GE provides a number of options for career growth.
cons: Bureaucratic environment and communication is lost through the different levels of leadership. Slow to make changes on projects and business strategies.  Too many different systems (piece-mealed together) in order to support job functions.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: What a turn around from our days as Tyco. This company went thru many tough times as Tyco/Lucent, and as Lineage it shed many of it's bad habits.
cons: Very few down sides. The company is driven by the Finance dept., but this has not caused undo hardship to the daily operations, and has resulted in an extremely healthy financial position for Lineage.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Global Company, great businesses, strong leadership
cons: too many initiatives causing people to work long hours
advice_management: continue working on streamlining process

summary: "If you willing to learn and practice the GE way, great opportunities present to you."
main_text: I worked at GE
pros:
Great knowledge sharing and systems available.
Strong leadership development opportunities
Opportunities to work in different business within the same company. 
Great resume builder in terms of variety of experience.
cons: Sometimes decision making can take time within the company.

summary: "Finance types have run a once proud product company into the ground."
main_text: I worked at GE
pros:
Reputation
Experienced professionals all around
Work with very smart people
Great place to learn
Great products in aviation, some other businesses
cons:
Metric driven--gaming the metrics more often than doing the right thing
Decisions based obsolete financial metrics and the stock price
Products that people want and value are secondary
Company hasn't invested in key facilities and product lines in decades
New health plan took away whatever advantage this had been in the past
advice_management:
Product, product, product.
GE has been a bank for too long and it hasn't served the company well. 
Reinvest in the people, technology, and hardware that made the company great in the past.
There are some early signs that Jeff Immelt has started to do this.  I fear that it's too late.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Great place to learn how a corporation works.  Good benny's.  Large corp. with many opportunities. many different career paths to choose from.
cons: Lots of type A's running around.  Long hours.  Total dedication to job required.  Work/Life balance a challenge.  Stay away from manufacturing.

summary: "even withh all of the resources at their (Corporate) fingertips, they hindered employees for proactive responses"
main_text: I worked at GE
pros: World wide locations for relocation; six-sigma and education benefits.
cons: too many managers that hinder progress- GE Information Systems WAS number one, but sloipped and lost the lead because of poor growth management.
advice_management: Listen and take action

main_text: I worked at GE
pros:
upper leadership great
middle management is not good at all
all career development opportunities depends upon how well you know your manager
kiss up kick down kind company
Era of Jack Welch is long gone and GE is turning into the same old  bureaucratic company with uncountable layers of management
cons:
middle management is not good at all
all career development opportunities depends upon how well you know your manager
kiss up kick down kind company
Era of Jack Welch is long gone and GE is turning into the same old  bureaucratic company with uncountable layers of management
advice_management: Upper Leadership: Listen to an average employee. If you depend too much on middle management, you will be long gone soon...

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Competitive salary, very focused. Very clear goals.
cons: Short term $$ driven, long term product and customer sacrifices. I was not proud of our products.
advice_management: Ask another question besides "When can we ship it?"

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Opportunity to advance and leadership programs are the best in the world. Leadership values and committment to company are evident in their success
cons: Being such a large company can lead to communication issues and can be slow to make decisions. But overall decisions are made for long term goals
advice_management: Continue to provide opportunities for leaders and managers to advance.  The people are the company and continue to develop their skill sets

summary: "Tons of options in a great company"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
- Healthcare benefits are good (but they used to be a bit less expensive)
- Pay is fair
- Amazing opportunities to move from one company within GE to another while retaining your years of service and benefits
cons:
- LARGE organization that is a bit slow to change at times
- some of the business units are rather political in how they are run (Supply Chain)
advice_management: Look for inconsistencies in how the different P&Ls are being run, some have great processes and leadership, some have a lot of room for improvement.  Keep innovating!

summary: "Great place to work (before purchase by Swiss Re) and GE (the parent company) is a great employer."
main_text: I worked at GE
pros: This was a company that consistently rewarded employees' exceptional performance, unlike Swiss Re.  GE treated employees with respect and as human beings, not as fungible commodities.  The benefits were good and pay was commensurate with industry standards.  Even though GE Insurance was purchased by Swiss Re (not a change for the better especially after laying off 20% of the GE staff as soon as the deal went through), I recommend GE in general as an employer.
cons: Being part of a massive corporation can be challenging in terms of communication.  The pension/401(k)/stock savings plan structure was a bit complicated.
advice_management: The company was purchased by Swiss Re in 2006, so there is no longer any GE Insurance leadership to advise.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
1.  Excellent training.
2.  Competitive environment.
3.  Unlimited opportunities.
cons:
1.  Opportunities usually mean transfer to eastern cities.
2.  Some "old" divisions being sold or down-sized:  lighting, appliances, plastics.
3.  Presently Company is going through a rework back toward original strategies:  engineering competency, excellent new product development and deemphasizing the financial element of the Company.
advice_management: Keep doing what you are doing.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Not being in production environment, Good place for team work and working with Smart qualified people. State of the art equipment.
cons: At the end of the day, you could have the best relationship with your immediate supervisor, and be a great employee, but you are still just a number to the Vp's.
advice_management: Find a way to get the older employees that are just taking up space, to move along or fire them, because you have too many 20+year employees that are taking advantage of the company and are just waiting on retirement.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Great work that is impacting and enjoyable.  Learned a lot from the people around me.
cons: People are sometimes over worked.
advice_management: Have more trust in the employees logging in the correct time.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Interesting equipment to work on
cons: Poor compensation for the amount of work that is completed.
advice_management: Share the wealth

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Excellent mid to upper mgmt that care about there employees. I feel very proud to work for this company and to help our customers get the best value for there product.
cons: Sometimes get lost in the company as it is very big and can get very competitive within each of the different levels of employment and careers.
advice_management: I would ask that they continue to respond to the needs and concerns of the  employees that make this company what it is.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Good start. Lots of training opportunities
cons: Promotion is slow. Low salary.
advice_management: Should react faster to market changing

summary: "Engineering work at GE Energy Services Measurement and Control Solutions"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:
Employee integrity - focus on safety, quality, timeliness, cost
Great products, challenging projects, flexible work time.
recreational opportunities, location: 20 minutes away from Lake Tahoe
cons: matrix management: it is hard to know what your priorities are and how to please multiple bosses.  some times it is hard to know what the right thing to do is due to conflicting goals.
advice_management: encourage employees to stay in job long enough to gain depth and experience. switching jobs every two years in order to get a better raise does not lead to depth.  Read the book Silos, Politics and turf wars.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Leadership Development, Adoption of great toolkits and business practices, Smart people
cons: Big, Highly structured environment, Type A culture, Women conform to a male culture to succeed
advice_management: Financial services business unit leaders do not always have a level of comfort in the industry necessary to effectively evaluate risk, and commonly do not have the respect of the individuals working for them who have a more sophisticated financial skill set.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Big company, slow pace, process oriented
cons: lots of cons, low compensation, only respect management
advice_management: none

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Good company to work for. Very nice colleagues. Nice Benefit package along with close location for commute. Enjoy my time there
cons: It is a well run company but the stock price isn't that great.  I think it might be better if the economy was better.
advice_management: GE needs to get away from finance.  Finance should focus on internal finance than external. Leave that to the banks.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: good place to learn the fundamental knowledge of this fields ,best for the fresh graduate to gain experience  first for the entry level, benefits are good
cons: slowly raise salary, no pension currently , a little bit down pay in this fields , career develop spaces is limited  to engineer, try become expert in this field first.
advice_management: there is some program offer   frequently to get responding training in leadership, as long as you have gain enough experience first .

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: collaborative, heplful colleagues and good upward mobility
cons: big firm culture sometimes too slow for its own good
advice_management: Better compensation and better communications

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: great health and retirement benefits
cons: equal and fair grwoth opportunities are not available to all
advice_management: should provide equal professional growth opportunities

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: The growth potential and leadership development programs at GE are tremendous and are definitely the strong point of the company
cons: Working as an employee at such a large company can make you feel overlooked and not cared about.  GE pushes their employees to the extreme and does not compensate well or recognize outstanding effort/performance.
advice_management: Treat your employees better and reduce the amount of stress applied during normal workdays.  No one should work 80 hours every week and get no recognition for their work.

summary: "Great opportunities but oppressively bureaucratic at times."
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Great Exposure to large company, very intelligent co-workers, great job security. Excellent access to top-notch training materials & courses. Compensation is competitive, but not great.
cons: Very bureaucratic organization that treats its salaried population much like it does its union(s): you will get promoted ONLY when you have been there long enough (not based on merit) and they will promote their long-time employees regardless of quality.
advice_management: Avoid the recent tendency to rely too much on HR policies and procedures that depend on averages and the 'least common denominator'. Leave more staffing decisions up to your front line managers.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Vast resources, diverse sources of income offer some protection during an economic downturn, strong development programs for young and diverse candidates
cons: Moved away from Welch's flat organizational model "nobody more than 6 levels away from the chairman"  Leadership is insulated from customers and management is insulated from accountability vs. performance targets.  Every organization has redundant functional leaders that are usually competing for the critical few knowledgeable resources that remain domestically.  Short term results trump long term investment every time.
advice_management: Flatten organization, reduce the number of functional administrators that keep the leaders from getting/staying connected to the customers and staff.  Stop managing to wall street and maybe the stock price will start to recover since they are the only blue chip that hasn't rebounded from 9/11

summary: "I never never never go back to work on this company!!!"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Great field friends on the site.
cons:
Poor managment
No family life, all is work and work and work...
If you work as Excempt is equal that now GE is your live and you need to work 24/7 365 days.....
advice_management: Put out some island plant managers... only looking for your own metrics and affect the overall company and employes life.    The plat with the most turn overs in the world.....

summary: "Good place to work especially if your in the boys club"
main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Good company with good benefits and excellent training program and opportunities.  The diversity of the productions and services help provide for added opportunities for the highly educated.
cons: boys club mentality and more emphasis on high education level rather than common or business acumen.
advice_management: Communicate better with the line employees so rumors don't affect moral so badly.

summary: "Average, a business company, not an engineering or technology company"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: I strong place for business focus.
cons: Technology and engineering is a commodity to be sourced and reduced.
advice_management: Be clear with your messages.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: 20 years with the company so far --- it has been a fair relationship.  High expectations are the price for carrying a GE business card
cons: Company size can be intimidating when workign with customers whom view GE as an immovable and inflexible company to do business with.
advice_management: Communication with employees is paramount

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: Excellent pay for the area.  Fair promotion practices.
cons: Have to work in inclement weather.  Once you reach highest technician level you are pretty much capped out.  Horrible time reporting system implemented 2010.
advice_management: Hire more managers who actually know the turbines and stop the "good ole boy" manager hiring of your Air Force buddies.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Fair treatment to employees.  Advancement opportunities are always available if you work hard and prove yourself.  The work environment is very good and the company is accepting when you need time off for personal reasons.
cons: Politics can be extreme in a business the size of GE.  Sometimes, due to the size of the company, projects that could typically get completed in a few months in a smaller company take much longer at GE.
advice_management: I think that the management at GE does a fairly good job.  It would be nice to have our leaders join us in the field once in a while to get a true feel for what is happening in the workplace.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: opportunity for advancement throughout the company
cons: Lots of Travel in the field positions
advice_management: Not really sure

summary: "If you want to work very hard and advance quickly professionally (but not in salary), this is a great opportunity."
main_text: I worked at GE
pros: GE holds the FMPs in high regard.  Almost all senior leaders are FMP grads and will want to help you succeed.  The path to high levels of management is laid out, and is attainable, but you must literally give your life to GE to get it.
cons: People at GE do not know how to relax.  They are very concerned with the numbers of hours they work, often staying at the office doing literally nothing so that people can see that they are there late.  They love to brag about how many hours they work.  A disturbing majority of the Finance employees have either never been married, or are married to someone in GE.
advice_management: Don't take yourself so seriously.  There are only two people at GE who anyone outside of GE has ever heard of.

summary: "Good place to grow. You can succeed only if you break your butt."
main_text: I worked at GE
pros:
Management does not micro manage. They give you the goals, its up to you to get the job done. Many times the job is what yo make it.
There are very few to no slackers at GE. Its a great opportunity to work with the best and brightest for the most part.
cons: You must be willing to go the extra mile to succeed. You will get what you put into it.
advice_management: Hang in there. If you can succeed in appliances you can succeed anywhere.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros: good company, global presence very strategic
cons: to big, just a number
advice_management: work life balance

summary: "OK . . I seen better . . office has lots of politics"
main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: good exposure to people and processes
cons: office politics is excessive . . . too much office fat not hussling
advice_management: get back closer to Jack Wech system . . . six sigma . . . . .currently too much office fat . . in us and over seas

main_text: I worked at GE
pros:
- Looks great on the Resume
- World-class benefits
- Professional Leadership
cons:
- Sink or swim; not much guidance to developing their junior managers
- Metrics or nothing
advice_management: - Provide better feedback to junior leadership and ensure that the normal training is provided on time.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Good pay, a lot of oppurtunity for advancement Ge is a world class company with locations in just about any area of the world.
cons: They will work you like a dog if it is needed in the job, I work 13 hrs four days a week and then you have overtime day.
advice_management: Treat the workers better, think about their home life not just the bottom line.

main_text: I worked at GE
pros:
- Provided projects that added value to company
- Co-workers do not make you feel like an intern
- GE's culture is second to none
cons:
- No choice on position coming into internship
- Averaged around  50 hours a week during summer internship at GE
advice_management: Most managers have time to deal with interns but I know some managers didnt put any time into their relationship with their intern

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Plenty of opportunity. Good project selection. Lots of freedom to explore and present ideas for growth. The management team is awesome and the company has plenty of room for advancement.
cons: I don't k ow if it's necessarily a bad thong, but GE really pressures its employees to stick around. Once they invest in you they want you to be there to invest your knowledge in the company.
advice_management: Continue to do what you do. Continue to congratulate employees on promotions and jobs well done. Continue to place employees in positions for immediate growth.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros: Invests in people and promotes from within
cons: deals with shady countries and should scrutinize deals more
advice_management: Invest in people and make sure to hire from within

summary: "Good work experience, but the people are horrible"
main_text: I worked at GE
pros:
Good learning work environment
Challenging work
cons:
People are not very friendly
Everyone is overworked
A lot of attitude and ego about how great they think they are ("You should be so lucky to work here")
Appliance Park is really run down and disgusting.  One of the buildings didn't have air conditioning for most of the summer one year and everyone was too afraid to mention it to management, which says a lot about the work environment.
advice_management:
Create a friendlier culture.
Get rid of the attitude

main_text: I worked at GE

cons: Your experience can vary greatly with the luck of the draw with your manager and program.  Sometimes there wasn't enough work to keep me busy.

main_text: I have been working at GE
pros:

cons:
-Dictatorial Management Style
-Lack of focus on the customer
-A large and slow ship to move
advice_management: Like Peter Drucker said..."The single most important thinkg to remember about any enterprise is that there are no results inside it's walls.  The result of a business is a satisfied customer."  Focus on the customer, eliminate wasteful internal meetings.

pros: Good Company to work for when you are willing to work hard.
cons: Sometimes they can overlook the obvious when it stares them in the face.
